abstract: The Spring, the "green, welcome Spring," has come again. The bright, sunny sky, and warm, luxurious atmosphere of yesterday, heralded its approach,
lead_paragraph: The Spring, the "green, welcome Spring," has come again. The bright, sunny sky, and warm, luxurious atmosphere of yesterday, heralded its approach, and the long-continued quiescence of Winter seemed fairly to give way before the vivifying beams of the vernal sun. Though the trees of Printing-house Park still look gaunt and chilly, and the withered grass-plots give no sign of life, yet underneath the surface the forces of nature are now actively mustering themselves, and the tender blades already begin to feel their way upward through the hard soil; a few days more of genial warmth and they will shoot forth into the air, and the leaf-stems on the trees, also, will begin to swell, and the leaflets burst forth.

abstract: On Tuesday evening the Police of the Twenty-first Ward were informed by the owner of the tenement house, No. 186 East Twenty-eighth-street, that there was a quantity of stolen goods in one of the rooms of that house, which was occupied by two young men. Sergeant WARD and Officer VER BRYCK immediately went to the place designated, where they found the door of the room locked. It was forced open, but it being dark inside, the Sergeant sent his companion for a light, he locking himself inside meantime. While thus waiting two men triad the door from the outside, but finding it fastened attempted to escape, when the Sergeant rushed from the inside, and succeeded in capturing one of them, while the other escaped. On searching the apartment silks, lace goods, gloves, &c., to the value of $250 were found. A quantity of burglars' implements were also seized, some of which were of superior workmanship. The prisoner, on being taken to the Station-house, gave his name as John Brown, and was locked up for examination. The goods recovered, supposed to be the proceeds of burglarious operations, are detained at the Twenty-first Precinct Station-house for identification.

abstract: The Albany States man wishes to know whether "Border Unionism is not disguised Secession." Judging
lead_paragraph: The Albany States man wishes to know whether "Border Unionism is not disguised Secession." Judging from the appearances we should think not. The "Border Unionists" seem to have too serious a time of it, to be merely playing a game. Unionism with them amounts to something, because it costs something. They are compelled to breast the swelling popular current of their own States. They run the risk of political ruin by defending the Union against the attacks of its enemies at home. They are charged with Abolitionism and are compelled to run the gauntlet of political persecution.

abstract: We Publish this morning, perhaps to the exclusion of more interesting matter, a sketch of some remarks made by Mr. Raymonds a few evenings since, on the position and policy of the Republican Party. Its main drift is to urge ...
lead_paragraph: -- We Publish this morning, perhaps to the exclusion of more interesting matter, a sketch of some remarks made by Mr. Raymonds a few evenings since, on the position and policy of the Republican Party. Its main drift is to urge the policy of terminating what little there is left of the controversy concerning Slavery in the Territories, and of rallying around the Administration all who are devoted to the Union and the Constitution, and especially to aid those who are struggling in the Border States against the attempt to drag them into the new Confederacy. In this way Mr. RAYMOND thinks the Border States may be retained in the Union, which is the first step towards a reorganization of the Confederacy and the restoration of our old relations. After that has been accomplished, he thinks that Louisiana would speedily be revolutionized, -- that the Union-men would secure control of her affairs, and repeal the ordinance of secession: -- that Mississippi would soon follow this example, and that thus one after another the people of the Gulf States, under the pressure of heavy taxation, the lack of postal facilities, a poor and unprofitable commerce, the increasing discontent of all classes and the general lack of incentives and stimulants to public action, would reverse the policy now adopted and resume their allegiance to the Federal Union.

abstract: The Albany Atlas and Argus declares with a great deal of emphasis that there is no truth in the reports.
lead_paragraph: -- The Albany Atlas and Argus declares with a great deal of emphasis that there is no truth in the reports about plots against Mr. LINCOLN'S life. "The whole story is false," it declares; "it is a pure invention; if not, let the conspirators be brought to justice." This is all very well. We echo the demand. But the failure of justice does not disprove the existence of crime. The Atlas has been vociferous for a long time in charging corruption upon the members of the Legislature; but, on its own theory, its allegations must be false, else why are they not brought to justice?

abstract: The Raleigh (N.C.) Banner does not entertain much respect for Mississippi. It says: "Who will take her bonds? A friend suggests that probably...
lead_paragraph: The Raleigh (N.C.) Banner does not entertain much respect for Mississippi. It says: "Who will take her bonds? A friend suggests that probably FLOVI, RUSSELL & CO. might, if an opportunity was afforded. We doubt it. They have no use for worthless bonds. Mississippi might leave her bonds out in the street all night, and if she will place a light near them, so that they can be read, we very much doubt whether any of them would be missing in the morning. Repudiates an honest debt, and asks credit for two millions! Don't she wish she could borrow it?"

abstract: The Buffalo papers tell a shocking story of an Irish undertaker who was employed to carry the corpse of pauper who died at the hospital to Lime Hill Cemetery. A dollar was paid ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Buffalo papers tell a shocking story of an Irish undertaker who was employed to carry the corpse of pauper who died at the hospital to Lime Hill Cemetery. A dollar was paid the fellow in advance, and he used it to get himself thoroughly intoxicated before he had got out of the city, so that before he reached the cemetery he succeeded in overturning the hearse in a ditch. The horse succeeded in kicking himself loose from the vehicle, and making his way to the cemetery gate, aroused the suspicions of the keeper, who started on a tour of discovery and found that his services were imperatively needed.

abstract: SALE OF THE ADRIATIC. The sale of the steamship Adriatic to the Galway Company was the theme of conversation yesterday in Wall-street, in which no little regret was expressed that the last steamer built by STEERS, and the one of which Americans had most reason to be proud, should have a passed into the hands of a foreign company, and that too at a ruinous ...
lead_paragraph: SALE OF THE ADRIATIC. -- The sale of the steamship Adriatic to the Galway Company was the theme of conversation yesterday in Wall-street, in which no little regret was expressed that the last steamer built by STEERS, and the one of which Americans had most reason to be proud, should have a passed into the hands of a foreign company, and that too at a ruinous sacrifice, as compared with her original cost. The negotiations have been going on for two months, the Panama Company, who owned five-ninths of the stock of the North Atlantic Company, against four-ninths owned by the Pacific Mall Company, opposing the sale. The influence of Mr. ASPINWALL, agent of the Galway line, in connection with the Pacific Mail Company, finally carried the day. The purchase-money had not been paid, up to yesterday, but the sale was considered as concluded. The North Atlantic Company expended some $90,000 on her engines, making her cost about $1,200,000. She has been sold for L87,500.

abstract: The guard of honor for Inauguration day at Washington will be selected from the most efficient companies of regular troops and marines.
lead_paragraph: The guard of honor for Inauguration day at Washington will be selected from the most efficient companies of regular troops and marines. The latter branch of the service has almost invariably furnished the only Government soldiers for the 4th of March ceremonies. Col. JOHN HARRIS, Commander-in-Chief of the Army Staff, and Capt. TAYLOR, will be the officers immediately in command under Gen. SCOTT. The bands of the Marine corps and two Army Regiments will be present.

abstract: Wm. S. Robinson et al. vs. the Brig Falmouth. -- This was an action for seaman's wages. The libellants claimed wages earned on a voyage from this port to the coast of Africa, and two months' extra pay because of the voyage being broken up at Porto Praya, by the arrest of the vessel. The United States intervened, by way of answer alleging that the vessel was during the whole time engaged in the Slave-trade, and the libelants knew it. On the trial it was shown that the United States had filed a bill against the vessel, alleging that the vessel was seized by a vessel of the United State for being engaged in the Slave-trade; that one Francis Revoy intervened in that suit as owner of the vessel and carrier of the cargo, and filed a general issue to the libel; that on the next day the District Attorney filed exceptions to the claim, and that nothing further had been done in that suit by either party, and that a criminal complaint against the libelants for engaging in the Slave-trade had been made and dismissed before a Commissioner, and the Grand Jury refused to find a bill against them.
lead_paragraph: Wm. S. Robinson et al. vs. the Brig Falmouth. -- This was an action for seaman's wages. The libellants claimed wages earned on a voyage from this port to the coast of Africa, and two months' extra pay because of the voyage being broken up at Porto Praya, by the arrest of the vessel. The United States intervened, by way of answer alleging that the vessel was during the whole time engaged in the Slave-trade, and the libelants knew it. On the trial it was shown that the United States had filed a bill against the vessel, alleging that the vessel was seized by a vessel of the United State for being engaged in the Slave-trade; that one Francis Revoy intervened in that suit as owner of the vessel and carrier of the cargo, and filed a general issue to the libel; that on the next day the District Attorney filed exceptions to the claim, and that nothing further had been done in that suit by either party, and that a criminal complaint against the libelants for engaging in the Slave-trade had been made and dismissed before a Commissioner, and the Grand Jury refused to find a bill against them.

abstract: One of the most puzzling knots in the great European tangle has been at last loosened, and that most opportunely. We are told by telegraph that Gaeta has finally capitulated, ...
lead_paragraph: One of the most puzzling knots in the great European tangle has been at last loosened, and that most opportunely. We are told by telegraph that Gaeta has finally capitulated, and that the young King, "the last of the chivalric monarchs of Europe," has taken refuge with his family on board a French frigate and fled, we know not whither, but may conjecture to France.

abstract: The Pensacola Tribune has intelligence from Fort Pickens to Feb. 16, Col. LOMAX, some reports say, had complied with Lieut. SLEMMER'S
lead_paragraph: The Pensacola Tribune has intelligence from Fort Pickens to Feb. 16, Col. LOMAX, some reports say, had complied with Lieut. SLEMMER's demand that he should stop mounting guns at fortifications evidently erected with the design of attacking the fort. Communication was frequent between the fort and the Wyandatte. The British war-steamer Gladiator was outside, and the rumor was that her Captain had offered his services to assist in repelling the rebels, as he called them. Some had it that the intention of attacking the fort was foregone, because it had been reliably stated that it would be peaceably surrendered on March 4; but Col. CHASE alleged that the assault would be commenced as soon as a negative reply had been received to the formal demand for its surrender, which would soon be made by the authorities of the C.S.A.

abstract: Freights from Liverpool to New-York were never so low as they now are. In the article of iron, freights average from 9s. to 10s. They have been as high as 17s., and as low as 8s. Now, ...
lead_paragraph: -- Freights from Liverpool to New-York were never so low as they now are. In the article of iron, freights average from 9s. to 10s. They have been as high as 17s., and as low as 8s. Now, however, offers are freely made by shipowners to carry iron to America for 3s. a ton. This rate applies to what the shipping agents now, for the first time, determinate "undamageable" iron. Damageable iron, such as sheets and hoops, which are unfavorably affected by oxidation, are to be charged 5s. a ton. There is little doubt, however, that all manufactured iron, whether damageable or undamageable, will be soon carried at the 3s. rate, for within the part week the freight of damageable iron bas been reduced 1s. a ton. Computing the distance from Liverpool to New-York at 3,000 miles, iron may now be carried across the Atlantic at 1s. per ton per 1,000 miles. These figures present a most tempting inducement to iron-masters to send out iron on speculation, but so little faith have, they in the expectations of correspondents in New-York, that the present great "difficulty" will soon be amicably adjusted, that it is not in any way influencing the proceedings of the iron trade.

abstract: Mr. RAYMOND was introduced to the meeting by SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., President of the Club, in some very complimentary remarks and, ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. RAYMOND was introduced to the meeting by SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., President of the Club, in some very complimentary remarks and, after the applause which greeted his appearance had subsided, he went on to say, that his object in coming to the meeting was not to deliver an "address," as he had been advertised to do, but merely to join with Republicans in rejoicing over the victory they had achieved, -- the most signal and important, in his judgment, which the political annals of the country had ever witnessed. It has been achieved, moreover, said Mr. R., after a comparatively brief struggle -- since the Republican Party, as a distinct national organization, was only five years old on WASHINGTON'S last birthday. Its first National Convention was held on the 22d of February, 1856, at Pittsburgh, and then for the first time the party put forth its programme of purposes and principles. The Address then issued vindicated at length the necessity which political emergencies had created for the formation of a new party, and set forth very clearly the specific reform which it proposed to effect in the administration of the National Government. The necessity for the new party grew out of the fact, which was open to the observation of all, that "the Government of the United States," to use the words of that Address, "had ceased to be administered in accordance with the Constitution, or for the preservation and prosperity of the American Union; -- but that its powers were systematically wielded for the promotion and extension of the interest of Slavery, in direct hostility to the letter and spirit of the Constitution, in flagrant disregard of other great interests of the country, and in open contempt of the public sentiment of the American people and of the Christian world." That Convention further proclaimed its belief that unless the policy which then controlled the Government of the United States could be arrested by the interposition of the People, "the hold of the Union upon their loyalty and affection would be relaxed, the domestic tranquillity would be disturbed, and all constitutional securities for the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity would be destroyed." This was the great fact which made the organization of the Republican Party necessary. The Slaveholding interest had obtained complete control of the Government; not by its own power, but by its alliances with other political parties. It controlled their policy, and thus ruled the country. No man could be appointed to office unless he believed that Slavery was right. No national policy or any subject could be adopted if it threatened in the least to interfere with the permanent interest of Slavery. A ban of proscription rested upon every man, North or South, who was not ready to prostrate himself at the shrine of this new divinity. And the aim of the Republican Party was to "determine whether Slavery should continue to be the paramount and controlling influence in the Federal Administration, or whether other rights and other interests shall resume the degree of consideration to which they are entitled." That battle has been fought, -- and has ended in victory, -- a victory which challenges the attention of the world, -- a victory whose importance no words can exaggerate. The Slave Power, as a controlling element in our national politics, has been dethroned. We have delivered our Government from the tyrannical ascendancy of this foul usurper, and if we use our victory wisely, its verdict can never be reversed, -- the Slave Power can never regain that supremacy in our national councils from which it has been expelled. [Applause.] This is a victory worthy of exultation. It is worth all it has cost, and all it is likely to cost, whatever that maybe. [Loud applause.] We have at last a government resting upon that broad, democratic, constitutional basis, the will of the people, -- free to consult all the interests of the people, -- and to use all the powers which the people give it to promote justice, enlarge the foundations of liberty, and secure the prosperity of ourselves and our posterity for all time to come. [Applause.]

abstract: The object of all compromise is to secure a harmony between the ideas of a people and their material interests and political relations.
lead_paragraph: The object of all compromise is to secure a harmony between the ideas of a people and their material interests and political relations. Whatever accomplishes this is compromise, no matter how effected. In our present divisions, whatever secures delay is a compromise, because it gives time for our people to learn that neither their material nor political integrity is to be affected by a change of parties. The Conferences held, even should it turn out that not a single measure proposed can become the law of the land, have been useful in disclosing how insignificant are the differences that agitate the country, how little remains for partition between the two sections, and how much is to be sacrificed by separation. The time gained allows passion to cool, and the traditions and consciousness of the past to repeat themselves. It is incredible that all these should be effaced in an hour; that the flag of the country, with its symbols of unity, under which all our great deeds have been achieved, should no longer excite sentiments of nationality or patriotism; and that a community of suffering and prosperity, of language, religion and race, should, for the first time in the world'shistory, go for nothing.

abstract: Yesterday, the Hall of the Historical Society, Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, was crowded with a highly select audience, on a rather unusual occasion. It was the First Commencement of the ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Hall of the Historical Society, Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, was crowded with a highly select audience, on a rather unusual occasion. It was the First Commencement of the New-York Homoeopathic Medical College of this City, and a large number of graduates were in attendance to receive their diplomas. We noticed a few Allopathists present, but like wise men' they entertained no revolutionary ideas, or, at any rate, they maintained a discreet silence. Dodworth's Band were engaged, and, of course, did all that was expected of them. Rev. MATTHEW HALE SMITH offered prayer, and the following gentlemen had their degrees conferred on them, and their diplomas given to them by Hon. D.F. TIEMANN, Ex-Mayor, the President of the Board of Managing Trustees:

abstract: -- A gentleman of very polished manners, calling himself Mr. Preston W. Hilliard, hailing from Baton Rouge, La., and pretending to be a brother of Hon. H.W. Hilliard, of Alabama, has gulled the citizens of Rochester most beautifully within the last few days. After flourishing about town in grand style, he paid his hotel bill with a check on the American Exchange Bank, of this City, and then left town. Two days afterwards the check was returned, with the information that about a dozen had been received from the same source, all of which were returned to those who had transmitted them, because there was no cash with which to honor them.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. The Board of Supervisors at its regular meeting, referred to the Penitentiary Committee a communication from the Committee on Schools, Arts and Sciences, of the Common Council, asking the appropriation of a portion of the Penitentiary grounds, whereon to build a Truant ...
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- The Board of Supervisors at its regular meeting, referred to the Penitentiary Committee a communication from the Committee on Schools, Arts and Sciences, of the Common Council, asking the appropriation of a portion of the Penitentiary grounds, whereon to build a Truant House, for which purpose $10,000 had been appropriated by the Joint Board. JOHN BRADSHAW, a deputy keeper of the Penitentiary, was removed from office on charges of incompetency and bad conduct, which a Committee reported were well founded. The Courthouse Committee reported unfavorably on several proposed sites, and favorably on one lying on Grand and Union avenues. The Committee was instructed to inquire the lowest price at which Mr. SCHOLES would sell certain land on Lee-avenue, in the Nineteenth Ward, and the subject was again laid over.

abstract: We have all our little troubles in this life, and for those who are not too proud, to use a popular phrase, ...
lead_paragraph: -- We have all our little troubles in this life, and for those who are not too proud, to use a popular phrase, it may be added that we have all our elephants to see. It is narrated of a certain farmer that his life's desire was to behold this largest of quadrupeds, until the yearning became well nigh a mania. He finally met one of the largest size traveling in the van of a menagerie. His horse was frightened, his wagon smashed, his eggs and poultry ruined. But he rose from the wreck radiant and in triumph. "A fig for the damage," quoth he, "for I have seen the elephant!"

abstract: Commodore ARMSTRONG'S cross-examination lasted all through yesterday's session of the Court-martial assembled to try Lieut. WALKE, of the United States Storeship Supply. The veteran officer's evidence was given with great frankness and direct bearing on the case, and, though rather long drawn out, will be found, when published, of great interest and importance. The witness succeeding Com. ARMSTRONG was Paymaster DUNN, of the Supply, who had been asked only one question when the time came for adjournment. The trial is continued to-day, and will probably proceed for some time without interruption.

abstract: A Berne telegram of the 13th, says it was through the medium of the Swiss Consulate at Algeria, that Mr. COBDEN proposed that Switzerland should mediate between the contending States of America. The Federal Council had declined the proposition, on the ground that it was not qualified for such an office, but at the same time expressed thanks to Mr. COBDEN.

abstract: As the time of the inauguration of the new President approaches the excitement in reference to that event increases everywhere, and especially in Washington. Aside from the apprehensions ...
lead_paragraph: As the time of the inauguration of the new President approaches the excitement in reference to that event increases everywhere, and especially in Washington. Aside from the apprehensions which may be entertained that the occasion will not be allowed to pass without some exhibition of hostility, and perhaps violence, there is much anxiety felt to know exactly the policy likely to be pursued by the incoming Administration, and curiosity as to those who may be called upon to occupy positions in the new Cabinet. With regard to the latter, besides Messrs. SEWARD and BATES, it is hardly yet known with certainty how any of the Departments will be disposed of. It is intimated in our Washington dispatches, however, that Messrs. CAMERON, of Pennsylvania, and CHASE, of Ohio, have been offered appointments, though it is not yet decided what their respective portfolios will be. Mr. LINCOLN yesterday dined with Mr. SPAULDING, the Representative from the Buffalo District of this State, in company with the Vice-President elect, Gen. SCOTT, GOV. CHASE, GOV. SEWARD, Mr. BATES, and several other distinguished personages.

abstract: Capt. Yates, of bark Homer, abandoned at sea, reports: Left Gaboon Dec. 11, for New-York, with a cargo of palm oil, had some very heavy weather, with ...
lead_paragraph: Capt. Yates, of bark Homer, abandoned at sea, reports: Left Gaboon Dec. 11, for New-York, with a cargo of palm oil, had some very heavy weather, with very heavy sea, some days after leaving, which caused the vessel to leak; kept the pumps going continually, until they got choked and all hands worn out with fatigue; concluded to abandon her. Feb. 17. lat. 3408 lon. 70 40, was taken off by Austrian bark Nicola Despol, and brought to this port. The H. was built at Bristol, Me., in 1848; rated A 2 1/2 -- 273 tons and was owned by Yates, Porterfield & Co., of this City.

abstract: Those who had weakly imagined that the resolutions of the Peace Conference were to be accepted as law by the President elect, and by the National Congress, are now plunged into the deepest gloom, at finding that they had given undue importance to an incongruous and irresponsible assemblage. It is now clear that the House of Representatives will never assent to any measure based on the idea of protection to Slavery in the Territories.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb. 28, 1861.

abstract: Already the other day a powder magazine burst at the south extremity of the Philippstadt Battery, causing considerable loss to the enemy; but I have now to record a far more terrible explosion. Yesterday, about 5 o'clock in the afternoon a shell from the Predmontese lines on the right penetrated into one of the powder magazines, which blew up and set fire to the great reserve store of projectiles, which blew up likewise.

abstract: Gen. TWIGGS' treason, it seems, is not likely to result in so easy an acquisition of all the Federal property in Texas as may have been anticipated. Capt. HILL, in command of Fort Brown, has positively refused to evacuate that post, or to surrender the Government property in his charge into the hands of the Texas Commissioners. It ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. TWIGGS' treason, it seems, is not likely to result in so easy an acquisition of all the Federal property in Texas as may have been anticipated. Capt. HILL, in command of Fort Brown, has positively refused to evacuate that post, or to surrender the Government property in his charge into the hands of the Texas Commissioners. It is further stated that Capt. HILL has taken the responsibility to order reinforcements from the Ringgold Barracks, in order that he may make an attempt to retake the Government property on Brazos Island. It may happen that the first collision between Federal and State troops may after all take place in Texas, as such a collision may be considered imminent.

abstract: In the case of the United States against the Captain and the mates of the alleged slaver Erie, and the crew of the alleged slaver Cora, Mr. J.J. Joachimsen, in behalf of the defendants, yesterday, made an application that they be admitted to bail, on the ground that they had been in prison a long time without being brought to trial, and that the witnesses for the prosecution were beyond the jurisdiction of the Court, and it was doubtful when they would return.

abstract: We receive from Madrid an announcement of semi-official authority to the effect that any immediate purpose of prosecuting hostilities against Mexico has been abandoned by the Spanish Government; no fact in the present relations of the two countries affording at this moment a justifiable cause of war. Coupled with the forbearing temper already exhibited by the British Ministry toward our neighbor, this declaration is abounding in good omens for the new Administration. For the regeneration of Mexico nothing is needed but tranquillity sufficient for the development of the new and beneficial policy the Liberals have inaugurated; a tranquillity which, in the absence of the banished clergy, is no longer seriously threatened by internal foes, and which, therefore, none but one of the two European Powers referred to, has been thought likely to impair. This danger is now withdrawn, and if the march of events be now undisturbed, there is no reason to fear that Mexico will fail within ten years to pay off every foreign debt, and proceed steadily in weath and prosperity. Such prophesies of such a people may seem rash, but they are no longer irrational.

abstract: Edward Butler, Felix Brennan, William Brennan, Patrick Cassiday, James McCahey, and James Ward, were yesterday apprehended by Detectives Farley and Eustace, charged with having committed a series of extensive robberies on board the steamships of the New-York and Philadelphia and Liverpool line of steamers. These men were engaged as stevedores at the Company's Pier, No. 44 North River, to load and unload freight. During the past year frequent complatin has been made by Liverpool consignees, that packages shipped to them were broken open and portions of their contents abstracted. Recently a case of watch movements, valued at $1,250, shipped by the steamship Vigo, was so despoiled, and on information being received here of that fact, the above Detectives were engaged to ferret out the perpetrators. Their investigations led them to suspect the persons whose names are mentioned above, and they were accordingly taken into custody. On searching the apartments occupied by them a large amount of jewelry, cutlery, dry-goods, &c, was found, all of which was doubtless taken from the steamers of that line. The watch movements were subsequently traced to a jeweler in Houston-street, who had bought them of the stevedores without a guilty knowledge. On being confronted with the prisoners the jeweler identified Butler as the one of whom he bought the property, while the others were recognized as his companions at the time the purchase was made. The stevedores being thus cornered, confessed their guilt, and acknowledged that the property thus stolen by them during the year past would amount to several thousand dollars. Their plan was to transform themselves into "baggage smashers," and break open the cases of freight while stowing them away in the hold of the vessels, secreting their plunder about their persons. They were locked up for examination.

abstract: The annual meeting of this most beneficent charity was held yesterday, at the Institution, in Fiftyfirst-street, near Third-avenue, and the large room was crowded, ladies constituting the majority of the audience. Mrs. ABRAHAM BININGER, the First Direc-...
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of this most beneficent charity was held yesterday, at the Institution, in Fiftyfirst-street, near Third-avenue, and the large room was crowded, ladies constituting the majority of the audience. Mrs. ABRAHAM BININGER, the First Directress presided. Prayer was offered by Rev. JOH COTTON SMITH, who was followed by Rev. Mr. HERRICK and other ministers in the reading of Scripture, and addresses. The Secretary's report was then read, and was most interesting, It contained some discouraging features, especially in the withdrawal of the First Directress to the Nursery; also, in the resignation of several members of the Board of Physicians, who had been for a long time, attendant upon the sick. Notwithstanding these discouragements, however, the children were healthier than ever they were known to be since the opening of the Institution. Contagious disease has been almost excluded. One hundred and twenty-five women and 337 children have been admitted during the past year. 43 women have been furnished with situations as nurses. The present number of inmates is: Children 126, nurses 20, employes 18, total 173. The report proceeds to state that "it is perhaps little known to the public that, in addition to the infants that are sheltered from harsh usage and neglect, the number of growing children is seldom less than 40. These children are subjected to the kindest and most judicious training; not only are their bodies cared for, healthful nourishment, cleanliness and warm clothing provided for them, but they are under the constant supervision of resident teachers. Four hours a day they are instructed in the rudiments of an English education, and the rest of their time is employed in sewing and housework, or healthful games and amusements.

abstract: We have just at this time two social and political pictures presented for our contemplation, each of which may be studied with profit by every reflecting mind. One is in the South,...
lead_paragraph: We have just at this time two social and political pictures presented for our contemplation, each of which may be studied with profit by every reflecting mind. One is in the South, the other in the Far West. As we penetrate into the former, the prospect becomes more dark and threatening, until at length the eye becomes weary with the gloom and confusion. The other becomes brighter as the eye traces beyond the foreground, and glimpses are got of a happy and industrious people, strong in their love of the Union, and everywhere laying the foundations of future wealth and greatness. That of the South presents us, just at this time, with a number of delirious men, perfectly conscious, not of yielding to a confessed weakness in their political system, but of wilfully misusing power, and committing a great wrong, simply because they had resolved to do it. Pride and fear, the two most dangerous offsprings of Slavery, find these men struggling with a despotism they will not ameliorate, and the downfall of which they blindly attempt to hasten, though it bring poverty and distress upon the whole people. There is nothing which so distinctly marks the boundaries between Freedom and Slavery as the peace, prosperity and intelligence seen on one side, and the poverty and confusion on the other. The line is as distinctly drawn as between Virtue and Vice. Freedom is progressive, Slavery retrogressive. The one represents those fearful inequalities of rank which take from the masses their rights, and give the wealth of the country to a few; which doom multitudes of our race, without fault of theirs, to hopeless, merciless suffering; sets their highest rights at defiance, denies their most sacred relations, lacerates their affections, and consigns them to a degradation on a level with the animal.

abstract: The necessity which renders every grant of a franchise a declaration of war between the public and the grantees, is of course deplorable; but must always, it seems, exist so long as capitalists love money, and the people crave accommodation. Where the chance of...
lead_paragraph: The necessity which renders every grant of a franchise a declaration of war between the public and the grantees, is of course deplorable; but must always, it seems, exist so long as capitalists love money, and the people crave accommodation. Where the chance of creating competition remains, the people are not powerless. But in their very nature, railroads in city streets are essentially monopolies, the only means of establishing a partial rivalry being the authorization of lines in parallel thoroughfares ; a measure not always expedient, tending as it frequently does to augment the very evil from which we would fain escape. Hence the extreme caution with which concessions of the sort, unguarded by every conceivable guarantee of the public interest, should be made; or, if made, the absolute charity which every popular demand for protection against encroaching corporations should receive at the hands of the Legislature. It is not at all necessary that a Railroad Company should make twelve per cent. a year ; but it is indispensable that the public should be permitted to travel with some trifling degree of comfort and convenience.

abstract: NARROW ESCAPE FROM BURNING Last evening, a lady residing in Second-avenue, entered a store in Second-street, for the purpose of making some purchases, and while there trod upon a match, which ignited and the flames communicating to her light under clothes, they were soon on fire; she was not...
lead_paragraph: NARROW ESCAPE FROM BURNING. -- Last evening, a lady residing in Second-avenue, entered a store in Second-street, for the purpose of making some purchases, and while there trod upon a match, which ignited and the flames communicating to her light under clothes, they were soon on fire; she was not aware of it, supposing from the warmth that she was standing over or near a furnace-register, until some persons sitting in a room back of the store, rushed out to her assistance. To aggravate her distress a ferocious dog, alarmed by the excitement, made an attack on her, but fortunately was restrained from injuring her. The flames were speedily extinguished, and beyond the destruction of her garments and a few slight burns, no immediate harm was done. The lady, however, on arriving at her residence, was seized with such a violent nervous attack, that her life was despaired of. This should serve as another warning to all, to avoid leaving matches where they will be liable to cause mischief.

abstract: The Court resumed its inquisition in the case of Commander WALKE, yesterday, with the cross-examination by counsel for the accused, of Paymaster DUNN, of the Supply. In the course of the day Commodore ARMSTRONG was recalled by the defence to answer an interrogatory which was, we suppose, of consequence to the completeness of Commander WALKE'S position, after which the Commodore was discharged from further attendance. Lieutenants BRADFORD and ERBEN, and Sailing-master ALLEN, all of the Supply, and Lieut. IRWIN, of the Navy, were called and testified as to certain details of the surrender of the Pensacola Navy-Yard, and the peculiar circumstances thereupon ensuing, Lieut. IRWIN'S depositions being of peculiar interest and importance. The defence hopes to conclude to-day. when nothing further can at present be known but the formal defence of Commander WALKE, which he will be allowed two or three days to prepare.

abstract: The Tribune perverts a paragraph in a communication published in our columns, for the purpose of saying that "in the view of the TIMES, while Mr. LINCOLN is nominally the President, in fact he is nobody and of no account." The TIMES has never said anything which even the Tribune's malevolent ingenuity could torture into such a sentiment. We are perfectly satisfied that Mr. LINCOLN is "somebody" and of considerable "account;" and we are inclined to think that the editor of the Tribune has discovered that fact also. That aspiring journal seems to have been laboring under the impression for some weeks past that Mr. GREELEY was President and Mr. LINCOLN only a sham.

abstract: "Don Giovanni" is a capital Opera to produce at the end of a season when the artists have nothing to study, and can give to the music a certain amount of attention, but at any other time it is not the safest card that can be played. Just at present the singers at the Academy have their hands full, and a single rehearsal, we suspect, is all that has been vouchsafed to MOZART'S masterpiece. Hence the performance was not so satisfactory as it will be to-night, when the work is to be repeated at the Brooklyn establishment. The caste, as it includes all the artists of the company, is of course excellent. We shall reserve what we have to say until after to-night's performance.

abstract: Whatever agreeable reminiscences of the outgoing administration may be treasured by those departments of the public service who are busily paying their adieux to the Old Public Functionary, it is safe to say the military arm is not likely to tender him any very regretful embrace. Throughout these hapless four years the army has indeed fared badly. Controlled by an in-...
lead_paragraph: Whatever agreeable reminiscences of the outgoing administration may be treasured by those departments of the public service who are busily paying their adieux to the Old Public Functionary, it is safe to say the military arm is not likely to tender him any very regretful embrace. Throughout these hapless four years the army has indeed fared badly. Controlled by an incompetent, corrupt and traitorous head; its service distributed by favoritism, and its supplies mulcted and plundered by peculators, whose gains, there is too much reason to believe, were shared by the head of the Department; the Army has been the sport of blunderers, and the speculation of knaves, to its serious demoralization, the damage of its honorable prestige, and the disgust of all its most valuable servants. To do justice to the shameful story no pen can so well answer as that of one of the officers who have helplessly witnessed this deliberate degradation of their profession; and, perhaps, when the proper time arrives, that of Capt. POPE, whose ability, after his popular lecture on military matters at Cincinnati, no one can doubt, would have the largest aptitude for the task.

abstract: In speaking of a disreputable gentleman. HORACE not GREELEY declared that he had hay on his horns, and requested all Romans to beware of him. Three of our Southern cotemporaries, according to this warning, must be indeed in a bad way, for though they do not bear the article in question on their foreheads, it sticks sadly in their throats, provoking odious splutterings and vile chokings. In...
lead_paragraph: In speaking of a disreputable gentleman. HORACE -- not GREELEY -- declared that he had hay on his horns, and requested all Romans to beware of him. Three of our Southern cotemporaries, according to this warning, must be indeed in a bad way, for though they do not bear the article in question on their foreheads, it sticks sadly in their throats, provoking odious splutterings and vile chokings. In short, much indignation has been elicited by the Northern boast' that King Hay is stronger than King Cotton, and much ingenuity has been exerted to dethrone the rival Yankee monarch. And it is settled at last by the discoverythat whereas hay is incontinently turned into butcher's meat, sold for only a shilling a pound, and then eaten, cotton is spun into all manner of expensive fabrics, some selling, in the form of lace, for their weight in twenty-four-carat gold, employing meanwhile no end of human labor.

abstract: The day for which so many anxious hearts have long waited impatiently, has dawned at last, and JAMES BUCHANAN ceases to be President with the setting of the sun that will have already risen before this congratulatory paragraph reaches the eyes for which it is written. Yet he must ...
lead_paragraph: The day for which so many anxious hearts have long waited impatiently, has dawned at last, -- and JAMES BUCHANAN ceases to be President with the setting of the sun that will have already risen before this congratulatory paragraph reaches the eyes for which it is written. Yet he must be an implacable foe, indeed, who can now entertain toward the broken old man who retires from the Chief Magistracy to-day any other feeling than that of sorrowful pity. The fiercest hatred, the bitterest disappointment, the vengeance of those he has betrayed, and the passions of those he has maddened by slander, may well be calmed down at sight of the baulked, forsaken, friendless old President. Even the relentless pen of History, while it chronicles his crimes, must be tempered with commiseration for his misfortunes. The old man's eyes are growing dim; the world is shrinking from his side; one by one his friends have deserted him; his country has repudiated him; and, like the dying HOBBES, he gropes about in the dark, cheerless and alone. "Governor," said he, to the seceding-Senator FITZPATRICK, a few days ago, "Governor, the current of events warns me that we shall never meet again on this side the grave. I have tried to do my duty to both sections, and have displeased both. I feel isolated in the world."
headline: {'main': 'A Happy Deliverance.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Happy Deliverance.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The great event to which so many have been looking forward with anxiety which has excited the hopes and fears of the country to an extent unparalleled in its comparatively brief history will take place to-day. ABRAHAM LINCOLN is to be inaugurated as President of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The great event to which so many have been looking forward with anxiety -- which has excited the hopes and fears of the country to an extent unparalleled in its comparatively brief history -- will take place to-day. ABRAHAM LINCOLN is to be inaugurated as President of the United States. The occasion has drawn to the Federal Capital a greater crowd, probably, than has ever been assembled there on any similar occasion. The hotels, our correspondent informs us, are filled to overflowing, and thousands, last evening, were seeking private accommodations. Whether the ceremonies will be marred by any untoward event, is, of course, a matter of conjecture, though grave fears are expressed on the subject. Mr. LINCOLN himself, however, it is understood, entertains no apprehensions, but believes that the measures which have been taken to preserve the decorum of the occasion will be amply sufficient. On Saturday evening the last great struggle over the Cabinet appointments took place. The conflicting powers were gathered at the rooms of the President elect, and he listened to the arguments urged by each in turn. The result was a resolution on his part to retain those gentlemen already fixed upon, and whose names have already appeared in the TIMES -- though possibly the distribution of positions may be slightly varied. The greatest contention seems to have been in reference to Ex-Governor CHASE, of Ohio, and the most strenuous opposition to his confirmation by the Senate is anticipated. On Saturday night, also, Mr. LINCOLN concluded his Inaugural Address, and submitted it to the inspection of Mr. SEWARD -- who, it is understood, found very few amendments to suggest. The character of the document is stated to be very positive and matter-of-fact, and treats the subject of the national difficulties very much as has been anticipated by the friends of the new Administration. We repeat our Cabinet list for the convenience of readers:

abstract: The German Stadt Theatre in the Bowery was quite filled yesterday afternoon, in response to a call for a meeting of " all those in favor of the repeal of the so-called Sunday laws." The meeting originated ...
lead_paragraph: The German Stadt Theatre in the Bowery was quite filled yesterday afternoon, in response to a call for a meeting of " all those in favor of the repeal of the so-called Sunday laws." The meeting originated among the Germans; was mainly attended by the masculine of that nation, and the proceedings were mainly conducted in their language, while German music and German lager contributed to stamp the nationality of the affair. Some of the speeches were in English, and a few of the gentler sex were present in the private boxes.

abstract: The withdrawal from the Academy bills of VERDI'S new opera, " Un Ballo in Maschera," although rendered necessary by the pressure of other novelties, and the need of some little repose for the singers, who, during the last week of its run, sang it here and in Brooklyn five times, was not altogether a profitable procedure. The house on Monday, when "Un Bailo" ...
lead_paragraph: The withdrawal from the Academy bills of VERDI'S new opera, " Un Ballo in Maschera," although rendered necessary by the pressure of other novelties, and the need of some little repose for the singers, who, during the last week of its run, sang it here and in Brooklyn five times, was not altogether a profitable procedure. The house on Monday, when "Un Bailo" was played for the last time, was very fine; on Wednesday, when Miss KELLOGG made her debut, it was from fair to middling; on Friday, when "Don Giovanni" was done, it was positively bad. This is the record in New-York. In Brooklyn, two performances -- one on Tuesday, ("I Puritani,") the other on Saturday, ("Don Giovanni,") have been given. The house, on both occasions, was but partly filled. A brilliant matinee, on Saturday, at the Fourteenth-street establishment, fortunately brought the week to a profitable end. On the whole, however, it has been the least satisfactory of the season, both in a pecuniary and artistic point of view. The performance of "Don Giovanni" was not what it ought to have been; even the admirers of Miss HINKLEY were unable to appreciate it, for the character of Zerlina is certainly beyond that lady's powers.To Miss KELLOGG then, we are indebted for the only real feature of the week. Critics seem to be divided about this lady's merits; but that she made a great success is not disputed. The future alone will determine whether she is destined to occupy a prominent place before our public. We confess that we see no reason why she should not. To-night VERDI's new opera will resume its place on the bills, and a large and fashionable audience may be expected. It is unquestionably a favorite with the operatic portion of our public. The season terminates with the present week, after which the artists will probably pay a short visit to Boston, and return in time for a Spring campaign, when "Aroldo" by VERDI, and "Zampa" by HEROLD, will be produced.

abstract: ESCAPE OF AN ALLEGED FUGITIVE SLAVE. -- As the steamship Yorktown was about sailing from her pier, No. 13, North River, for Virginia, on Saturday afternoon, a carriage drove on to the wharf, containing an alleged fugitive slave named JOHN POLHEMUS, in custody of two Deputy United States Marshals. On alighting from the carriage, the negro appeared disinclined to embark on board the steamer, and his unwillingness assumed a more determined form when the Marshals resorted to force. They attempted todrag him across the plank, but he stoutly resisted, and, seizing the rails, cried lustily for help from the bystanders. Responsive to the cries, a large crowd soon collected on the wharf, among whom was a policeman named ARMSTRONG, who interfered in behalf of the negro, and asked the Marshals to produce their authority for the proceeding in which they were engaged. They had left the papers behind them, and while one of them was gone after the documents, the negro escaped from the custody of the other Marshal and ran away. The Marshal gave chase, but POLHEMUS proved the more nimble-footed, and succeeded in making his escape. When last seen, he was running up West-street. The negro was alleged to be a fugitive from Mr. JAMESON, of Lynchburgh, Va., and to have confessed the fact to his master, now in this City. Whether any legal proceedings were taken in the case, or whether the negro consented to return with his master, but afterwards repented, did not transpire.

abstract: When Mr. TYLER returned to Richmond,reporting that nothing was to be hoped from the Peace Conference, and that sauve que peut was the order for the Border States, he enacted a part for which he had unquestionably prepared himself from the first. From the very first it was apparent that either Mr. TYLER misrepresented the sentiment of Virginia, or that the Northern Slave States were in no position to negotiate for peace. His attitude ...
lead_paragraph: When Mr. TYLER returned to Richmond,reporting that nothing was to be hoped from the Peace Conference, and that sauve que peut was the order for the Border States, he enacted a part for which he had unquestionably prepared himself from the first. From the very first it was apparent that either Mr. TYLER misrepresented the sentiment of Virginia, or that the Northern Slave States were in no position to negotiate for peace. His attitude was not that of a mediator, but of an agent and attorney for the seceded States. He was the medium through which President DAVIS and Gov. PICKENS transmitted their insulting messages to the Federal Executive; the negotiator who attempted to bring about an evacuation of the forts; the prompt and menacing interrogator of Government, as to any rumored energy of action, in order to forewarn his principals in the Gulf States. This activity in behalf of insurgents and traitors could not fail to neutralize the apparent zeal of the Ex-President for peace; and, reviewing his labors and their result in the light of these attachments, we are driven to the conviction that it was not to restore union, but to make the union appear impracticable, that the author of Texan annexation embarked in his late profitless enterprise. It was to complete that task of precipitation which YANCEY had planned, and DAVIS but half realized, that we have been amused with these displays.

abstract: The Secessionists are beginning to realize that the victory which they claim to have achieved in seven States of the Union, has not been exempt from very serious drawbacks. Thus, the Savannah Republican already finds that the Postal system, than which "no service performed by the Government is more essential to the interests of the people," must be extensively retrenched and abridged in the Southern Confederacy. Those citizens of ...
lead_paragraph: The Secessionists are beginning to realize that the victory which they claim to have achieved in seven States of the Union, has not been exempt from very serious drawbacks. Thus, the Savannah Republican already finds that the Postal system, than which "no service performed by the Government is more essential to the interests of the people," must be extensively retrenched and abridged in the Southern Confederacy. Those citizens of the Confederate States, it says, who are "expecting no abridgment of the facilities heretofore enjoyed" under the Postal system of the United States, are doomed to be disappointed, and "must be reconciled" to the diminution of the mail service as one of the "inconveniences incident" to the secession programme.

abstract: While the Presidential Inauguration was going on at Washington, yesterday, another inauguration, probably none the less important to the City of NewYork, was taking piece here at home the inauguration of the new street cleaning regime.
lead_paragraph: While the Presidential Inauguration was going on at Washington, yesterday, another inauguration, probably none the less important to the City of NewYork, was taking piece here at home -- the inauguration of the new street cleaning regime. Unfortunately for us, however, the simile ends with the common title, for, while the Washington Inaugural was characterized by firmness, promptness, and every indication of a due regard for duty, the New-York inauguration was characterized by a very suspicious circumstances. To drop the fanciful and assume the fact, It may be briefly stated that the new street-cleaning contractor commenced operations by notifying certain Aldermen that they could appoint the foremen of the different Waid gangs, and likewise some of the sweepers. Now it is not possible that these appointments were given to the Aldermen as a partial return for their votes for the confirmation of Mr. HACKLEY's contract. It could not be so, because Alderman BRADY told the TIMES' Reporter that he did not ask HACKLEY for the appointments, and that HACKLEY voluntarily told him he might have them. It is therefore a slender to suppose that this bit of patronage is part payment to the City Fathers for over-slaughing the binder whose figures were only half a million less. Our Aldermen are well known to be above all such influences.

abstract: The manner in which President LINCOLN'S Inaugural was transmitted by telegraph is deserving of especial commendation. The American Telegraph Company, under the able management of E.S. SAN- FORD, Esq., its President, placed at the disposal of the Associated Press three wires between Washington and this City.
lead_paragraph: The manner in which President LINCOLN'S Inaugural was transmitted by telegraph is deserving of especial commendation. The American Telegraph Company, under the able management of E.S. SAN- FORD, Esq., its President, placed at the disposal of the Associated Press three wires between Washington and this City. The delivery of the Inaugural commenced at 1 1/2 o'clock, Washington time, and the telegraphers promptly to the minute, began its transmission to New-York. The first words of the Message were received by the Agent of the Press at 1 3/4 o'clock, and the last about 3 1/2 o'clock, while the entire document was furnished to the different newspers by 4 o'clock. Such rapidity in telegraphic communication has never before been reached in this country, and it should be a source of pride to the American Company, its President and accomplished operators, that so notable an act has been accomplished. To Mr. SANDFORD are the thanks of the Press and the public especially due for the kind manner in which he placed the line under his charge at the disposal of the Press.

abstract: In San Antonio the United States have an arsenal and a large supply of ordnance and ordnance stores. These, by the act of Gen. TWIGGS, have been turned over to Texas Commissioners, and not to superior forces.
lead_paragraph: In San Antonio the United States have an arsenal and a large supply of ordnance and ordnance stores. These, by the act of Gen. TWIGGS, have been turned over to Texas Commissioners, and not to superior forces. In San Antonio were 44 cannon and howitzers of different caliber; 1,900 muskets, rifles and Sharp's carbines; 400 Colt's pistols; two magazines full of ammunition, containing 1,500,000 ball cartridges, and 5,500 pounds powder in kegs, &c. There was a magazine full of ammunition at Fort Brown, another at Fort Duncan, and another at Fort Clark; and there were cannon at forts Brown, Duncan and Clark.

abstract: The last grand "cus tom" of the King of Dahomey seems to have slightly shocked the nerves of English philanthropists, and, like the mild-mannered man of Yankee story, they really think that any one who could commit such very barbarous murders ought to be talked to. That is to say, a...
lead_paragraph: -- The last grand "custom" of the King of Dahomey seems to have slightly shocked the nerves of English philanthropists, and, like the mild-mannered man of Yankee story, they really think that any one who could commit such very barbarous murders ought to be talked to. That is to say, a deputation of the African Aid Society waited recently upon Lord PALMERSTON, to urge that something be said to the benighted royal blackamoor on the bad moral effects of cutting one or two thousand throats, and hint that should it and slave-hunting be discontinued, a subsidy might be paid to compensate him for the loss of amusement and of property involved. And all of this would cost nothing, since it is believed that the amount required may be obtained by a corresponding deduction in the cost of the African squadron.

abstract: LOSS OF BRIG ADELINE SPRAGUE, OF BOSTON. -- The ship Compromise, Capt. Zerega, from Liverpool, via Fayal, brings home the officers and crew of brig Adeline Sprague, of Boston, lost at Terceira, one of the Windward Islands, about Jan. 28, during a heavy gale from S.W. She was from Madeira for Terceira, to load fruit for New-York. During a heavy gale, she dragged ashore, and became a total wreck; crew all saved. The Captain had left in the steamer for England. The A.S. was built in 1854 and rated A2. Capt. Zerega also reports the loss of a number of other vessels in the same gale, all English and Portuguese. At St. Michael's, the gale was also very severe. A large number of vessels lost, but no Americans.
lead_paragraph: LOSS OF BRIG ADELINE SPRAGUE, OF BOSTON. -- The ship Compromise, Capt. Zerega, from Liverpool, via Fayal, brings home the officers and crew of brig Adeline Sprague, of Boston, lost at Terceira, one of the Windward Islands, about Jan. 28, during a heavy gale from S.W. She was from Madeira for Terceira, to load fruit for New-York. During a heavy gale, she dragged ashore, and became a total wreck; crew all saved. The Captain had left in the steamer for England. The A.S. was built in 1854 and rated A2. Capt. Zerega also reports the loss of a number of other vessels in the same gale, all English and Portuguese. At St. Michael's, the gale was also very severe. A large number of vessels lost, but no Americans.

abstract: ABRAHAM LINCOLN, of Illinois, was yesterday inaugurated as the Sixteenth President of the United States, and the occasion, we are happy to state although the City of Washington was crowded to an unwonted extent, and although apprehensions of scenes of violence were entertained by many was not marred by a single untoward event.
lead_paragraph: ABRAHAM LINCOLN, of Illinois, was yesterday inaugurated as the Sixteenth President of the United States, and the occasion, we are happy to state -- although the City of Washington was crowded to an unwonted extent, and although apprehensions of scenes of violence were entertained by many -- was not marred by a single untoward event. The ceremonies were similar in detail to those which have taken place at former inaugurations, and were carried out with precision and promptness. The arrangements for the suppression of any unwelcome demonstrations were most perfect, thanks to the foresight of Gen. SCOTT and the efficiency of the police -- and from first to last no token of disrespect to the new President was exhibited. The scene at the East Portico of the Capitol, when the Inaugural Address was delivered, was grand and impressive. When Mr. LINCOLN made his appearance before the assembled thousands, he was greeted with a burst of applause which must have gladdened his heart, and as he proceeded with his Address, he was frequently interrupted with marked demonstrations of approbation. Every reader of the TIMES will, of course, peruse this important document for himself. Its effect in Washington, our correspondent informs us, was extremely good. At the conclusion of its delivery, the venerable Chief Justice TANEY administered the oath of office to the new President, and the ceremonies at the Capital concluded. Subsequently he was conducted to the White House by Mr. BUCHANAN, who there took leave of him. The Diplomatic Corps were then introduced, and after them the public, who flowed in in a great stream for a time, congratulating the new President and themselves on the auspicious termination of the day's proceedings And the Inauguration was complete.

abstract: A lad, eleven years of age, named Edward Brown, whose parents reside near the corner of Twenty-sixth-street and First-avenue, was drowned on Sunday evening, while flying a kite on the pier at the foot of Twenty-sixth-street. The lad while watching his kite, walked into a hole in the pier, and falling into the dock, was drowned. His body was not recovered.

abstract: President LINCOLN being now happily inaugurated and his constitutional advisers selected, it becomes one of the first duties of the new Administration to reorganize the various departments of the public service. At such a crisis as this, the appointments to be made are of very serious importance, and the claims of all candidates should be scrutinized with more than common attention.
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN being now happily inaugurated and his constitutional advisers selected, it becomes one of the first duties of the new Administration to reorganize the various departments of the public service. At such a crisis as this, the appointments to be made are of very serious importance, and the claims of all candidates should be scrutinized with more than common attention. This is true of the domestic appointments, which exercise so powerful an influence in shaping the policy and guiding the course of local organizations; -but equally true and still more important is it with reference to those selections which are to be made of men to represent the Government of the United States abroad.

abstract: A horrible outrage was perpetrated in Harris County, Ga, a few days since. A negro man named George, owned by Mr. Abel Nelson, Sr., was suspected of having committed a gross personal outrage upon the wife of Mr. Isaac N. Middlebrook, and upon that suspicion was arrested and lodged in jail.
lead_paragraph: -- A horrible outrage was perpetrated in Harris County, Ga, a few days since. A negro man named George, owned by Mr. Abel Nelson, Sr., was suspected of having committed a gross personal outrage upon the wife of Mr. Isaac N. Middlebrook, and upon that suspicion was arrested and lodged in jail. A night or two afterwards, an infuriated mob, overcoming the opposition of the Sheriff, broke into the prison, seized the negro, and conveying him to the outskirts of the town, there chained him to a tree, and despite his earnest protestations of innocence, burned him to death.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC A very good house assembled last evening to witness the tenth performance of VERDI'S new opera "Un Ballo in Maschera" the best house numerically and otherwise that Fourteenth-street has seen since the opera was withdrawn on Monday of last week.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- A very good house assembled last evening to witness the tenth performance of VERDI's new opera -- "Un Ballo in Maschera" -- the best house numerically and otherwise that Fourteenth-street has seen since the opera was withdrawn on Monday of last week. There can no longer be a doubt that it is already one of the most popular works in the repertoire. That it increases in public interest, is certain. The Academy was the only place of amusement that could boast of a good attendance last evening. The performance was an average one.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN'S Inaugural Address must command the cordial approval of the great body of the American people. The intellectual and moral vigor which pervades it will infuse new hope and loyalty into the American heart. The calm firmness with which it asserts the rightful authority of the Federal Government,...
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN's Inaugural Address must command the cordial approval of the great body of the American people. The intellectual and moral vigor which pervades it will infuse new hope and loyalty into the American heart. The calm firmness with which it asserts the rightful authority of the Federal Government, -- the declared purpose which it embodies to preserve, protect and defend the Union and the Constitution, the easy force with which it sweeps away all the cobwebs of secession logic, and vindicates the supreme duty of the Government to defend its own existence, cannot fail to impress even the most determined Secessionist with grave doubts as to the justice of his cause. The characteristic feature of the Address is its profound sincerity, -- the earnest determination which it evinces to render equal and exact justice to every State, to every section, to every interest of the Republic, -- and to administer the Government in a spirit of the most thorough and impartial equity. To this purpose every other consideration is made to bend. And no one who can understand and appreciate such a character as that of Mr. LINCOLN, will doubt that this spirit will mark every act of his Administration.

abstract: The owners of woodlands on Long Island seem to be peculiarly unfortunate. The woodlands there have been burned over and over again, and generally about the time the trees became of the most value. abstract: People of all parties in this City, as elsewhere, were on tip-toe all day to know what was going on at Washington, and especially to hear what President LINCOLN would say in his Inaugural.
lead_paragraph: People of all parties in this City, as elsewhere, were on tip-toe all day to know what was going on at Washington, and especially to hear what President LINCOLN would say in his Inaugural. Republicans, in the morning, meeting on their way to their places of business, congratulated each other that the 4th of March was at length come, and that their chosen one was about to take in hand the ribbons of the national destiny. Men of every political complexion, who love the Union, and give credit to the honest purpose of the new Chief Magistrate to sustain it, were not less ready to express their gratification that the day had come when the fact that we have a Government should be known and felt. The morning papers were in great demand, and those whose Washington dispatches were known to be most reliable and full were especially sought after. The intimations found therein of the probable tone of the Message and of the preparations for the inaugural ceremonies, were the subject of frequent comment; but there were few wagers lost and won upon the probabilities of the position which the President would assume. There seemed to be very little difference of opinion among the many as to the view that Mr. LINCOLN would express of his obligation to execute the laws; for the express stipulation of his oath of office, it was well known, is that he shall do just this. It seemed to be the prevailing opinion that "Old ABE" was a square-toed man, and would neither shrink from indicating clearly what he believed to be the path of his duty, nor from following it without deviation to the end. Still there was great curiosity among all classes to see the message itself, and read word for word the protocol of the President's address. So, as the hours wore on the people began to congregate in and about the newspaper offices -- the faucets whence the stream of the desired information, brought through wire conduits from the Capital, was to flow forth.

abstract: On Tuesday night last, a man named JOHN McCAULEY was attacked, as alleged, by a party of five persons on Columbia, near Atlantic-street, and so severely beaten by them that he died of the injuries on the following day in the Long Island College Hospital. Four of the five parties accused are now under arrest. Their names are THOMAS COSTELLO, JOHN COWAN, JAMES RILEY and JAMES HANLEY.

abstract: PRESENTATION OF A BANNER AND REGALIAS TO A NEW-YORK IRISH PROTESTANT LODGE. Last evening an interesting ceremony took place in the large hall of the Cooper Institute, the occasion being the pre- sentation of a banner and regalias to the New-York Lodge No. 3, A.P.A.
lead_paragraph: PRESENTATION OF A BANNER AND REGALIAS TO A NEW-YORK IRISH PROTESTANT LODGE. -- Last evening an interesting ceremony took place in the large hall of the Cooper Institute, the occasion being the pre- sentation of a banner and regalias to the New-York Lodge No. 3, A.P.A. This association is of recent origin, and is composed mainly of Irish Protestants.It was organized Jan. 14, 1857. The exercises last evening were opened with prayer by Rev. T. WALSH, after which an address was delivered by the Chairman, J. NICHOLSON, Esq. The banner, bearing an appropriate inscription, was presented by Mr. C.B. COTTON, and received in behalf of the Lodge by J. MCKINLEY. Addresses were subsequently delivered by Rev. J. BRASH. Rev. J.S. INSKIP and Rev. J. DOWLING. The large hall was crowded, and many ladies were among the audience. The Washington Brass Band played national airs, and the whole meeting was one of unusual eclat.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer is playing a very bold, but a very hazardous game, in the interest of secession. It is insisting that the Gulf States shall immediately attack Forts Sumter and Pickens, as the only mode of securing the cooperation of Virgina.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Enquirer is playing a very bold, but a very hazardous game, in the interest of secession. It is insisting that the Gulf States shall immediately attack Forts Sumter and Pickens, as the only mode of securing the cooperation of Virgina. The fact that "the Confederate Government still permits the occupation of forts by Federal troops," the Enquirer urges, is the great argument on which the Unionists of Virginia rest their hopes of reconstruction.

abstract: The prospects of Italy were never brighter than at the present moment. The elections have terminated most favorably, and all doubt and anxiety and there was a good deal felt as to the result in the Southern Provinces, as well as in Milan and Genoa have given way to confidence and hope. Even the opposition, small as it is, is agreed with the Government as to the main points of foreign policy.

abstract: The Congress of this Republic, which has just adjourned, passed an act authorizing the Government to make a loan of $500,000 for public works. abstract: This Republic has not yet recovered from the prostration consequent on the late change of Government and the subsequent attempt at revolution. Money continues very scarce, and a feeling of insecurity prevents these who fortunately have any, from investing. The coffee crop will prove a small one, and prices will by no means come up to those of last year.

abstract: The United States Senate assembled in extra session yesterday, for exclusively executive business. The floor and galleries of the Senate Chamber were crowded, and the utmost anxiety was manifested to learn the exact truth relative to the distribution of the Cabinet appointments. After the appointment of a Committee to wait on the President to inform him of the readiness of the Senate to receive any communication he might ...
lead_paragraph: The United States Senate assembled in extra session yesterday, for exclusively executive business. The floor and galleries of the Senate Chamber were crowded, and the utmost anxiety was manifested to learn the exact truth relative to the distribution of the Cabinet appointments. After the appointment of a Committee to wait on the President to inform him of the readiness of the Senate to receive any communication he might be pleased to make, a recess was taken until 4 o'clock P.M. On reassembling, the appointments were immediately sent in, and almost unanimously confirmed, as follows:

abstract: Officer Hanaban testified that he arrested the prisoner Wilson, on the 15th of January, in a stage, and found upon him a $3 bill on the North River Bank, here produced and identified; the counsel for the defence admitting that it was counterfeit. At the Police Court, subsequently, the witness told the prisoner that he could not make any promises; but the Magistrate promised them that if they would tell all about the money, and where it came from, he would intercede with the District-Attorney, and have them used as witnesses against other parties. The counsel for the prisoner here objected to admitting confessions made under such inducements. The Court overruled the objection, and the witness stated that the prisoner consented to tell from whom he obtained the money; he obtained it from McConnell.
lead_paragraph: Officer Hanaban testified that he arrested the prisoner Wilson, on the 15th of January, in a stage, and found upon him a $3 bill on the North River Bank, here produced and identified; the counsel for the defence admitting that it was counterfeit. lead_paragraph: -- The Mobile Register takes exception to certain of our comments on the great Floyd-Russell larcenies, recently developed in the War and Interior Departments at Washington; but, to the credit of the Register be it added, that it makes no attempt to deny the justice of the charges advanced against the fugitive felon who was, until within a few months ago, Mr. BUCHANAN'S Secretary of War. Its apology for FLOYD is of the "you're another" style of logic; and this peculiarly feminine plea is set up on the assumption that "a Mr. JAY GIBBONS, an honorable member of the New-York Legislature," who is now charged with having attempted to extort a bribe for his vote on a private bill, is, as the Register "will venture to say, a Republican of the most kinky wool."

abstract: PRESENTATIONS TO COL. CORCORAN AND THE SIXTY-NINTH REGIMENT.?On the evening of the 15th inst., at the City Assembly Rooms, the Sixty-ninth Regiment are to be presented with a magnificent banner in commemoration of their refusal to parade at the time of the reception of the Prince of Wales. Col. Corcoran, also, is to be presented with a sword...
lead_paragraph: PRESENTATIONS TO COL. CORCORAN AND THE SIXTY-NINTH REGIMENT. -- On the evening of the 15th inst., at the City Assembly Rooms, the Sixty-ninth Regiment are to be presented with a magnificent banner in commemoration of their refusal to parade at the time of the reception of the Prince of Wales. Col. Corcoran, also, is to be presented with a sword of honor, magnificantly mounted, and having a scabbard ornamented and embossed with appropriate designs. These testimonials are in the nature of a tribute of regard and sympathy prepared by a Committee of which JOHN J. BRADLEY, Esq, is Chairman; and the presentations will be made the occasion for some significant speeches in reference to Irish affairs. The banner is a very costly and rich one of green silk, having embroidered on it in gold thread the sun-burst, harp, shamrock and other appropriate emblems.

abstract: JOHN C. NASH, Republican, was elected Mayor to-day by about 600 majority. All the Republican City ticket is elected, except Police Justice. The Republicans elect eight Aldermen and the Democrats four, which makes the Common Council stand fifteen Republicans to nine Democrats. TLe City Supervisors will stand about the same as Aldermen, possibly five Democrats to seven Republicans.

abstract: If there is any subject which comes as a stumblingblock in the way of modern philanthropy, it is homes for the poor. It is in the crowded, filthy and dark tenement-house that vice and degradation flourish most.
lead_paragraph: -- If there is any subject which comes as a stumblingblock in the way of modern philanthropy, it is homes for the poor. It is in the crowded, filthy and dark tenement-house that vice and degradation flourish most. Yet how provide the poor with homes? LOUIS NAPOLEON builds them, London philanthropists attempt to build them, and it is found that the number who are accommodated are a mere drop in the bucket. Clearly the only way is to enable the poor to build their own homes, or to enlarge every facility for so doing.
