abstract: Via Paita, Peru, intelligence has been received from Guayaquil to 14th inst. Another difficulty is likely to occur soon between Peru and Ecuador, growing out of the refusal of the latter to receive the Peruvian Minister accredited to FRANCO'S Government, and its refusal also to acknowledge the treaty ratified by FRANCO, by which she virtually relinquished to Peru nearly one-third of the Ecuadorian territory. A Peruvian steamfrigate arrived at Paita on the 19th inst. on the way to Guayaquil to carry the rejected Minister to Callao; while another Peruvian war steamer is left at Guayaquil, for what purpose it is not known.
lead_paragraph: Via Paita, Peru, intelligence has been received from Guayaquil to 14th inst. Another difficulty is likely to occur soon between Peru and Ecuador, growing out of the refusal of the latter to receive the Peruvian Minister accredited to FRANCO'S Government, and its refusal also to acknowledge the treaty ratified by FRANCO, by which she virtually relinquished to Peru nearly one-third of the Ecuadorian territory. abstract: In Chinandega it was generally thought that GAVERR, the murderer of JOSEPH L. WHITE, would be acquitted. The plea set up for letting him loose is that their witnesses who saw, the murder were all the friends of Mr. WHITE, and consequently their evidence could not be received; so that to kill a man with impunity in Nicaragua, it is only necessary to do so in the presence of his friends.
lead_paragraph: In Chinandega it was generally thought that GAVERR, the murderer of JOSEPH L. WHITE, would be acquitted. abstract: We are almost the only country in which appointments to office, from the highest to lowest, are made without the least reference to qualifications. The excellency of our Government seems to be entirely negative in the freedom allowed to individual energy and enterprise, which have achieved results that are ...
lead_paragraph: We are almost the only country in which appointments to office, from the highest to lowest, are made without the least reference to qualifications. The excellency of our Government seems to be entirely negative -- in the freedom allowed to individual energy and enterprise, which have achieved results that are really the admiration of the world. But the moment it takes a step in a positive direction, all faculty is at an end, rendering it to foreigners an object of censure, from its imbecility and weakness -- in striking contrast to the universal admiration bestowed upon the people. This is mainly owing to the fact, that since the advent of Jacksonism, the whole power and patronage of Government have been wielded for the reward of political partisanship.

abstract: As a general thing President LINCOLN's Inaugural is well received. It is only in the more ultra partisan journals, and in one or two that live by promoting dissension and commotion, that its sentiments are regarded as other than just and conciliatory. While the position he has taken in regard to the rights of the Government is firm and impregnable, he reserves the right, and proclaims the purpose, of adapting the means of vindicating those rights to the emergencies and contingencies of the hour.
lead_paragraph: As a general thing President LINCOLN's Inaugural is well received. abstract: The regular stated meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held yesterday evening at the Society Rooms, Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, the President, LUTHER BRADISH, Esq., in the chair. There was a full attendance, and the proceedings were of more than ordinary interest.
lead_paragraph: The regular stated meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held yesterday evening at the Society Rooms, Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, the President, LUTHER BRADISH, Esq., in the chair. There was a full attendance, and the proceedings were of more than ordinary interest. The minutes of the last meeting having been read by the Secretary, Dr. OSGOOD reported the receipt of some valuable documents, instancing in particular a letter from Hon. JOSIAH QUINCY, written in his 90th year, and addressed to him, the speaker, its subject being the present critical state of the Union. Coming from such a venerable person, Dr. OSGOOD thought it was worthy of preservation in the archives of the Society. An amphora, brought from Alexandria by Capt. SIMPSON, was also presented, as likewise was a curious pitcher that was said to have belonged to WASHINGTON, made in England during the first year of his administration, and which was ornamented with an admirable likeness of the Great Father of his Country. Several of these pitchers were made at that time, but that presented to the Society last night is believed to be the only perfect specimen in existence. In donating it, Dr. OSGOOD offered as a sentiment: "May Americans never forget to look upon the face of WASHINGTON, or cease to drink living waters out of his pitcher."

abstract: We have been indulging the hope that, after the inauguration, the Journal of Commerce would recognize the duty of supporting the Government of the United States in all fair and proper efforts to defend its own existence whatever it might think of the political principles of the Republican party.
lead_paragraph: We have been indulging the hope that, after the inauguration, the Journal of Commerce would recognize the duty of supporting the Government of the United States in all fair and proper efforts to defend its own existence -- whatever it might think of the political principles of the Republican party. But we have been mistaken. The Journal is not at all satisfied with the President's Inaugural, and its main point of objection to it lies in the fact, that it recognizes the Government of the United States as an existing Government! abstract: We presume nobody is astonished to hear that the Secessionists regard the Inaugural as a "declaration of war." It would have been very strange, indeed, if they had not done so.
lead_paragraph: We presume nobody is astonished to hear that the Secessionists regard the Inaugural as a "declaration of war." It would have been very strange, indeed, if they had not done so. In fact, it was part of their programme that it should be so regarded, no matter what it might contain. It has been relied on by the Precipitators as a potent weapon for the accomplishment of their plans. The election of LINCOLN did something towards plunging the South into rebellion, -- but it did not accomplish all. The Border States refused to catch the contagion. They thought the future welfare of fifteen millions of people worth some little reflection, and refused to plunge them into the horrors of civil war, on the instant demand of the desperate adventurers who have planned this conspiracy. Their action gave pause to the secession movement, and threatens to ruin it altogether, by substituting the deliberate and calm action of the people for the hot-headed recklessness of demagogues and traitors.

abstract: -It is rumored from Washington that President LINCOLN intends to signalize his advent to power by the promotion of the loyal Major who is in command of Fort Sumter to the rank of Brigadier General, made vacant by the removal of the traitor TWIGGS. We most earnestly hope that this report may prove true, the conduct of ANDERSON entitling him to the highest rewards in the gift of a grateful country. Moreover, it would need some such appointment as this to restore dignity and public respect to the position which TWIGGS has disgraced. Let ANDERSON be promoted as the first act of Mr. LINCOLN'S Administration, and every Union-loving man in the country will applaud the maiden exercise of the President's power.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The gentle zephyrs of Spring, when sandwiched between hyperborean blasts of wind and dust as they have been during the last few days do not regulate the vocal organs with that nicety which singers admire and cultivate. To this circumstance we owe the fact that there was no performance at the Academy last evening.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The gentle zephyrs of Spring, when sandwiched between hyperborean blasts of wind and dust -- as they have been during the last few days -- do not regulate the vocal organs with that nicety which singers admire and cultivate. To this circumstance we owe the fact that there was no performance at the Academy last evening. It was discovered during yesterday that one of the principal artists who was to have sung in "Poliuto" would unquestionably be unable to make his appearance. The announcements were consequently changed, and "Martha" was to have been substituted. Towards evening it was ascertained that two more of the company were "down," and so "Martha" became impossible. A general postponement was, therefore, inevitable.

abstract: The Adriatic, advertised by Mr. ASPINWALL for Havre and Southampton, was yesterday receiving the coal for her trip, the purpose to put her on the dry dock having been abandoned. Some necessary formalities still interfere with the final transfer of the ship, the late intelligence of difficulty in the house of OVEREND, GURNEY & Co., with whom are the credits for the payments, operating to delay settlement. The fact that the contract with the British Government requires the Galway Company to have a certain number of ships ready at a given time, is understood to be one of the reasons for dispatching the Adriatic to Europe.

abstract: Yesterday the new contractor for cleaning the streets, had so far completed his arrangements that he had a number of men at work in every Ward in the City. His office, which, by an understanding with the Comptroller, is, temporarily, in the upper part of the Fire Engine building, in the Park, was crowded with applicants for work. Mr. HACKLEY says all the appliances, boats. &c., necessary to the progress of the work will be continued, as when employed by the City until he can have boats built to suit him, and until his work is thoroughly systematized. Most of the work of removing filth from the streets is now done in the lower Wards and on the east side of the City, as those are in the worst condition. The dust yesterday was stirred by the wind, and was very annoving.

abstract: Mr. Allen J. Keeler, alias Griffen, was yesterday taken before Justice CONNOLLY on a charge of false pretences, preferred against him by Mr. John Thompson, of No. 54 Cumberland street, Brooklyn. The complainant alleges that he recently attended an auction sale of household furniture in Sixteenth-street, where the accused was acting as auctioneer. Believing the statements made by Mr. Keeler, the complainant invested $150 in the articles sold. Among his purchases were some parlor curtains, sold as Nottingham lace, which proved to be manufactured of an interior fabric; the rosewood furniture was the merest trash, and his curled hair mattresses were but little better. These articles were sent to the residence of Mr. Thompson before the cheat was discovered, and he now complains that he was swindled out of $150 by the false representations made by Keeler. The accused having been arrested, Justice CONNOLLY held him to answer in $500 bail.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer, of March 4, comes to us arrayed in mourning -- not for the death of Hon. GEORGE W. HOPKINS, as it takes pains to say -- but because "on this day, the chosen and avowed representative of the tyranny of fanaticism -- of the meanness of political corruption -- of the violence of inequality. Injustice and intolerance -- is installed as the Chief Executive of the shattered residuum of a once glorious Union of coequal sovereign States, peopled by communities of freemen. Fellow-citizens of Virginia, we mourn in the grief of shame. We are treated as slaves. Shall we remain in slavery?"
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Enquirer, of March 4, comes to us arrayed in mourning -- not for the death of Hon. GEORGE W. abstract: Mr. William Houseman, of Staten Island, appeared in the Mayor's Office, yesterday, and complained that he had been swindled by some Peter Funk, at No. 100 Broadway. He stated that he came up to the City for the purpose of purchasing iron, and passing up Broadway was induced to enter the mock auction shop by the very low prices at which watches were being sold. Nevertheless he did not bid readily, and one of the Funks, fearing they might lose him, pretended to be anxious to purchase -- represented to Mr. Houseman that he was $8 short of the purchase money, and that if he would oblige him with that amount he would return it and pay for the use of it as soon as he obtained the watch. Houseman let him have the money, and when, as the watch had been sold, he discovered that he could not get it back again, after a great deal of talk to settle the matter, they agreed to sell the watch again for the benefit of Mr. Houseman. It was sold, and Mr. Houseman received $3 of the $8 he had so incautiously loaned. Whereupon he discovered that he had been swindled, and went and made his complaint. The matter will be attended to to-day.

abstract: Henry Drew vs. The Sixth-avenue Railroad Company. This is an action brought to recover damages sustained by being run over by the care of the defendant. The complaint alleges the carelessness and negligence of the defendants. The plaintiff is an in-...
lead_paragraph: Henry Drew vs. The Sixth-avenue Railroad Company. -- This is an action brought to recover damages sustained by being run over by the care of the defendant. The complaint alleges the carelessness and negligence of the defendants. The plaintiff is an infant, who, while playing in the streets, on the 23d of January, 1857, caught his foot between the wheel and the track and had it amputated without surgical assistance. The child suffered severely, as is fully set forth in the complaint. The defendants, however, deny that there has been any act of carelessness on their part as the plaintiffs allege, but that there was carelessness on the part of the infant plaintiff in this action. The evidence, however, shows that the child is a cripple for life, and has been somewhat deformed on account of the injuries received by this accident. Case still on.

abstract: Notwithstanding the fact that Mr. CHASE has signified his acceptance of the Secretaryship of the Treasury, and attended a Cabinet meeting yesterday, it seems that he still hesitates about retaining the position. It was intimated in Wash-...
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the fact that Mr. CHASE has signified his acceptance of the Secretaryship of the Treasury, and attended a Cabinet meeting yesterday, it seems that he still hesitates about retaining the position. It was intimated in Washington yesterday that it was more than likely he would retire, and that Hon. JOHN SHERMAN would be appointed in his stead. Judging from the dispatch of our Correspondent, the pressure of the office-seekers upon the President is severe. He seems to take matters quite coolly, however, and is little disposed to be driven into granting audiences excepting at such times as he may deem proper.

abstract: The unexpected turn of affairs in the Texas Department, by which all or nearly all of the troops have a been suddenly discharged from service by the treacherous surrender of the various military posts in that State, has devolved on the War Department the necessity of promptly furnishing them with the means of subsistence, and, if required, with conveyance to more Northern posts. From the best information that...
lead_paragraph: The unexpected turn of affairs in the Texas Department, by which all or nearly all of the troops have a been suddenly discharged from service by the treacherous surrender of the various military posts in that State, has devolved on the War Department the necessity of promptly furnishing them with the means of subsistence, and, if required, with conveyance to more Northern posts. From the best information that can be gathered, it is with this view that the steamer Empire City has been chartered, and during the week she has been receiving on board large quantities of army stores, sufficient for the subsistence of two or three thousand men, which, with the necessary coal for the outward and return trip, has loaded that vessel nearly to the water ways.

abstract: The protracted spell of warm weather last week has done much to clear the Hudson of ice, and travel will, undoubtedly, soon be resumed by the various lines of steamers. All of these have been thoroughly refitted, newly painted, and in some cases freshly upholstered, to render them attractive to passengers.
lead_paragraph: The protracted spell of warm weather last week has done much to clear the Hudson of ice, and travel will, undoubtedly, soon be resumed by the various lines of steamers. All of these have been thoroughly refitted, newly painted, and in some cases freshly upholstered, to render them attractive to passengers. The New World and Hendrik Hudson, of the People's Line, are already prepared for a start as soon as the little remaining ice about Tarrytown gives way. These boats will make trips as usual, leaving every evening. The North America and Hero will constitute the Merchant's Line, and. will leave on alternate days from the foot of Robinson-street. The Hero went up on Tuesday, making the trip without mush difficulty. The Daniel Drew and Armenia will run as before in Smith's Line, the Drew leaving the foot of Harrison-street on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, and the Armenia from foot of Jay-street on alternate days. The new boat will be placed on the line about the 1st of May.

abstract: We have not the slightest objection to the Tribune's practice of translating our articles on the internal trade of the country and the mutual relations of Commerce and Disunion, into Tribunese, for the benefit of its readers. But we suggest the propriety of its sending its proofs over to us for revision, before it ventures on publication, -- as it might thus avoid some very awkward errors into which it habitually falls whenever it leaves, its more familiar walks of political vituperation.

abstract: Cornelius Van Dine vs. Jas. C. Willett. The plaintiff in this case sued as assignee of one Wykoff, to whom at this port a quantity of saws had been shipped. Before the arrival of the saws, however, the assignment was made to the plaintiff, by Wykoff, who by the terms of the instrument, assigned all the goods in his store, and all goods shipped to him which might be in the Custom-House.
lead_paragraph: Cornelius Van Dine vs. Jas. C. Willett. -- The plaintiff in this case sued as assignee of one Wykoff, to whom at this port a quantity of saws had been shipped. Before the arrival of the saws, however, the assignment was made to the plaintiff, by Wykoff, who by the terms of the instrument, assigned all the goods in his store, and all goods shipped to him which might be in the Custom-House. The Sheriff seized upon the saws when they arrived, by virtue of an attachment, and the plaintiff brought this action to recover possession of them, as assignee. The defendant set up that as the saws had not arrived when the assignment was made, by the terms of the instrument of assignment they were not included. The plaintiff replied, contending that having been shipped to, and being expected by Wykoff, they were virtually and impliedly included in the assignment.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of the Supervisors was held last evening in the County Jail building, Raymond-street, the President, Supervisor CROWELL, in the Chair. It was expected that some action would be taken relative to the Clerk of this Board, who wrote to a member of the Louisiana Legislature asking that body to extend an invitation to the Southern District of New-York and New-Jersey to join the Southern Confederacy; but as that gentleman was absent no action was taken. A petition signed "D. Richards," complaining that some injustice had been done him at the last meeting, was presented, but referred back to the member presenting it, to ascertain whether there was in fact any such person as that whose name was attached to the document. After the transaction of the regular business of the Board the subject of selecting a site for a Court-house was called up, when Supervisor TALBOT, of the Fifteenth Ward, presented a resolution in favor of purchasing the plot of ground owned by Alderman Scholes and others, in the Nineteenth Ward, bounded by Lee avenue, Marcy-avenue, Hooper and Hewes streets, at the rate of $756 per city lot, as a site for the proposed County Court-house. Supervisor BERGEN moved to amend by inserting the Schenck property, at the rear of the City Hall, upon the terms heretofore proposed by the owner. The Chair decided that he could not entertain this motion as an amendment or substitute, because it had been voted upon at a previous meeting, and the motion was accordingly not pressed. After some discussion, a vote was taken on the original resolution with the following result:

abstract: Considerable excitement was caused among the residents of Second-avenue, yesterday morning, by the discovery of the bodies of three infants in the sink attached to the house No. 535 in that street. A cord was found about the necks of the bodies, which led to the belief that the infants had been strangled before being placed there. Coroner JACKMAN investi-...
lead_paragraph: Considerable excitement was caused among the residents of Second-avenue, yesterday morning, by the discovery of the bodies of three infants in the sink attached to the house No. 535 in that street. A cord was found about the necks of the bodies, which led to the belief that the infants had been strangled before being placed there. Coroner JACKMAN investigated the case, when it appeared that Mr. Arthur Bently, proprietor of the drug-store at the corner of Thirty-third-street and Second-avenue, had placed the bodies in the sink. Mr. Bently recently took possession of the drug store, and on doing so found the three bodies there, preserved in spirits as anatomical specimens, and he wrapped them in paper and threw them into the sink. Some Paul Pry in the neighborhood observing his actions, notified the Police, and raised the indignation of the neighbors. The jury in the case rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts above stated.

abstract: "There is a woman in the public eye; whose name had all along been associated, in our mind with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack', and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer.
lead_paragraph: "There is a woman in the public eye; whose name had all along been associated, in our mind with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack', and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious association in all other minds. Whatever notions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse -- the GOOD Nurse -- the BEST Nurse. Whether we shall have female physicians or not is a question which must be decided by time andprinciple, and not as a matter of taste. Pride, prejudice, caprice and custom may as well behave themselves, for if there is really a want there will also be a supply -- if there be a 'calling,' there will be a 'coming.' Nature and Human Society are always self-supplying, and though Art and Fashion may hinder, they cannot prevent.

abstract: In the present issue will be found highly interesting dispatches from Mexico. The Constitutional Government is pursuing the work of reform with energy, determination, and, to all appearance, discretion, according to the programme laid down in what may be termed the Inaugural Message of the Liberal Government. This able State paper is well worth perusal, and we recommend it particularly to the attention of our legislators and Executive in Washington.

abstract: No meeting of the Board took place yesterday, because there was not a quorum present. The weekly statement is as follows: Number of emigrants arrived from the 1st of January up to date, 4,321, against 4,618 arrived here during the same time last year; 380 arrived here during the past week; 1,121 inmates are cared for in the various institutions under the care of the Board. The aggregate receipts during the past week amounted to $1,208, while the current expenses were $6,461 24. leaving a balance of $1,968 58 of the commutation fund in the Bank.

abstract: The Summit County Bank, of Ohio vs. The Phenix Bank of the City of New-York. -- This case was stated in yesterday's TIMES. The Jury now rendered a verdict for the defendant. It will be remembered that the plaintiff's claimed that a bill of exchange for $1,000 was deposited by them with the Ohio Life and Trust Company for collection; but that that Company subsequently assigned it to the defendants, in payment of a debt, contrary to their express protest and direction.

abstract: Called by his Excellency, the Constitutional President of the Republic, to form his Cabinet, his Excellency the Licenciado Don IGNACIO RAMIREZ in the Department of Justice and Public Instruction, his Excellency D. GUILLERMO PRIETO in that of Treasury and Public Credit, his Excellency Gen. D. JESUS GON-...
lead_paragraph: Called by his Excellency, the Constitutional President of the Republic, to form his Cabinet, his Excellency the Licenciado Don IGNACIO RAMIREZ in the Department of Justice and Public Instruction, his Excellency D. GUILLERMO PRIETO in that of Treasury and Public Credit, his Excellency Gen. D. JESUS GONZALEZ ORTEGA in that of War and Marine, and the undersigned in that of Foreign Relations, we have today taken possession of our respective portfolios, regretting extremely that the pressure of circumstances and the necessity of not paralyzing the public administration at the moment when the triumph of legal order has just been consummated, has not permitted us to await the arrival, or at least the replies, of their Excellencies, D. PEDRO OGAZON, Governor of the State of Jalisco, and D. MIGUEL AUZA, Governor of the State of Zacatecas, called by his Excellency the President to the Secretaryships of Government and of the Interior.

abstract: The United States vs. One Hundred and Fifty Bales of Wool. -- This case has been referred to several times. A verdict was yesterday rendered for the claimants, the jury finding that the wool was entitled to be entered free of duty, it having been invoiced at less than twenty cents per pound, its actual cost. The District-Attorney moved for a new trial which the Judge now denied, holding that under the Tariff Acts of 1799 and 1830, the wool was properly entered.

abstract: has recently been agitated by the elopement of John Mundorf, a man who has lived half a century, with Mrs Daniel Steppey, a lady of some forty years, and the mother of five children. The parties were arrested in Rockville after a desperate fight, in which revolvers and bowie-knives were exhibited, and were lodged in Harrisburgh Jail. A daughter of Mrs. Steppey followed her mother's example so far as to receive very marked attention from a young man, who, with her, accompanied the more edderly couple.

abstract: The quadrennial revel of the office-seekers is now in full blast at Washington. The daily telegrams inform us that the pressure upon the President is terrific; and even the sturdy Rail-splitter, who has long been accustomed to the hardest kinds of mental and physical labor, is incapable of bearing up under it. He retires at night, pale and haggard, for a few hours' repose; in the morning the assault is renewed upon him with fresh vigor; his privacy is invaded, his footsteps are dogged, and even the members of his family, and his servants and negro man are not safe from the approaches of the impudent cormorants who pursue their quarry with all the ferocity of selfishness. Each of his seven ministers also are ceaselessly beset by pertinacious fellows, armed with petitions, recommendations, testimonials of party service -- showing their fitness or unfitness, perhaps, for any possible office, from a diplomatic mission down to the smallest Postmastership.
lead_paragraph: The quadrennial revel of the office-seekers is now in full blast at Washington. abstract: At the present day the promotion of material interests is almost the sole guide in National politics. In the past generation it was the maintenance of balance of power, or dynasties, or of religious or political ideas. It is now the development of commerce, trade and manufactures; the creation of markets for the surplus products of a nation. It is natural, therefore, that European powers should look at our great question of disunion simply inthe light of their own interests, and that they should form very erroneous notions as tothe manner in which, at the present crisis,these are to be best promoted.

abstract: The advent of a Republican Administration was never a consummation devoutly wished by the employes of the Federal Government in this City. They were, of course, for the most part, among the most active partisans of the Democratic Party in the Metropolis during the recent Presidential campaign, and when the death blow was inflicted in November, they fell to making preparations for yielding up the ghost of political preferment and departing to the purgatory of a private station, soon after the 4th of March. The 4th has come and gone, and the question of succession in the United States offices in New-York will speedily be decided. In the Custom-House and the Office of the Surveyor of the Port, as at the other udders of the Federal patronage, there is at present much gnashing of teeth, and many are disposed to view all things mundane as through glasses of cerulean hue. A man who has been engaged in the labor attendant upon the collection of the customs for four years or more, acquires a habit of doing his little work and drawing his little salary which it is painful to discontinue suddenly.
lead_paragraph: The advent of a Republican Administration was never a consummation devoutly wished by the employes of the Federal Government in this City. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- To-night, VEEDI'S "Ballo in Maschera" will be played, for the close of the season. It has enjoyed a brilliant run from the time of its production, and, more than all the other operas in the repertoire, has contributed to the success of the season -- a success quite remarkable, when it is remembered how dismal was the failure of the preceding one, under Mr. ULLMAN'S management. The artists have reason to be satisfied with the pecuniary result of their efforts, and the public to be content with its fare, for what was promised has been laid before them without gasconade. One of the most striking features of the season just closing is that there has been no artists' quarrels from beginning to end -- a thing very remarkable, when it is remembered that two successful debuts have been made, and a popular tenor added to the ranks, since it commenced.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- To-night, VEEDI'S "Ballo in Maschera" will be played, for the close of the season. The artists have reason to be satisfied with the pecuniary result of their efforts, and the public to be content with its fare, for what was promised has been laid before them without gasconade. One of the most striking features of the season just closing is that there has been no artists' quarrels from beginning to end -- a thing very remarkable, when it is remembered that two successful debuts have been made, and a popular tenor added to the ranks, since it commenced.

abstract: The steamer Empire City, of M.O. ROBERTS' New-Orleans and Havana line, which has been cleared for Indianola, sailed yesterday morning, with a large quantity of army stores for the supply of the different garrisons in Texas. She will relieve the United States troops which have been sent to the seaboard, and transport such of them as it may be necessary to other ports. The Daniel Webster, lately dispatched to Brazos, is expected to arrive here about the 10th, with such of the troops as were not required for service at Tortugas and Key West.

abstract: Officer Fellman, of the Fourth Ward, yesterday arrested two lads named John McElvany and John Eagan, aged 13 and 16 years, charged with having stolen $143 worth of goods from the store of Devlin Hudson & Co., No. 258 Broadway. McElvany was employed in the store, and took the property at various times, at the instigation of Eagan. The latter sold the articles to John Acearn, in Pearl-street, who was subsequently charged with receiving stolen goods. Justice OSBORN committed the prisoners to answer.

abstract: The Italian Parliament was opened Feb. 18 by the King in person. His Majesty, in his speech, said: Italy, almost entirely free and united, confides in
lead_paragraph: The Italian Parliament was opened Feb. 18 by the King in person. His Majesty, in his speech, said: Italy, almost entirely free and united, confides in your wisdom, and it is on you devolves the task of her organization. You will establish the greatest administrative liberty, taking care, at the same time, that her unity be protected. Public opton is favorable to our national tendencies. The Emperor of the French, although assuring to us the benefits of non-intervention, has deemed it fitting to call his Envoy. This act has excited our deep regret, without, however, affecting our gratitude. At Magenta and Solferino, France and Italy have riveted ties of amity which will be indissoluble. England, the ancient home of liberty, has recognized our right to dispose of ourselves. We shall preserve an imperishable remembrance of the support which her good offices have afforded us.

abstract: Affairs in Washington continue much the same as reported yesterday. No nominations were sent to the Senate for confirmation, but the Cabinet held a meeting at which a number were prepared, which will be sent in to-day -- among them probably those for the Collectorship and Surveyorships of this port. The chances of the various candidates are fully canvassed in the dispatch of our correspondent. The President in the afternoon received the Diplomatic Corps, who made their appearance in full Court costume, and were presented by Secretary SEWARD. The Senior member of the corps, the Portuguese Minister, delivered a complimentary and congratulatory address, expressive of the good feeling entertained by Foreign Governments for that of the United States, and hoping that peace and prosperity might be continued. The President responded in a feeling manner, and the Corps were subsequently introduced to the members of the Cabinet and to Mrs. LINCOLN. The occasion was a very interesting and agreeable one. The President will give his first public reception to-night, and Mrs. LINCOLN to-morrow morning.
lead_paragraph: Affairs in Washington continue much the same as reported yesterday. abstract: The Berlingske Fidende declares that no difference of opinion on questions of principle has existed between the Ministers, and that complete unanimity now prevails between them. abstract: Divided upon other issues, all parties in our City agree on the necessity of placing the Bureau of City Chamberlain on a surer foundation than it now rests upon. The present Democratic incumbent, who owes his appointment to a Democratic Board of Aldermen, is to-day appealing to the Legislature for a bill to place his Bureau beyond any further reach of Municipal huckstering. It is notorious that the office has several times been disposed of for illegitimate considerations; and possibly it may be his knowledge of how remunerative is the business of making City Chamberlains, which induces the present incumbent to petition the Legislature, through his friends, for a four years' lease of official life, exempt from the taxation which might otherwise be imposed on him. The Democracy are thus placed on the record as demanding legislation for an evil which can be cured in no other manner.
lead_paragraph: Divided upon other issues, all parties in our City agree on the necessity of placing the Bureau of City Chamberlain on a surer foundation than it now rests upon. The present Democratic incumbent, who owes his appointment to a Democratic Board of Aldermen, is to-day appealing to the Legislature for a bill to place his Bureau beyond any further reach of Municipal huckstering. It is notorious that the office has several times been disposed of for illegitimate considerations; and possibly it may be his knowledge of how remunerative is the business of making City Chamberlains, which induces the present incumbent to petition the Legislature, through his friends, for a four years' lease of official life, exempt from the taxation which might otherwise be imposed on him. The Democracy are thus placed on the record as demanding legislation for an evil which can be cured in no other manner.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon a detachment of United States marines left this City to join the ship's company of the United States steamer Michigan, on the lakes. The Michigan is a snug little vessel, about 400 tons burden, and was built at Erie, Penn., some years ago. She cruises on her land-bound station about eight months of the year. abstract: That standard political maxim, "To the victors belong the spoils," while it creates no little satisfaction to the victors, per contra creates a species of sword of Damocles for the defeated from the moment of the election. The New-York Post-office is in this respect no exception to the Custom-house and other departments of the General Government new transferred from the control of the Democracy to that of Republicanism. The transition from the one regime to the ether is of course a species of purgatory -- something like the state of mind that a condemned man must be in between the time the black cap is drawn over his face and the moment the rope is cut. This state of mind must be something similar to that of the engineer of a locomotive when he knows he is to encounter a collision the next minute -- he suffers a variety of collisions, and is mentally smashed a dozen times before the real crash comes; and when by any miracle the crash is averted they are equally elated.
lead_paragraph: That standard political maxim, "To the victors belong the spoils," while it creates no little satisfaction to the victors, per contra creates a species of sword of Damocles for the defeated from the moment of the election. The transition from the one regime to the ether is of course a species of purgatory -- something like the state of mind that a condemned man must be in between the time the black cap is drawn over his face and the moment the rope is cut. This state of mind must be something similar to that of the engineer of a locomotive when he knows he is to encounter a collision the next minute -- he suffers a variety of collisions, and is mentally smashed a dozen times before the real crash comes; and when by any miracle the crash is averted they are equally elated.

abstract: The bark Cora, seized by Capt. FAUNCE, of the Revenue-cutter Harriet Lane, long since, on suspicion that she was going a slaving, which was afterward bonded, released, seized a second time, tried, and condemned by Judge BETTS, and sold by the United States Marshal, was yesterday, seized a third time just as she was getting underway to leave the port. She lies under the protection of the guns of the Harriet Lane, pending the proper legal proceedings to test the probable character of her voyage. A now era appears to have dawned in New-York touching the fitting-out of slavers.
lead_paragraph: The bark Cora, seized by Capt. She lies under the protection of the guns of the Harriet Lane, pending the proper legal proceedings to test the probable character of her voyage. A now era appears to have dawned in New-York touching the fitting-out of slavers.

abstract: The fearful conflagration in Fortieth-street which occurred yesterday morning, and by which a whole family of seven persons perished miserably in the flames, may be taken as another sample of the reckless disregard for human life evinced by those landlords, who have dealings with the poor. The house itself was a mere tinder-box inside, filled with the most combustible materials; and yet so unusually narrow was the stairway that "even under ordinary circumstances," we are told, "egress would be difficult."
lead_paragraph: The fearful conflagration in Fortieth-street which occurred yesterday morning, and by which a whole family of seven persons perished miserably in the flames, may be taken as another sample of the reckless disregard for human life evinced by those landlords, who have dealings with the poor. abstract: On Wednesday afternoon, at 6 o'clock, the thermometer suddenly fell to within a few degrees of zero. The wind was sharp and cold, blowing a gale all night. At different points along the Hudson River, from Albany to New-York, a snow-squall prevailed with more or less fury. It reached Peekskill about fifteen minutes to 9 o'clock, and from. Rhinebeck to that village, exceeded any storm that has preceded it this Winter, so thick and fast did the snow fall. The squall kept pace with the Express train at Hudson, Rhinebeck, Fishkill, Peekskill, Yonkers and New-York, where it arrived at 10 1/4, and by 10 1/2 the snow had ceased to fall. The cold continued to increase along the river all night and yesterday. At Hudson and Albany the thermometer yesterday morning at 6 o'clock varied from zero to five degrees below.

abstract: Rudolph Bloomingberg was put on trial yesterday morning, charged with perjury. This is his second trial, the jury having disagreed on the former trial. He was one of the sureties to the bond on which the slaver Onion was discharged from custody, and the alleged perjury consisted in his swearing to the value of his property. The testimony against him did not materially differ from that on the former trial.

abstract: The latest intelligence from the steamer Mount Vernon, ashore at Little Egg Harbor, states that most of her cargo had been placed in lighters, and as soon as the weather became moderate -- a contingency not likely to happen soon -- she would come off. She will, no doubt, be obliged to return to New-York for repairs, as she must be considerably strained, notwithstanding her acknowledged strength of hull. She is insured for about $40,000, and cost $60,000. The wind being off-shore makes the sea comparatively smooth along the beach. Should an easterly blow occur, it is feared she would break up.

abstract: The letter-writers at Montgomery, Ala., furnish us some interesting items of informatian. A house has been rented for President DAVIS at $5,000 per annum, and another for Mr. TOOMBS at $3,000. The living and rents are so high, in fact, that it is doubtful whether the seat of Government will long be located
lead_paragraph: The letter-writers at Montgomery, Ala., furnish us some interesting items of informatian. A house has been rented for President DAVIS at $5,000 per annum, and another for Mr. TOOMBS at $3,000. The living and rents are so high, in fact, that it is doubtful whether the seat of Government will long be located at Montgomery. Some more central point, such as Atlanta. Macon or Columbus, is talked of. The permanent Constitution is not yet adopted. It provides for a term of six years for the President, and gives the Cabinet Officers the power of vindicating themselves and speaking in Congress, but not to vote. It preserves the three-fifth ratio of representation in slaves. Mr. TOOMBS has appointed his son-in-law, WM.F. ALEXANDER, of Washington, Ga., Chief Clerk in the State Department.

abstract: At about 6 o'clock yesterday, morning a fire was discovered in the basement of the two-story and attic frame house No. 102, West Fortieth-street. The first floor of the building was occupied by Mrs. CATHARINE HOVEY as a cigar store, and PETER CUNNEN as a residence. The second floor was occupied by HENRY S. OAKLEY; who was the lessee of the premises. HENRY WOOD and his family, and two men named CLARK and GARVIN lived in the attic. A portion of the basement was used as a shop by Mr. WOOD, who was an uphulsterer. Mrs. OAKLEY was the first to discover the fire, and she hastened to alarm the other occupants of the premises. But a very few moments elapsed before the fire mounted from the basement to the first floor, and, sweeping along the wood-work, was soon climbing the stairs in all its fury. Mrs. OAKLEY, in attempting to escape by the stairway, was severely burned about the face, neck and hands, but eventually gained the street.

abstract: Leonard Gohring vs. John W. Farmer. -- The plaintiff, in his complaint in this action, alleges against the defendant, as a cause of action, that on the 7th day of January, 1860, the said defendant made an excavation in the sidewalk in front of the premises No. 123 Broome-street, in this City. The plaintiff, whose occupation is driving a lager-bier wagon, while driving along this street, on the said 7th day of January, 1860, was precipitated into the aforesaid hole, together with his horse and wagon, by reason of which he sustained damage to the amount of $5,000. The defendant avers that said excavation was properly guarded, so as to render it quite unnecessary for any one to precipitate himself into it; that it was made by the plumber, in order to construct some repairs necessary to be done to the water-pipes.

abstract: About 11 o'clock on Thursday night, as Mr. Thomas H. Copkins, of No. 74 Horatio-street, reached the corner of Bleecker and Bond streets, he was met by two men, one of whom remarked, "That's him" and immediately knocked his hat over his eyes. Both the ruffians then seized the blinded man and threw him into an area, 15 feet below the side-walk. The violence attending the fall rendered Mr. Copkins insensible, affording the villains an opportunity to rob him of $60. The unconscious victim was found soon after the robbers fled by a policeman of the Ninth Ward, who conveyed him to the Station-house. When Mr. Copkins recovered his senses, he made known his loss, but was unable to give any description of his assailants, the outrage having been so suddenly perpetrated, and consequently there is little hope of bringing them to justice.

abstract: FIRES. Thursday evening a frame dwellinghouse on First-street, near South Tenth street, E.D., owned by RICHARD BERRY and occupied by Mr. CAMERON, was destroyed by fire. On the same night a frame stable in Ainslie-street was destroyed by fire, together with a horse kept there belonging to Mr. MYERS. The building was owned by ALEXANDER H. PURDY, whose logs is $400 no insurance.

abstract: FIRE ON RANDALL'S ISLAND. At about 1 o' clock on Friday morning, a fire was discovered in the three story brick shoe factory on Randall's Island, which, despite of all efforts to extinguish it, entirely destroyed the building and contents. The fire was plainly visible from the upper part of the City, and several fire companies endeavored to cross over, but were uuable to do so on account of its being low tide.
lead_paragraph: FIRE ON RANDALL's ISLAND. -- At about 1 o' clock on Friday morning, a fire was discovered in the three story brick shoe factory on Randall's Island, which, despite of all efforts to extinguish it, entirely destroyed the building and contents. The fire was plainly visible from the upper part of the City, and several fire companies endeavored to cross over, but were uuable to do so on account of its being low tide. The building was owned by the Society for the Reform of Juvenile Delinquents, but was occupied by E. WHITEHOUSE & Co., contractors. There was a large amount of stock on the premises, including 17,000 pairs of shoes, owned by Messrs. W., & Co., which was valued at $12,000. This was entirely destroyed, as the flames, owing to the high wind prevailing at the time, made such rapid progress, that it was impossible to enter the factory. WHITEHOUSE & Co. were insured for $2,500 in the American Insurance Company, Philadelphia, and $2,500 in a Brooklyn Company. The building, valued at $6 000, is a total loss, and, we are informed, was not insured. It is thought that the factory was set on fire by one of the boys on the Island, but what his motive could have been has not transpired. Fire Marshal BAKER was notified of the matter, and will make a thorough investigation as to the origin of the fire.

abstract: President LINCOLN, it will be seen by our Washington dispatches, has a very aggravating way of dealing with the office-seekers by whom he is daily beset. He refuses to grant any private interviews, but insists upon receiving all verbal communications in the presence of third parties. By this means he undoubtedly escapes much pertinacious annoyance. Mr. SEWARD was too unwell yesterday to attend personally to business, and probably for this reason no further nominations were made. He was, however, well enough to be out last evening, and will most likely be ready for duty again to-day. With reference to the candidates for the various prominent offices, and their relative chances, there is very little to be added to what was said in yesterday's TIMES. The first public reception at the White House, under the new regime, took place last night, and of course attracted a very numerous and brilliant company.

abstract: Some of the students in Dickinson College, at Carlisle, Pa., have got themselves into a bad scrape. Various burglaries of jewelry shops, stationary stores, , have recently been committed in the town, and ...
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the students in Dickinson College, at Carlisle, Pa., have got themselves into a bad scrape. Various burglaries of jewelry shops, stationary stores, , have recently been committed in the town, and for a long time the efforts to arrest the culprits were unsuccessful but finally a student was suspected, and a search of his room, while absent, resulted in the discovery of a large quantity of valuables hid under the floor. A complete set of burglars' tools were also found. Already a son of a respectable citizen of Carlisie has been arrested as an accomplice, and it is probable that others will be implicated.

abstract: The intelligence brought by the Bremen that the Bonaparte-Patterson case has been decided, in the Tribunal of First Instance, adversely to the claim of the American family, will elicit much regretful sympathy in this country.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence brought by the Bremen that the Bonaparte-Patterson case has been decided, in the Tribunal of First Instance, adversely to the claim of the American family, will elicit much regretful sympathy in this country. There has been everything to admire in the proud patience with which the repudiated wife of JEROME BONAPARTE -- beautiful, cultivated, vivacious, and eccentric -- has waited for her rights, and in her extreme old age crossed the ocean in pursuit of them; and there are thousands in Maryland to whose minds her tenacious and somewhat arrogant devotion to her one fine idea -- the recognition by France of the legitimacy of her son and her own elevation to exalted rank -- has long been matter of interest. Therefore it is sad to see her very reasonable ambition thus summarily dismissed by the judgment of a "Family Council," speaking for despotic and brilliant power against feeble obscurity, and for the most absolute of men against one of the humblest of women.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Harris Asher, convicted on the previous day of receiving stolen goods, was sentenced to the Penitentiary for one year, and fined $250 -- the prisoner to stand committed until the fine is paid. The prisoner had been strongly recommended to mercy by the jury, and his counsel, Judge Russel, represented to the Court that his wife was now in a critical condition, and surrounded by a family of children, all depending on the prisoner for support.

abstract: A regular meeting of the American Geographical and Statistical Society was held Thursday evening at the Society's Rooms, Clinton Hall, Rev. Dr. HAWKS, President, in the Chair. The Secretary, Mr. STANSBURY, read the minutes of the previous meeting, after which Mr. ARCHIBALD RUSSELL nominated as new members, A.G. MCNULTY, Esq, of New-York, and JOHN APPLETON BAILEY, of Boston. The Librarian reported the addition to the library of 58 political, agricultural and historical pamphlets; 32 volumes and documents, and 7 volumes of the New-York State Manual from Hon. H.J. RAYMOND; 5 volumes of State Documents from Hon. F.A. CONELING, and three copies of "Remarks Illustrative of the Sounding Voyage of H.B.M. ship Bulldog," presented by Capt. Sir F.L. MCCLINTOCK.

abstract: The publishing season, of 1861 may be said to be fairly inaugurated by the appearance of Mr. MOTLEY's History of the United Netherlands, from Messrs. HARPERS' Press. Few books of the same solid character have attracted so much attention since Lord MACAULAY's writings, and both here and in England the public demand outran the expectations of the publishers. Mr. MURRAY's first edition of 2,500 copies was all taken up preliminary to the appearance of the work, and Messrs. HARPERS find that two -- almost simultaneous -- issues of 3,500 copies each are barely sufficient for present need. The copyright paid Mr. MOTLEY in this country is said to be the highest yet known in the annals of the book trade. American purchasers have a decided advantage over the English as regards price -- the two volumes selling here for four dollars, which command in London seven dollars and a half, or L1 10s. sterling. Though the cost and style of manufacture may have something to do with this difference, it is mainly owing to the various habits of book buying which prevail in the two countries; here every one who takes an interest in the book buys his copy, and would not be content with a borrowed one; there mingle the artificial system by which books are forced up to an irrational price. No man of moderate income thinks of making such a purchase, but depends on Mr. MUDIE's gigantic circulating library for the gratification of his taste. When the first rush for a new book is over, Mr. MUDIE sells off the extra number of copies that he had purchased to meet it at half price, or less, and these are the books really bought by the public -- so circuitous is the route by which expensive new books actually reach the consumer.

The copyright paid Mr. MOTLEY in this country is said to be the highest yet known in the annals of the book trade. American purchasers have a decided advantage over the English as regards price -- the two volumes selling here for four dollars, which command in London seven dollars and a half, or L1 10s. sterling. Though the cost and style of manufacture may have something to do with this difference, it is mainly owing to the various habits of book buying which prevail in the two countries; here every one who takes an interest in the book buys his copy, and would not be content with a borrowed one; there mingle the artificial system by which books are forced up to an irrational price. No man of moderate income thinks of making such a purchase, but depends on Mr. MUDIE's gigantic circulating library for the gratification of his taste. When the first rush for a new book is over, Mr. MUDIE sells off the extra number of copies that he had purchased to meet it at half price, or less, and these are the books really bought by the public -- so circuitous is the route by which expensive new books actually reach the consumer.

abstract: Elias J. Pattison vs. Jared G. Bacon. -- The plaintiff in this action recovered judgment against the defendant, a little more than two years ago upon a promissory note, upon failure to answer. Recently the defendant moved before Justice INGRAHAM to have the judgment opened and to be allowed to come in and defend. The ground alleged for the motion was that the note in suit was given by the defendant for the purchase price of a note sold by the plaintiff to the defendant, and that the defendant was defeated in recovery on the note bought by him, by evidence that the note had been paid; hence that there was no consideration for the note in suit.

abstract: The Bank of the State of New-York vs. The Farmers' Bank of Salem. -- This action was brought to recover of the defendant as an indorser of a bill of exchange. On the trial it appeared that, in August, 1857, the defendant owned the bill in suit, and that its cashier, for safety of transmission, as alleged, wrote upon it the words, "Pay E. Ludlow, cashier, P.S. Campbell, cashier," and sent it to the New York branch of the Ohio Life and Trust Company for collection. The name of the defendant did not appear upon the bill. The plaintiff, making a loan to the Trust Company, was given the bill as collateral.

abstract: Felix Mancho vs. The Brig Experiment and Benedict, Burr & Benedict and others -- This case came up on exceptions to the libel on behalf of the firm of Benedict, Burr & Benedict. The libel was founded on a bill of lading for a box of specie, alleged by the libelant to have been shipped on board the brig at San Juan del Norte to be brought to this port, but which was never delivered, and was filed against the vessel and her master and owners and certain consignees of her cargo, the parties excepting having afterwards been brought into the suit by an amendment to the libel, charging that they held, "on special deposit in their possession, or under their control, a part of the freight before mentioned and referred to." The exceptions taken to the libel were, that it joined in one suit the vessel, her master and owners, and Benedict, Burr and Benedict, who were third parties, in no way interested in the controversy, and that it contained no cause of action as against the parties excepting.

abstract: Application having been made to the Legislature of this State to enact a law authorizing the sale and transfer of the present site of the Post-office in New-York to the Federal Government, it was intimated that an indorsement of the application by the business men of the City would add to its importance. Accordingly, a meeting was organized at the Corn Exchange to-day, by the election of AMMI DOWS, Chairman, and LEWIS ROBERTS, Secretary. Mr. E.H. WHITE stated the object of the meeting, and introduced appropriate resolutions. Mr. HENRY W. SMITH, of the firm of JESSE HOYT & Co., objected to the adoption of the resolutions, as no proper notice had been previously given of the intention of calling the meeting, and merchants were wholly unprepared for action on the resolutions. He, in common with several other members of the Association, wished for time to examine and discuss the subject intelligently. He added that the present site was, in every respect, undesirable as the permanent location for a general Post-office in this great City. Mr. WHITE thought the subject had been sufficiently discussed in the public prints already, that it was wholly unnecessary to postpone the consideration of the subject, and he, therefore, moved the passage of the resolutions. This motion having been duly seconded, the resolutions were separately read and adopted. The following are the resolutions:

abstract: THE WOMAN's LIBRARY. -- We understand that JOHN B. GOUGH is to deliver a lecture at the Church of the Puritans on Union-square, on the evening of the 13th, for the benefit of the Woman's Library. His subject will be "Woman's Influence for Good or Evil," and it will doubtless be treated in connection with his favorite topic, the temperance reform. Mr. GOUGH is one of the most popular and attractive speakers whom our citizens ever have an opportunity of hearing, -- and the excellent object to be aided by this lecture will unquestionably augment still further the number of his hearers on this occasion. The Library, we are glad to know, is in a very flourishing condition, and is fully vindicating, by its already extended and increasing usefulness, the efforts which led to its establishment. The terms of the Lecture will be found in our advertising columns.

abstract: Before the River Railroad awoke men and echoes on the banks of the Hudson, a quiet valley on one of the tributaries to that glorious stream had acquired from WASHIONGTON IRVING classic fame as "Sleepy Hollow," and was sacred to the memory of Rip Van Winkle.
lead_paragraph: Before the River Railroad awoke men and echoes on the banks of the Hudson, a quiet valley on one of the tributaries to that glorious stream had acquired from WASHIONGTON IRVING classic fame as "Sleepy Hollow," and was sacred to the memory of Rip Van Winkle. European authors accused our kindly author of plagiarism from a German legend. He had supposed every one knew the story; it was no new fancy; there always had been Sleepy Hollows and Rip Van Winkles, and would they not continue to the end of the world -- people who do not know the cosmopolite tendencies and progress by which they are surrounded, and who think and talk according to the traditionary ideas of a time that has passed away?

abstract: The news that Texas has resolved to abandon the Northern and join the Southern Union, is followed by the announcement of Gen. HOUSTON'S resignation of the Gubernatorial chair. Now HOUSTON is unquestionably patriotic in his turn, and strongly disposed to retain his associations with the North, which have always been his conspicuous pride ...
lead_paragraph: The news that Texas has resolved to abandon the Northern and join the Southern Union, is followed by the announcement of Gen. HOUSTON's resignation of the Gubernatorial chair. Now HOUSTON is unquestionably patriotic in his turn, and strongly disposed to retain his associations with the North, which have always been his conspicuous pride and glory; and eager to preserve that union of States, to enter which was the object of the Texan war of independence. But these things probably had only a secondary influence in causing the Governor to resign.

abstract: The Convention met at 10 o'clock this morning. A number of resolutions of similar import to those already reported and referred to the Committee on Federal Relations were offered. A resolution declaring that Mr. LINCOLN'S Inaugural was a declaration of peace, was tabled, it being considered inexpedient to forestall the action of the Committee on Federal Relations.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Friday, March 8.

abstract: ENCOURAGING AND SATISFACTORY. -- The Anti-Slavery Standard denounces the President's Inaugural with a degree of vigorous vehemence which will be eminently consoling to those who have feared its radical tendencies. It denounces him for not being sectional in his sentiments and his policy, for not recognizing disunion as an "accomplished fact," and for trying still to preserve the Union. These are precisely the reasons why sensible men approve it.

abstract: JERSEY CITY CHARTER ELECTION. -- The Charter Election for city officers in Jersey City is to take place on Tuesday, April 2. Already a large number of aspirants are in the field and "pulling wires" in order to accomplish their wishes. The following offices are to be filled: Mayor, Aldermen, Recorder, Chief of Police, Collector of Revenue and Water Commissioners. For the office of Mayor, eleven prominent gentlemen are named; for Aldermen there are about fifty candidates. The present Winter two additional Wards (the Fifth and Sixth) have been set off, the office of Chief of Police was made elective, and the office of Collector of Revenue has been created. The election bills fair to be a very spirited one.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY CHARTER ELECTION. -- The Charter Election for city officers in Jersey City is to take place on Tuesday, April 2. Already a large number of aspirants are in the field and "pulling wires" in order to accomplish their wishes. The following offices are to be filled: Mayor, Aldermen, Recorder, Chief of Police, Collector of Revenue and Water Commissioners. For the office of Mayor, eleven prominent gentlemen are named; for Aldermen there are about fifty candidates. The present Winter two additional Wards (the Fifth and Sixth) have been set off, the office of Chief of Police was made elective, and the office of Collector of Revenue has been created. The election bills fair to be a very spirited one.

abstract: We see it stated that CARL SCRURZ is to be sent to represent the United States at the Court of Sardinia. We trust this is not so, not from any personal objection to Mr. S., for whose abilities and political services we have the highest esteem, but because of the principle which his appointment would involve.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer evidently has much greater faith in the fears of Virginians than in their judgment and common sense. It has been laboring zealously for some time to induce the Charleston people to attack Fort Sumter, utterly regardless of the lives that would be lost in such an enterprise, for the purpose of stimulating the State Convention to pronounce for Secession. Failing in this, it now appeals to the fears of the people.

abstract: There is a great deal of speculation as to the intentions of the Administration in regard to reinforcing Fort Sumter. It is assumed by some that the President must of necessity send at once reinforcements to that fortress, and force an entrance inta the harbor regardless of consequences. And the general expectation that this will be done, has created a very general apprehension of immediate hostilities.

abstract: DEMONSTRATION IN FAVOR OF SUNDAY OBSERVANCE BY THE GERMANS. -- The Stadt Theatre Anti-Sunday Meeting, as reported in our columns last Monday, has scandalized the better portion of the German community. At a preliminary meeting of some society of our leading German citizens, on Thursday last, arrangements were perfected for giving expression to the sentiments of the numerous class they represent in opposition to the repeal of the Sunday Liquor and Theatre laws, and in favor of a quiet, orderly Sabbath. For this purpose a public meeting will be held at Cooper Institute, next Sunday evening, with addresses by Mr. SCHWAB and other laymen, by Dr. STOHLMANN, Professor RAUSCHENBUSH, of Rochester University; Professor HITCHCOCK, of this City, and other well known gentlemen.
lead_paragraph: DEMONSTRATION IN FAVOR OF SUNDAY OBSERVANCE BY THE GERMANS. -- The Stadt Theatre Anti-Sunday Meeting, as reported in our columns last Monday, has scandalized the better portion of the German community. abstract: Capt. ISAIAH RYNDERS received his commission as Marshal of the Southern District of New-York, and entered upon the duties of his office on the 31st of March, 1857. During the first part of the Administration the offices of the Marshal, United States Circuit Court, District-Attorney and United States Commissioners were in College-plece, where the accommodations were wholly inadequate to the proper dispatch of the business appertaining to the different departments, and the Burton Theatre property in Chambers-street was leased and fitted up for their use.

abstract: Advices from Key West, via Havana, report the arrival at that port on the 22d of February, having on board ninety recruits in charge of Capt. DAWSON, of the First Artillery. The day following her arrival sixty-two recruits were landed for Capt. J.M. BRANNAN'S company at Fort Taylor. A large quantity of stores for the use of the garrison were also landed. She coaled and proceeded to Tortugae for the purpose of landing recruits for Major ARNOLD'S command, and also six month's provisions for that post. It was understood at Key West that the Webster was bound to Brazes and Indianola for the troops at those points, Major PORTER having charge of the expedition with instructions to accompany the troops to their destination. A salute of 34 guns was fired at Fort Taylor on WASHINGTON'S birthday by Capt. BRANNAN. The American Flag floated from the top of all the Government and nearly all the other public buildings in Key West, and the day was patriotically observed by all.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Key West, via Havana, report the arrival at that port on the 22d of February, having on board ninety recruits in charge of Capt. DAWSON, of the First Artillery. abstract: BURGLARS CAPTURED. On Friday night last, Capt. SMITH, of the First Precinct Police, captured two burglars, just as they had entered the door of
lead_paragraph: BURGLARS CAPTURED. -- On Friday night last, Capt. SMITH, of the First Precinct Police, captured two burglars, just as they had entered the door of house No. 243 Adams-street. He handed one over to a citizen, to be conducted to the Station house, from whom he managed to make his escape. The other, who gave his name as JAMES R O'BYRNE, was safely lodged in a cell, and was on Saturday committed for trial. On the person of accused was found several pawn-tickets for overcoats, for which owners are wanted.

abstract: The Vicksburgh Whig, in eulogizing Hon. JERE CLEMENS, on the strength of his appointment to the position of Major General of the Army of Alabama, goes through the usual motions incident to the promotion of Alabama Majors, including of course a liberal sprinkling of the adjectives incident to wonderful men of war. But the Whig, rising from height to height of eulogy, concludes by informing us that the illustrious promoted, "holds a high place among American literati."

abstract: Extensive preparations are being made by citizens of all parties to extend a fitting welcome to Hon. JOSE A. DIX, the late Secretary, on his return from Washington. Not only will he have the use of the Governor's Room in the City Hall, in which to receive his friends, but a public dinner will be tendered him, in behalf of the mercantile community, so justly grateful for his efficient discharge of his onerous duties in recuperating the national finances.

abstract: Henry Giso, a Spaniard, was arrested on Saturday eveving, by Detective Dusenbury, charged with having stolen $700 worth of clothing from the house of Manfel Truxillo, No. 125 East Thirtccath street.
lead_paragraph: Henry Giso, a Spaniard, was arrested on Saturday eveving, by Detective Dusenbury, charged with having stolen $700 worth of clothing from the house of Manfel Truxillo, No. 125 East Thirtccath street. It appears that the complainant, some time since, left his house in charge of a servant, and Giso induced her to allow him to sleep there one night. In the middle of the night Giso got up and carried off what silk dresses, &c., he could lay hands upon. The prisoner confessed his guilt, and was locked up to answer by Justice OSBORN.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday on the body of an unknown man who was crushed to death at Pier No. 5, East River, on Friday evening. It appears that as the steamboat Rescue was coming up to the pier on that evening this man was seen to fall from the pier into the river.
lead_paragraph: Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday on the body of an unknown man who was crushed to death at Pier No. 5, East River, on Friday evening. It appears that as the steamboat Rescue was coming up to the pier on that evening this man was seen to fall from the pier into the river. The captain of the boat made immediate efforts to rescue the drowning man, and to this end caught him by the collar with a boat-hook. Before he could be lifted from the water, however, the steamboat swung around and crushed the unfortunate man against the pier. The Coroner's Jury found a verdict of accidental death. The deceased was apparently about 30 years of age, was of medium height, had sandy hair and whiskers, and was respectably dressed.

abstract: Our Washington dispatches this morning are highly important, and indicate that the question of reinforcing Forts Sumpter and Pickens will soon be decided. Indeed, so far as Fort sumpter is concerned, it may have been decided already.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington dispatches this morning are highly important, and indicate that the question of reinforcing Forts Sumpter and Pickens will soon be decided. Indeed, so far as Fort sumpter is concerned, it may have been decided already. One dispatch states that there is a strong probability that an evacuation will soon take place, while the general character of all our intelligence relative to the subject leads us to the conclusion that some definite action may be expected immediately. The question has no doubt been anxiously discussed, and the opinions of prominent military men have been sought, with a view or arriving at a proper determination. Gen. SCOTT is understood to hold the opinion that reinforcements could not now be thrown into Sumpter without an immense loss of life, and that the military and naval force at the immediate command of the Government would not be sufficient to accomplish that object. Under these circumstances, and in view of the fact that an attempt to reinforce that or any other garrison would have the effect of concentrating the sentiment of the South against the Government, it is the general impression in Washington that all the troops will be withdrawn, with the exception of a Corporal and two men, who will be left in charge, with the American flag flying; still leaving the South Carolinians the task of "capturing" the fort, which they will then probably have force sufficient to do. It is the belief among Southern conservative men that such a course would prove the death-blow of secession.

abstract: The most prolific, versatile and popular playwright of France, EUEGENE SCRIBE, has just died, in Paris, at the ripe age of 71. Less a dramatist than a manafacturer of comedies,
lead_paragraph: The most prolific, versatile and popular playwright of France, EUEGENE SCRIBE, has just died, in Paris, at the ripe age of 71. Less a dramatist than a manafacturer of comedies, vaudevilles and opera librettos, SCRIBE produced, in the fifty years of his professional life, more material for the theatrical amusement of France, and all the rest of the world, than any ten others in his line of business; for with him it was a mere business -- its operation mechanical, and its object money. More than four hundred plays are ascribed to his pen, and for the concoction of these he had a veritable factory, where he employed the services of such journeymen and apprentices as in France are elegantly denominated collaborateurs; indeed, this collaborating system was inaugurated by SCRIBE, and ALEXANDRE DUMAS owes him a monument. Among the clever workmen in this great playmaker's shop were such handy fellows as CASSIMIR DELAVIGNE, MELLESVILLE, BRAZIER, CARMOUCHE, DUPIN, VARNER and BAYARD. Each had his specialty -- this for the idea, that for the plot, another for the dialogue, still another for the verses -- so that a vaudeville, such as should set all Paris in a roar, in passing through the pens of these gentlemen, went through almost as many processes as a pin. Then there was the incalculable SCRIBE, full of expertness and industry, overseeing all, directing all, adding here a quaint character, there a bewildering situation, in another place a sparkling epigram -- all point and surprise; and the end that crowned the work was the honesty (for which M. DUMAS, the elder, will not venture to dedicate a monument to him) of attaching, beside his own signature, the name of his principal collaborateur.

abstract: -- The Tribune commits a very ferocious assault upon Senator DOUGLAS for sustaining President LINCOLN'S Inaugural, and supporting the Union in general. abstract: At an early hour on Saturday morning it was discovered that a diabolical attempt had been made to set fire to the five-story tenement house No. 274 East Houston-street.
lead_paragraph: At an early hour on Saturday morning it was discovered that a diabolical attempt had been made to set fire to the five-story tenement house No. 274 East Houston-street. The incendiary had stealthily entered the hallway and kindled a fire under the stairs, which speedily burned a hole in the floor and set the stairs on fire. JACOB BENHACK, one of the occupants of the house, having been awakened to attend to the wants of his sick wife, smelt the smoke, and after a lengthy search discovered the origin and alarmed the inmates of the building. With the assistance of the police the names were extinguished, but not until considerable progress had been made in the destruction of the stairs. Damage to the amount of $10 was the result; insured for $2,000 in the Pacific Insurance Company. This building, being five stories in height, towers 20 feet above the adjoining houses, so that escape by the roof would have been almost impossible for the numerous women and children in the house. The stairway was nearly destroyed, so that, had the fire got good headway, a fearful loss of life must necessarily have ensued. The building, which is specially adapted for the scene of another Elm-street catastrophe, is owned by Mr. F. MEYER, and is in no way provided with fire-escapes. Fire-Marshal BAKER commenced an investigation with the hope of fending out the author of the fiendish attempt, but as yet has obtained no clue to direct suspicion toward any person.

abstract: Mr. Martin, the wherry-berryman, who rowed a skiff from Boston to this City some time since, has lately been trying to see how many things he could do to make himself ridiculous. He has gone without eating from Sunday until Friday, then lived on apples for that length of time, slept out doors in all kinds of weather, all the time keeping an accurate record of his weight, feelings, &c., &c. The only practical result reached by his experiment is the demonstration of the fact that Boston has one very foolish man in it.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Martin, the wherry-berryman, who rowed a skiff from Boston to this City some time since, has lately been trying to see how many things he could do to make himself ridiculous. abstract: CLEANING THE STREETS -- The contractor has some four hundred men at work, and it is a subject of comment among all who see the gangs in the various Districts, how differently they work from those employed heretofore by the City Inspector. abstract: The Academy forces brought their campaign to an end on Saturday, here and in Brooklyn, and are now gravitating in a somewhat catarrhal condition to-...
lead_paragraph: The Academy forces brought their campaign to an end on Saturday, here and in Brooklyn, and are now gravitating in a somewhat catarrhal condition towards the hub of the universe, where, if nothing breaks, they will certainly appear to-night. Their chances in Boston are more than usually brilliant, inasmuch as they carry with them three operas that have never been heard in the City of Notions, and a company sufficiently strong to render the best works of the standard repertoire, in a thoroughly efficient manner. If the times do not interfere with the fortunes of the opera, there can hardly be a doubt that four weeks will pass pleasantly enough, and leave something beyond the receipts for the associate artists, with which to return to New-York. A short Spring season will then introduce us to VERDI's "Aroldo."
