abstract: -- The Provisional President of the C.S.A. does not seem destined to repose upon a bed of roses. His veto of the Act passed by the Southern Congress, reducing the offence of Slave-trading from the rank of piracy, punishable with death, to the grade of a simple misdemeanor, has drawn down on the head of JEFFERSON DAVIS the severe and violent denunciations of the more rabid Fire-eaters. They begin to suspect that even he may not be "true to the South," according to their standard of trueness; while two of his Cabinet officers, Secretaries TOOMBS and MALLORY, are openly proclaimed to be unsafe men to be intrusted with the guidance of Cottondom's future. The report of Secretary TOOMBS in favor of continuing the U.S. Tariff of 1857 as the Tariff of the C.S.A., "will raise," we are told, "strong opposition and intense disgust;" while Secretary MALLORY is held up to fire-eating odium as one "opposed to the cause of secession," and who "could not get more than one vote in the Legislature of Florida for any position whatever." DAVIS, STEPHENS, MALLORY and MEMINGER, all suspected of being "reconstructionists," and TOOMBS declared to be creating opposition and "intense disgust" by his anti-free-trade policy, -- the South Carolina patriots must soon begin to realize that their stepping out of the Union has not been an unqualified blessing.
lead_paragraph: -- The Provisional President of the C.S.A. does not seem destined to repose upon a bed of roses. DAVIS, STEPHENS, MALLORY and MEMINGER, all suspected of being "reconstructionists," and TOOMBS declared to be creating opposition and "intense disgust" by his anti-free-trade policy, -- the South Carolina patriots must soon begin to realize that their stepping out of the Union has not been an unqualified blessing.

abstract: The Scotch Harlequin of the Herald is very anxious that foreigners should be sent to represent this country abroad. He tried to seduce BUCHANAN into the same opinion, -- but failed so far as his own case was concerned. We don't think he will be any more successful with LINCOLN. Scotch caps are well enough in their way; -- bare legs will, do, when not too badly scarred with the horsewhip; -- and the Scotch fiddle is entertaining for those who like it. But in spite of all this, our neighbor will scarcely figure at the court of Sardinia, now that his "poor old friend" BUCHANAN (as he has already begun to call him,) is out of power. It is true, as he says, that some of these foreigners are great nuisances at home -- but that is no reason why we should inflict them on nations with which we are at peace. It might do well enough to send BENNETT Special Envoy to South Carolina, especially if we wish to render the war with her perpetual; -- but such a proceeding towards any power that has insulted us less grossly, would be intolerable.

abstract: The open opposition to the observance of the Sabbath as a day of worship in this City, has heretofore come mainly from our German population, and many have been led to suppose, in consequence, that infidelity was the prevailing sentiment among this class of our population.
lead_paragraph: The open opposition to the observance of the Sabbath as a day of worship in this City, has heretofore come mainly from our German population, and many have been led to suppose, in consequence, that infidelity was the prevailing sentiment among this class of our population. The meeting at the Cooper Institute last evening was the beginning of a movement which is destined to dissipate this error, and to relieve the respectable Germans of the City from the odium resulting from the injudicious conduct of a minority of their countrymen. The respectable, order-loving, and Christian Germans of New-York, are determined that the few Socialists and Infidels and general disturbers of the public peace in their midst, shall no longer misrepresent the character and sentiments of their countrymen in this City. With this view they held a meeting last evening, in the large hall of the Cooper Institute, which at an early hour was filled to its utmost capacity. On the platform were seated a large number of German clergymen, and prominent citizens both German and American, while the body of the hall was filled with ladies and gentlemen representing the best class of the German population of the City. A few of the anti-Sabbath men were scattered here and there through the audience, and appropriately vindicated their peculiar principles by frequent attempts to disturb the meeting, but they were promptly taken in charge by the police, and quietly marched out of the hall, one after another, as the attempts were renewed. In this manner six persons were taken off to the Seventeenth Ward Station-house. The officers of the meeting had been selected beforehand, and were as follows:

abstract: The Committee of the Virginia State Convention, appointed to inquire into the reports that Federal troops and arms had been moved from various points in Virginia, with the object of acting against Southern States, has made its report. lead_paragraph: The Committee of the Virginia State Convention, appointed to inquire into the reports that Federal troops and arms had been moved from various points in Virginia, with the object of acting against Southern States, has made its report. Besides stating the fact that certain parties near Fort Monroe have discussed the feasibility of taking that place, and that those within it had only taken proper measures of defence, the Committee reports no other facts than those set forth in the following letter from Secretary HOLT: WAR DEPARTMENT, Feb. 27, 1861.

abstract: Capt. MERRITT, the underwriter's agent, expected, on Thursday last, (the latest intelligence received from the wreck.) that he would be able to get the steamer off at high water on Saturday morning. At that time, however, a heavy blow set in from the southeast, which increased in violence throughout the day, varying at times to the eastward. If during this severe gale directly on shore, the vessel has not been bilged or broken up, she must have been driven hard ashore, and thus the chances of saving her rendered very remote.
lead_paragraph: Capt. MERRITT, the underwriter's agent, expected, on Thursday last, (the latest intelligence received from the wreck.) that he would be able to get the steamer off at high water on Saturday morning. At that time, however, a heavy blow set in from the southeast, which increased in violence throughout the day, varying at times to the eastward. If during this severe gale directly on shore, the vessel has not been bilged or broken up, she must have been driven hard ashore, and thus the chances of saving her rendered very remote.

abstract: PRIZE-FIGHTS On Sunday afternoon a party of runners, said to belong to Engine Companies Nos. 3 and 4, of Jersey City, repaired to the Cedars, in Bergen, for the purpose of enjoying a prize-fight. Before the performance closed four fights occurred.
lead_paragraph: PRIZE-FIGHTS. -- On Sunday afternoon a party of runners, said to belong to Engine Companies Nos. 3 and 4, of Jersey City, repaired to the Cedars, in Bergen, for the purpose of enjoying a prize-fight. Before the performance closed four fights occurred. Two of them were between RAFFERTY and CONNOES, and CLERKE and KIEK. Neither side being satisfied, another match was made for yesterday afternoon, and the parties started in the direction of West Hoboken. The Jersey City Police were notified and pursued the parties, when they scattered in all directions.

abstract: -A new Central Park bill is before the Assembly, urged, it is said, by an uncommonly strong lobby. There is one reason why the present Commission, should be maintained, which, so long as very culpable bad management is not proved against it, should be conclusive. The present Commission stands pledged to give us a complete Park at a certain cost. A new Commission cannot be held to this pledge. The present Commissioners are unpaid, yet they have a character at stake, which is the best possible security against the hungry horde of patronage-beggars, with which at every step of their duty, they must be beset. We trust the Assembly will let them alone, or at least make no changes for which they do not themselves ask, or which would in any manner relive them of responsibility.

abstract: The Evening Post, even where its views might naturally be expected to take a very much wider and more practical range, can never lose sight of the colored object in the hedge. It ascribes, for instance, the submission of the purchase of the Post-office site to the resolution of Secretary COBB "that so much money should not be expended in a Northern State;" a resolution, we may remark, which, malignant and bigoted as it was, he proceeded with even augmented malignity to carry into effect by submitting the whole subject to the Northern State in question! It is, perhaps, needless to say, the ratification of State Legislatures to the transfer of any portion of soil to the Federal Government is always requisite, else the anomaly would exist of the national authority being upon so much of its property subordinate to local law -- a state of things for obvious reasons inadmissible. The late evil-designing Secretary therefore simply and perhaps reluctantly fulfilled a constitutional duty in proceeding as he did.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK OPTHALMIC HOSPITAL COMMENCEMENT. The New-York Opthalmic Hospital held its annual commencement for the Session 1860 and '61, at the University Medical College, Fourteenthstreet.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK OPTHALMIC HOSPITAL COMMENCEMENT. -- The New-York Opthalmic Hospital held its annual commencement for the Session 1860 and '61, at the University Medical College, Fourteenthstreet. The valedictory address was delivered by Dr. JOHN P. GARRISH, the attending surgeon of the Hospital, in an able an eloquent manner, showing the importance and value of the eye, and how necessary it was to understand the treatment, as the eye was incident to such a variety of diseases and accidents. He asked of what value were the beauties of the world without the eye to see them? The doctor closed his remarks amid the loud plaudits of a large audience, among which there were many ladies. Dr. JAMES L. KIERNAN, one of the graduates, addressed his classmates in a very pleasing and satisfactory manner. Dr. GARRISH commences his Spring course of lectures on Monday, the 18th inst., at the Hospital, No. 63 Third-avenue. The introductory will be delivered at 3 o'clock P.M. The profession and students of medicine are invited to attend.

abstract: Some inquiry has been made of late by men curious in such matters as to the real meaning of "a Big Thing on Ice." One conjecture suggests a water-melon, while another believes that it was especially typified by the assembly of one hundred and five thousand persons who gathered on the Central Park Pond on the 9th ultimo. But the Savannah Republican may fairly claim to have found out the very biggest thing as yet put on ice -- that is to say, the duty of ten per cent. laid by the Southern tariff on that delicious solubility. Ten per cent.! and ice-cream almost as unattainable as the stars, now, to anybody less than a twenty-five-nigger man. Ten per cent on water ices; on frozen fruits; and, oh, ye glacial gods! ten per cent. on cobblers, smashes and juleps! This is indeed intolerable, and justice demands that ice be just as free as ever. "We are strong for no duty on ice," says the at length tariff-ied and unfortunate Republican. And we condole with our cotemporary. There is, as we can see, only one way out of the trouble. Push South; keep on; go ahead, until your possessions embrace Patagonia and Terra del Fuego, and then, oh Southrons! you can grow your own ice and garner your own snow-flakes, and get highly exalted, on festive beverages, into which nothing Northern hath entered, be it of earth or water or air. Freeze, to it!

abstract: The absurd and self-contradictory charges made against the General-Superintendent of Police by an officer dismissed for drunkenness, disobedience of orders and insolence, have been fully met and refuted by the plain statement of facts made by Mr. KENNEDY yesterday before a meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners.
lead_paragraph: -- The absurd and self-contradictory charges made against the General-Superintendent of Police by an officer dismissed for drunkenness, disobedience of orders and insolence, have been fully met and refuted by the plain statement of facts made by Mr. KENNEDY yesterday before a meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners. So far from the General Superintendent's ever having had relations of confidence with the discharged detective, it now appears that he did not even know WILLIAMSON as an officer of the force, until the day on which the dismissed officer -- very drunk and in a high state of excitement -- forced himself into the General Superintendent's Office, with an insolent demand for leave to visit Washington at the public expense. The ridiculous and malicious report, that Mr. KENNEDY had previously confided to this tipsy subordinate his design to get up the appearance of a plot to assassinate Mr. LINCOLN, in order have the merit of discovering and abating the danger as a claim on the President for the office of United States Marshal, is thus effectually set at rest. It was in itself too absurd for belief, and we did not need, on this point, the General Superintendent's assurance that he has "never been a candidate for any office under the Federal Government."

abstract: In reply to inquiries made at the office of Mr. CUNARD, it appears that no passenger list of this ship has been received by steamers recently arrived. Concerning the cause of her extraordinary detention, the agents have no information other than that possessed by the public. Besides some natural anxiety, they, however, express little concern for her safety. If she had reached the middle of the Western Ocean, before being disabled by an accident to her machinery, there has not been sufficient time for her to complete her voyage under canvas, or to have returned to Liverpool, so as to be reported by any vessels yet arrived.

abstract: Mr. John McGrath, a stevedore, was accosted by Jane Lester, while walking through Water-street on Sunday evening, and forgetting morality, accompanied her to her room. Soon after leaving her apartment, to discovered that a wallet containing $10 had been abstracted from his pocket, and having made his loss known to Officer Templeton, of the Fuerto Precinct, he arrested the woman. The money was found in her possession, and she was committed to see Tombs for trial McGrath was sent to the House of Detention as a witness.

abstract: The House was compelled to adjourn on Saturday evening for want of a quorum, leaving three items in the Supply bill not passed upon. On meeting this morning, it found itself in the same condition. A call of the House was resorted to, but the morning trains bringing a few members, and our double friend from Erie having succeeded in getting himself both up the Capitol Hill, a quorum was obtained and the call suspended.

abstract: It is not long since we had occasion to comment on the extent of that portion of the pamphlet-literature of France which is devoted to discussing or covertly attacking the Roman Church.
lead_paragraph: It is not long since we had occasion to comment on the extent of that portion of the pamphlet-literature of France which is devoted to discussing or covertly attacking the Roman Church. The latest mails inform us that it has been augmented by another brochure, entitled France, Rome and Italy, written nominally, by M. GUERRONIERE, but bearing intrinsic proof of Imperial inspiration, and defended and elucidated by the Imperial and official Press.

abstract: We are glad to see that Alderman FROMENT is acting on the suggestions made in these columns some weeks ago, in reference to adopting a more equitable system of paying for trap-block pavement. In certain cases, as we showed -- and chiefly in such wealthy streets as Twenty-third-street, Fourteenth-street and Lexington-avenue -- the City assumes the whole cost of laying down these pavements; while in many of the very poorest and least profitable neighborhoods, the property-holders along the line of improvement are assessed with two-thirds, three-fourths or even the whole of the expenses incurred in this work. In the Tax-levy of this year we observe an item of $500,000 for this species of pavement -- our City Fathers being evidently pleased with the double gains made on this particular branch of industry, -- first, from the "arguments" in favor of ordering the Belgian pavement presented by the contractors who supply the same; and secondly, we may infer, from the "arguments" of a still more potent kind presented by those property holders who desire to make the City Treasury disburse the entire cost of improving their private property. Alderman FROMENT is fully justifying the reputation with which he entered the Board, and we hope that he may never grow weary of well-doing.
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that Alderman FROMENT is acting on the suggestions made in these columns some weeks ago, in reference to adopting a more equitable system of paying for trap-block pavement. In the Tax-levy of this year we observe an item of $500,000 for this species of pavement -- our City Fathers being evidently pleased with the double gains made on this particular branch of industry, -- first, from the "arguments" in favor of ordering the Belgian pavement presented by the contractors who supply the same; and secondly, we may infer, from the "arguments" of a still more potent kind presented by those property holders who desire to make the City Treasury disburse the entire cost of improving their private property. abstract: Dr. VERMEULE, of New- Market. New-Jersey, late of this City, committed suicide on Saturday morning, the 9th inst., at that place, by throwing himself upon the track of the Central Railroad just as the Express train dashed by at as high rate of speed. He was horribly mutilated, and killed instantly. He had been in a state of partial insanity much of the time during the past year, and his self-destruction was undoubtedly the result of mental aberration.

abstract: Three weeks have now elapsed since the new contract for the cleaning of streets went into operation, and during nearly all that time the weather has been peculiarly favorable for the work; yet the contractor has made so...
lead_paragraph: Three weeks have now elapsed since the new contract for the cleaning of streets went into operation, and during nearly all that time the weather has been peculiarly favorable for the work; yet the contractor has made so poor a show that even the accumulations of ashes and garbage seem too much for him. By the terms of his contract, Mr. HACKLEY is required to clean all the streets once, and some of them twice a week; and no one can doubt that the whole ground might have been thoroughly gone over by this time. For all this, we have yet to discover the evidences of a decent attempt on his part to discharge his duty. Our reporters are met, at the Contractor's office, with promises as flimsy as the usual quality of Corporation pie-crust. "To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow," strong gangs of men and trains of carts are to be put on -- but as yet neither men nor carts, in numbers at all adequate to the requirements of cleanliness, comfort or health.
headline: {'main': 'The Street-Cleaning.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Street-Cleaning.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is worthy of remark as somewhat more, perhaps, than a mere coincidence, that Major ROBERT ANDERSON, now in command of Fort Sumpter; Lieut. A.J. SLEMMER, who within the walls of Fort Pickens, has defied the secession forces of Florida, Mississippi and Alabama; Capt. J.B. RICKETTS, of Fort Brown, Texas, who has refused to surrender the post under his charge to the rebel authorities; and Capt. BENNETT H. HILL, also of Texas, who has displayed true loyalty and courage, by refusing to obey the treasonable order of TWIGGS for the surrender of the Federal property under his charge, avowing his resolve to defend it to the last extremity, and calling in reinforcements to aid him in doing so, -- all belong to the First Regiment of the United States Artillery. As one of the best educated and most intelligent branches of the National military service, this loyalty on the part of the Artillery is not without significance. It speaks well for the morale of the whole regiment to find the four of its officers, who have been tried, thus proving themselves equal to the various emergencies of their respective situations and loyal to the banner of the Union.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN, There is an extensive range of character that Miss JANE COOMBES, who commenced an engagement here last evening, can interpret with better feminine grace than almost any other "star" actress now upon the stage.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- There is an extensive range of character that Miss JANE COOMBES, who commenced an engagement here last evening, can interpret with better feminine grace than almost any other "star" actress now upon the stage. Her presence is pleasing, her manner entirely unaffected, and her perception of character very clear if not always very foreible. But the part of Margaret Elmore in "Love's, Sacrifice," whilst it requires all the characteristics we have mentioned, demands in the last two acts something more, and this something was wanting in Miss COOMBES' otherwise charming performance last evening. Without being able to point to any positive blemish in her rendering, or even to indicate a decided weakness in it, we were all the while unpleasantly conscious of a lack of means to picture with sufficient histrionic strength the second phase of Margaret's character. This proves simply that the selection of the part was injudicious, and to this belief we are further inclined by the many really exquisite episodes which were its illuminating points, and which demonstrated amply that Miss COOMBES possesses sufficient ability to insure success in a different line of character. As it was, the audience applauded and seemed perfectly well satisfied. The performance, indeed, was more than an average one.

abstract: Coroner SCHIAMER yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of Caroline King a married woman, 21 years of age, residing at No. 21 Forsyth street, who took corresive sublimate on Friday last, with the object of suicide.
lead_paragraph: Coroner SCHIAMER yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of Caroline King a married woman, 21 years of age, residing at No. 21 Forsyth street, who took corresive sublimate on Friday last, with the object of suicide. It appeared from the testimony that deceased had been in very poor health during the past few months and as her physician was unable to give her hope, she became much depressed in spirits, and decided to commit self-destruction. On Friday last she obtained some corrosive sublimate at a drug store, and took it without the knowledge of her friends, but a few hours subsequently she informed them of what she had done. It was them too late for an antidote to be of service and after languishing until yesterday morning she expired.

abstract: Four months ago it was in the power of the Government at Washington to have armed and kept every fortification it possessed in the Southern States.
lead_paragraph: Four months ago it was in the power of the Government at Washington to have armed and kept every fortification it possessed in the Southern States. There was unmistakable warning that the possession of all of them would be the subject of early controversy. In regard to those in the harbor of Charleston, the danger was by the highest, and it might almost be said, the only military authorities in the country, regarded as so imminent, as to invoke an earnest presentation of the subject to the President, and a recommendation that not a moment should be lost in providing for the protection of Forts Moultrie and Sumpter. How that recommendation was received is a matter of shameful history. So far from strengthening those important points, every energy of the Administration was devoted to arming those who proposed to capture them. Artillery of the heaviest calibre; guns of the most recent and improved invention; munitions sufficient for the reduction of a Bergen-op-Zoom, were placed within reach of the insurgents, whose designs, we now have conclusive reason to believe, were as well known to the Federal Executive as they were among the conspirators themselves. And for fear the proper amount of skill should be lacking to direct the use of the implements of warfare thus deposited in the hands of an unskilled mob, a sufficient number of practised and veteran officers were permitted to resign from the regular service, to furnish the rebels with a competent military direction. It was, of course, assumed that with such ample preparation on the one hand, and such entire inertia on the other, that the forts would be seized without resistance, and as if by surprise; and the administration of Mr. BUCHANAN, while really abetting the designs of the captors, would be able to discharge itself of any very formidable responsibility for the loss. An accident only defeated this plan. Major ANDERSON, with some three score men, instead of remaining where in the Administration programme, he might have been readily reduced, and captured, threw himself into Fort Sumpter, and defied his assailants. His example was followed at Pensacola and at other Florida forts. This interruption of the plot utterly disconcerted the Government, up to that moment absolutely controlled by SLIDELL, WIGFALL, and DAVIS. It was left the choice of publicly declaring its complicity with treason, or of disguising its criminality by pretending to reinforce the gallant fellows whose loyalty and courage had proved so embarrassing. Had this course been adopted with promptitude, it was possible to have saved Fort Sumpter. But weeks were allowed to pass without action, during which the rebels were permitted to obstruct the harbor, enfilade all its approaches with powerful batteries, remove the lights and buoys essential to the safe entrance of relieving-vessels, and to surround Sumpter with forts, armaments and batteries exceeding in number and in guns the defences of the garrison. It was only when these difficulties had been raised, that the Star of the West attempted, with an ostentatious announcement of the intention, to bear reinforcements to Major ANDERSON. Its failure was a foregone conclusion; indeed, no one previously counted upon its success; unless upon the assumption that the rebels would, at the critical moment, decline to fire the shot which should inaugurate civil war, and that thus the vessel might safely reach the fort. The event showed the futility of such calculations; and with the knowledge that every hour was reducing the number of men in the garrison through the expiration of terms of enlistment; that the provisions were rapidly failing; that fuel was almost exhausted, and that lights were even not to be had, no further effort was made by Mr. BUCHANAN or his advisers to succor the beleaguered post. There seems to have been a nice calculation that the resources of the defence would last until the 4th of March, and the late President's retirement from office; and beyond that epoch, none of those reckless men cared to pursue the consequences of their own default.

abstract: Judge LEONARD came in yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, and opened the Court in the General Sessions room, no other place having been provided. As no trials could be had under such circumstances, the petty jury was dismissed till next Monday, and the Grand Jury were discharged, having brought in since they were impanneled seventy-one indictments. Several prisoners were then arraigned, pleas were taken, and the Court adjourned to Monday morning.

Several prisoners were then arraigned, pleas were taken, and the Court adjourned to Monday morning.

abstract: The announcement that Ex-Gov. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, proposes, before his return to the South, to visit New-York, suggests the propriety of making his coming hither the occasion of some appropriate demonstration of popular respect. There are several reasons for this tribute to the gallant Senator. While it is abundantly due to his personal and social qualities, it is yet more distinctly so for his chivalrous and patriotic stand in the defence of the Union against the incipient spirit of secession in the Border States. As the representative of the sturdy conservatives of that section who have confined the insurrectionary movement to so narrow limits, it will be especially desirable to mark, by our hospitality to the Senator from Tennessee, our sense of their inestimable services. Ex-Gov. JOHNSON has already been invited to visit Boston and Cincinnati. A similar courtesy from New-York would be even more graceful and becoming.

abstract: All our dispatches from Washington tend to the conclusion that the question of Fort Sumpter will soon be decided, and most likely in favor of its evacustion.
lead_paragraph: All our dispatches from Washington tend to the conclusion that the question of Fort Sumpter will soon be decided, -- and most likely in favor of its evacustion. The effect of the simple announcement that such a policy was in contemplation by the Cabinet, shows with what faith the Secessionists have built upon the idea of a collision with the Federal Government to further their plans. It has filled them with the utmost alarm; and some of them have even gone so far as to declare that should the policy prevail, secession will be dead in a short space of time. Late last evening no decision had been come to by the Cabinet, but there was little doubt in Washington that the order for evacuation would soon be issued. Considerable sensation was created yesterday by the announcement that Secretary CHASE had resigned on account of the determination to withdraw the troops, but the report, of course, proved to be without foundation.

abstract: A permanent Constitution has been adopted. It has been kept secret, but a member of the Congress states that among its provisions the President is to serve six years; the Executive appointments under the grade of Cabinet officers are to hold office during good behavior, and removed for causes assigned in writing; the Slave-trade is prohibited. A clause was adopted that Cabinet officers are not prohibited from holding seats in Congress.

abstract: About 8 o'clock last evening, a fire was discovered by the Police of the First Precinct in the premises No. 56 Broadway, one of the row of brick buildings formerly occupied as a United States Bonded Warehouse, extending through to Exchange-place.
lead_paragraph: About 8 1/2 o'clock last evening, a fire was discovered by the Police of the First Precinct in the premises No. 56 Broadway, one of the row of brick buildings formerly occupied as a United States Bonded Warehouse, extending through to Exchange-place. An alarm soon brought a large number of firemen to the place, and operations with the object of saving the building and its valuable stock were soon in progress. So rapidly, however, did the flames spread, that the firemen were unable to do more than prevent the total destruction of the adjoining buildings, while the warehouse in which the fire broke out, together with its valuable contents, was entirely consumed. The fire originated on the second floor, in the warerooms of H. E. HART, cap manufacturer, whose loss is estimated at $15,000. The first floor and basement were occupied by MASTERTON & REIMER, grocers, whose loss is supposed to be about $30,000. The remaining floors of the building were not tenanted. The structure was four stories in height, and was valued at $20,000. The flames communicated to the adjoining building, No. 54, the first floor and basement of which is occupied by M. J. KING, whose loss is about $5,000, mainly by water; covered by an insurance of $40,000 in the City Companies. REX & GOTTGETREW, manufacturers of children's hats, occupied the second floor, and their stock was also slightly injured by water. The cap warehouse of LEUGSTACK & RAHNER, was on the 3d floor. They suffered likewise by water, to slight a degree. The stock of CARHAM & BROTHER, in the building No. 58, was also injured slightly by wetting. The entire loss is estimated at about $75.000, and the losers are probably insured to the full amount of the damage, but the lateness of the hour at which the fire occurred made it impossible to obtain a list of the insurances. The origin of the fire is to be made the subject of an investigation by the Fire Marshal.

abstract: -- Mr. ANDREW J. HACKLEY, and his friends in the Common Council, are running their engine with a high pressure of steam. So high, indeed, that there would seem every certaintyof an early and fatal explosion. No sooner has the street-cleaning contract been achieved, than we find Mr. HACKLEY receiving from the Common Council an immense additional bonus to swell the profits of his job. He is virtually made a present by our virtuous City Fathers of "the use" of the wharves, piers and slips heretofore occupied as dumping grounds by the City, for an unlimited term of years. In other words, he is given gratuitously the use of city property which should be rented for many thousand dollars a year -- possibly as a reward for his dexterity in persuading the Boards of Aldermen and Councilmen to accept the highest instead of the lowest bid.

abstract: On Saturday last, the Star of the West commenced taking in coal and provisions, evidently for a lengthy voyage, and the rumor is that she is to follow the Empire City, which has just left for Indianola, with the view of provisioning the destitute troops disbanded by Gen. TWIGGS, and to convey portions of them to other posts. There is, of course, no truth in the supposition that her expedition, on this occasion, has anything to do with the relief of the garrison of Fort Sumpter.

abstract: The steamer Cahawba, Capt. SMITH, left yesterday for Havana and New-Orleans, with a full freight for the latter place and the usual complement of passengers. Senor CHACON, the Spanish Consul, delivered on board two deserters, belonging to the Spanish frigate Berenguela, who were placed in irons, to be conveyed to Cuba. Just as the steamer was about leaving the doek, a sad, and, it is feared, fatal, accident occurred. A young gentleman named M. MENDIACO, who had come on board to bid adieu to two Cuban friends, was standing near the main-hatch, when, in order to allow a lady to pass, he stepped backward and fell down the hatchway, striking head-long among the boxes, and causing him serious injury. He was taken up insensible, and conveyed to the New-York Hospital by his friends and Police-officer MCWATERS. It appears that the open hatch was concealed from view by a canvas stretched around it, and consequently the unfortunate young man did not notice his danger. He was a student of the Academy of Languages, in Broadway.

abstract: ROPEWALK DESTROYED BY FIRE A small ropewalk, on Meeker, near Bushwick-avenue, owned by PETER COOPER, and occupied by CHRISTOPHER McWay, was destroyed by fire on Monday night. abstract: This structure is to exceed its illustrious predecessor in grandeur, in beauty of design, and elegance of finish. The main had is to be 550 feet long, 250 feet wide, and 220 feet high! The picture galleries, built of brick, will be 2,300 feet in length, 60 to 70 feet high, and from 35 to 55 feet wide. The have and transepts are to be 2,200 feet long, 80 feet wide, and 100 feet high. The sheds and outer necessary buildings are planned on a corresponding scale. The whole work must be finished in less than one year from the present time, or by the 12th of February next. The Guarantee Fund, which amounts in all to L350,000, is headed by that truly royal patron of the Arts and Sciences, the Prince consort for L10,000. It is stated by competent authorities, that the entire structure will cost L250,000, or $1,000,000. It is to be located at South Kensington. The building will be made suitable for permanently remaining on the site and will in every way outshine the Crystal Palace of 1861, or any other structure of modern times. A writer states that the great hall will contain a cubical area more than ten times as large as that of the great transept of the Hyde Park building, and that it would contain five of the centre transepts of the present Crystal Palace; its height will be unparalleled. There is a vast space to be occupied by two world's products, its inventions, manufactures, and works of art.

The Guarantee Fund, which amounts in all to L350,000, is headed by that truly royal patron of the Arts and Sciences, the Prince consort for L10,000. It is stated by competent authorities, that the entire structure will cost L250,000, or $1,000,000. It is to be located at South Kensington. The building will be made suitable for permanently remaining on the site and will in every way outshine the Crystal Palace of 1861, or any other structure of modern times. A writer states that the great hall will contain a cubical area more than ten times as large as that of the great transept of the Hyde Park building, and that it would contain five of the centre transepts of the present Crystal Palace; its height will be unparalleled. There is a vast space to be occupied by two world's products, its inventions, manufactures, and works of art.

abstract: It will be no matter of surprise if, among the earliest acts of the new Administration, there shall be a demand for an extra session of Congress. The necessity will grow out of more than ordinary causes. The last Con
lead_paragraph: It will be no matter of surprise if, among the earliest acts of the new Administration, there shall be a demand for an extra session of Congress. The necessity will grow out of more than ordinary causes. The last Congress left no appropriation bill unpassed, and made through its tariff and loan bill provision which it deemed adequate for the current expenses of Government. All was accomplished that was exacted by the assumption of a perfectly normal and equable movement of public affairs; and if the ship of State were really afloat upon Summer seas it would need nothing additional to speed or supply it. But peace was the assumption at the foundation of all this legislation, whereas the exigencies which the new Administration is called to meet are anything but normal or pacific. One half of the seaboard of the Union is in the hands of an insurgent Government, which repudiates our laws, and will oppose their execution with the utmost force of armed resistance. Nor is this negative attitude the only difficulty. Yielding to the necessity of the case, the new Confederaey having been obliged to postpone its free-trade experiment, has adopted as its basis of revenue the Tariff of 1857, and at all its ports goods and manufactures of nearly every description will find admission under that scale of duties, and the revenue will go to enrich the treasury of secession. In any ordinary circumstances such loss of revenue might be submitted to, because the cost of collecting it would pretty fairly exhaust the gross product. But the new and injudicious tariff fastened upon us by the Thirty-sixth Congress makes the affair a very much more serious one; for its largely augmented rates afford an irresistible invitation to importers to introduce their merchandise at Southern rather than at Northern ports, where they may either be sold, or carried overland to the Northern consumers. The effect of this perfectly feasible and legal proceeding would be to build up the rebel States of the Union at the expense of the loyal; to cripple the foreign trade of the Northern cities; and leave the Treasury at Washington in a far less satisfactory condition than if the late tariff had been undisturbed.

abstract: In another column will be found a strong letter from District-Attorney WATERBURY to the Board of Supervisors, urging that measures may be speedily taken to furnish proper accommodations to the Courts of Oyer and
lead_paragraph: In another column will be found a strong letter from District-Attorney WATERBURY to the Board of Supervisors, urging that measures may be speedily taken to furnish proper accommodations to the Courts of Oyer and Terminer and General Sessions in the building originally set apart for their use and that of the Supreme Court, but a great portion of which is now occupied by the two branches of the Superior Court under orders from the Common Council. The District-Attorney complains that he has been unable to avail himself of a special term of the Oyer and Terminer ordered by the Governor at his request, for the purpose of more speedily adjudicating certain important indictments, there being no Court-room to be found for the use of this extra tribunal. He also complains that while the number of prisoners detained in the City Prison on untried charges, loudly calls for the sitting of two branches of the Court of General Sessions under the Recorder and City Judge, this salutary and necessary measure is rendered impossible through the occupancy by one branch of the Supreme Court of the Court-room in which the extra General Sessions should be held.

abstract: French doctors are illustrious for great discoveries, and Monsieur FLOURENS, the gentleman who found out that man's natural life is, or ought to be, at least a century, is among the liveliest in that line. For, distinctly defying the vulgar sneers of the earthly mob, he has found out that men can live without bones, -- be, in fact, deossified, -- and seizing the propitious moment, has induced the Academy of Sciences to propose a prize for the most effectual proofs of the fact.

abstract: In his charge to the Grand fury, yesterday, Judge McCUNN called the attention of that body to the condition of the City Prison, and the large numbers who are constantly confined there awaiting trial. He urged upon the
lead_paragraph: In his charge to the Grand fury, yesterday, Judge McCUNN called the attention of that body to the condition of the City Prison, and the large numbers who are constantly confined there awaiting trial. He urged upon the Jury the duty strict diligence on their part in disposing of cases, so that those who are clearly innocent may be speedily set at liberty, and those against whom bills shall be found, may be presented for immediate trial, and the expense of their support be transferred from the City to the State, where it properly belongs. We apprehend that the position of prisoners confined upon the mere charge of crime, is by no means generally appreciated. The legal presumption that every man is innocent until proved guilty, is corroborated by daily experience in the criminal counts, where upon trial a very large proportion of all the persons placed at the bar are found innocent by a jury and discharged; not, however, in some instances, until they have been confined weeks and even months. On Monday last an illustration of this state of things occurred in the case of an old German cripple, who had been in confinement for six months, without having been brought to the attention of the Grand Jury, until Judge MCCUNN, learning the facts of the case, had it sent to that Inquest, where the charge against the prisoner was dismissed, and he was consequently discharged.

abstract: Those who know Judge HALIBURTON as the humorous satirist of the lower strata of Yankee life and there are few in this country who can read who are not familiar with his
lead_paragraph: Those who know Judge HALIBURTON as the humorous satirist of the lower strata of Yankee life -- and there are few in this country who can read who are not familiar with his eccentric fictions -- will peruse with gratification the decidedly able speech on the ANDERSON slave-case, delivered by him in the House of Commons on the 22d February. It is almost impossible to deny, in perusing this concise, but comprehensive summary of facts and law, that the speaker makes out apparently the clearest of cases in establishing that there had been two violations of the rights of the people of Canada during the trial in question and before its termination. The Court if Queen's Bench had acted apparently in this case on the supposition that they were adjudicating on the terms of a genital treaty, which would have been quite in he line of their duty. Under these circumstances application to the Court should have been made to the law officers of the Crown; but instead of this "involuntary" action in fulfilment of official duty the affair had been voluntary, the writ of habeas corpus having been granted in his opinion most improperly -- to a foreigner in no way connected with the authorities of Canada or England. Again, the English Court had based its decision on the treaty, but the best authority in Canada questioned any power to make such a treaty -- having a Government and legislation of their own. To send a writ to Canada to take a man out of the country and bring him to England to be adjudicated upon, was to invade the constitutional rights of the people of Canada.

abstract: COLLISION ON THE NORTH RIVER Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, as the ferry-boat Chancellor Livingston was crossing from Barclay-street to Hoboken, she was run into by a small propeller, which carried away some twelve feet of the guard and a portion of the rail. The propeller also sustained damage, but to what extent was not ascertained, as she at once proceeded to a dock on the New-York side.

abstract: The case of the three Italians -- Lopell, Elting and Sabetallo, who were arrested on the 7th inst., upon complaint of Martha Radcliffe, of Brooklyn, for passing spurious quarter dollar pieces, with intention to cefraud, came up yesterday for examination before U.S. Commissioner CARROLL. A large number of wit-were present, obliging the Commissioner to adjourn nesses to the Circuit Court room. Sabetllo was first examined. James Ryckman, W.C. Cameron, and other witnesses fully identified the prisoner, who, it seems, called on the evening of the 6th of March at their various places of business and purchased some trifling article, offering the spurious coins in payment and receiving good money in change. The coins were good imitations of the genuine, and well calculated to deceive in the evening. One of the witnesses, however, easily hit out a portion of the edge of one of them, showing the material to be very light and brittle. The case is still on.

abstract: THE GLOUCESTER FISHING FLEET. -- We are pained to hear that four of the George's Bank fishing fleet, from Gloucester, are missing, and were probably lost in the heavy and cold westerly gale of the 7th February, and their crews, numbering forty to fifty men, perished. This winter fishing is carried on at too great a sacrifice of life. If it were not voluntarily engaged in by the fishermen, the world would pronounce it the harshest cruelty to send men for a meagre remuneration upon such dangerous service. -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: Coroner O'Keefe held an inquest yesterday at No. 226 Sullivan street, upon the remains of Michael Whalen, a native of Ireland, 29 years of age, lately employed as porter at the Hone a House, Broadway. It appeared from the testimony that deceased, on going home last Monday night, accidentally stumbled while descending the stairs, and, falling headforemost to the bottom, fractured his skull. He died yesterday morning.

abstract: The attempt of the Cotton States to divide the country upon the line between free and slaveholdings territory has signally failed.
lead_paragraph: The attempt of the Cotton States to divide the country upon the line between free and slaveholdings territory has signally failed. In large portions of every State in which slaves are held, they are not the paramount interest. In such, the conviction is universal, that they must ere long give way to labor better adapted to their soil and climate, and to the development of their resources. In all such districts, consequently, we find loyalty to Government, and sympathy with the North.

abstract: In the House of Commons, Feb. 21, Mr. E. FORSTER [???] to ask the noble Lord, the Secretary of State of Foreign Affairs, whether he had any objection to lay upon the table of the House a copy of the recent correspondence between Her Majesty's Minister at Washington and and the United States Secretary of State for foreign Affairs relative to the clearance of Branch vessels in the part of Charleston, S.C. Having referred to the circumstances which had rendered necessary the correspondence between Lord LYOMS and the United States Government, the honorable gentleman sold that, without going into the question as to whether diplomacy should in general be secret or open, he was convinced that any attempt to carry out secret diplomacy with the United States would fail, because, if the documents which passed between the two countries were not published on this side the Atlantic, they would be ferreted out by the writers for the Press on the other. He was the last man who would wish that we should interfere in the lamentable quarrel between our friends and kinsmen in America, but it must not be forgotten that we had treaties with the United States Government, and therefore with all the States, for the suppression of the Slave-trade, treaties which both in honor and by our interest we were bound to see carried out; and therefore, although he had every confidence in the noble Lord the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs and the noble Lord at the head of the Government, he should be glad to see them take counsel with the country in any eventuality which might arise.

abstract: The Directors of the Great Ship Company had compiled a report that was to be presented to the shareholders at a public meeting to be held at the London Tavern on the 28th ult. They congratulate the shareholders that the trial trip to New-York was made at a loss of only L344 odd. As explained in their previous report it was their intention to have dispatched the ship on a second voyage to New-York on the 17th October last, but after considering the requirements of the Board of Trade for one voyage only, and the very imperfect state of the decks laid down by Mr. J. SCOTT RUSSELL under his contract, the directors, with the advise and concurrence of some of the largest proprietors, whom they invited to confer with them on the subject, abandoned that intention. They then reduced the staff and all other expenses as much as possible, and proceeded with the alterations and repairs. The bearing of the screw shaft was far the most serious task. By very skillful arrangements the necessity of removing the shaft from the ship was overcome, and the work has made such progress as to leave no reasonable doubt of its satisfactory completion, together with the feed pumps to the paddle-boilers recommended by the Board of Trade, in the ensuing month. The main deck bas been sheathed with 1 3/4 inch boards over a layer of tarred patent felt, thus forming a double deck. The directors believe that by these means the deck (hitherto a constant source of injury and annoyance) will be water-tight, and the inconveniences thoroughly removed. The saloon and cargo decks have been caulked, and many other minor but important works are in progress. The question of future employment for the ship has received the most serious consideration of the directors. The want of public confidence in the ship has hitherto baffled the directors in their endeavors to obtain sufficient passengers and freight to remunerate the proprietors. They hope that the voyage to America has, in a great degree, removed the impediment. The passengers unanimously expressed their appreciation of the ease and comfort they enjoyed, and the total absence of seasickness, even to the most sensitive. Her excellence as a sea boat has been proved, and notwithstanding the inevitable disadvantages of an experimental voyage, the Directors can now place full reliance on her steady speed. They believe that another successful voyage to America will establish the desired confidence, and that she might then be profitably employed in any trade where her great capacity and power can be developed. It is clear that by a computation of her speed now established, she would accomplish a voyage to India or Australia within forty days, upon a ration of consumption of coals far below that of other steamships. The directors have, therefore, resolved upon dispatching the ship to America early in April next, and they hope that the receipts from all sources will at least equal the expenditure, as experience has proved that the working expenses of this ship may be reduced to the ordinary charges of merchant steamers, which reduction your directors are determined to effect.

It is clear that by a computation of her speed now established, she would accomplish a voyage to India or Australia within forty days, upon a ration of consumption of coals far below that of other steamships. The directors have, therefore, resolved upon dispatching the ship to America early in April next, and they hope that the receipts from all sources will at least equal the expenditure, as experience has proved that the working expenses of this ship may be reduced to the ordinary charges of merchant steamers, which reduction your directors are determined to effect.

abstract: The noted temperance orator, JOHN B. GOUGH, will lecture this evening at the Church of the Puritans, on Union-square, for the benefit of the Women's Library. Those for whom the desire to promote a beneficent and admirably conducted institution is not a sufficient motive to attendance, will find abundant attraction in the lecture of the most remarkable dramatic orator of his age, whose astonishing powers have succeeded in securing the praise of the Old and New World for their wonderful extent and variety. The theme will be "Woman's Influence for Good or Evil;" and the lecture will, with a single exception, be the last delivered by Mr. GOUGH in this City.
lead_paragraph: The noted temperance orator, JOHN B. GOUGH, will lecture this evening at the Church of the Puritans, on Union-square, for the benefit of the Women's Library. abstract: THE STREET-CLEANING CONTRACT STRIKE OF THE CARTMEN Yesterday morning the cartmen employed by Mr. HACKLEY, contractor for cleaning streets, struck in a body, demanding twenty shillings per day, instead of eighteen, which they have been receiving. Mr. H, refused to accede to their demands, and in consequence the removal of the piles of dirt, which now encumber the streets, will remain untouched for the present.
lead_paragraph: THE STREET-CLEANING CONTRACT -- STRIKE OF THE CARTMEN. -- Yesterday morning the cartmen employed by Mr. HACKLEY, contractor for cleaning streets, struck in a body, demanding twenty shillings per day, instead of eighteen, which they have been receiving. Mr. H, refused to accede to their demands, and in consequence the removal of the piles of dirt, which now encumber the streets, will remain untouched for the present.

abstract: Yesterday morning Mr. WILLIAMSON, the accused Detective, appeared before Commissioners BOWEN and ACTON, accompanied by his counsel, Mr. HOLMES, who stated to the Commissioners that he had been surprised that the case had been proceeded with on Monday morning in the absence of Mr. WILLIAMSON.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning Mr. WILLIAMSON, the accused Detective, appeared before Commissioners BOWEN and ACTON, accompanied by his counsel, Mr. HOLMES, who stated to the Commissioners that he had been surprised that the case had been proceeded with on Monday morning in the absence of Mr. WILLIAMSON. Mr. HOLMES said that he desired to make a motion in the matter, which he hoped the Commissioners would hear at that time. He then read two affidavits of his clerks, one of whom stated that before 11 o'clock, on Monday morning last, he left a note, by the direction of Mr. HOLMES, with a person in attendance at the Police Head-quarters, which note was addressed to Mr. Commissioner BOWEN. That this person refused to admit him to Mr. BOWEN'S presence, but said that he would immediately deliver the note to Mr. BOWEN. The other clerk swore that he copied the note which was sent, and that it was as follows:

abstract: The New-Hampshire-election, for State officers and Congressmen, took place yesterday, and resulted in the complete triumph of the Republicans. Returns were received last night from 102 towns, which indicated that their majority in the State would be from 3,500 to 4,000. All the Republi
lead_paragraph: The New-Hampshire-election, for State officers and Congressmen, took place yesterday, and resulted in the complete triumph of the Republicans. Returns were received last night from 102 towns, which indicated that their majority in the State would be from 3,500 to 4,000. All the Republican candidates for Congress are elected, four of the five Councilors, eight or nine of the twelve State Senators, and an overwhelming majority of the State Representatives.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 22d February, Mr. HALIBURTON, before putting to the Under-Secretary for the Colonies the question of which he had given notice on this subject, wissed to refer briefly to
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on the 22d February, Mr. HALIBURTON, before putting to the Under-Secretary for the Colonies the question of which he had given notice on this subject, wissed to refer briefly to what had appeared respecting the slave ANDERSON. He had been an inhabitant of Missouri and had escaped from Slavery. He took the life of a white man, also an inhabitant of that State, who was endeavoring to capture him while he was trying to escape from his master. After that event ANDERSON succeeded is effecting his escape and got into Canada. The relatives of the man who was killed, having traced him out, demanded him under a law of the province -- not under a treaty, as had been stated in this country -- but under a law of the province containing many provisions of a treaty. A certain treaty that had been agreed upon between this country and the United States was adopted by the province and passed into a law, to give it the only validity which it could have. Under that law the question had been brought before the Supreme Judges. It had been inquired into and adjudicated on by that Court. He now wished that he might not be misunderstood, for in a case of this kind, which had created so much feeling in this country, he might be misrepresented. He therefore distinctly stated that it was not his intention to offer any opinion on the act of the man ANDERSON, as to whether it amounted to murder, or manslaughter, or justified homicide; as to whether he was rightly captured in Canada, or as to whether the judgment of the Court there was right or wrong. On all these questions he had no observation to make. His object was neither to vindicate the rights of the State of Missouri nor to vindicate the rights of the prisoner ANDERSON, but to state that there had been two violations of the rights of the people of Canada during the trial of this case and before its final termination. An application was made to the Court of Queen's Bench in this country for a writ of habeas corpus to bring ANDERSON out of the jail in Canada and before the Court in order to have his case inquired into. There had been some very singular circumstances attending this case in the Queen's Bench. Here, again, he wished to explain that it was very far from his intention to make any remark whatever disrespectful to the Judges of that Court. Their learning, their very great ability, and the wisdom and impartiality with which they decided everything that came before them, not only entitled them to, but commanded for them, the respect of every one. The country ought to be proud of such a Court, and he should be wanting in self-respect if he made any remark derogatory to its Judges; but at the same time they were not infallible. Appeals from decisions of the Queen's Bench had at various periods of our history been brought before the House of Lords; and in some cases those decisions had been reversed. In the present case he could only suppose that the Court acted on the supposition that they were adjudicating on the terms of a general treaty, which was within their cognizance and jurisdiction. But, if such was the fact, one would have imagined that some reference would have been made to the law officers of the Crown, and that the application to the Court would have been made under their authority. Instead of that the affair was a voluntary one. A man with an unpronounceable name, who he (Mr. HALIBURTON) believed was a Polish refugee, and in no way connected with the authorities of Canada or those of this country, made a voluntary affidavit. The writ of habeas corpus was granted, and addressed to the jailers who had possession of the prisoner, and to the Governor of Canada, a civil officer with military powers. A writ of habeas corpus might with as much propriety be addressed to the Governor of Newgate and the Duke of Cambridge. He spoke the sentiments of some of the ablest lawyers in this country when he said that the decision of the Court of Queen's Bench had created great surprise here, and he knew that it had caused the greatest consternation in the colony. In these observations he made no reference to the case of ANDERSON. They would apply equally to any other case. The people of Canada complained that their rights had been violated. The Court of Queen's Bench, no doubt, founded its jurisdiction on the treaty; but the best authorities in Canada called in question the power of any authority in this country to do so -- they called in question the treaty-making power. The Colony had a Government and a Legislature of its own, and was competent to perform all the acts that were necessary to the government of its people. There was provision made for appeals from the decisions of its courts of law. If a man was dissatisfied with the decision of any of the ordinary courts, he had a right of appeal to a higher tribunal, and from that again he could appeal to the Privy Council. That was the only mode in which the judgments of the Canadian Courts could be reversed, and a very proper mode it was. However able and learned the Canadian judges might be, they were themselves ready to admit that they had neither the experience nor the erudition of the judges of England. To send a writ to Canada to take a man out of the country, and bring him ever here to be adjudicated upon, was to invade the constitutional rights of the people of Canada. The people of the Colony, and especially of Montreal, rejoiced to think that they had got rid of the responsibility of this case, and were nearly illuminating their houses; but still they wished that the thing should be done legally, and not at the expense of their rights. The ordinary course of appeal had been passed over; a writ of habeas corpus had been sent over, and an officer sent with it to receive the man. It was rather a humiliating proceeding to see an officer of one of the superior courts of this country sent on such an errand, considering the answer he was sure to receive. The answer would be that in Canada they did not recognize the authority of such a Court. He certainly wished that they would deliver the man up under protest, as such a case is not likely to occur again. No one pretended to say that there was any intentional violation of the rights of Canada in what had been done. He supposed the Judges of the Court of Queen's Bench had some idea that there was such a place as Canada, just as he had that there were such places as Guernsey. Jersey, Alderney and Sark. [A. laugh.] He took it for granted there was such a place as Sark, as it was to be found in the map, but he had never seen it, and never saw a man who had. [A. laugh.] The Judges of the Court of Queen's Bench seemed to have some such idea of Canada. With regard to the orders sent by the Duke of Newcastle to Canada, he would like to know first of all what authority he had to send orders at all. The Colonial-office seldom interfered in the colony at the right time, and when it did it usually did so in a wrong manner. [A. laugh.] He hoped the correspondence would be laid on the table, that the people of Canada, and of the other colonies, too, might be able to see what these orders of the Duke of Newcastle were, and whether they were justified by the Constitution of Canada. As the nominee of the Colonial-office, the Governor of Canada was often in communication with the Colonial Secretary; and there might be many occasions on which it was necessary for the latter to communicate advice to the Governor, and to recommend that he should take such and such a course. But orders were public documents, and as such ought to be made known. The country was not to be governed by orders that were not to be seen. The Government of a constitutional colony was to be carried on by the Governor, by and with the advice of his Council. If, therefore, any order went out which directed him to pursue a certain course without the advice of his Council it would be a contravention of the constitutional rights of the people. The Duke of Newcastle had been recently in Canada, and had seen there the noble reception given to His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales; he had seen the enthusiasm and heartfelt demonstrations of the people -- not demonstrations got up, as in a neighboring country, by means of spies and police, but hearty, honest outbursts of loyalty and affection; he might have seen what the character of those colonists was -- that they were Englishmen in feeling and principle, and not a people likely to put up with what they considered a slight or an insult. He took it for granted, therefore, that the Duke of Newcastle would be cautious how be addressed them, and that the orders contained nothing that was unconstitutional. But if the production of these orders was refused, he would take it for granted that they were like certain letters which he wrote to the Mayors of some of the town in Canada. It might be said that this was only bad manners, but bad manners implied bad conduct. There were not people to put up with nonsense, although they would do anything they were asked in civil language. The difficulty arose merely from their having been badly managed. He would, however, say no more on this subject, as it would probably at no distant day be brought before Parliament. He would confine himself at present to asking the Under Secretary of State for the Colonies for information as to the extradition of the American slave ANDERSON, now in custody in Canada; and if he would lay upon the table copies of all correspondence that had passed in relation thereto between the Secretary of State for the Colonies and the Governor in Canada, and for all orders issued thereupon.

abstract: Among several nominations sent to the Senate yesterday, that of THOMAS CORWIN, as Minister to Mexico, will be accepted by the country with singular approbation. Mr. WELLER, the latest of Mr. BUCHANAN'S appointees, upon that mission, has involved himself in unpleasant relations with the Liberal Government, at a moment of all others when it is important to secure with it the best feeling and the largest influence. Especially important is it to place in communication with them a person who shall be able and faithful to counteract the schemes of secession -- schemes, which are likely to compass at once the deglutition of the prey so long and hungrily coveted. Mr. CORWIN, as an earnest opponent of the Mexican war, will be likely to meet with a very different reception from that he awarded the American invaders; in fact, he will immediately exert an influence with the Government, which will greatly strengthen it to resist not only the advance of secession, but the unfriendly and untimely pressure of the European Powers. He will, of course, be confirmed.

abstract: The suicide of Mrs. KING, who died last Monday morning from the effect of prison deliberately procured and taken for the purpose of self-destruction, furnishes another forcible commentary on the uselessness of all laws designed to put now this crime. We have
lead_paragraph: The suicide of Mrs. KING, who died last Monday morning from the effect of prison deliberately procured and taken for the purpose of self-destruction, furnishes another forcible commentary on the uselessness of all laws designed to put now this crime. We have statutes in nominal force against the sale of poisons to persons who bring with there no medical order, or who are not accompanied by two acquaintances to vouch for their identity. But of so little practical effect are these prohibitions, that we find one member of a respectable drug firm confessing that he had "heard of a law regulating the sale of poisons, but had never read it." This witness, we are bold to say, is more a representative man than an exceptional case of those who dispense medicines throughout our City. The law to prevent suicide by surrounding the purchase of poisons with difficulty, is felt to be of no avail -- many of the most deadly drugs, when used in excessive quantities, being among the very commonest articles of commerce, and fraught with usefulness when properly applied.

abstract: Whether or no it be true that black sheep are greedier than white ones, is still a subject of dispute. But the wild scramble now going on
lead_paragraph: Whether or no it be true that black sheep are greedier than white ones, is still a subject of dispute. But the wild scramble now going on at Montgomery for every phantom office created by his Dictatorship DAVIS, shows conclusively that the lust for office down there has already attained a development that dwindles into insignificance even the greed of the hungry hordes which now besiege Washington. Great numbers of office-seekershave flocked to the new capital within the last month from South Carolina, Georgia and Louisiana. But, unfortunately, there are found to be far more applicants for place than there are either places or spare cash; and the disappointed fire-eaters wander about the muddy streets of the village, care-worn, disconsolate and mad.

abstract: A German, named Jaques Traub, living in the upper part of the house No. 113 Bowery, while intoxicated last evening, made an unprovoked attempt to murder a little girl named Hannah Delee, daughter of one of his neighbors. The child's father keeps a
lead_paragraph: A German, named Jaques Traub, living in the upper part of the house No. 113 1/2 Bowery, while intoxicated last evening, made an unprovoked attempt to murder a little girl named Hannah Delee, daughter of one of his neighbors. The child's father keeps a cap-store in the basement of the building where Traub lives, and she was in the shop about 8 1/2 o'clock, in company with a little boy. Traub came reeling down into the place, and appeared to be very much irritated, but before either of the children spoke to him, he turned to the boy and threatened to shoot him, at the same moment producing a pistol. Hannah implored him not to fire at the lad, whereupon he turned toward her, and leveling the pistol at her head, pulled the trigger. The weapon was loaded with buckshot, several of which entered the face and neck of the girl, causing serious injury. The report of the pistol attracted Officers Knight and Sommers, of the Tenth Ward Police, who secured the ruffian, and removed him to the Station-house. Police-Surgeon Waterman attended the sufferer, and managed, with difficulty, to extract the shot, after which she was sent to the New-York Hospital.

lead_paragraph: ATTEMPT TO PASS COUNTERFEIT MONEY. -- A man named SAMUEL SMITH, keeper of a small shoeshop in Newark-avenue, Jersey City, was taken before Recorder TILDEN, yesterday, charged with attempting to pass a counterfeit $5 bill, of the Munson Bank, Mass. It is alleged that he first offered the bill at Mr. CAFFREY's store, when he was informed that it was a bad one, and soon afterwards offered it at Mrs. MCBRIEN'S, No. 71 Montgomery street, when he was taken into custody. The accused was held in $500 bonds to appear for examination.

abstract: A grocery man, living in Cleveland, Ohio, Eilringer by name, was robbed in a very singular manner a few days ago. He left his store about 8 o'clock to go down and make some purchases, and soon after he started he was hailed by a man who...
lead_paragraph: -- A grocery man, living in Cleveland, Ohio, Eilringer by name, was robbed in a very singular manner a few days ago. He left his store about 8 o'clock to go down and make some purchases, and soon after he started he was hailed by a man who jumped into the wagon and asked the priviege of riding. This, under the circumstances. Mr. Eilringer could hardly refuse, but he remembered riding but a shore distance with him. Everything else is a blank, until his wife succeeded in rousing him from a stupor late in the evening. She found him lying in his wagon, which the horse drew to the door, apparently from force of habit, and not because he was guided thither, but Mr. Eilringer is utterly unable to tell where he spent the day. As he had been robbed of over $60, the supposition is that the stranger, who suddenly scraped acquaintance with him, applied to his mouth in some mysterious way a cloth saturated with opium.

abstract: Below we give a list of the appointments made by Mr. HACKLEY, the new contractor for cleaning the streets, with a statement of the work done by him. The strike of the dirt cartmen alluded to yesterday, was confined to the Sixth and Twentieth Wards, and was not as stated, (upon wrong information,) for an advance of day wages, they not being paid by the day, but by the load.
lead_paragraph: Below we give a list of the appointments made by Mr. HACKLEY, the new contractor for cleaning the streets, with a statement of the work done by him. The strike of the dirt cartmen alluded to yesterday, was confined to the Sixth and Twentieth Wards, and was not as stated, (upon wrong information,) for an advance of day wages, they not being paid by the day, but by the load. Other cartmen have been substituted, and the work is progressing as rapidly as is possible. Mr. HACKLEY, contrary to all established usages, has not commenced on the great thoroughfares, where his work would be seen by the most people, but has commenced on the streets leading from either River, working up towards the broad avenues and thoroughfares. He has made the following appointments of Inspectors and assistants at the various dumping grounds:

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- We cannot honestly compliment Miss JANE COOMBS on the merit or novelty of her repertoire. It may perhaps be a serviceable one for the Provinces, but here, where freshness is most in demand, it is anything but attractive. Last evening BULWER'S very young-manish play of the "Lady of Lyons" was produced, and considering the badness of the weather and the staleness of the piece, attracted a better house than could reasonably have been expected. It is rather too late in the day to speak of its merits as a literary work, but we may say that a purely dramatic revelation of character is avoided in the role of the heroine, whose character is wrought upon and utterly changed by the mimic events which are made to transpire. For this reason, the piece is always popular with young lady actresses, who, seeing the path clearly mapped out before them, generally tread it with success. Miss COOMBS is, in many respects, the best Pauline we have recently had on the stage. Her personal appearance, so youthful and prepossessing, suggests all the confiding love and ambition of the earlier portions of the work, and the passionate bursts which a warm and poetic temperament lend naturally to an indignant woman seem to come properly from a loveliness that has been so grievously outraged. These expositions of womanhood were clearly and ably rendered by Miss COOMBS, but with occasional strainings after points, which, whilst they pained the listener, added nothing whatever to the effect. If the lady would trust to her natural powers, and to the sensitive instincts of a fine nature, rather than to the dreary tradition of an imperfect and old-fashioned histrionic education, she would leave but little to be desired. As it was, and notwithstanding occasional mannerisms, which could only have been gathered from the worst of teachers, her success was pronounced and merited. Miss COOMBS has, in fact, much to unlearn, but in view of her rare natural talent, it must be a matter of interest to the critic to observe how quickly she can perform that most difficult of all feminine tasks.

abstract: The fact that the Mayor had affixed his signature to the City Tax Levy bill, as agreed upon by the Common Council, which was done yesterday, was made known to all the Departments with almost the instantaneousness of the telegraph, and new life seemed to be infused into all. Clerks and inferior employes were gladdened by the certain payment of their salaries, without the ten per cent, exacted by those who advance the means to enable them to live Public works, of necessity long delayed, will at once be commenced, and prosecuted with a vigor increased by the certainty of prompt pay. In the Croton Department no less than eleven contracts will be awarded on Monday of next week, and a similar activity is being exhibited in the Street Department. Mr. BYNES, Superintendent of Lands and Places, deriving eucouragement from the passage of the bill, is at work on all the Parks, with his aid, JOSEPH MURPHY, and is getting them in order to greet the advent of Spring. Trees have been trimmed, shrubbery clipped, walks graded and leveled, and even the fountains have been allowed to play, as it in appreciation of the joyful event. And all this has been done by the simple affixing of one signature to one official document. Magna est pecunia et prevalebit.
