abstract: The Association formed under this name in France some twenty years ago, met so successfully a want generally felt in the Roman Catholic Church, that similar organizations have sprung up in different sections of the world with surprising rapidity. The primary object of the organization is for disseminating the Catholic faith, and, incidentally, aiding the male poor; therefore, "all Christian young men who desire to unite in a communion of prayers and a participation of the same works of charity, may become members wherever they may happen to reside." While the primary object of the organization is, as before stated, to exert a Christian influence among the poor, still, no work of charity is regarded as foreign to the objects of the Society. Its members are expected to embrace every opportunity of affording consolation to the sick and to prisoners, of instructing the poor, unprotected or imprisoned children, and of procuring the succors of religion for those who need them at the hour of death. Every church may have a society connected with it, and where there is more than one in the same place, there is also a Council of Direction which exercises a supervisory control. In this city the first conference or society was organized, in the Diocese of Brooklyn, on the 10th of January, 1855, under the direction of the Right Reverend Bishop, under the name of St. James Church Conference, and now nearly every church of this denomination has a similar society connected with it. The St James Conference, in their annual report just submitted, complain bitterly of the Truant law. The report represents that "the Truant law as at present in operation in this country, leaves the Catholic poor under sad disabilities; indeed, so much so that it may be said that the poor man holds his children entirely at the mercy of the police the Police Justices and the many proselytizing societies."

abstract: Contrary to the hopes of all who desire to witness the self-immolation of the Republican Party in its hour of victory, the people who reside on the granite hills of New-Hampshire sturdily refused on last Tuesday to confess that they repented of Mr. LINCOLN'S election, or that their eyes had been opened to any new and hostile view of the principles placed in power by his success.
lead_paragraph: Contrary to the hopes of all who desire to witness the self-immolation of the Republican Party in its hour of victory, the people who reside on the granite hills of New-Hampshire sturdily refused on last Tuesday to confess that they repented of Mr. LINCOLN'S election, or that their eyes had been opened to any new and hostile view of the principles placed in power by his success. Strange as it may appear to the amiable and disinterested advisers who were defeated in the last Presidential struggle, the victors in that contest display no eagerness as yet to retrace their steps, or to adopt while in power the very policy for opposing which they received the suffrages of the people. New-Hampshire has just given a firm and hearty reindorsement to the principles affirmed by her Electoral vote last November -- her citizens, apparently, failing to see in the peaceful inauguration of a Republican President any ground for penitence or any argument against their political faith.

abstract: THE WOMAN'S LIBRARY. -- Mr. GOUGH, the world-renowned temperance orator, spoke at Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, last evening, for the benefit of the Woman's Library, and very appropriately took for his theme the "Influence of Woman for Good or Evil in Relation to Temperance" After reminding his audience that he was not in the habit of sticking very closely to his text, he went on to treat the subject in his usual discursive style, by anecdote and illustration, drawn from all manner of sources, and presenting his idea in every possible light -- serious, comic and pathetic. The influence of woman as wife,mother, sister, daughter and sweetheart, was forcibly illustrated by stories purporting to have come under the actual observation of the speaker, and which were told in the inimitative and extraordinarily effective style peculiar to Mr. GOUGH. The dignified, noble, pure, true-hearted woman was contrasted with the empty-hearted, silly, gigling, fashionable flirt, and the good influence of the one class compared with the evil influence of the other. The speaker paid a well-deserved tribute to the lady founder of the "Woman's Library," and closed by an effective appeal to the women of the audience to exert their influence on the side of truth, justice and temperance. Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather, there was a large audience in attendance, giving assurance of a welcome acquisition to the finances of the Woman's Library.

abstract: Far beyond the western confine of American civilization seven hundred miles west of the turbulent Missouri beyond the "Great American Desert" (as most of the maps viciously label the vast pastoral plateau of ...
lead_paragraph: Far beyond the western confine of American civilization -- seven hundred miles west of the turbulent Missouri -- beyond the "Great American Desert" -- (as most of the maps viciously label the vast pastoral plateau of the Continent) -- amid the rock-ribbed mountains themselves -- American pioneers have, during the past year, laid the foundations of a Free State, broad and solid as the hills among which it is founded; and the vernal sun which now bursts on the snow-capped summits of Pike's Peak beholds around its base an organized community of forty thousand men. Attracted thither by the magnetism of the mountains and the lust of gold, as well as by that inscrutable impulse which, from the earliest dawn of time, has ceaselessly impelled the historic races on their journey toward the setting sun, during the last two years a converging host of pioneers have turned their impetuous march along the great valleys that skirt the Platte, the Smoky Hill and the Arkansas; and the silent plains have resounded to the tramp of myriads of venture-some pilgrims. Men on mules, pilgrims afoot, with their packs on their backs, families in ox wagons, passengers by the overland express, and the endless procession of white-sailed "prairie schooners," have given a picturesque animation to the unpeopled solitudes where heretofore the bison has held eternal sway. Now, as the result, we behold the sublime apparition of a free and orderly community superseding as by magic the savage reign of the Ute, the Cheyenne and the Arrapahoe. The bustling town and the waving wheat-field, the church, the theatre and the gallows, the newspaper and post-office, the shout of the gold-digger and the hymn of the Christian household, have opened new scenes and awakened new echoes amid the solemn canons of the Sierra Madre. And the golden strata, in response to the picks, long-toms and crushers of the miners, have already yielded millions of dollars of the coveted metal.

abstract: During the session of last evening, the Supply bill being under consideration, the particular item being an appropriation of thirty thousand dollars to complete the draining of the Cayuga Marshes, a motion was made to strike out the words "Cayuga Marshes," and insert "State Treasury." abstract: A meeting of gentlemen favorable to the establishment of a Pawners' Bank in this City, was held at No. 63 William-street, yesterday afternoon, of which Hon. DANIEL F. TIEMANN was Chairman, and J. SMITH HOMANS, Esq., Secretary. BENJAMIN R. WINTHROP, Esq., read the proposed act of incorporation as an explanation of the objects of the meeting. The act is modeled after the charter of a similar institution in Boston, and provides that the Bank shall not be a Bank of issue, and shall loan money upon pledges only. The capital is not to exceed $500,000, and when $50,000 shall have been subscribed, and $25,000 paid in, the stockholders shall meet and commence operations. The Bank to loan to the amount of four-fifths of the value of the pledges, and the rate of interest is to be 18 per cent.

abstract: There remained unsold at the Twenty-fourthstreet stables, 480 horses. No sales reported of firstclass coach horses. Some very good ones on hand at $800@$1,000 per pair. Second-class teams sold at $550@$600 per pair. Sales for good single horses have been somewhat better than last week. Prices the same, $250@$300 each; second-class, $175@$200. No sales reported of first-class saddle horses; but few in market. First-class draught horses sold well at $250@$275 each; second-class at $175@$225 each.
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK, Wednesday, March 13, 1861.

abstract: A statement to the effect that Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, had sequestrated the stock of the Macon and Western Railroad, held by Northern stockholders, obtained circulation a few days ago. It also obtained credit; for with three months' experience of the vagaries of secession, there is no excess of impolicy and absurdity which may not be anticipated from these daring experimenters in the science of government.
lead_paragraph: A statement to the effect that Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, had sequestrated the stock of the Macon and Western Railroad, held by Northern stockholders, obtained circulation a few days ago. It also obtained credit; for with three months' experience of the vagaries of secession, there is no excess of impolicy and absurdity which may not be anticipated from these daring experimenters in the science of government. Governor BROWN, moreover, has established a peculiar reputation in this particular department of the inexact science referred to, insomuch that posterity, if indeed it find any trait in his character partaking of grandeur, will doubtless remember him as the great confiscator. But rumor in the present instance did injustice to the South and to Gov. BROWN. We have an authoritative statement that no such seizure was intended; and what is better, we are furnished with a reason why it is impracticable, namely, that there is a specific act forbidding any deprivation of rights and interests held in Georgia by foreign capitalists. The shares, therefore, of the Northern owner will remain in his undisturbed possession.

abstract: Gov. HOUSTON does not seem disposed to allow the Seceders to have everything their own way in Texas, after all. According to a dispatch which reaches us from Galveston, he has refused further to recognize the State Convention -- considering that its functions terminated with the submission of the secession ordinance to the people. He accordingly announces that the Legislature is soon to meet, and himself will now attend to such public questions as may arise, and declares himself in favor of a new Convention, to make necessary changes in the State Constitution. He at the same time does not hesitate to declare his opposition to the Southern Confederacy. The Convention have taken issue with him, and have passed an ordinance claiming full powers, and proposing to consummate the connection of Texas with the Southern Confederacy as speedily as possible. They also propose to make it obligatory upon all State officers to take an oath to support this new Government, and on the refusal of Gov. HOUSTON, to supersede him. Meantime a report is current that the Governor is raising troops on his own account.
lead_paragraph: Gov. HOUSTON does not seem disposed to allow the Seceders to have everything their own way in Texas, after all. He accordingly announces that the Legislature is soon to meet, and himself will now attend to such public questions as may arise, and declares himself in favor of a new Convention, to make necessary changes in the State Constitution. He at the same time does not hesitate to declare his opposition to the Southern Confederacy. The Convention have taken issue with him, and have passed an ordinance claiming full powers, and proposing to consummate the connection of Texas with the Southern Confederacy as speedily as possible. They also propose to make it obligatory upon all State officers to take an oath to support this new Government, and on the refusal of Gov. HOUSTON, to supersede him. abstract: Never did oracle, in its most evasive response, receive so many, and such various interpretations, as did the President's Inaugural on its first appearance. It has now, however, been read by the million, and, no doubt, marked, conned, and inwardly digested by the thousand a liberal proportion even in this enlightened land and the first excitement having subsided, public opinion. In regard to it seems to have found its natural level.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Saturday, March 9, 1861.

abstract: The ship Boston Light, Capt. HOLWAY, from Calcutta Sand Heads, 98 days, arrived at this port yesterday, with merchandise to BASSETT, BACON Co. She also brought Mr. LAW and five seamen, late of the British ship John Lowry, of Greenock, abandoned in ...
lead_paragraph: The ship Boston Light, Capt. HOLWAY, from Calcutta Sand Heads, 98 days, arrived at this port yesterday, with merchandise to BASSETT, BACON Co. She also brought Mr. LAW and five seamen, late of the British ship John Lowry, of Greenock, abandoned in the Indian Ocean in a sinking condition, these persons, constituting one of the boats' crews which left the ship, having been picked up Dec. 30, lat. 20 30 S., long. 6620 E., after being eight days in their boat, subjected to the horrors of exposure and thirst under a tropical sun. Mr. LAW has furnished our reporter the following particulars of the disaster:

abstract: Last Fall the ship-builders anticipated one of the busiest seasons at the opening of Spring that they have had since 1852 and 1853. Parties had in contemplation the building of quite a number of vessels, but owing to the Southern difficulties these projects have been abandoned for the present. Work on two or three vessels for the Southern trade, which are being built at the Brooklyn yards, has been stopped altogether. The following is a list of vessels now on the stocks:

abstract: Among the many voices raised in Europe over the disaster of secession, amid the groans of sorrow, cries of indignation and tones of sympathy which reach us from many lands beyond the sea, there is one neither loud nor mocking, but which, like the endless monotone in the poet's description of the uproar in hell, is more tormenting than all the other sounds combined.
lead_paragraph: Among the many voices raised in Europe over the disaster of secession, amid the groans of sorrow, cries of indignation and tones of sympathy which reach us from many lands beyond the sea, there is one neither loud nor mocking, but which, like the endless monotone in the poet's description of the uproar in hell, is more tormenting than all the other sounds combined. We mean that complacent "We told you so" of the friends of the old order of things -- of the men who have always predicted the downfall of the Republic -- not from any knowledge of us, but from the arbitrary assumption that Democracy is a false principle, and that, therefore, every Republic must be a failure.

abstract: Last evening, at Irving Hall, sixty young gentlemen, from almost every State in the Union except South Carolina, including also three or four from the British Provinces, were donated with diplomas, and instructed to heal the sick. The Hippocratic oath was administered to them by the venerable Dr. EDWARD DELAFIELD, President of the Medical Department of Columbia College, of which institution these sixty young gentlemen were members. Lively music by Dodworth's Band succeeded the Hippocratic oath, and was interspersed -with the other formalities of the occasion. The names of the graduates are as follows:

The Hippocratic oath was administered to them by the venerable Dr. EDWARD DELAFIELD, President of the Medical Department of Columbia College, of which institution these sixty young gentlemen were members. abstract: -- The Macon Telegraph, of March 4, says that a difficulty occurred in that city at the store of Hardeman & Griffin, between Capt. Lucius Lamar and Mr. James Ralston, in which Capt. Lamar was severely cut several times in the breast by Mr. Ralston. Although apparently out of danger, it will be two or three days before he can be pronounced safe. Capt. Lamar fired a derringer pistol at Mr. Ralston, which did not take effect, although within two or three feet of him. It is said that a button of Mr. Ralston's coat received the ball.

abstract: "Several journals in the Slaveholding States of America lately spoke in a triumphant tone of the arrival in France of a deputation from South Carolina, for the purpose of cultivating an alliance with NAPOLEON III., and the New-York TIMES, in a recent article, headed, 'How the Deputation was Received,' recorded with great glee that it had met with a snubbing at the Tuilleries. But it now appears that the whole story of the deputation was founded on error. Col. FAULKNER, the American Minister here, never having heard of the facts alleged by the transatlantic papers, called on M. THOUVENEL a day or two since to inquire whether there was any truth in them, and he received from the French Minister for Foreign Affairs the most positive assurances that no delegate from South Carolina, or from any other Secessionist State, has ever been received either by the Emperor or by himself. One only citizen of a Slave State has lately had an audience of the Emperor, namely, Gen. STEVENSON, of Tennessee, (a State, by the way, which has not left the Union,) and he solicited this audience merely in his character of Chairman of the Pacific Railway Company. Col. FAULKNER knows of no delegates from South Carolina having arrived in Paris, and he wishes this statement to be made public."

abstract: Gorham D. Abbott vs. The American Hard Rubber Company et als. -- This suit has been several times before the Court, and has been mentioned in the TIMES. It is an action brought by a stockholder in the American Hard Rubber Company, a Connecticut corporation, to set aside an alleged fraudulent sale of the assets of the Company to Messrs. Poppenheusen, Konig & Funcke, of this City. The plaintiff showed, it will be remembered, that he was a stockholder and creditor of the Company to the amount of upwards of $100,000. The Company held certain patent rights, under the Goodyear patents, for the manufacture of India rubber under the form of what is known as the "Hard Compound," and was organized for the purpose of manufacturing and selling articles under those rights. The Directors of the Company made a sale of all the patent rights, stock, machinery, tools &c, to Poppenheusen & Co. On these facts the plaintiff some months ago obtained an injunction, pending suit, against the Company, and its Directors and Poppenheusen, Konig & Funcke, and an order for the appointment of a Receiver.

abstract: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE Early in January last, a young German, named ADAM SCHLOSSER, residing at Newark, left that city for New-York, for the purpose of receiving a remittance of several hundred dollars from his agent, Mr. SATTIG, of No. 204 Broadway. The missing man called upon his agent, but the remittance at that time had not arrived,...
lead_paragraph: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE. -- Early in January last, a young German, named ADAM SCHLOSSER, residing at Newark, left that city for New-York, for the purpose of receiving a remittance of several hundred dollars from his agent, Mr. SATTIG, of No. 204 Broadway. The missing man called upon his agent, but the remittance at that time had not arrived, and he left, since which time he has not been heard from. About ten days since, the body of an unknown man was found by some rag-pickers in the Morris Canal, about two miles from Jersey City, upon which an inquest was held by Coroner GAFFNEY. The body was examined by Dr. QUIDOR. No marks of violence were discovered, and it having been in the water some length of time, the jury came to the conclusion that death was caused by drowning. A few days since Mr. VALENTINE PAPST, an associate of SCHLOSSER, caused the body of the drowned man to be disinterred, and was very positive that it was the body of SCHLOSSER. At the time of leaving home he was known to have on his person over $100 and a galvanized silver watch of German manufacture. SCHLOSSER was a single man, a native of Darmstadt, Germany, where he had considerable property. For some time he had been the owner of an extensive milk route at Newark. The matter will probably be further investigated by the Coroner, should he deem the facts set forth of sufficent importance to warrant such a proceeding.

abstract: While there is no doubt that the French people are sincerely opposed to Slavery, it is natural that their journalists should fail to comprehend the real significance and objects of secession. The Paris Constitutionnel, consequently, in commenting upon the views of this paper, doubts whether the policy of the Cotton States is purely slave propagandism, and whether they are bent upon seizing NewMexico, Central America and Cuba, for the...
lead_paragraph: While there is no doubt that the French people are sincerely opposed to Slavery, it is natural that their journalists should fail to comprehend the real significance and objects of secession. The Paris Constitutionnel, consequently, in commenting upon the views of this paper, doubts whether the policy of the Cotton States is purely slave propagandism, and whether they are bent upon seizing NewMexico, Central America and Cuba, for the purpose of erecting a grand Slaveholding Empire. All this seems incredible to foreigners, though perfectly palpable to those who come in contact with the leaders of the movement, and with the current literature of the South.

abstract: The Cincinnati Commercial tells the following incident of Inauguration Day on the authority of an Ohio M.C. It says: "On approaching the platform where he was to take his oath and be inducted into the office of Chief Executive, Mr. Lincoln re-...
lead_paragraph: -- The Cincinnati Commercial tells the following incident of Inauguration Day on the authority of an Ohio M.C. It says: "On approaching the platform where he was to take his oath and be inducted into the office of Chief Executive, Mr. Lincoln removed his hat and held it in his hand as he took the seat assigned him. The article seemed to be a burden. He changed it awkwardly from one to another, and finally, despairing of finding for it any other easy position, deposited it upon the platform beside him. Senators and judges crowded in and to make room for them he removed nearer the front of the stage, carrying his tile with him. Again it was dandied uneasily, and as Senator Baker approached to introduce him to the audience he made a motion as if to replace the tile on the stage under the seat, when Douglas, who had been looking on quietly, and apparently with some apprehensions of a catastrophe to the hat, said, 'Permit me, Sir,' and gallantly took the vexatious article and held it during the entire reading of the Inaugural. Douglas must have reflected pretty seriously during that half hour, that instead of delivering an inaugural address from that portico, he was holding the hat of the man who was doing it."

abstract: The steam-frigate Powhatan hauled into the stream at the Navy-yard yesterday. Her arrival was telegraphed to the authorities at Washington, who have commanded her to remain as she is for the present. Neither her officers nor crew have been detached, and it is thought she will remain in commission. Not having been overhauled in four years, since she was fitted out for the East Indies, she cannot advisedly be left long in active service.

abstract: BONE-BOILING ESTABLISHMENTS. -- A man has been on trial in the Kings County Court of Sessions for several days past, upon an indictment for maintaining a nuisance in the shape of a bone-boiling establishment, in the Ninth Ward. Yesterday morning the defendant was acquitted by the jury, thereby establishing the fact, so far this case is concerned, that bone-boiling is not a nuisance. The verdict in this case was looked forward to with great interest by a large number of persons engaged in similar business in different parts of the city.

abstract: James L. Cheesman vs. James H. Sturgess, Andrew Thorp and Thomas S. Thorp. -- This action is brought for an accounting between partners. The plaintiff, it appears, held in August, 1855, two contracts with "The People's Ice Company" for conveyances to them of certain land at Athens, N.Y., and for the erection of buildings, docks and wharves thereon. In August, 1855, the plaintiff, the defendant Sturgess and one Braisted, entered into a copartnership arrangement for the purpose of carrying out these contracts. The plaintiff, it seems, assigned to each of the others a one-third interest therein, Sturgess and Braisted to advance the means, and after all moneys advanced were refunded, the profits, it appears, were to be equally divided. The plaintiff took title to the partnership property, but Sturgess advancing the purchase money, the plaintiff conveyed to him, and vested the title to the same in mm. Sturges then executed an instrument, by which he declared that he held the property for the benefit of plaintiff, Braisted and himself, and agreeing not to dispose of the property except for the purpose of the said contract, and with the constant and approbation of the said parties. The contract of building it appears was carried out. Braisted failing to furnish any of the money. It is claimed that Sturges paid over into the hands of plaintiff, to be disbursed in the enterprise, about $40,000, and as alleged, retained a balance of some amount. Sturges denies retaining any sums in his hands. There appears, however, to be two accounts between the parties, one offsetting the other, which is the matter in dispute. The case will occupy the Court for two or three days

abstract: Benjamin Sutherland vs. The Brigantine Lady Mansell This was a libel filed to recover the amount of a bill of blacksmith's work done on the vessel. The vessel was a foreign vessel, and came into this port disabled, and requiring this work to enable her to proceed on her voyage to her home port.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Sutherland vs. The Brigantine Lady Mansell. -- This was a libel filed to recover the amount of a bill of blacksmith's work done on the vessel. The vessel was a foreign vessel, and came into this port disabled, and requiring this work to enable her to proceed on her voyage to her home port. Her master consigned her to a Mr. Bulley, agent of the foreign owners. The owners had at the time the repairs were made ample credit, and actual funds in Mr. Bully's hands, and the libelant had implied notice of that fact through his personal and business intercourse with him, and could have had explicit assurance of the fact, if inquiry had been made of the agent or master.

abstract: The resolutions adopted by the Board of Councilmen last evening, calling upon the members of the Assembly from this City to oppose the bill permanently locating the General Post-office on its present site, and recommending a removal of the same to "a location not lower than the south end of City Hall Park," will give satisfaction to five-sevenths of those who are most deeply interested in the question of proper mail facilities for Manhattan Island.
lead_paragraph: The resolutions adopted by the Board of Councilmen last evening, calling upon the members of the Assembly from this City to oppose the bill permanently locating the General Post-office on its present site, and recommending a removal of the same to "a location not lower than the south end of City Hall Park," will give satisfaction to five-sevenths of those who are most deeply interested in the question of proper mail facilities for Manhattan Island. Great as may be our wish to benefit private property in the vicinity of the Middle Dutch Church, we cannot consent that it shall be propped up at a sacrifice inflicting such serious injury on the commerce and industry of our City. New-York is constantly stretching northward, business moving up town with sturdy strides, and the mansions of the rich pushing aside the humble tenements in which the laboring classes have heretofore squatted throughout the upper Wards. In a few years more, Broad-street, Pearl-street and Front-street will have submitted to the fate which has already overtaken that portion of Greenwich-street situated in the First Ward. The buildings now occupied as stores and warehouses will be converted into emigrant boarding or tenement houses; and even the stately vista of Wall-street will become a financial, desert, all its banks and insurance companies -- as they are already rapidly doing -- moving into corner buildings on Broadway.

abstract: Coroner GAMBLE was notified yesterday to hold an inquest upon the body of Patrick Lynch, a laborer, who was run over and killed on Wednesday afternoon by the locomotive attached to a train of the New-Haven Railroad. Deceased was walking on the railroad track near Sixty-fifth-street, and having been observed by the engineer, the steam-whistle was sounded while there was ample time for him to step aside. He failed to heed the warning, however, and notwithstanding the fact that the engine was reversed, its speed was not checked sufficiently to avoid a collision. Mr. Lynch was thrown a considerable distance in advance of the train, and when picked up, was at the point of death. His remains were taken to his residence in Forty-second-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. The friends of deceased say that, he was afflicted with partial deafness, and could not have heard the alarm signal given by the engineer.
lead_paragraph: Coroner GAMBLE was notified yesterday to hold an inquest upon the body of Patrick Lynch, a laborer, who was run over and killed on Wednesday afternoon by the locomotive attached to a train of the New-Haven Railroad. abstract: Our dispatches from Washington indicate no definite movement in reference to Fort Sumpter, further than the announcement that a special meeting of the Cabinet was held yesterday morning, which was supposed to relate to the policy to be pursued. Army officers at the Capital, however, expect that the garrison at Sumpter will be in Washington next week. Messrs. CRAWFORD and FORSYTH, the two Southern Commissioners, have communicated with the President, through Secretary SEWARD, asking an audience. They were informed that the Administration was not prepared to receive them, and that they would be informed when the proper time should arrive. It is understood that the Commissioners express a perfect willingness to wait until the matters now under discussion before the Cabinet shall have been disposed of, before making any formal demand of any kind. They also deny that "President" DAVIS has any intention of attacking Fort Pickens until they shall have reported the result of their mission to Washington.

abstract: Egbert Deming, Trustee, &c., vs. The New-York Marble Company et al. -- This case has been frequently reported in the TIMES under the above title. It was now brought to trial, and after nearly three days' examination of the plaintiff, his case was rested; whereupon, the Court, without further proceedings, gave judgment for the defendants, stating that the plaintiff's evidence was too conflicting and contradictory, to be relied upon, and being unsupported by other evidence, it would not sustain his case.

abstract: In spite of the exceedingly unpleasant weather a large number of his fellow-citizens, without distinction of party, called upon Hon. JOHN A. DIX, late Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, in the Governor's Room at the City Hall, yesterday, and congratulated him upon his efficient administration of the affairs of finance during his brief term of office. The flags were flying over the City Hall in honor of the occasion, policemen were stationed within to preserve order, and in the Governor's Room, at a little before 12 oclock, the Mayor and Common Council were waiting to receive their guest. Punctually at noon he arrived in a carriage with the Committee of Reception, and proceeding to the Governor's Room, was formally introduced to the Mayor by Alderman FROMENT.
lead_paragraph: In spite of the exceedingly unpleasant weather a large number of his fellow-citizens, without distinction of party, called upon Hon. JOHN A. DIX, late Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, in the Governor's Room at the City Hall, yesterday, and congratulated him upon his efficient administration of the affairs of finance during his brief term of office. The flags were flying over the City Hall in honor of the occasion, policemen were stationed within to preserve order, and in the Governor's Room, at a little before 12 oclock, the Mayor and Common Council were waiting to receive their guest. Punctually at noon he arrived in a carriage with the Committee of Reception, and proceeding to the Governor's Room, was formally introduced to the Mayor by Alderman FROMENT.

abstract: The annals of litigation furnish no two more interesting or peculiar cases than those of Madame PATERSON BONAPARTE, and of Mrs. MYRA CLARK GAINES, both of which have, for many years, occupied prominent positions before, not only the legal profession, but the eyes of the world. These cases are singularly suggestive, and peculiarly illustrative of certain phases of American society, and as such,...
lead_paragraph: The annals of litigation furnish no two more interesting or peculiar cases than those of Madame PATERSON BONAPARTE, and of Mrs. MYRA CLARK GAINES, both of which have, for many years, occupied prominent positions before, not only the legal profession, but the eyes of the world. These cases are singularly suggestive, and peculiarly illustrative of certain phases of American society, and as such, possess other interests than those of a merely pecuniary character. Each has reached, after portracted struggles, a decision, the one adverse to and the other in favor of the claimant -- the one loses all she deemed worth living for, while the other gains not only a fortune of fabulous amount, but establishes forever the honor of her mother. Had the Imperial Court been more kind, the American claimant of a kingly hand would now be in possession of a vast estate, with her son's legitimacy acknowledged before the world, while, as it is, these are denied her, and perhaps forever.
headline: {'main': 'The Victory of Mrs. Gaines.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Victory of Mrs. Gaines.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The British Parliament has again witnessed a debate on the Slave question, which was not merely interesting from the fact that such men as Lords JOHN RUSSELL and PALMERSTON took earnest part in the proceedings, but because it may be in a great degree regarded as almost exhaustive of representative English opinion on this all-important topic at the present day.
lead_paragraph: The British Parliament has again witnessed a debate on the Slave question, which was not merely interesting from the fact that such men as Lords JOHN RUSSELL and PALMERSTON took earnest part in the proceedings, but because it may be in a great degree regarded as almost exhaustive of representative English opinion on this all-important topic at the present day. Within a few years the English mind has acquired much information and imbibed many new ideas on the subject of Slavery and the Slave-trade. The growing importance of labor, on the one hand, and the horrors and difficulties of the Slave-trade on the other, have compelled inventiveness and humanity to become not only more tolerant but more active. By us of the United States the views promulgated in the debate in question should be not less carefully studied than they will be by the Press of all Europe.
headline: {'main': 'The Slave-Trade in Parliament.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Slave-Trade in Parliament.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A correspondent of the Alexandria (Va.) Gazette, writing from Harrisonburg, tells a story too shocking for belief. Mrs. COOLEY, the wife of B.B. COOLEY, who lives near Middletown, Frederick Co., left home about 2 P.M., on the afternoon of Feb. 28, to visit a neighbor, as was supposed, but as she did not return by nightfall, alarm was excited, and as the hands came in from work they were sent out to hunt her up. Some of them heard groans in the smoke house near by, and having gained access to it, found Mrs. COOLEY sitting on the floor, her hands covering her face, and perfectly unconscious. Some of her clothing was hanging from the meat hooks in the rafters, and some was strewed about the floor. A salting tray was almost filled with blood, apparently freshly spilled. Marks, resembling those made by the pressure of fingers, were upon her arms, and her head, neck and sides were horribly mutilated by what appeared to be a blunt pointed instrument. Her shoes and stockings were found under her bed in her chamber, saturated with blood. Medical aid was promptly procured, and everything done for her that science and skill could suggest, but all was of no avail. She lingered for two or three days when death came to her relief. A negro woman has been arrested on suspicion of having murdered her, but no satisfactory evidence has yet been found against her.

abstract: Several pilot boats came in from sea yesterday morning, and reported the wind outside as fresh from the Northeast. They also reported having boarded a number of barks, brigs and schooners, but no ships, from the eastward, although a large number are now due. A large fleet of clippers and other vessels are at anchor in the North river, outward bound, and will proceed the first slant of wind. The steamer Empire City is yet at anchor at Quarantine awaiting Government orders. There was a storm of sleet and rain prevailing at 12 M., with a cold atmosphere, which makes mittens, great coats and comforters neceesary on the water.

abstract: The City Assembly Booms were thronged, last evening, by an assemblage consisting for the most part, as an Hibernian would say, of Irishmen of both sexes, who came together to witness the presentation of a stand of colors to the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.T.S.M., and of a sword of honor to Col. MICHAEL CORCORAN, its Commander, "as a testimonial," in the words of the card of invitation, signed by JOHN CLANOY, Chairman, "of sympathy with said regiment and officers in their refusal to perform an extra parade, not prescribed by law, in honor of the Prince of Wales." The officers and men of the regiment were present, in full uniform. At a little after 8 o'clock they marched in, led by the regimental band, playing the Irish air, "Larry O'Gaff," amid loud plaudits, and presented arms to Messrs. A.V. Stout, T.F. Meagher, Chandler, O'Connor, E. and T. Hearne, Wm. E. Robinson, Maguire, J. Hennessy, Dunphy, Jas. Lynch, J.P. Tully, Alderman Farley, Ex-Alderman Bradley, and others, as they came on to the platform.

abstract: The fifth article of the Constitution of the United States prescribes two modes in which amendments may be made to it. The first and simplest of these declares that, whenever two-thirds of both Houses of Congress shall deem it necessary, amendments may be submitted to the action of the States, and if the Legislatures or Conventions of three-fourths of the States approve the proposed amendments, they become parts of the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: The fifth article of the Constitution of the United States prescribes two modes in which amendments may be made to it. The first and simplest of these declares that, whenever two-thirds of both Houses of Congress shall deem it necessary, amendments may be submitted to the action of the States, and if the Legislatures or Conventions of three-fourths of the States approve the proposed amendments, they become parts of the Constitution. The other mode of amendment provides that, at the instance of two-thirds of the State Legislatures, Congress shall call a General Convention, whose proposed amendments must likewise be agreed to by three-fourths of the States.

abstract: FIRE IN UNION-SQUARE LODGE ROOMS BURNED OUT. Shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out on the second floor of the brick building No. 8 Union-square, known as Thorp's Hotel. An alarm brought the firemen to the place with their usual alacrity, but their efforts to stay the ravages of the flames were of no avail until the whole interior of the building was destroyed.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN UNION-SQUARE -- LODGE ROOMS BURNED OUT. -- Shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out on the second floor of the brick building No. 8 Union-square, known as Thorp's Hotel. An alarm brought the firemen to the place with their usual alacrity, but their efforts to stay the ravages of the flames were of no avail until the whole interior of the building was destroyed. The first floor and basement of the house was occupied by M.A. DECKER as a bar-room and restaurant, whose loss of stock amounts to about $7,000, upon which he had no insurance. Mr. E. GILDERSLEEVE owned the furniture and bar fixtures, and his loss, estimated at $1,000, is covered by insurance in the Commonwealth Insurance Company. The upper floors of the building were used as lodge-rooms by various Masonic Societies, the loss of each of which varies from $500 to $1,000, and neither of them had their property insured excepting the Holland Lodge, and even this suffered to a greater, extent than the amount for which it had policies -- its loss being estimated at $6,000, and its insurances amounting only to $4,000. The building, owned by Mr. A.L. Cox, was injured to the extent of about $7,000; insured for $6,000 in the Niagara, and $5,000 in the Germania Insurance Companies. Mr. THORP had leased the premises for a term of years, and considers that he is out of pocket $16,000 by the disaster. The fire is believed to have originated from a grate on the second floor, where a fire had been kept several days for the purpose of drying a newly elected partition wall in one of the lodge-rooms. Following are the names of the lodges who occupied the premises: Crescent, Holland, Continental, Arcana, Concord, Benevolent, Pacific and Washington, and the Metropolitan, Jerusalem and Coeur de Leon Chapters.

abstract: VENICE LONG AGO. LEUTZE has just completed a "View in Venice" in the olden time, which is in several respects a master-piece, displaying effects of light and color superior even to his best previous productions, and indicating that progress which is the crowning proof of the firstclass artist.
lead_paragraph: VENICE LONG AGO. -- LEUTZE has just completed a "View in Venice" in the olden time, which is in several respects a master-piece, displaying effects of light and color superior even to his best previous productions, and indicating that progress which is the crowning proof of the firstclass artist. It represents the embouchure of the Canale Grande, with the Church Santa Maria della Salute, of course, to the left, and the long row of palaces on either hand, fading in dim distance. The fore-centre is occupied by a gondola, such as gondolas were before an edict of the Consiglio sentenced them to be clad in black, in order to repress the excessive luxury which the nobility displayed in ornamenting these boats. A lady is seated in it, beneath a rich crimson canopy -- through which the light falling produces a peculiarly rich glow -- while a cavalier near her, and the gondolier dozing unreproved behind, complete the incident. The picture, however, embraces many other noticeable points. The remarkable variety of aerial effects introduced is equaled by those given in the play of the water, in the waves, and especially in the reflections from "castle, tower and town." The rich, fresh green under the gondolas is peculiarly and strikingly balanced by the liberal light of the crimson canopy, and the exquisite purple reflection to the left, with other harmonious hues introduced in the middle distance, appropriately prepare the eye for the dreamy dimness of the city.

abstract: Owing to an unfavorable season the farmers of several counties in the State of Mississippi have for some weeks been in great straits for grains, and recent accounts from there demonstrate very clearly that not only inconvenience but absolute starvation has been the consequence. Appeals to the residents of their...
lead_paragraph: Owing to an unfavorable season the farmers of several counties in the State of Mississippi have for some weeks been in great straits for grains, and recent accounts from there demonstrate very clearly that not only inconvenience but absolute starvation has been the consequence. Appeals to the residents of their own State were in vain, and at last when necessity became imperious, a public meeting was called, and one Major HAWKINS was deputed to go to the Northwest and procure in some way, and from any quarter, the needed aid.

abstract: A report reached New-Orleans on March 8, that Mr. BUCHANAN had ordered the reconsideration of the order striking Gen. TWIGGS' name from the Army Roll, and the Delta says that when informed of it, the General declared, "with characteristic emphasis, that they should not reconsider the case; but that he would, as soon as his health permitted, proceed to consider their case, and to hand BUCHANAN and HOLT, down to posterity as the most black-hearted calumniators who ever disgraced humanity." The Delta says further, that "so far from having anticipated the assumption of command of the Department by Col. WAITE, by surrendering the public property to Texas, the General, as soon as apprised that WAITE had been sent, at his own urgent and repeated solicitation, to supercede him, Gen. TWIGGS insisted that WAITE should enter immediately on the duties of the command. The neglect of WAITE to do so continued the General in command until the Texans had assembled an overwhelming force."
lead_paragraph: A report reached New-Orleans on March 8, that Mr. BUCHANAN had ordered the reconsideration of the order striking Gen. abstract: It is needless to inform the world that Cottondom at present breathes nothing but war, and sees everything as some sufferers by delirium tremens are said to do steeped in blood. From the entire sececs-pool rise deathly vapors, and young gentlemen at parties, when called on by the ladies for sentiments, (they do such things down there,) respond with such little amiabilities as "Blood is cheap," "Northern Invaders in Southern graves," and the like.
lead_paragraph: It is needless to inform the world that Cottondom at present breathes nothing but war, and sees everything -- as some sufferers by delirium tremens are said to do -- steeped in blood. From the entire sececs-pool rise deathly vapors, and young gentlemen at parties, when called on by the ladies for sentiments, (they do such things down there,) respond with such little amiabilities as "Blood is cheap," "Northern Invaders in Southern graves," and the like.

abstract: John G. Quackenbos, a native of this country, about 40 years of age, employed as book-keeper by Reeve & Co., merchants at Nos. 229 and 231 Front-street, committed suicide yesterday forenoon, by shooting himself through the head with a pistol at his boardinghouse, No. 106 Bowery. The report of the pistol having been heard, entrance was at once forced to his apartment, and he was found lying upon his face quite dead. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest upon the body, and the evidence showed that deceased had recently separated from his family ,who had gone to live at Deansville, Ct. This separation seems to have been brought about from the fact that deceased was rather intemperate in his habits, and letters were found addressed to him both by his wife and father, imploring that for the sake of his children he would reform. Deceased had lately been a great sufferer from rheumatism, and to relieve the pain had used laudanum to a considerable extent. In view of these facts the jury were of opinion that his mind had become unsettled, and they rendered a verdict of suicide resulting from family troubles.
lead_paragraph: John G. Quackenbos, a native of this country, about 40 years of age, employed as book-keeper by Reeve & Co., merchants at Nos. 229 and 231 Front-street, committed suicide yesterday forenoon, by shooting himself through the head with a pistol at his boardinghouse, No. 106 Bowery. The report of the pistol having been heard, entrance was at once forced to his apartment, and he was found lying upon his face quite dead. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest upon the body, and the evidence showed that deceased had recently separated from his family ,who had gone to live at Deansville, Ct. This separation seems to have been brought about from the fact that deceased was rather intemperate in his habits, and letters were found addressed to him both by his wife and father, imploring that for the sake of his children he would reform. Deceased had lately been a great sufferer from rheumatism, and to relieve the pain had used laudanum to a considerable extent. In view of these facts the jury were of opinion that his mind had become unsettled, and they rendered a verdict of suicide resulting from family troubles.

abstract: Begs to say that, of their innumerable letters, he does not find it practicable (being quite infirm) to read one in five, nor to answer one in thirty. Applications for autographs and offices are most burdensome. The former increase with his inability to use the pen, and of the latter he has, within his own gift but two small places, (long well filled,) and he recommends no one whatever, other than an old soldier, nor for any office whatever out of the army.

abstract: The policy of the Administration in regard to Fort Sumpter is not yet promulgated in any shape which may be deemed official, though little doubt remains in the public mind at Washington that an evacuation has been determined upon.
lead_paragraph: The policy of the Administration in regard to Fort Sumpter is not yet promulgated in any shape which may be deemed official, though little doubt remains in the public mind at Washington that an evacuation has been determined upon. When it will take place, however, is wholly a matter of conjecture -- though some of the correspondents insist that the necessary order has already been forwarded to Major ANDERSON. The opinion that the fortress will soon be in their peaceful possession now generally prevails among the Charlestonians, and even the Mercury receives it with confidence. President LINCOLN called another special meeting of the Cabinet yesterday morning, at which Gen. SCOTT and Gen. TOTTEN -- the latter the head of the Engineer Corps -- were present. It is presumed that the subject under discussion related to the Southern fortifications.

abstract: The weakness of the Confederated States in their finances, is shown by the fact that the proceeds of a special tax is mortgaged for the payment of their first loan. This is the common resort of a slip-shod, thriftless nation, and a confession that the ordinary revenues, and, in fact, its future faith, is not to be relied on. Hence its action is to be tied up for...
lead_paragraph: The weakness of the Confederated States in their finances, is shown by the fact that the proceeds of a special tax is mortgaged for the payment of their first loan. This is the common resort of a slip-shod, thriftless nation, and a confession that the ordinary revenues, and, in fact, its future faith, is not to be relied on. Hence its action is to be tied up for a given period. But all such agreements are not only worthless in themselves, but are a confession of weakness tending more than anything else to destroy its credit. The tax may be repealed any day. A sovereign State is not to be impleaded in courts of justice, if we except the magnanimous State of Mississippi, which has allowed herself to be summoned to the bar of her own courts, at the same time repudiating the solemn judgments which these tribunals rendered against her.
headline: {'main': 'The Finances of the Confederated States.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Finances of the Confederated States.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At a little past 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, fire was discovered in the fifth-story of the Franklin Buildings, No. 106 Orange-street, occupied by the American Hoop-Skirt Company. The alarm was immediately given, and the firemen and citizens promptly repaired to the spot, and succeeded in extinguishing the fire before much damage was done to the premises, but unfortunately not in season to prevent the loss of one life and prevent another from being put in great jeopardy.

abstract: We are requested to repeat that the United States ships Supply, Mohawk, and Crusader, which left the Navy-yard on Thursday, are destined to join the squadron which has been recalled from the Gulf of Mexico to our seaboard. The revenue vessels added to the fleet are intended to augment it to a respectable coast guard, as already stated.
lead_paragraph: We are requested to repeat that the United States ships Supply, Mohawk, and Crusader, which left the Navy-yard on Thursday, are destined to join the squadron which has been recalled from the Gulf of Mexico to our seaboard. The revenue vessels added to the fleet are intended to augment it to a respectable coast guard, as already stated. The chartered vessels. Star of the West, Empire City, Philadelphia, and Coatzacoalcos, are employed for the purpose openly avowed by the Government, viz.: that of conveying United States troops from Texas, and between other posts. The detachment called off on the island on Thursday is for Florida. The Mohawk and Crusader will report to the Commander-in-Chief of the station in the neighborhood of Pensacola. The Philadelphia will probably be used, if Sumpter be evacuated, to bring the garrison of that fort to Old Point Comfort, Va.

abstract: The privilege of taxing the travel through the streets of such a City as New-York is worth an almost untold sum. This privilege is now exercised by a few favored companies, whose profits have, for years, set an innumerable lobby at work at Albany, to obtain similar grants. A number were passed last year,
lead_paragraph: The privilege of taxing the travel through the streets of such a City as New-York is worth an almost untold sum. This privilege is now exercised by a few favored companies, whose profits have, for years, set an innumerable lobby at work at Albany, to obtain similar grants. A number were passed last year, over the veto of the Governor, but thus far they have proved valueless in the hands of their holders, and will very likely be repealed the present session of the Legislature, as the stepping-stone to something else. From the conflict of interests, it is very probable that no new grants will at present be made, and that the project of the Broadway Railroad will again get the go-by.

abstract: While the President has an undoubted right to weigh carefully the claims of all candidates for Federal employment, there are two of Mr. BUCHANAN'S appointees in this City whose instant removal is demanded alike by humanity and justice. We refer to Marshal ISAIAH
lead_paragraph: While the President has an undoubted right to weigh carefully the claims of all candidates for Federal employment, there are two of Mr. BUCHANAN'S appointees in this City whose instant removal is demanded alike by humanity and justice. We refer to Marshal ISAIAH RYNDERS and District-Attorney ROOSEVELT, two officials under whose benignant and fostering protection the Slave-trade has established itself amongst us as a secure and influential business-interest, -- the merchants engaged therein being carefully screened from view, and any prisoners taken on the Coast of Africa having before them the absolute certainty of release, either on account of some accidental flaw in the indictment as drawn by ROOSEVELT, or through the accidental leaving open of some door by the neglect of RYNDERS or his deputies.

abstract: "Sprigs of shillelah and shamrocks so green" were rampant, yesterday, on the recurrence of the birthday of that honored Saint, St. Patrick, who, though said to have been born on the 8th or 9th of Marth, has the homage this year of natal celebration on the 17th and 18th for it must ho remembered the secular festivities of the occasion are to be continued to-day possibly reaching into tomorrow morning.
lead_paragraph: "Sprigs of shillelah and shamrocks so green" were rampant, yesterday, on the recurrence of the birthday of that honored Saint, St. Patrick, who, though said to have been born on the 8th or 9th of Marth, has the homage this year of natal celebration on the 17th and 18th -- for it must ho remembered the secular festivities of the occasion are to be continued to-day -- possibly reaching into tomorrow morning. So far as the devotional character of the ceremonies yesterday would permit, the devotees of St. Patrick enjoyed the day. But they generally reserved until this evening the more delightful recreation and observance of "drowning the shamrock" -- which the "Friendly Sons" are in the habit of doing to their hearts' content.

abstract: The Philharmonic Society gave its fourth concert on Saturday evening to a fine and fashionable audience. The programme opened with BEETHEVEN's 7th Symphony not very carefully played, and especially defective in the light and shade which a conductor should give to an orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The Philharmonic Society gave its fourth concert on Saturday evening to a fine and fashionable audience. The programme opened with BEETHEVEN's 7th Symphony -- not very carefully played, and especially defective in the light and shade which a conductor should give to an orchestra. After this came a concerto by MZART (NO 8,) for piano and orchestra -- a charming work of a past age, for the resuscitation of which every lover of simple grace and melodic richness must feel indebted to Mr. HOFTMAN. This gentleman interpreted the piano part, and with a finish of execution and elegance of phrasing which we hardly hope to hear surpassed. The tempi of the various movements were as usual modernized, and advantageously, as we think; a couple of well-devised cadenzas, calculated in an innocent way to show off the capabilities of the pianist, were also engrafted on the original work. Mr. HOFFMAN'S performance was all that could be desired. Later in the evening he played two solos, one an unimportant nocturne by TEDESCO; the other a grand Polonaise by LURECK, a composer and performer of rising fame. The last named is literally crowded with ideas, and for that reason is somewhat incoherent; but it indicates a vigorous mind, and as a concert piece strikes us most favorably. Mr. HOFFMAN's performance of these morceaux was so satisfactory that he was compelled to play an encore piece.

abstract: DANGEROUS BLASTING UPON BLACKWELL'S ISLAND. At about 1 o'clock on Saturday last, the quarrymen engaged near the excavations for the new reservoir on Blackwell's Island, set off a very heavy blast, which sent large masses of shattered
lead_paragraph: DANGEROUS BLASTING UPON BLACKWELL's ISLAND. -- At about 1 1/2 o'clock on Saturday last, the quarrymen engaged near the excavations for the new reservoir on Blackwell's Island, set off a very heavy blast, which sent large masses of shattered granite high into the air, a whole shower of "splinters" falling within half the length of the steamer Enoch Dean, which was passing, and directly opposite at the instant of the explosion. Pieces of rock, apparently as large as good-sized cheeses, fell within startling proximity to the steamer, causing considerable alarm among the passengers. Any one of these missiles, the Captain averred, had they struck the vessel, would have gone clear through her, and probably would have done fatal damage in the crowded condition of the steamer. The steamboat Island Home, with a barge in tow, was also near by at the time. The passengers expressed their aversion to repetitions of that species of salute.

abstract: Shortly before 10 o'clock yesterday morning a fire occurred in KUBBEL & RETTBERG'S grocery, No. 540 Grand street, corner of Cannon, causing damage to the extent of $150 by destruction of the stock, which was insured for $1,000 in the Central Park Insurance Company. The damage to the building, of which MAX SELIGMAN is owner, amounts only to $50; covered by insurance of $800 in the St. Mark's. Capt. STEERS, of the Thirteenth Ward Police, believing the fire to have been the work of incendiarism, caused the arrest of LOUIS KUBBEL, one of the proprietors, on suspicion of the offence, and telegraphed for Fire Marshal BAKER to come and investigate the facts of the case. The prisoner, in answer to the Marshal, denied that he had been to his store since Saturday night, notwithstanding the circumstance that he had been seen to leave the place, by the Cannon-street door, five minutes previous to the discovery of the fire. On searching the prisoner the key of the Cannon-street door and some pennies were found in his pockets, and his partner, Mr. RETTBERG, identified the key and one of the pennies as having been left within the store when he closed it at 11 1/2 o'clock on Saturday night. Upon this evidence the prisoner was detained, and to day he will be taken before Justice BRENNAN, who, doubtless, will commit him for trial. The police of the Thirteenth Ward have been very active lately in tracing out incendiary fires, and during the past four months have made four arrests for arson. Three of the prisoners have been tried and convicted of the offence.

abstract: Quite a large audience assembled at Irving Hall, last evening, to hear a lecture which had been advertised to be delivered before the Catholic Library Association, by Rev. Dr. LYNCH, Catholic Bishop of Charleston, upon the "Conversion and unwavering faith of the Irish Nation;" but for some reason the Bishop was not able to get here in season, and at a late hour the audience was informed by Dr. FINNELL, the President of the Association, that Archbishop HUGHES would fill his place. The Archbishop, who was dressed in his official robes, arose to address the audience, and was greeted in a manner which indicated that the audience were by no means displeased with the change in the programme. He said that it was only within an hour that he had felt impelled to represent, however imperfectly, the distinguished Dr. LYNCH on that occasion. The twilight of St. Patrick's day, for 1861, had already closed in upon them, and wherever the sun has traveled in his westward journey, there was St. Patrick's day celebrated by the scattered children of that nation whom he had rescued from superstition, and bathed in the glorious effulgence of Christianity.

abstract: Bequests to the Catholic Church and St. Vincent's Hospital. -- The will of Mary Whitworth was now admitted to probate. The will gives several lots of ground at Fordham to St. Vincent's Hospital, under the care of Mother Jerome. Three hundred dollars are left to Archbishop Hughes for the benefit of poor young men preparing for the Catholic priesthood. Several private bequests are then made, and the residue of testatrix' property left to the Catholic Orphan Asylum.

abstract: Two weeks remain for preparation for the election in Connecticut. We trust the time will be improved. It is important that Connecticut should indicate her purpose to support the Administration which she aided in electing, -- especially at the outset, and until it has had a fair opportunity to develop its policy and vindicate its claim to public favor. The circumstances of the case call for a vigorous canvass, and a thorough discussion of the public questions at issue before the people.

abstract: Notwithstanding the apparent certainty with which the announcements relative to the proposed evacution of Fort Sumpter have been promulgated, it appears, after all, that there is no certainty about it. Our correspondent telegraphs positively
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the apparent certainty with which the announcements relative to the proposed evacution of Fort Sumpter have been promulgated, it appears, after all, that there is no certainty about it. Our correspondent telegraphs positively that no final order for the withdrawal of the troops has been given, and that it is by no means certain yet that any such order will be issued. Meantime the Southern Commissioners remain in Washington awaiting the action of the Administration on their application for recognition. It is understood that they express strong hopes of a peaceful solution of the difficulties, though the precise ground on which such a hope is based does not at present clearly appear.

abstract: The St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, on Pacific-street, near Vanderbilt-avenue, was originally organized about twelve years ago, under the most embarrassing circumstances, by Rev. Father O'NELL.
lead_paragraph: The St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, on Pacific-street, near Vanderbilt-avenue, was originally organized about twelve years ago, under the most embarrassing circumstances, by Rev. Father O'NELL. At a later period, however, under the exertions of Father O'NEIL, the Society increased so rapidly that greater church accommodations were rendered a matter of necessily. Accordingly, about one year ago, the project of crecting a new church was started, and met with such favor that in April last the work was formally commenced, and yesterday the new building, complete in every requisite quality, was dedicated. The exercises were commenced at 10 1/2 o'clock A.M., when Rev. D.W. CAHILL, D.D., delivered a dedication sermon, and Bishop LOUGHLIN performed the act of dedication, assisted by Rev. Fathers O'Neil, Celebrant; Cassidy, Deacon; Keegan, Sub-Deacon; O'Birne, Kelly, Fagan, McKenna, and McGuire. A solemn High Mass (LAMBELOTTE's) was performed, with Mr. SELLE, of the Church of Assumption, as organist, and in the Choir, Mrs. CLARK, soprano; Miss EAGAN, alto; Messrs. E.B. CADLEY and JOHNSON, tenors, and Mr. FREIDENBAUGH, bass. The music was exceedingly well rendered, notwithstanding the Choir had no opportunity for rehearsal.
headline: {'main': "BROOKLYN NEWS.; Dedication of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "BROOKLYN NEWS.; Dedication of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The prolonged absence of the steamship Australasian, which left Liverpool on the 16th ult., and should in due course have reached this port by the 2d inat., has been a source of extreme anxiety on this side of the Atlantic. By the Arabia, we are happily furnished with the intelligence that no fatal disaster had caused the destruction of the missing ship, nothing more serious than head winds and a fractured screw having occurred to compel her return to Ireland. From the log, which is subjoined, it will be seen that her voyage until after, on her outward voyage, she had called at Cork, and taken on board her malls, was without notable incident. On the 18th, she experienced light variable winds, and on the following day there was a strong breeze and a heavy sea, rendering it very difficult to manage the ship. The morning of the 20th, however, was still more severe, betokening a violent storm. Not only had the noble vessel to contend with a succession of terrific squalls and a high tea, but a heavy gale contributed to the impending danger. While vainly attempting to weather the storm, she broke two bars of the screw, which, of course, disabled her, and rendered it impossible to proceed on her voyage by steam-propelling power. The accident to the screw is supposed to have happened from striking some piece of a wreck, as several logs were seen floating about at the time.
lead_paragraph: The prolonged absence of the steamship Australasian, which left Liverpool on the 16th ult., and should in due course have reached this port by the 2d inat., has been a source of extreme anxiety on this side of the Atlantic. abstract: The United States storeship Supply, which arrived here some time since with the garrison of the Washington station, left the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, bound for a convenient rendezvous of the Floridian Coast, at which the vessels of the home squadron may be concentrated. The late commander of the Supply,
lead_paragraph: The United States storeship Supply, which arrived here some time since with the garrison of the Washington station, left the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, bound for a convenient rendezvous of the Floridian Coast, at which the vessels of the home squadron may be concentrated. The late commander of the Supply, Capt. WALKE, who was tried by court-martial, has been superseded, and Capt. GIBSON appointed in his place. The cargo of the ship consists of what is called, in naval parlance, "Purser's stores," no ordinance, ammunition, or mechanical affairs being on board. The authorities have been informed that some of the home fleet are suffering for want of provisions. Several of them have been obliged to economise for over five weeks; and it is to be feared that the crews of more than one are on short allowance. Seldom has a vessel taken from this port for any squadron a larger mail than the Supply. The friends and relatives of the different chip's companies seem to regard them engaged in war. The new officers of the Supply are: Commander, ALEXANDER GIBSON; Lieutenants, J.H.B. Caldwell, James G. Maxwell, Alfred Hopkins; Master, John A. Howell; Surgeon, Sanford; Paymaster, E.W. Dunn; Clerks, Vandyke and Bowie.

abstract: ARRESTED FOR PASSING COUNTERFEIT BANK NOTES. -- A young woman, giving the name of Mary Smith, and a man calling himself John Brown, were apprehended on Saturday evening, each charged with having passed a counterfeit five dollar bill, purporting to be the issue of the Continental Bank, Boston, Mass. The woman palmed her counterfeit upon the proprietor of the drug store, No. 330 Second-avenue, in payment for a quarter's worth of medicine, while the other prisoner invested one of the notes at a shoe store kept at No. 324 Hudson-street. It is thought that other tradespeople have been swindled by the accused, and Justice CONNOLLY has temporarily committed them to afford opportunity for complainants to appear.
lead_paragraph: ARRESTED FOR PASSING COUNTERFEIT BANK NOTES. -- A young woman, giving the name of Mary Smith, and a man calling himself John Brown, were apprehended on Saturday evening, each charged with having passed a counterfeit five dollar bill, purporting to be the issue of the Continental Bank, Boston, Mass. abstract: As most of the Brooklyn Irish Societies decided to join the demonstration in New-York, there was no general demonstration in this City. The Ancient Order of Hibernians, to the number of about 800, paraded in full regalia; the Laborers' Union Benevolent Society, to the number of 350; the Shamrock Society and the Napper Tandy Light Artillery, all turned out, marched through some of the principal streets and crossed to New-York. Last evening the Friendly Son's of St. Patrick gave their Annual Dinner at Montague Hall.

abstract: The escape of Capt. LATHAM, of the slave-back Cora, from the custody of the United States DeputyMarshal, was yesterday the theme of general conversation. The only official information yet made public upon the subject, came out yesterday forenoon in the proceedings of the United States Circuit Court.
lead_paragraph: The escape of Capt. LATHAM, of the slave-back Cora, from the custody of the United States DeputyMarshal, was yesterday the theme of general conversation. The only official information yet made public upon the subject, came out yesterday forenoon in the proceedings of the United States Circuit Court. Upon the opening of the Court, United States District-Attorney ROOSEVELT asked the Court to grant a verbal order that the Marshal should come before the Court and make a statement, as one of its officers, of the particulars of the escape of Capt. LATHAM, who had been committed upon a Bench warrant issued out of this Court. In a few moments the Crier brought in the Marshal, who made the following statement: He said that, before leaving for Washington, he gave express orders that none of the prisoners should be taken out of jail on any pretext whatever; and that Capt. LATHAM, particularly, should not be taken out, unless by an order of the District-Attorney, which he knew from experience would not be granted. On his return, Saturday morning, he was informed of the escape of LATHAM from the custody of JOHN CULLIGAN, one of his Deputies. He immediately telegraphed to his Deputy, Mr. THOMPSON, who was then in Washington, directing him to offer a reward of $200 for his arrest, as he suspected the fugitive would go South. The Marshal dismissed CULLIGAN from his office. In excuse for his conduct, CULLIGAN told him (RYNDERS) that "some persons" applied to him saying that LATHAM needed shirts and clothing, and promised him $25 for his trouble if he would get an order to take LATHAM to BROOKS' store in Broadway. CULLIGAN applied to Mr. LOTT, the Clerk in the Marshal's Office, to write an order on Mr. MCLEOD, Keeper of Eldridge-street Jail, to take him out. LOTT wrote the order, and with it CULLIGAN went to the jail, and, on presenting it to MOLSOD, Capt. LATHAM was permitted to go with him. All this was entirely contrary to the Marshal's orders. CULLIGAN then took the Captain to the store corner of Grand-street and Broadway, and upon his arrival "some persons," before referred to, told Capt. L. that he might select a suit of clothes for himself, and while he was doing so, at a moment when the attention of the Deputy was diverted, he escaped from the store to a carriage, in which he was driven off. Subsequently CULLIGAN obtained the assistance of a police-officer, and walked up and down Broadway in search of the missing Captain.

abstract: The principal part of the celebration of "St. Patrick's Day in the morning," yesterday, took place in the afternoon and evening.
lead_paragraph: The principal part of the celebration of "St. Patrick's Day in the morning," yesterday, took place in the afternoon and evening. By daylight, the forces of the Emerald Islanders that inhabit hereabouts paraded in force, and by gas-light there was eating, and drinking, and speech-making, and dancing, to the sacred memory of the sainted Patrick. Ever since the distant direful day on which the good man who drove the snakes from Ireland lay down to feed the worms, those whom he benefited, and their descendants have annually honored the day on which he was born, and religiously regretted that on which he want to.

abstract: FIRE IN A SILK BONNET MANUFACTORY. A fire was discovered, about 6 o'clock last evening, on the fifth floor of the building No. 75 Trinity-place, occupied by BALDWIN NIVRN, manufacturers of silk bonnets and artificial flowers.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN A SILK BONNET MANUFACTORY. -- A fire was discovered, about 6 o'clock last evening, on the fifth floor of the building No. 75 Trinity-place, occupied by BALDWIN NIVRN, manufacturers of silk bonnets and artificial flowers. In consequence of the difficulty in obtaining access to the building, considerable time elapsed before the firemen could bring the water to bear upon the flames, but when this was finally accomplished, it did not take much time to extinguish the fire. The floor below was also occupied by the same firm, and the damage to the stock will probably amount to about $1,500; fully insured. The second and third floors, extending through to Broadway, known as No, 47, and also the fourth and fifth floors on Broadway, are occupied by CHARLES MILES. dealer in straw goods. His loss is estimated at $500 from water; insured for over $50,000 in various City Companies. The damage to Mr. MILES' stock would have been very great had it not been for the activity of the Insurance Payrol, in removing the goods and covering them with oil cloths. The first floor, basement, and cellar of the premises are occupied by [???]. T. FISS & Co., dealers in hats, whose stock was slightly injured by water, probably to the amount of $500; insured for $100,000 in various Companies. The injury to the building is estimated at $600 to $700. Mr. HENRY O. BAKER. Assistant Fire Marshal, investigated the cause of the fire and found that it had originated in a pile of rubbish. Mr. BALDWIN [???] of the proprietors of the manufactory, was the last person who left the premises, having shut up only a few minutes previous to the discovery of the fire.

abstract: A convict made his escape from Sing Sing yesterday afternoon between 1 and 2 o'clock. He was soon missed, and a search made, but he could not be found. It was supposed that he escaped on board a vessel which had left the prison dock loaded with shocks, bound for New-Haven. Officers are in search of him, and dispatches were at once sent to different places along the river describing the sloop, with orders to detain her.

abstract: We chronicled a few weeks ago the involuntary retirement to Sing Sing of a puissant knight of the revolver, who will doubtless be restored before many hours to that society which he had previously graced.
lead_paragraph: We chronicled a few weeks ago the involuntary retirement to Sing Sing of a puissant knight of the revolver, who will doubtless be restored before many hours to that society which he had previously graced. Unfortunately Judge GOULD, who sent the redoubtable BILLY MULLIGAN to State Prison, in his zeal for purifying the immoral atmosphere of the Metropolitan Criminal Courts, lost sight of, or over-stepped some principles of law, which his usual perspicacity would have induced him to heed under different circumstances. At the General Term of the Supreme Court, to which the case had been taken on exceptions to the rulings of Judge GOULD, a decision was yesterday rendered, granting the motion of the prisoner's counsel for a new trial.

abstract: Several important foreign appointments were yesterday sent to the Senate for confirmation among them those of CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS...
lead_paragraph: Several important foreign appointments were yesterday sent to the Senate for confirmation -- among them those of CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS as Minister to London, WILLIAM L. DAYTON as Minister to France, GEORPE P. MARSH as Minister to Sardinia, JAMES WATSON WEBB as Minister to Constantinople, and WILLIAM S. THAYER as Consul General at Alexandria. It is understood that Mr. ADAMS has already signified his acceptance. The mission to France, it was expected, would be conferred upon Mr. FREMONT; but it being uncertain, under the present condition of that gentleman's private affairs, that he could remain abroad for four years, it was decided best to confer the mission upon some other person. Mr. CORWIN is rapidly recovering his health, and it is now considered certain that he will accept the Mexican Mission.
