abstract: Under existing circumstances, the customary preparatory time allowed to newly-appointed officers in the Army and Navy must be curtailed.
lead_paragraph: Under existing circumstances, the customary preparatory time allowed to newly-appointed officers in the Army and Navy must be curtailed. Those gentlemen, therefore, who have recently obtained commissions and appointments in either branch of the service, will get themselves in readiness for immediate orders, resignations and other contingencies having largely diminished force in the duty rolls. The following named officers, recently promoted, have been ordered to proceed, without delay, to join their proper stations, viz.; Lieut. Mercer, First Dragoons, to Fort Crooke; Capt. Tyler, Second Dragoons, to Fort Laramie; Lieut. Emroy, First Cavalry, to Fort Cebb; Capt. Ransom, do., to Fort Arbuckle, C.N.; Lieut. Thompson, do., to Fort Wise, Kansas; Lieut. Riddick, do., to Fort Wise, Kansas; Capt. Hatch, Mounted Riflemen, to Fort Stanton, N.M.; Capt. Wilcox, Seventh Infantry, to Fort Craig, N.M.; Lieut. Taylor, Eighth Infantry, to Fort Breckinridge, N.M.; Major Whiting, Tenth Infantry, to Santa Fe; Capt. Marshall, do., to Fort Laramie, N.T.; Lieut. W. Rossell, Tenth Infantry, to Camp Floyd, U.T. Lieuts. A.M. Randall and J.M. Wilson, have been retransferred to the Artillery -- the former to the Third Regiment and the latter to the First Regiment. Paymaster A.J. Smith, Eleventh Infantry, has been ordered to Washington.

abstract: St. GEORGES, Bermuda, March 6. The ship Virginia Dare has restowed sound cargo, and is now reloading damaged tobacco and flour, (unsold) The bark Ida. Kimball has had stern temporarily repaired, and is now...
lead_paragraph: St. GEORGES, Bermuda, March 6. -- The ship Virginia Dare has restowed sound cargo, and is now reloading damaged tobacco and flour, (unsold) The bark Ida. Kimball has had stern temporarily repaired, and is now discharging cargo of staves. She will proceed in ballast to Rockland, for full repairs. Schr. Arietus, from New-York for Jacmel, has had mainmast temporarily refitted, and will proceeed, under short sails. The ship Cygnet. from Manila for New-York, has had her top sides thoroughly recaulked, and worn-out pumps replaced with good, sound second-hand ones, and will be ready for sea this week. Schr. A. F. Linnell, from New-York for Valencia, Spain, is at Hamilton in a leaky condition; has suffered considerable damage; lost sails, &acc. Will probably discharge a portion of cargo, and undergo thorough repairs.

abstract: Mr. T. BUTLER KING left this port for Europe, in a recent steamer, to be immediately followed by WILLIAM L. YANCEY, P.A. ROST, and A. DUDLEY MANN, Commissioners, for the purpose of presenting the new Confederacy to...
lead_paragraph: Mr. T. BUTLER KING left this port for Europe, in a recent steamer, to be immediately followed by WILLIAM L. YANCEY, P.A. ROST, and A. DUDLEY MANN, Commissioners, for the purpose of presenting the new Confederacy to the favorable consideration of the old world, and of opening the era of "direct trade with Europe," so long sighed for at the South. Mr. KING was long a prominent Whig politician in Georgia, and afterward Collector of the port of San Francisco. On leaving this office he turned a somerset into the Democratic ranks, and followed that party into secession. His most recent exploit was in connection with the Southern Pacific Railroad. It is enough to say that he left each one of the specialties named with a greatly weakened reputation. His associates have been less conspicuousyl before the public, but they are all known to be first-class dreamers seeking to effect by some charm or incantation what elsewhere comes of hard work. That everything valuable costs in proportion, is a lesson our Southern brethren can never learn. Mr. A. DUDLEY MANN has been laboring, we know not how many years, to realize that philosopher's stone, to reach that perennial fountain of wealth and felicity -- " direct trade." How eloquently has he painted the beauty of the Sunny South, its vast productiveness, and its spacious harbor of Norfolk, and how this should be the centre of the commercial system of the United States. But all this vast wealth the barbarous hordes at the North remorselessly devour, while the Lower Chesapeake is still the favorite haunt of the canvas-back as it was two hundred years ago, undisturbed by the busy life and hum of industry, that frightened it long ago from Northern waters.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Alderman was held last evening, President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair. As many of the members desired to partake of the annual dinner given by the St. Patrick's Society, there...
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Board of Alderman was held last evening, President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair. As many of the members desired to partake of the annual dinner given by the St. Patrick's Society, there was but little disposition to transact business, and consequently the Board was in session only a short time. The Comptroller was directed to advertise for proposals for the lease of the bulkhead, belonging to the City, at the foot of Fulton-street, for the term of ten years. A petition, asking to have the limits of the proposed park on Prospect Hill extended, so as to make it a better shape, was laid on the table. table Law Committee was authorized to settle the claim of PETERS against the city for damages occasioned by the emptying of the Bond-street sewer upon his land. He claims that he has sustained damage to the amount of $5,000. The Chief-Engineer of the Eastern District Fire Department submitted his annual report, which represents that branch of the service to be in a creditable state of efficiency. The Department consists of one Chief-Engineer, five Assistant Engineers and 812 men. There are 12 engine companies, 8 hose companies, 3 hook-and-ladder companies -- making in all 23 companies in active service. There is in charge of the Department 285 lengths of hose; 100 lengths (5,000 feet) are in ordinary condition, and 85 lengths (4,250 feet) in bad condition; 280 lengths (14,000 feet) are required to make the complement of the Department complete. The Chief-Engineer calls for 5,000 feet for immediate use. During the last year there were 571 bell and 33 still alarms and 51 fires. The report was referred to the Fire Department Committee, and the Board adjourned for one week.

abstract: The Conven SECESSION AND THE PEOPLE. The Conven tion of Louisiana has decided not to submit the Constitution of the new Confederacy to the vote of the people.
lead_paragraph: -- The Convention of Louisiana has decided not to submit the Constitution of the new Confederacy to the vote of the people. This refusal is in spite of the request of the Legislature that it might be submitted. In the Alabama Convention the same subject is warmly discussed, and it seems probable that the same result will be reached.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- There are few plays in the modern repertoire that can equal in interest of plot, neatness of dialogue, or clearness of characterization, the "Wife's Secret," produced here last evening. In the long range of "star" attractions it is, perhaps, the only work that has not been thoroughly debased by inapt selections and inefficient performance. It escaped this fate last evening, and was really produced in a very satisfactory way. The cast was as good as we have ever had it in New-York, and in some respects much better. Especially was this the case in the two principal characters, Lady Eveline (Miss JANE COOMES) and Sir Walter, (Mr. JAB. W. WALLACK, JR.,) which were most ably interpreted. The lady in particular is, we are sure, seen to greater advantage in the "Wife's Secret," and allows to her genius more unrestrained sway than in any other play she has yet essayed. Her success was correspondingly great, as it always must be under such circumstances. Mr. J.W. WALLACK's interpretation of a part alternately severe and emotional, was to our judgment perfect. This gentleman's clear and intellectual insight into character is not the least of his merits as an actor. His style, too, is quiet, peculiarly so in this piece.

abstract: A dispatch from the Washington correspondent of the Associated Press, informs us that it has been ascertained from a reliable quarter the source of the information, however, does not appear that Fort Sumpter is to be evacuated today, the necessary orders to that effect having already gone forward. Should this report prove
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from the Washington correspondent of the Associated Press, informs us that it has been ascertained from a reliable quarter -- the source of the information, however, does not appear -- that Fort Sumpter is to be evacuated today, the necessary orders to that effect having already gone forward. Should this report prove to be correct, the public anxiety relative to that point at least will soon be relieved. Our own correspondent, however, asserts that no decision has as yet been reached. With regard to Fort Pickens, it appears that the numerous assertions that it was to be immediately attacked by the Southern forces have been without foundation. The Montgomery Commissioners now in Washington state that they are in the receipt of assurances from persons in authority that no attack is at present contemplated. The Commissioners, it is understood, do not expect any definite answer to their application for recognition for ten or twelve days.

abstract: NATIONAL GYMNASIUM EXHIBITION. A large audience of ladies and gentlemen assembled at the National Gymnasium in Kitcherbocker Hall corner of Twenty-third street and Eighth-avenue last evening, to witness the performances of a choosen corps of the pupils of Mr. B. FRANKLIN BEACH, the proprietor.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL GYMNASIUM EXHIBITION. -- A large audience of ladies and gentlemen assembled at the National Gymnasium in Kitcherbocker Hall corner of Twenty-third street and Eighth-avenue last evening, to witness the performances of a choosen corps of the pupils of Mr. B. FRANKLIN BEACH, the proprietor. The exhibition was a testimonial to him for his efficient efforts in the cause of physical education. Mr. WM. P. HALSTED, President of the organization formed for the purpose of offering Mr. BEACH this gratifying taken of appreciation, opened the exercises with a brief address on the advantages of gymnastic culture, and a practical exemplification of them followed. About twenty young gentlemen, [???] limbed, [???] eyed came forward and engaged in the exhibition on the ladders, rings, bars, inclined [???] trapeze, the clack-rope, the vaulting-horse, and with dumb bells, in groupings, tumbling and [???] Most noteworthy among the amateurs, all of whom has received their training at this gymnasium, were Messrs. Bennett, Weir, Halsted, Ryder, Chevalter, Lofferts, Allison, Tejada, Bogert, Benoing, Mr. Beach himself and a youthful prodigy of strength and agility [???]. A band of music [???] to the enjoyment of the occasion, which [???] altogether a very delightful one. Another exhibition will be given to-morrow evening.

lead_paragraph: The author of Eothen's long-promised book on the Russian War, takes definite shape in Mr. MURRAY's announcement as the History of the Invasion of the Crimea., by ALEXANDER WILLIAM KINGLAKE, M.P. Volume 1, "containing a narrative of the transactions which brought on war between Russia and the Western Powers," is said to be nearly ready, but no intimation is yet given of the probable extent of the work. Earl STANHOPE (better known to historical readers as Lord MAHON) has made more progress in his Life of Rt. Hon. William Pitt, with extracts from his Unpublished Correspondence and MSS. Papers. The whole will form three volumes, small octavo, and volumes one and two are now ready.

abstract: AN ALDERMAN ON TRIAL FOR WILLFUL VIOLATION OF HIS OFFICIAL DUTY. In the Kings County Court of Sessions, yesterday, the case of DANIEL GREEN, indicted to willful violation of official duty, was called on for trial. The defendant is an Alderman, and represent the Tenth Ward of Brooklyn in the Common Council Chamber. As such officer, as authorized by the City Charter, he entered into con
lead_paragraph: AN ALDERMAN ON TRIAL FOR WILLFUL VIOLATION OF HIS OFFICIAL DUTY. -- In the Kings County Court of Sessions, yesterday, the case of DANIEL GREEN, indicted to willful violation of official duty, was called on for trial. The defendant is an Alderman, and represent the Tenth Ward of Brooklyn in the Common Council Chamber. As such officer, as authorized by the City Charter, he entered into contract with one JAMES MUSTAGH, May, 7, 1860, to clean the streets of the Tenth Ward for one year, remove a 1 garbage, ashes, &c., once each week and oftener, if required, at the rate of $3,000 per annum, to be paid as follows: $300 on the 15th of June, 1860; $250 on the 7th of August, and the like sum on the 7th of each succeeding month, until the 7th of May, 1861. Before a contractor can draw the payments, the Alderman of a ward is required to certify in each case that the work for the previous month has been properly done, and the indictment alleges that the defendant, on the 7th of November, 1860, did "unlawfully, falsely and corruptly," certify that the work of the contractor was properly done for the previous month, when, in fact, the indictment alleges the contractor had wholly failed performing his duty, and the defendant knew it. The Corporation Counselor appeared for the accused, and proven to quash the indictment, on the ground that it did not allege that the streets or any particular part of the Ward needed cleaning, and that the mere omission to clean the streets every week, did not practically, amount to a negligence of duty on the part of the contractor, if the streets were really clean, and there were no ashes, &c., to be removed; that the departure from the mere letter of the contract was not material, and further, the ticket itself was [???] as it conferred no authority on the Comptroller to pay the bid. The motion was denied, and the case was proceeded with, and will probably occupy the attention of the Court for several days. It is proper to state that when the indictment was returned by the Grino Jury, Alderman, GELEN demanded an investigation of the case in the Board of Aldermen, when a Special Committee, appointed for the purpose, reported, exculpating him from all [???].

abstract: Hon. HORACE GREELEY delivered an address before this Club, at its regular weekly meeting in Cooper Institute last evening. After a song from Mr. ANDERSON, Mr. GREELEY was introduced, and prefaced his speech with some sarcastic remarks about the crisis through which the country was passing at the present time, and the number of times the Union had been "saved" during the last twenty years.
lead_paragraph: Hon. HORACE GREELEY delivered an address before this Club, at its regular weekly meeting in Cooper Institute last evening. After a song from Mr. ANDERSON, Mr. GREELEY was introduced, and prefaced his speech with some sarcastic remarks about the crisis through which the country was passing at the present time, and the number of times the Union had been "saved" during the last twenty years. The sole cause of this last crisis, so far as he could discover, was the fact that the Republicans had elected a President whom the South did not like. And they had a very good reason for not liking him, which was that they did not know him. The South claimed that, although the election was constitutional in form, it was, nevertheless, against the spirit of that instrument. And why? Simply because a Northern man had been elected by Northern votes. Now, for his part, he tried to have a Southern man nominated at Chicago; [laughter;] but admitting, for argument's sake, that the election of a Northern President by Northern votes was contrary to the spirit of the Constitution, it was clear that the South were solely responsible for the event. It was only by their acts at the Charleston Convention, in breaking up the Democratic party, that the success of the Republican party became possible; and the very men who were most active in the secession movement were the men who persisted in breaking up that party. The truth was, secession was a foregone conclusion with the men who initiated and carried on the movement, and had nothing to do with the "sectionalism" of the Republican party. Mr. GREELY then proceeded to argue that concession, by the Republicans, was useless; that no concession short of an acknowledgment that slavery is a blessing, and that we would do all we could to help them extend it, would be at all satisfactory, or have the effect of disarming the Secessionists. The question at the present time, then, was Union or no Union. Now, for one, he believed there were things of more importance than Union. Truth was higher than the Union; so was justice. The only Union worth preserving was that which submitted to a constitutional administration of the Government and the enforcement of the laws. As for compromise, it was not to be thought of on the platform of the Secessionists. Every man engaged in that movement deserved to be hung He might, perhaps, consent to so far compromise as to hang half of them. [Laughter and applause.] Three fourths of the press of this City were in favor of reconstruction, but how was the thing to be brought about? Were we to reinstate General TWIGGS as a general in the United States Army? Were honorable officers to be compelled to serve under such a man as that? There was no middle ground between obedience to the laws and rebelion against the laws. Mr. LINCOLN, as President of the United States, was entitled to obedience from Texas as well as from Vermont. Any compromise with treason would be a quasi admission of its justice, and would utterly debauch and demoralize the Government. The Government would then be a mere rope of sand, the United States only a series of dissolving views, the Union but a rainbow, visible one moment and vanished the next. Those who talked of compromise and reconstitution, were the most dangerous, because the most sneaking of traitors. How the presentstate of affairs was to end he could not tell; it might terminate in strife, perhaps in bloodshed, but their duty as Republicans was clear. Their course heretofore had been legal, constitutional and just; they had nothing to atone for, no apologies to offer, no compromises to make, and as in the past, so in the future, they should go on doing sign, acting justly, and having the consequences to God. [Applause.]

abstract: M. LAGUERONNIERE's pamphlet, France, Rome and Italy, was the gauntlet which LOUIS NAPOLEON threw among the French Bishops, and the bold prelate of Poitiers has promptly covered it with a gage of battle in the form of a pastoral letter to the clergy of his diocese, in which he prohibits the reading of the obnoxious document as a crime, formally pronounces his malediction upon it, and passing by M. LAGUERONNIERE as a mere alias, treats the Emperor in person to one of the most tremendous tirades that petulance ever dictated or insolence uttered; for the logic is the logic of petulance, and the language the language of insolence. It augurs well for social and political progress in France that a priest can with impunity lampoon an Emperor in every chapel of his diocese on the same day, and send so many congregations home with the startling impression that LOUIS NAPOLEON means Pontius Pilate. Monseigneur of Poitiers is evidently a frantic zealot, if he is not a shrewd candidate for martyrdom, who would carry off the honors of political persecution by a coup de main. The provocation should be much greater than it is to excuse the phrenzy of his phraseology, which bursts out at last in a bluster of blasphemy that only a passionate Bishop could flourish; as if that were but a professional technicality in him, which would be a gross indecency in a layman.

lead_paragraph: The American public has been unwilling to believe in the corruption of the Canadian Government. Partisan charges are easily fabricated, and it is difficult for strangers to tell whether they are true or false. Apart from the representations of the Canadian Press on either side, it was known to American tourists that charges of the most gross political dishonesty were made in the Provincial Parliament; that in some cases they were merely evaded, and in others denied, but the denial was coupled with assertions directly contradicted by such an irrefutable mass of Parliamentary evidence, as left no room for doubt in the minds of impartial hearers. Such individual cases as these are as nothing in comparison with the gross amount of dishonesty which has recently been officially exposed by a careful investigation into the affairs of the Grand Trunk Railroad.
headline: {'main': 'Recent Exposure of Canadian Politics.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Recent Exposure of Canadian Politics.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The present moment is an era of political change and dismemberment, both in the Old World and the New. In the Old the rapid advance of the working classes in means and intelligence, is scattering to the winds fossilized despotisms deaf to every appeal for reform, and exacting great concessions from rulers who have the sense to estimate the manifest tendencies of the age. The most
lead_paragraph: The present moment is an era of political change and dismemberment, both in the Old World and the New. In the Old the rapid advance of the working classes in means and intelligence, is scattering to the winds fossilized despotisms deaf to every appeal for reform, and exacting great concessions from rulers who have the sense to estimate the manifest tendencies of the age. The most emphatic tribute paid to this tendency hasbeen by the most powerful potentate of Europe, whose iron will is backed by half a million of men in arms. But France expands in intelligence and wealth, and must have an enlarged articulation for their proper use. With a far-seeing wisdom, her master anticipates the demand, and in this way confirms his power. In Italy an unrelenting despot has been swept from his throne. Absolute Russia for a time, at least, foregoes her traditional policy, to enfranchise millions of her subjects. In every country in Europe this tendency towards greater freedom for the people proceeds with resistless stride, strengthening those who favor it, but destroying those who resist. It is simply according to man the privileges that belong to the higher places he has gained, and with them the power of enforcing, if need be, his rights.

abstract: Judge SHIPMAN, of the U.S. Circuit Court, yesterday, on motion of judge ROOSEVELT, summoned before him Mr. LOTT, the acting clerk in the Marshal's office, in relation to his alleged agency in the escape of Capt. LATHAM. Judge ROOSEVELT questioned LOTT, who merely confired the particulars of the case, which have already been made public.
lead_paragraph: Judge SHIPMAN, of the U.S. Circuit Court, yesterday, on motion of Judge ROOSEVELT, summoned before him Mr. LOTT, the acting clerk in the Marshal's office, in relation to his alleged agency in the escape of Capt. LATHAM. Judge ROOSEVELT questioned LOTT, who merely confired the particulars of the case, which have already been made public. The Judge suggested that CULLIGAN should be arrested and brought to trial. Marshal RYNDERS agreed that an investigation should be made, and was willing to make the complaint on which to issue the warrant, if a simple declaration that he (CULLIGAN) had wrongfully permitted the prisoner to escape were sufficient, but not knowing more than anybody else on the subject, he could not swear that he had been corruptly influenced, and he would not do so to please anyone. Judge SHIPMAN said he was sorry there was no one to make the complaint, and the investigation here closed. Afterwards Capt. RYNDERS signed the proper complaint, and a warrant was issued by Commissioner BETTS, which the Marshal placed in the hands of Mr. DOWDEGAN, with directions to serve it at once. Mr. CULLIGAN, it is said, has expressed his willingness to have the whole matter thoroughly investigated. He will now have an opportunity. Marshal RYNDERS informally stated to Judge ROSEVELT and others, who were present in the Court-room, that he learned at BROOKS store that a short time before LATHAM arrived at his' place on Friday afternoon, a rather aged man, with gray hair and whiskers, who appeared to be a Spaniard, came into his place and began to look about as if to make some purchases. On being spoken to, he made an evasive reply. When LATHAM and CALLIGAN came in this person recognized LATHAM and showed that he was in some way connected with him. While LATHAM and his friend was looking at some shirts and hose, one of the party told CULLIGAN he might select a pair of pants for himself, by way of rewarding him for the trouble he had been at. CULLIGAN then selected a pair which suited him, and stepped behind the curtain to try them on. While he was in that place LATHAM and his friend stepped out of the door, entered a carriage, which was evidently waiting for them, and drove off. Without his pantaloons, the officer was in no state of preparation to follow the prisoner.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon a drunken fireman encountered a Frenchman, who was peddling candies at the corner of Ann and Nassau streets, and out of sheer mischief, caught his tray and upset the contents in the mud. The wanton act was witnessed by several persons, who gathered about the discomfited confectioner, and pretty soon a Second Ward policeman came up to learn what had happened.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon a drunken fireman encountered a Frenchman, who was peddling candies at the corner of Ann and Nassau streets, and out of sheer mischief, caught his tray and upset the contents in the mud. The wanton act was witnessed by several persons, who gathered about the discomfited confectioner, and pretty soon a Second Ward policeman came up to learn what had happened. He was informed, but meantime the ruffian who had occasioned the mischief had taken refuge in the Chester House, No. 38 Ann-street. The policeman told the Frenchman that he had no power to arrest the offender, as he did not see the offence committed, and advised him to go to the Tombs Police Court and get a warrant. While this parley was in progress four other policemen, reached the place, and almost at the same moment the fireman came from his hiding-place, having exchanged his fireman's uniform for citizen's clothes. His disguise, however, was not sufficient to prevent his being recognized by the crowd, who pointed him out to the police and demanded his arrest. Two or three of the officers attempted to make the man a prisoner, but he ran down a flight of cellar steps, and having gained the bottom, placed his firsts a la Heenan, and dared the police to approach him. Although by this time six or seven policemen had come up, not one of them was brave enough to attempt the apprehension of the drunken man, until a Sergeant came and insisted that it should be done. It was then finally accomplished, after the ruffian had defied the police for at least fifteen minutes. Such an instance of craven imbecility does not frequently occur.

abstract: Theodore Beuder, a German, was arrested on Friday last in First-avenue, charged with passing counterfeit half and quarter dollars. Yesterday he appeared before U.S. Commissioner STILWELL, and offered for $1,000 surety two persons named Louis Kline and Andres Beyer, who were willing to swear to being worth $1,000 each, but upon investigation the Commissioner refused to accept them, and Beuder was again committed.

abstract: The Richmond Whig exposes the fraud which was practiced in the Petersburgh election, of which so much has been said. The tickets cast by the Secessionists bore these words: "Election March 13th, 14th, 15th for C.F. Collier's Resolutions."
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Whig exposes the fraud which was practiced in the Petersburgh election, of which so much has been said. The tickets cast by the Secessionists bore these words: "Election -- March 13th, 14th, 15th -- for C.F. Collier's Resolutions." COLLIER's resolutions, which were thus indorsed, were simply a denial of the doctrine that negroes are not property under the United States Constitution, and do not at all pretend to instruct the delegates in Convention to vote for immediate secession.

lead_paragraph: Gov. HICKS, of Maryland, has written a letter to Mr. WM. PRICE, denying that he has been or intends to be an applicant for office under the new Administration; that he has indorsed no candidate, nor will he do so unless his advice is asked by the appointing power; that he has never prepared, or begun to prepare, a proclamation to the people regarding the crisis, consequently none could have been destroyed, as was reported, and that had he ever doubted the correctness of the stand taken by him regarding the call of a Convention he should consider his course as fully indorsed by the refusal of Delaware, Kentucky, Tennessee and North Carolina to call Conventions.

abstract: There is evidently a misunderstanding regarding the disposal of the $15,000,000 loan asked for by the C.S.A. Nearly a week ago we were informed on good telegraphic authority that the entire amount had been taken by New-Orleans capitalists at a premium of 5 per cent., and yet we find a communication in the Crescent of the 16th, imploring the faithful most piteously to walk up to the captain's office and settle. Among the arguments adduced in favor of this course are these: "That the tax is easily assessed and cannot be evaded;" "that the rate of interest, 8 per cent., is that which usually obtains in the South even in times which are not freed from commercial embarrassments;" and the writer adds, rising to the sublime height of impudence, "this rate exceeds that accepted recently by the capitalists of New-York upon a loan to the United States, with its empty treasury, heavy debt, and disrupted, revolutionary condition!" But as if this were not enough, this ardent political economist appeals to God to forbid that the C.S.A. should ask for money in vain, and with the seizure of the forts and the theft of millions of United States property and funds fresh in his memory, urges the people to remember "that this is a loan upon Southern faith, which has never yet been tarnished."

abstract: The positive assertion that Port Sumpter was to evacuated yesterday appears to have had no foundation in fact, and the whole matter now rests in just as much uncertainty as ever. It is probable, however, if the order for evacuation has not been actually issued, it soon will be. This is the prevailing impression among prominent Republican Senators, who admit -- so our Washington correspondent informs us -- that this step has been definitely settled upon. Advices received from Montgomery assert that the condition of affairs at Fort Pickens has been much misrepresented -- that the danger of collision is not at all imminent; that, on the contrary, the best feeling exists between the garrison of the Fort and the Southern forces. It may be as well, however, to receive such reports, coming from Montgomery, with a grain of allowance.
lead_paragraph: The positive assertion that Port Sumpter was to evacuated yesterday appears to have had no foundation in fact, and the whole matter now rests in just as much uncertainty as ever. abstract: Our City Fathers, it will be seen, have sought to symbolize their own estimate of their own merits in the purest and most valuable of metals.
lead_paragraph: -- Our City Fathers, it will be seen, have sought to symbolize their own estimate of their own merits in the purest and most valuable of metals. Discarding the massive silver badge of last year, and all preceding years, Rear-Admiral BOOLE, the entertainer of the Turkish Ambassador, of the Japanese Princes and the Prince of Wales, and the builder of scow fleets uncertain of destination, -- will hereafter flame amazement through our fashionable thoroughfares with a star of virgin gold scattering its effulgence from the left side of his impeccable breast. "Fit emblem," all will say -- at least such is BOOLE'S hope -- "fit emblem of the golden Aldermanic nature, or Aldermanic nature crapulous of gold, which beats within the distinguished wearer's veins!"

abstract: EXTENSIVE SWINDLE BY A RUNNER MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE On Friday last a German, about 70 years of age, arrived in Jersey City by the New-York and Erie cars, on his way to Germany.
lead_paragraph: EXTENSIVE SWINDLE BY A RUNNER -- MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE -- On Friday last a German, about 70 years of age, arrived in Jersey City by the New-York and Erie cars, on his way to Germany. As is alleged, he was met at the cars by a runner named WM. BASCHE, who keeps an office in Exchange-place. The old man was induced to go to this office with BASCHE, and there bargained for a passage ticket in the steamer which was to sail on the following day. He had with him a draft for $1,200 on a New-York bank, which BASCHE got possession of to get it cashed, and out of which he was to receive the passage money. The old man then went to a German boarding-house in Mercer-street, near Greene, with his baggage. BASCHE deposited the draft in his own name at the Mechanics' and Traders' Bank in Jersey City, and on Monday he drew the money, since which time he has been missing. The old man has not been seen or heard of since Saturday morning last, and his baggage still remains at the boarding-house. The matter was brought before Justice BEDFORD, yesterday, by a partner of BASCHE'S, but as the old man was the only person that could make a complaint, the Judge could do nothing in the matter.

abstract: The refusal of the leaders of the secession movement to submit their new Constitution to the popular vote indicates unmistakably their sense of the weakness of their cause. It shows clearly that the whole thing is a conspiracy, and not a movement of the people.
lead_paragraph: The refusal of the leaders of the secession movement to submit their new Constitution to the popular vote indicates unmistakably their sense of the weakness of their cause. It shows clearly that the whole thing is a conspiracy, and not a movement of the people. Those who originated it succeeded in gaining the cooperation of the people at the outset, by taking advantage of the excitement and alarm created among them by the election of a Republican President. But they have no faith in their permanent support of the movement, else they would not take the high-handed measure of refusing to submit the question to their decision.

lead_paragraph: One of THACKERAY's minor heroes was accustomed to decide every question that came up for judgment, by referring to something he had seen or heard while he was an attache at the Court of Pumpernickel. Our neighbor of the Tribune has a similar fashion. He was once member of Congress for three months, -- and the amount of wisdom which he imbibed during that brief period has sufficed for all subsequent emergencies, and bids fair to supply his necessities for the whole of his natural life. abstract: We are glad to see confident statements in intelligent quarters, that the President intends to offer CARL SCHURZ some high and honorable office in recognition of his talents and political services.
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see confident statements in intelligent quarters, that the President intends to offer CARL SCHURZ some high and honorable office in recognition of his talents and political services. We opposed his appointment to Sardinia, or to any of the leading diplomatic posts in Central Europe, not from any disposition to underrate his abilities, but because we considered the circumstances of his past career likely to destroy his usefulness there, and needlessly to embarrass our relations with those countries. Our Government undoubtedly had the right to send him as our Representative to the Government which had exiled him: -- but no one, we presume, would deem it a wise or a friendly act. And our objections to sending him to Sardinia were similar in kind, though less in degree.

abstract: THE BRICK-YARD RIOTERS. Nineteen of the rioters (all Germans) arrested for beating the foreman of a brick-yard, where they have been employed, in Van Brunt-street, gave bail yesterday before Justice BLACHLEY, to appear for examination.
lead_paragraph: THE BRICK-YARD RIOTERS. -- Nineteen of the rioters (all Germans) arrested for beating the foreman of a brick-yard, where they have been employed, in Van Brunt-street, gave bail yesterday before Justice BLACHLEY, to appear for examination. Nearly all of he accused belong to one of the numerous German musical associations in the city, from which society the foreman, for some cause, had recently been expelled; end it is alleged that in consequence of this he was rather overbearing towards those under him who had voted for his expulsion. The wife of one of the parties who considered himself aggrieved, accompanied by the wives of several other workmen of the yard, called upon the foreman for an explanation of his treatment of their husbands, when, it is alleged, he drew a revolver to defend himself, and then the workmen fell upon him and came very near making a case for the Coroner.

abstract: Timid and short-sighted men have been appalled during the last few months by, a vague apprehension that some general social cataclysm was about to burst over the country; that the political imbroglio in the Cotton States was, somehow or other, to lead to a general revolutionary melee of some indefinite kind, and that society itself would perhaps be wrecked in the universal storm. Over and again have the tropical declaimers and presses of the South threatened that, somehow or other, some hydra-headed monster, which they designated as the "dangerous classes" of the North was to be "let loose" among us; that the "brutal masses," whom they represented as untold millions were to be enticed from their dens by the sweet prospect of general plunder and rapine; and that, with such auxiliaries, treason could gain an easy victory in the midst of a general anarchy. On the other hand, again, those unacquainted with the constitution of Southern society have fancied that the black savages and poor whites of the Slave States were but a powder-magazine, which needed only the touch of fire to produce a social explosion from Maryland to Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Timid and short-sighted men have been appalled during the last few months by, a vague apprehension that some general social cataclysm was about to burst over the country; that the political imbroglio in the Cotton States was, somehow or other, to lead to a general revolutionary melee of some indefinite kind, and that society itself would perhaps be wrecked in the universal storm. On the other hand, again, those unacquainted with the constitution of Southern society have fancied that the black savages and poor whites of the Slave States were but a powder-magazine, which needed only the touch of fire to produce a social explosion from Maryland to Mexico.

abstract: -The Special Committee appointed by the lower House of our State Legislature to investigate the charge of an attempt to extort a bribe, made against Hon. JAY GIBBONS, of Albany Country, by the...
lead_paragraph: -- The Special Committee appointed by the lower House of our State Legislature to investigate the charge of an attempt to extort a bribe, made against Hon. JAY GIBBONS, of Albany Country, by the District-Attorney and Assistant District Attorney of Albany City, have reported that, in their judgment, Mr. GIBBONS has been guilty of the offence charged, and have accordingly moved the House for his expulsion. With the conclusions arrived at by the Committee, but few who have read the affidavits on which Mr. GIBBONS was arrested in the criminal suit still pending against him, will feel authorized to differ; but against the indecent haste which demanded the concurrence of the House in the report, without any examination of the evidence, every man possessing the love of justice in his heart must indignantly protest.

abstract: It cannot be denied that there is a growing sentiment throughout the North in favor of letting the Gulf States go. The Abolitionists everywhere have been in favor of a dissolution of the Union from the beginning. They have been hoping that the border States would join the secession movement, and that we should then have two Confederacies, -- one free and the other slave. In this way they think we should rid ourselves of all responsibility for the existence of Slavery, -- deprive it of the protection which it now enjoys under the Federal Constitution, and prepare the way for open warfare upon it. The course of events has led very many persons to concur in the wish for a peaceful separation, who do not at all sympathise with these views of the Abolitionists. The dread of war, the apprehension that collisions may occur between the Federal authorities and the seceding States, -- has, perhaps, more to do with this desire than any other motive. Let us separate in peace, -- let us dissolve the partnership and let the Slave States take care of themselves, rather than run the risks of a civil war, -- is the sentiment and language of thousands who have no sympathy with the ultraists on either side.

She was supplied by the steamtug Rescue, yesterday and proceeded on her voyage. She has the following passengers: Messrs. J.P. Stearns, G.H. Briggs, and Chas J. Oliver, who came to the City yesterday. Capt. MORTON reports that he left Havana on Feb. 16. That night came in collision with British brig Homer, of Windsor, N.S., from Cardenas for New-York, and sunk her in fifteen minutes. Launched a boat and saved all hands. 13th inst. made Fire Island Light, then took the wind from N.E, which increased to a hurricane, and was driven as far South as lat. 38Â° 55', and since then bad northerly winds. Being short of provisions and fuel, put into New-York Bay for a supply. Forty miles E.S.E, from Fire Island passed the wreck of a large vessel.

abstract: Upon learning that a warrant had been issued for his arrest, the late Deputy Marshal CULLIGAN, it is rumored, took the first steamer for Jersey City, in which vicinity he is at present staying at the house of...
lead_paragraph: Upon learning that a warrant had been issued for his arrest, the late Deputy Marshal CULLIGAN, it is rumored, took the first steamer for -- Jersey City, in which vicinity he is at present staying at the house of an acquaintance until he can arrange with some of his friends to become his bail in the sum of $5,000. Unless he succeeds in doing this, he would be subjected to the inconvenience of taking up his abode in the quarters recently vacated by Capt. LATHAM, until the sitting of the Grand Jury. Adopting the theory that, being in New-Jersey, he is out of the United States, he intends, it is understood, to take things easy, until he can arrange his bonds, when he will show himself, and abide the result of an investigation of his conduct. There are strong predictions, on the other hand, that he will continue to make himself scarce hereabout for a long time to come.

abstract: The "Southern-Rights" and State-Convention men in this city met this evening to pass a set of resolutions, as the sentiment of Louisville, prepared by the editor of the Courier, the Grand Secretary of the former Know-Nothing Party and their clique; but...
lead_paragraph: The "Southern-Rights" and State-Convention men in this city met this evening to pass a set of resolutions, as the sentiment of Louisville, prepared by the editor of the Courier, the Grand Secretary of the former Know-Nothing Party and their clique; but they failed, and dispersed without doing or saying anything except in mock show. They were outnumbered and thwarted by the "Submissionists," who kept up an uproar for Mr. GUTHRIE. If the "conditional Secessionists" on and about the stand had let him speak, order would have been restored, and they, too, would have had a hearing. But they threatened Mr. GUTHRIE with personal violence if he attempted to mount the stand. Anyhow, he will be heard tomorrow night. The Secessionists were armed to the teeth. They had on hand many hired bullies and fillibusters, such as Gen. BICKLEY and his Knights of the Golden Circle, to second motions, and do the clapping, shouting and fighting; and they had threatened to knock down and drag out every Union man who should dare open his mouth at their meeting to speak or to vote. They had boasted they would to-night purify Louisville, "the most rotten spot in Kentucky." And their vagabonds had one night this week tied crape to the door of one of our staunchest Union men, J.L. SMYSER, with a card attached bearing this Jacobinic threat: "Death to the Submissionists! Down with the left wing of the Lincoln Party!" Many Unionists, though blameworthy, were consequently so exasperated that they determined that not even "conditional secession" should go forth to-night as the sentiment of the city of Louisville. Regarding secession as the very quintessence of mobocracy, they are resolved to keep down by any means whatever those who are striving directly or indirectly, openly or covertly, to inaugurate mob rule and a reign of terror and of anarchy in Kentucky.

abstract: We chronicled, yesterday, in our dispatches from Washington, the nomination of Gen. WEBB, the Senior Editor of this paper, as Minister to Constantinople. Gen. WEBB is now laboring under an attack of sickness which confines him to his residence, near Tarrytown, but we are informed, that on seeing the announcement of his nomination in the morning papers of yesterday, he immediately telegraphed to Washington, that in no event, would be accept of such an appointment if tendered to him. -- Courier and Enquirer.

abstract: During the first nine weeks of the present year ending on the 4th inst., the City Inspector has reported 3,554 deaths in the City. The average for the first five weeks, (January,) was 397 each week; for the last four weeks, (February,) 392 each week. The returns show a decrease of 856, or 19 per cent. as compared with the same period in 1860.

abstract: THE QUESTION OF FORT SUMPTER. A report was received here, to-day, that the vessel sent to Charleston was not sent to bring away the troops from Fort Sumpter, but contained supplies and reinforcements for Major ANDERSON. The news created quite an excitement, but soon subsided when the report was contradicted.

abstract: The question of Fort Sumpter is still in abeyance or, rather in uncertainty. The Administration is disposed to keep its own counsel in reference to it for which nobody, probably, will blame them, when a too free knowledge of their intentions might be a serious disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: The question of Fort Sumpter is still in abeyance -- or, rather in uncertainty. The Administration is disposed to keep its own counsel in reference to it -- for which nobody, probably, will blame them, when a too free knowledge of their intentions might be a serious disadvantage. Up to Wednesday evening, however, it is pretty certain that no orders for an evacuation had been issued, and our correspondent telegraphs that the matter was discussed in the Cabinet yesterday. We also receive an authoritative contradiction of the statement that an armistice of ten days had been agreed upon between the Southern Commissioners and the Administration. No such armistice has been even thought of, much less suggested -- the Commissioners being content to await the action of the President.

abstract: The Professor's story, Elsie Venner, which has so long lent interest to the pages of the Atlantic Monthly, is published in two neat volumes by TICKNOR FIELDS. In giving it to the public in its entirety, the publishers rather forestall the interest of its continuation in their Magazine, and yet we thank them for the work.
lead_paragraph: The Professor's story, Elsie Venner, which has so long lent interest to the pages of the Atlantic Monthly, is published in two neat volumes by TICKNOR FIELDS. In giving it to the public in its entirety, the publishers rather forestall the interest of its continuation in their Magazine, and yet we thank them for the work. A serial story has ever been our special detestation. We have a horror of anything published in parts. "To be continued," at the close of a magazine article, always has the effect upon us of "keep out," on a room door -- we'd not cross the threshold however inviting the interior might be. It is impossible to keep one's curiosity and interest on the stretch for a month. The manner, too, in which these serial gentlemen of times trifle with the feelings of the public is worthy of grave censure. We have known a heroine, after falling over a steep cliff, to be left hanging by her hoops from the inevitable providential tree until four weeks had rolled their weary round. Now, we submit that there is no reason why the reader should be left in suspense for that time, though the lady was. Again, when an officer is on the track of the inevitable villain, and has nearly reached him, it conflicts with our notions of right and wrong to know that the hands of Justice and the officer, are to be arrested for a month. In that interim a thousand things may happen. The author may die, or the reader may. In either event we should be debarred from learning the offender's fate, and the previous time spent in industriously following at his heels would be irretrievably lost. There is only one incomplete work, as an addendum to which the announcement of a continuation finds a welcome and an appropriate place. When in good man's labors are suspended, when the tears have been shed and the sod pressed above his breast, it will then do to write on the tablet at his head,

abstract: In calling upon the Cabinet for their separate opinions in writing as to the proposed evacuation of Fort Sumpter, the President has, we think, taken a step in the direction of a salutary administrative authority, and that independent responsibility which must tend to impose a check on the heads of Department, and hold them to individual account before the country. We have a sound republican objection to the name and the thing "Cabinet Council," for though certainly Republican enough in its suggestion of genial cigars and boots familiarly elevated, there is in the spirit of it an aristocratic twang, which if it had not already proved repulsive to the simple good sense of the earlier Presidents, had certainly not recommended itself to them by any qualities which should be acceptable to Executive minds. It was WASHINGTON's wont as to grave measures of State policy to address letters to his several Secretaries and so draw out their views in carefully digested replies, which should thenceforth stand recorded, to enhance or disparage their wisdom or their patriotism. There was no mysterious laying together of departmental heads in cozy corners of the White House, no aying and noing, no pairing off and dividing, no diplomatic bulling and bearing, no voting at the next Presidency, and taking the bearings of important questions through a four years' telescope. The separate views, and the reasons for them, once submitted to the Executive, the decision rested with him, and it was rendered with a full sense of Executive accountability, and no lack of that dignified self-reliance with which the confidence of the country should inspire the man whom a free people have placed at its head.

It was WASHINGTON's wont as to grave measures of State policy to address letters to his several Secretaries and so draw out their views in carefully digested replies, which should thenceforth stand recorded, to enhance or disparage their wisdom or their patriotism. abstract: A few days since a man, apparently under the influence of liquor, called upon the Sheriff of Detroit, and told him an incoherent story about some murder which had been perpetrated in that city.
lead_paragraph: -- A few days since a man, apparently under the influence of liquor, called upon the Sheriff of Detroit, and told him an incoherent story about some murder which had been perpetrated in that city. Thinking that he might know more than he would care to tell when sober, the Sheriff locked him up. He has just received a note from the prisoner, saying that two men with whom he had been carousing had frightened him by threatening to have him arrested for a murder, and that, with the intention of forestalling their action, he had gone to the Sheriff to tell him of the affair. In conclusion, he says: "I am not a quarrelsome man, but, like most others, am not free from fault -- whisky is my "besetting sin." Should you consider this satisfactory, I hope you will let me out of this infernal bedlam, and I will depart a wiser and a better man, remembering, too, that when wine is in, wit is out." The Sheriff let him go.

abstract: A casualty, which was fortunately not attended with fatal results, occurred Wednesday evening at the draw-bridge of the New-York and Erie Railroad, which crosses the Hackensack River, about 7 miles from Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: A casualty, which was fortunately not attended with fatal results, occurred Wednesday evening at the draw-bridge of the New-York and Erie Railroad, which crosses the Hackensack River, about 7 miles from Jersey City. The New-York and Hackensack train, consisting of a locomotive, tender, and a very long iron car, in which were about twenty passengers, including two ladies, left Jersey City at 6:35 P.M. Upon approaching the Hackensack bridge, the engineer, BENJAMIN CARLEY, observed white lights standing upon the bridge, but did not see the red ball which was raised as a signal for the train to stop. He was not, therefore, aware of the danger until the locomotive reached the end of the bridge, when he blew the brakes down, but in consequence of the snow and ice on the rails, the wheels did not take hold, and a moment afterwards the locomotive plunged off, and went to the bottom of the river, which, at that point, is 27 feet deep. The engineer went down with it, and sustained severe bruises. He managed to extricate himself, however, and rising to the surface, seized hold of some broken timber, and making his way to a pile was afterwards rescued.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon several workmen in Mr. L. ARNOLD's printing-ink manufactory, No. 61 Ann-street, were severely scalded by the scattering of the contents of a sixty-gallon kettle of oil. The kettle of oil stood upon a small steam-boiler, which exploded and caused the mishap. JOHN EBBS, MOSES PETERSON, and a man named JONES, were all injured, the former so badly that he was removed to the New-York Hospital.

abstract: The business in the United States District-Attorney's office continues to be performed by Judge ROOSEVELT, and his assistant, Mr. HENRY, Messrs. ANDREWS and MACOMBER attending more particularly to the details, which require the drawing of papers, conducting examinations, attending to the records, c., until they are relieved by the new appointees.
lead_paragraph: The business in the United States District-Attorney's office continues to be performed by Judge ROOSEVELT, and his assistant, Mr. HENRY, Messrs. ANDREWS and MACOMBER attending more particularly to the details, which require the drawing of papers, conducting examinations, attending to the records, &c., until they are relieved by the new appointees. Their chief, Judge ROOSEVELT, having resigned, the business of the office, it may well be imagined, in the state of suspense which exists, is by no means in a satisfactory condition. From a sense of courtesy, or of duty to the Government, they continue, however, like dutiful soldiers, at their post, until regularly relieved. Meantime, all the supplies of the office, such as fuel, stationery, &c., have been exhausted, and have to be replenished from the private purse of the District-Attorney.

abstract: Mr. WALDO P. JOHNSON has been elected United States Senator from Missouri, in place of JAMES S. GREEN. The change is, of course, for the better. JOHNSON is a new-comer in the world of politics. Six months ago his name would have fallen without recognition upon the ear of nine out of ten at the State Capital; or if heeded at all would have been known as a small local politician from the Southern or Slaveholding Counties, where he had been an ineffectual candidate for a variety of small offices. His merits consist in the fact that in the long warfare waged by PHELPS, GREEN, and their faction, against BENTON, JOHNSON adhered to the fortunes of the latter, and until the death of his great leader inclined decidedly to the advanced opinions which have given rise to the Free-Soil Party in Missouri. What accident suggested his name to the Governor, we do not know; but he was sent to Washington as a member of the late Peace Conference, where he took no notable part, only achieving distinction upon his return by a rabid and senseless address at Jefferson City, recommending immediate secession. His election can only be regarded as a posthumous triumph of Bentonism -- not the success of any distinguishable principles, or a tribute to any personal claims.

abstract: District Attorney OULD has been retained in office long enough to enable him to show his gratitude to the high ex-official who originally procured his appointment.
lead_paragraph: District Attorney OULD has been retained in office long enough to enable him to show his gratitude to the high ex-official who originally procured his appointment. He has had the pleasure of assisting in the discharge of JOHN B. FLOYD from two indictments, each containing the substance of a felony -- one discharge being procured on his own allegation as District Attorney that there was no evidence to sustain against the Ex-Secretary of War the charge of complicity with GODARD BAILEY in his abstractions of the Indian Trust Bonds; and the second on the purely technical issue that the prosecution for Malfeasance in Office must fall to the ground under the act of 1857, prohibiting a criminal prosecution where the party implicated had previously been summoned before a Committee of either branch of Congress to testify in relation to the matter forming the body of the indictment.

abstract: Coroner HORTON, last evening, at the City Hall, commenced an investigation of the causes which led to the death of SUSAN A. WILSON and ANN B. TRANAHOR, at No. 196 Orange-street, on Friday evening last.
lead_paragraph: Coroner HORTON, last evening, at the City Hall, commenced an investigation of the causes which led to the death of SUSAN A. WILSON and ANN B. TRANAHOR, at No. 196 Orange-street, on Friday evening last. At this time, it will be remembered, a fire broke out in the rooms occupied by the American Skirt Company, in such a place as to cut off the escape of the persons named above, one of whom, to escape death by fire, jumped out of a window in the fifth-story and was instantly killed, and the other remained in the room and died from the effects of inhaling smoke. The foreman of the establishment, GEORGE ALBRECHT, is under arrest on suspicion of having fired the place, but up to the present time not a particle of evidence has been produced against him.

abstract: Whether it be wiser in the Legislature to occupy twelve hours a day in deliberations, or to create that dubious contrivance, a "Grinding Committee," is a question which distracts Albany correspondents. The Assembly, departing from modern instances, has selected the former plan, to the chagrin of many who see in the protracted and exhausting labors of an all day and night session, the death-blow of calm, judicious and considerate legislation. It were better, say these, to accept the results of the partial inquiry and hasty investigation which the Grinding Committee insures as a prelude to the action of the House, than to brave the consequences of a weary and desultory discussion in the House itself, evolving no light upon the question submitted, and tending in no degree to expedite sensible legislation. Now, on either side of this issue, there is so much to be said, that we may fairly seek an escape from both. This, we think, is furnished by the application of a simple test. Let all bills not obviously demanded by the public -- all bills merely urged for private or corporate objects, or to escape the consequences of previous legislation, or to balk necessary legal or administrative reforms, be dismissed at once to the bottom of the calendar, to take their chance, in the last hours of the session. Of the remainder, let those of unquestionable expediency be promoted to the head of the list, to be first acted upon; while others, the expediency of which is contested by conflicting petitions and representations, may be made to take a secondary place. By this feasible recast of the order of business, to achieve which the rigor of rules should be relaxed, whatever of beneficial legislation is still incomplete may be perfected; much of a mischievous character effectually defeated; and the integrity and industry of members alike escape exhaustion.
lead_paragraph: Whether it be wiser in the Legislature to occupy twelve hours a day in deliberations, or to create that dubious contrivance, a "Grinding Committee," is a question which distracts Albany correspondents. Now, on either side of this issue, there is so much to be said, that we may fairly seek an escape from both. This, we think, is furnished by the application of a simple test. abstract: -- Died, in Libertyville, Lake County, Ill., Feb. 26, Hon. Horace Butler, son of the late Hon. Josiah Butler, of New-Hampshire, aged 46 years. Mr. Butler graduated at Dartmouth College in 1836, and soon after removed to Illinois, where he has successfully practiced law up to the period of his decease. He has held various positions of honor and trust in the State, and although he has gone to his rest "while it was yet day," he lived to finish a course of usefulness which few of maturer age attain. -- Chicago Times.
lead_paragraph: -- Died, in Libertyville, Lake County, Ill., Feb. 26, Hon. Horace Butler, son of the late Hon. Josiah Butler, of New-Hampshire, aged 46 years. abstract: The event of the week was the opening of the thirty-sixth Annual Exhibition of the National Academy of Design. A time-honored custom has been to extend invitations to brother artists, journalists, patrons, and the fair sex generally, to attend a private view on the night prior to the formal and public opening.
lead_paragraph: The event of the week was the opening of the thirty-sixth Annual Exhibition of the National Academy of Design. A time-honored custom has been to extend invitations to brother artists, journalists, patrons, and the fair sex generally, to attend a private view on the night prior to the formal and public opening. Private views always were humbugs, -- this one was a humbug, and unless very marked changes are made by the future Committees of arrangements private views will always be classed amongst the genus bore. Heretofore an unlimited number of "influentials" received invitations for themselves and all their friends to enjoy a private view, and the consequence was, that the private view was all in one's eye, and unless he had the very best of company hanging on his arm, the enjoyment to be derived from the aforesaid privates by any viewer whomsoever, would be exceedingly and very limited. This year females were excluded -- potables and Havanas being admitted in their stead -- and the natural result was, that a great many queerly customed individuals, of the sterner sex, congregated in the hall, examined the pictures some, but indulged in the goodies more. The suggestion of a cotemporary -- an Evangelical brother -- that none but artists and journalists with their ladies, be invited on the first opening, and that the hall be open in the day as well as at night, is eminently good, and we hope it may be adopted in future.

abstract: WILLIAM ABSON, the wife poisoner, closed his mortal career, by committing suicide in his cell, in the Hudson County Jail, yesterday morning, at 2 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM ABSON, the wife poisoner, closed his mortal career, by committing suicide in his cell, in the Hudson County Jail, yesterday morning, at 2 o'clock. Up to Wednesday forenoon he had expressed a strong hope and belief that his sentence would be commuted, but being informed on that day by Sheriff FRANCIS that the Court of Pardons had refused to grant the petition, he gave up in despair. Previous to this a watchman had been employed to keep a strict watch over him at night, but on Monday last an attempt having been made by a brother of the condemned man to pass something to him in a surreptitious manner, the Sheriff determined to use increased precaution to prevent ABSON from carrying out his threat, "That he would never be hung." An additional watchman was accordingly employed, in order that he might be watched every moment, both day and night.

abstract: The severe weather of the last few days, which has again blocked up the Hudson River with ice, and stopped the steamers which, it was supposed, had finally opened up navigation to Albany, and which ...
lead_paragraph: The severe weather of the last few days, which has again blocked up the Hudson River with ice, and stopped the steamers which, it was supposed, had finally opened up navigation to Albany, and which has brought back the reign of Winter in its sharpest features along the valley of the Hudson, has taken on a milder, but not less disagreeable form in this latitude. Early yesterday morning, with the wind from the southeast, snow began to fall in large flakes, which soon covered the ground to the depth of several inches, to be soon melted, however, by the mild temperature prevailing, thus rendering the streets and crossings in the City more uncomfortable, if possible, than they have been before during the past Winter. All outdoor business was suspended, and few, who were not compelled to do so by business, ventured abroad.

abstract: A tremendous snow storm has been raging here for the past twenty hours. Snow to the depth of fifteen inches has already fallen, with a prospect of plenty more. Navigation is impossible on the river. The boats due here this morning from New-York could only reach Newburgh. The steamer Hendrik Hudson, from New-York on Tuesday, bound for Albany, has succeeded in making a safe harbor in the creek here, after lying two days at Rhinebeck.

abstract: The enactment of a highly protective Tariff on the heel of the last session of Congress, without the slightest provision made for its enforcement, and at the very time when secession was so fully matured as to indicate its character and purpose, was an act of reckless folly unparalleled in our legislative history.
lead_paragraph: The enactment of a highly protective Tariff on the heel of the last session of Congress, without the slightest provision made for its enforcement, and at the very time when secession was so fully matured as to indicate its character and purpose, was an act of reckless folly unparalleled in our legislative history. The measure is equally bad in every point in which it can be viewed. It is not a revenue Tariff. Its object was to discourage importations. It cannot be enforced on more than three thousand miles of seacoast, and fifteen hundred miles of interior line. We treat the seceding States as a portion of our Confederacy. A ship may lawfully enter their ports, and put its goods in warehouse. In seizures for condemnation, the case would have to be tried in the United States Courts, and before a local jury. No such Courts exist. If they did it would not be difficult to tell how the jury would decide. The President has no power whatever in the premises. His guides are well-established laws which contemplated nothing like the present state of affairs. The spectacle of a great nation unable to enforce a law enacted with all due solemnity and upon the observance of which the exercise of all its functions depend, is humiliating to the last degree.

abstract: Now that something definite is likely to be done by our Legislature about City railway charters, it becomes extremely important for the public to demand such legal provisions as will preserve the ordinary convenience of street traffic and protect miscellaneous vehicles from unusual and unnecessary wear and tear and delay.
lead_paragraph: Now that something definite is likely to be done by our Legislature about City railway charters, it becomes extremely important for the public to demand such legal provisions as will preserve the ordinary convenience of street traffic and protect miscellaneous vehicles from unusual and unnecessary wear and tear and delay. However imperative may be the demand for more cars and better appointments -- improvements which can be at any time introduced -- the laying of a track which will not infringe upon the rights of every owner of a private vehicle, nor impair the original convenience of the highway, is evidently of primary importance. Mistakes in this direction are not likely to be corrected at all.

abstract: We cannot but think that our Courts are very injudiciously encouraging matrimonial differences, by the facilities granted and the privacy insured to husbands and wives seeking release from the chains of matrimony.
lead_paragraph: We cannot but think that our Courts are very injudiciously encouraging matrimonial differences, by the facilities granted and the privacy insured to husbands and wives seeking release from the chains of matrimony. Instead of the old-fashioned, fair jury trial provided for under the common law, divorce suits are now almost invariably referred to some private counsel, who is to take evidence in the seclusion of his chambers, and make a report to the Court, which report is usually adopted, without question, as the Court's decision. Three such cases are noticed to-day in our law intelligence, and several hundred of such suits are similarly disposed in the course of a year.

abstract: The following is Capt. WHEELER's statement of the stranding of the bark Harvest Queen, and the loss of six men of her crew, as given on the books at the Merchants' Exchange: "Bark Harvest Queen, Capt. WHEELER, reported ashore at Scituate yesterday, made Thatcher's Island light at 10 1/2 o'clock Monday night; it bore north and by east half east distant five miles, and steered southwest half west for Boston light. At 11 1/2 P.M. shut in with a heavy northeast snow storm. At 2 A.M. Tuesday, made a large light right ahead, which I took for Boston Light. Hauled to, to get the light to bear west northwest; soon after found the water was shoaling, with hard rocky bottom. Lost sight of the light, took in all sail, and let go both anchors in four fathoms of water. At daylight found the bark had drifted close to the breakers, and was still driving; found it impossible to keep from going ashore, and prepared to leave with the boats. At 7 A.M. launched the boats, sent the mate, JAMES PIKE, the second mate, JAMES SMITH, seamen, Wm. Saunders, Joseph Young, Carl Schmitt and George Boyd, away in the large surf-boat, with orders not to let go their anchor till I joined them with the small boat. At 7 1/2 A.M. I determined to leave the vessel with the small boat, containing myself, steward JACOB Fritch, seamen Edward Gibbons, P.S. Wisner, Thomas Morton, James Farrell, G.R. McIlwain. On passing the mate's boat, I signalized her to follow me to the beach. They appeared to be undecided what to do, but at length followed. I landed with my crew in safety, and have no further recollection. The mate's boat capsized in the surf, and those in her perished. I do not understand how some of the men were not saved, as they were supplied with life buoys and cork fenders in the boat. On inquiry on shore, I found that the light that I had seen was a large fire on the beach, built by watchmen. I cannot account how the bark drifted so far to the south by the current.
lead_paragraph: The following is Capt. WHEELER's statement of the stranding of the bark Harvest Queen, and the loss of six men of her crew, as given on the books at the Merchants' Exchange: "Bark Harvest Queen, Capt. WHEELER, reported ashore at Scituate yesterday, made Thatcher's Island light at 10 1/2 o'clock Monday night; it bore north and by east half east distant five miles, and steered southwest half west for Boston light. At 11 1/2 P.M. shut in with a heavy northeast snow storm. At 2 A.M. Tuesday, made a large light right ahead, which I took for Boston Light. Hauled to, to get the light to bear west northwest; soon after found the water was shoaling, with hard rocky bottom. Lost sight of the light, took in all sail, and let go both anchors in four fathoms of water. At daylight found the bark had drifted close to the breakers, and was still driving; found it impossible to keep from going ashore, and prepared to leave with the boats. At 7 A.M. launched the boats, sent the mate, JAMES PIKE, the second mate, JAMES SMITH, seamen, Wm. Saunders, Joseph Young, Carl Schmitt and George Boyd, away in the large surf-boat, with orders not to let go their anchor till I joined them with the small boat. At 7 1/2 A.M. I determined to leave the vessel with the small boat, containing myself, steward JACOB Fritch, seamen Edward Gibbons, P.S. Wisner, Thomas Morton, James Farrell, G.R. McIlwain. On passing the mate's boat, I signalized her to follow me to the beach. They appeared to be undecided what to do, but at length followed. I landed with my crew in safety, and have no further recollection. The mate's boat capsized in the surf, and those in her perished. I do not understand how some of the men were not saved, as they were supplied with life buoys and cork fenders in the boat. On inquiry on shore, I found that the light that I had seen was a large fire on the beach, built by watchmen. I cannot account how the bark drifted so far to the south by the current.

abstract: The schooner Edward Herbert, which arrived at Norfolk on Monday from Boston, reports having fallen in with the British schooner Wrenn, of St. Andrews, on Friday last, in distress, with headstays carried away and leaking so badly that it was deemed impossible to keep her afloat -- accordingly took off the captain and crew and brought them to this port. The Wrenn was from Matanzas, bound to New-York, with a cargo of molasses.

abstract: The third volume of AGASSIZ' magnum opus, the Contributions to the Natural History of the United States, recently issued in superb style by Messrs. LITTLE, BROWN Co., of Boston, is entirely occupied with a monograph on the class of Aealephs or Jelly-fishes, one of the three classes of the Radiata, which again form one of the four great types after which all animal structures are built.
lead_paragraph: -- The third volume of AGASSIZ' magnum opus, the Contributions to the Natural History of the United States, recently issued in superb style by Messrs. LITTLE, BROWN & CO., of Boston, is entirely occupied with a monograph on the class of Aealephs or Jelly-fishes, one of the three classes of the Radiata, which again form one of the four great types after which all animal structures are built. Zoologists will find their account in the full and exhaustive treatment of the Ctenophorae, while the general reader will be more readily attracted to the introductory portion occupying the first couple of hundred pages, in which the master gives some of those philosophic generalizations in which he is always so copious and so happy. Here also he has an episode on the Darwin question. Announcements had led us to expect something like a systematic examination of that now famous hypothesis: there is really, however, nothing of the kind, the author confining himself to general declarations, as thus: "The arguments presented by DARWIN in favor of a universal derivation from one primary form have not made the slightest impression on my mind." If we understand the following passage, it seems simply to shut out forever from all scientific investigation the whole question of the origin of species: "We must look to the original Power that imparted life to the first being for the origin of all other beings, however mysterious and inaccessible the modes by which all this diversity has been produced may remain for us." There was a time when a certain laxity of speculation was associated with the name AGASSIZ; but the most rigorously orthodox could no further go than he in his later productions.

abstract: The evidently strong disposition to accept, in some quarters, the military necessity which may compel the evacuation of Fort Sumpter, as an index of the policy to be pursued by the Administration, must, if uncorrected, lead to mischievous results.
lead_paragraph: The evidently strong disposition to accept, in some quarters, the military necessity which may compel the evacuation of Fort Sumpter, as an index of the policy to be pursued by the Administration, must, if uncorrected, lead to mischievous results. There is really no ambiguity in the business. If, yielding to circumstances created by the treason or negligence of Mr. BUCHANAN's Cabinet, Major ANDERSON's command be withdrawn, and the post abandoned, the fact has, indeed, no political significance whatever; raises no precedent for other military positions still in our hands and still defensible; and must in no case be treated as a concession to local or sectional demands, or as a departure from the principles which the President indicated at Indianapolis and at Washington as the rule of his Administration. It is enough to say that were Fort Sumpter in the condition of Forts Pickens, Taylor and Jefferson, abundantly manned, armed and provisioned, we have every reason for believing it would be held to the last extremity against every assailant; and while all would profoundly deplore the waste of life which assault or siege might occasion, they would have to bear the sanguinary responsibility who should begin the conflict. The duty of the President is too palpable to admit of the slightest doubt. What powers he discovers himself to possess are pledged to the protection of the Federal property. The pledge can only be dispensed where its attempted fulfillment is found to involve impossibilities.

abstract: His testimony was couched in and befogged by the usual amount of doctorial Latin, which may be translated in substance as follows: The deceased was brought to the hospital with a gun-shot wound in his thigh. For some time he improved, but in a few days a part of the wadding came away from the wound, and the prisoner grew rapidly worse till the 27th of December, when he died, from the effects of the absorption by the system of pus generated by the shot-wound. The ball was sought for at the time that the deceased was brought in, but was not found. Upon a post-mortem examination the ball was found in one of the muscles of the thigh.
