abstract: Notwithstanding the warlike reports from this country in which the European Press abounds, the number of emigrants arriving at this port is now larger than even the great influx of the corresponding period of last year. From the 1st of January up to the 20th inst, 6,131 arrivals had been registered at Castle Garden, as against 5,667 to the same date last year, and a large number of passenger-laden vessels are now overdue at this port. Emigrants from any part of the world need have no apprehension about coming to America from anything that has transpired -- or, indeed, that is likely in any contingency to transpire -- in our political relations. In the fertile Territories of the boundless West -- far beyond the possible limits of sectional strife, there is yet plenty of room and peaceful homes for myriads of industrious freemen. There are hundreds of millions of acres of virgin prairie which are but waiting the touch of industry to fructify with golden harvests. There are green valleys and pleasant dells, and all the other romantic spots in endless variety, yet to be squatted on by whoever chooses -- where none shall ever molest or make afraid. Not to mention Illinois, which alone could give room even yet to half the Austrian Empire, and which is now offering great inducements to settlers, the vast grain regions of Minnesota, and Washington and Nebraska and Oregon, and other Territories, are freely open to the emigrant. If to pick up money in a tangible form be the need, plenty of it can be had for the taking, in the new and splendid empire henceforth to be ruled by that most jovial of Governors, Gen. NYE; while if you prefer the golden nuggets, you can still find them in abundance concealed in the heart of the great mountains from Fraser's River to Mexico. No war, nor invasion, nor civil turmoil is ever likely to approach any part of all this grand domain, which has been forever consecrated to labor, and Freedom and independence. So let the emigration continue; and both Europe and America will be, as heretofore, the gainers.

abstract: The new Adjutant-General of the Army has taken charge of his duties at Washington. Col. LORENZO THOMAS is one of the ablest officers in the service; and his administrative talents have been for a long time appreciated by Gen. SCOTT, who has embraced the first opportunity to exalt him to one of the first positions at his disposal. The Adjutant received his first, commission in 1823, since which time he has distinguished himself in every branch, of an officer's duty. He presided at the head-quarters of the Army in this City for some years, and has left many warm admirers to regret his departure.

abstract: The Alligator Sovereignty of Florida, which still -- in the irresistible phraseology of its Ordinance of Secession -- maintains its attitude as an "independent nation," has recently been engaged in an extraordinary effort to raise the wind. The treasury, you observe, has been now for some time disgustingly empty; and that serene and generous Uncle under whose favor the Floridians have heretofore waxed fat, has lately had quite enough ado attending to himself. So the supreme authorities have succeeded in negotiating the sale of half a million of acres of their national domain to a company of New-Orleans speculators, at two cents an acre -- said land being situated upon and in the vicinity of Caloosahatchie. By this masterly financial stroke, a sum of not less than ten million mills is secured to the sovereign exchequor -- that is if the Pelicanders are silly enough ever to pay it. Such a bit of finance, at the present exigency of her national history, exhibits a shrewdness worthy of YULEE himself; for the likelihood is that one cent an acre, even if made payable in Pelican bills, will be quite as much as the choicest tid-bits of peninsular soil will command in a year or two from now, if it persists in being or remaining an independent national tail to South Carolina. If the young nation, however, will offer the whole of her dry land for sale in one parcel, and will agree to make an auto-du-fe of all her fire-eaters, she might be able to negotiate its sale at present high prices. We ourselves might give a moment's consideration at least to it. The advertising receipts for the TIMES, even in these hard times, for a week, would be amply sufficient, at the maximum price, to purchase the whole State, not to mention one or two able-bodied hands to take care of it.

abstract: Early yesterday morning one of the most infamous disorderly houses in the City, located at the corner of Oak and Roosevelt streets, was visited by the Police cf the Fourth Ward, who arrested the proprietor, an Irish woman, 28 years of age, Mary Fleming by name, and a large number of the inmates, comprising persons of all colors and both sexes.
lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning one of the most infamous disorderly houses in the City, located at the corner of Oak and Roosevelt streets, was visited by the Police cf the Fourth Ward, who arrested the proprietor, an Irish woman, 28 years of age, Mary Fleming by name, and a large number of the inmates, comprising persons of all colors and both sexes. At the time the descent was accomplished the officers found negro men occupying the same rooms with white women and vice versa. The miserable horde were conducted to the Station-house, where they were confined for the night, and yesterday morning all of them having been arraigned before Justice OSBORN, the males, both white and black, were reprimanded and discharged, while the women were committed to Blackwell's Island as vagrants. The police authorities took this action against the vile den on complaint of Mary McQuade, a girl 17 years of age, who robbed her parents, who live at Troy, of $40 about three weeks ago and lied to this City. While loitering about the streets she was met by one of the harpies who procure girls for houses of prostitution, and induced to go to the place in question. She was treated well until all her money had been spent, when the proprietor of the place proposed that she should cohabit with a negro, and upon refusing, she was shamefully abused. She finally applied at the station-house on Wednesday afternoon for redress, with the result as above narrated. She was sent back to her parents yesterday.

abstract: Stocks are ample, while the demand is limited. Prices exhibit no remarkable alteration. abstract: It is not easy to see how we are to avoid the necessity of an Extra Session of Congress. Critical and extraordinary as the condition of the country is, the President is without power to take any effectual step towards its relief.
lead_paragraph: It is not easy to see how we are to avoid the necessity of an Extra Session of Congress. Critical and extraordinary as the condition of the country is, the President is without power to take any effectual step towards its relief. He can adopt no fixed and decisive policy towards the seceding States, because no laws give him authority to carry it into effect. He cannot enforce the laws, because no power has been put at his command for that purpose. He cannot close the ports which refuse to pay Federal duties, nor has he authority to enforce payment except through the local authorities.

abstract: The storeship Supply, with provisions for Fort Pickens, has fallen, we are told, into the hands of the adversary. An unsatisfactory dispatch says she was seized at Pensacola, with what circumstances or with what display of force we are not informed. The fact justly occasions surprise. Not because the Secessionists have added this particular form of theft to the varieties they have almost exhausted elsewhere, but that the theft should have been possible in case of a vessel provided with the ordinary means of defence, and we may reasonably presume, further protected by the guns of Fort Pickens. It is, of course, possible that the capture could not have been avoided or defeated by any displays of courage or precaution; but so long as we continue to tread among the treasonable traps and pit-falls left us as a legacy by the late Administration, we cannot proceed too guardedly, or look into the causes of such misadventures as the present too curiously.

abstract: In Monday's sitting of the Senate, Senator BOISSY expressed his regret that in the draft address no mention was made of the navy, which would render such great service in a war with England, which he desired. This remark was received with expressions...
lead_paragraph: In Monday's sitting of the Senate, Senator BOISSY expressed his regret that in the draft address no mention was made of the navy, which would render such great service in a war with England, which he desired. This remark was received with expressions of dissatisfaction. Senator BOISSY maintained that the benefit of the English alliance had been exaggerated, and declared that a great majority of the country were of his opinion. He further attacked England on the subject of the arrangements respecting passports.

abstract: We have seen of late months far too many bold political coups de main, both at home and abroad, to be readily startled; and have read too much recent and vigorous oratory to easily experience a decided sensation;
lead_paragraph: We have seen of late months far too many bold political coups de main, both at home and abroad, to be readily startled; and have read too much recent and vigorous oratory to easily experience a decided sensation; but it must be admitted that the late speech of Prince NAPOLEON, before the French Senate, strikes us as gifted with piquancy of unusual savor. We are so accustomed to verbal right-and-left striking and sharp hitting, in our own national councils, that such sparring appears doubly lively when it comes from a Prince of the Empire -- a semi and family official organ of LOUIS NAPOLEON himself -- and cannot avoid, if we would, applauding his vigorous defence of the latter.
headline: {'main': "Prince Napoleon's Speech.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Prince Napoleon's Speech.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our Washington Correspondent telegraphs the only definite item which has for some time reached us relative to the action of the Government on the Fort Sumpter question.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington Correspondent telegraphs the only definite item which has for some time reached us relative to the action of the Government on the Fort Sumpter question. Intelligence has reached that city from Charleston, to the effect that a special Government messenger had arrived from Washington, and had proceeded to Fort Sumpter by permission of the authorities, accompanied by Capt. HARTSTEIN. There is little question that his mission related to the evacuation of the fort, which there is no longer reason to doubt has been determined upon.

abstract: In the course of some re marks in this paper, yesterday, in regard to an extra session of Congress, we embraced among the causes likely to embarrass the action of the body, the fact that the representa-...
lead_paragraph: -- In the course of some remarks in this paper, yesterday, in regard to an extra session of Congress, we embraced among the causes likely to embarrass the action of the body, the fact that the representation, because several of the States have yet to elect members to the Thirty-seventh Congress, would be far from perfect. Such, however, is not the case. When, in 1841, the newly inaugurated administration of Gen. HARRISON found itself so surrounded with financial difficulties, arising from the expiring tariff of 1832, as to require the aid of a special session, the proclamation appeared on the 17th of March, convoking the meeting for May 31. With the exception of Mississippi, all the States which had not yet chosen representatives, held special elections, so that when Congress assembled, the usual numbers, bating those from the State named, were in attendance. In those days there was no telegraph to expedite the Presidential summons; hence the prolonged interval between the call and the meeting. Now there would be no difficulty in completing the elections and organizing the House within a fortnight; and if, as events appear to intimate, a special meeting shall be required, it may be had in time for even the most sudden emergency.

abstract: The newspapers A NOT VERY CIVIL WAR--The newspapers are discussing with a good deal of warmth the question whether the Tribune's Charleston correspondence is written at Charleston, or only dated there. The Tribune meets the various attempts that are made to impugn the...
lead_paragraph: -- The newspapers are discussing with a good deal of warmth the question whether the Tribune's Charleston correspondence is written at Charleston, or only dated there. The Tribune meets the various attempts that are made to impugn the authenticity of these letters with a good deal of ingenuity. But it has never yet ventured to make the direct assertion that they are written in Charleston, or that they come with the post-mark of that city upon them. This discreet abstinence in itself looks a little suspicious, and is scarcely offset by the ridiculous pretension that three of its "staff" are stationed at Charleston, or by the adroit defence of some of the suspicious features of the correspondence itself.

abstract: A fellow named John Henry alias Kelly, was arrested yesterday morning, charged with robbing the cabin of the brig Ashby, lying at Pier No. 2 East River, of clothing and money to the value of $36.
lead_paragraph: A fellow named John Henry alias Kelly, was arrested yesterday morning, charged with robbing the cabin of the brig Ashby, lying at Pier No. 2 East River, of clothing and money to the value of $36. It appears that while the steward, a colored man, washing in his bunk, at 2 1/2 o'clock in the morning, he saw Henry and another man stealthily enter the cabin and apply a handkerchief saturated with chloroform to the face of the Captain, Wm. Wright, who lay asleep in his berth. As soon as the drug had taken effect, the scoundrels forced open the Captain's trunk, and took from it the articles above named, with which they decamped. The steward all this time was so frightened that he did not dare to give an alarm; but as soon as the thieves had gone, he went open deck and watched them until he saw them go on board another vessel. He then acquainted Officer Hays, of the First Ward, with what had occurred, and that officer proceeded on board the vessel and succeeded in capturing Henry and in recovering the property. The confederate managed to escape. Henry was taken to Court and locked up for trial.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, James Deuel, indicted for forgery in the third degree, was put to the bar, and pleaded guilty in the fourth degree. The document forged was a check on the Park Bank, for $107, purporting to be drawn by the assistant-cashier of the Bank of Commerce, payable to the order of W.G. Ray, whose indorsement thereon had also been forged, and the amount of the check had been paid. The prisoner was sent to the Penitentiary for six months.

abstract: A CHILD STOLEN BY A BEGGAR WOMAN, AND RESTORED AFTER A MONTH'S ABSENCE. -- On the 17th inst., two brothers named IRA and CHARLES CHAPMAN, while walking in the woods near the village of Sing Sing, Westchester County, encountered a party of seven men and two women gathered around a camp fire, and apparently leading a Gipsey life. One of the women had with her a little girl, about two years of age, who was crying bitterly, and whose forlorn andneglected condition excited the commiseration of the young men to such an extent that they asked the woman to place her under their protection, where she would receive better care than could possibly fall to her lot under the circumstances which then surrounded her. The woman willingly complied, and the young men took the child to Mr. T. MANEY, Overseer of the Poor at Sing Sing, by whom she was kindly provided for. On Friday last, Mr. MANEY observed an advertisement in one of the City papers, descriptive of a lost child belonging to Mr. GREENAN, a respectable man living in James-street, and believing it to refer to the little walf in his custody, he telegraphed Mr. G. to come up and look at her. On Saturday Mr. GREENAN and Detective WILSON went to Sing Sing, where the heart of the former was made glad at discovering that the child was his 'own little daughter, who had been stolen from him on the 20th of last mouth, although in the interval the hardships she had suffered had changed her so sadly that he at first scarcely recognized her. In their efforts to find the child, its parents learned that she had been abducted by an Irishwoman, named ANN MCCLUSKY, formerly keeper of a brothel in Water-street, who, having been turned out of her wretched home, had taken to street-begging for a livelihood, and used the little girl to excite the sympathy of the charitable. The woman MCCLUSKY is still at large.

abstract: Judging from the dispatches which we publish this morning, there seems to be no longer room to doubt that the order for the evacuation of Fort Sumpter has actually been issued. Our Washington correspondent telegraphs that he has received a dispatch from a gentleman in Charleston, who has just returned from a visit to the Fort, and who found Major ANDERSON busily engaged in taking an inventory of all the Government property, preparatory to turning it over to the authorities of South Carolina. Notwithstanding the reportsto the contrary, it was understood that the Major was to be allowed to exercise his own judgment as to the method of evacuation. The Charleston Courier, of Friday, contains a corroboration of the dispatch published by us on Saturday morning, announcing the visit of Surgeon Fox, of the Navy, to the Fort, in company with Capt. HARTSTEIN. The Courier also announces the arrival in Charleston of Congressman HOLMES, with assurances that the policy of the Administration is a peaceful one.
lead_paragraph: Judging from the dispatches which we publish this morning, there seems to be no longer room to doubt that the order for the evacuation of Fort Sumpter has actually been issued. abstract: The concert and dramatic saloon, known as Canterbury Hall, was burned down yesterday morning shortly after 5 o'clock, and by the falling of the walls the contiguous buildings were slightly damaged,involving a loss in the aggregate of probably $17,000. The fire broke out among the scenery on the stage, and was discovered by the watchman of the premises.
lead_paragraph: The concert and dramatic saloon, known as Canterbury Hall, was burned down yesterday morning shortly after 5 o'clock, and by the falling of the walls the contiguous buildings were slightly damaged,involving a loss in the aggregate of probably $17,000. The fire broke out among the scenery on the stage, and was discovered by the watchman of the premises. The firemen responded to the alarm with their accustomed alacrity, but the combustible character of the material made it impossible to check the progress of the flames, and it was not very long before the building with its contents, was destroyed. The hall was situated in the rear of the premises No. 663 Broadway, and was entered through a long passage-way. It was a three-story building, having a front of 40 feet, and a depth of 125, and was more familiarly known as Mozart Hall, the head-quarters of the Anti-Tammany Democracy. The property formed a part of the estate of the late Rev. Mr. WILEY, and, including the buildings on Broadway, was insured for $15,000. The loss is estimated at $6,000, and the insurances are distributed as follows: $4,000 each in the Knickerbocker and American, $2,000 each in the Niagara and Lorillard, and $3,000 in the American, of Philadelphia. The proprietors of Canterbury Hall, estimate their loss at $10,000, upon which are insurances for $8,000, as follows: Stuysevant, $3,000; Hartford, $2,000; Liverpool and London, $3,000. By the falling of the walls the rear part of the buildings Nos. 190, 192 and 194 Mercer-street were slightly damaged. They also belong to the Wiley estate. The rear part of the Stuyvesant Institute was injured to the extent of $300 by the same means: insured in the Relief Insurance Company for $5,000. Some injury resulted from water to the stock of boots and shoes in the store of R. MIDDLETON, No. 663 Broadway; Mr. M. is insured for $4,000 in the Brevoort, and $5,000 in the New-World Insurance Company. The fire is said to have been of incendiary origin, and the various rumors with reference to the guilty are to be investigated by the Fire Marshal.

abstract: The week which precedes Easter is seldom a very nourishing one in theatrical matters, being usually devoted by managers to the preparation of forthcoming novelties. There are a few changes in the bills at the leading places of amusement, to night, but nothing of a very striking character. The most noticeable novelty is the commencement of the Wizard of the North at the Academy of Music, where during six nights he will give a series of magical soirees. This is the first time our Fourteenth-streethouse has been let for such a purpose, and recalls irresistibly the career of the Astor place Opera-house, which, it will be remembered, passed into the hands of the conjurors in a like manner. Prof. ANDERSON is one of the best of his kind, and will undoubtedly supply the public with a pleasant evening's entertainment. We hear from the opera now in Boston that the first week was good, and the second (notwithstanding snow and storm) moderate. Miss KELLOGG made a genuine success, and is lauded in all the papers. VERDI'S new opera -- the scene of which, it will be remembered, is laid in Boston -- drew a good house on its first performance, but appears to have fallen off in interest. The Press is favorable, and makes a great deal of fun out of the story and personages -- tracing both to American history with an amount of erudition that is almost painful. The present week brings the Boston season to an end. On their way to Philadelphia the artists will give a few performances here. "Aroldo" -- another opera by VERDI -- is the work spoken of as the attraction.
lead_paragraph: The week which precedes Easter is seldom a very nourishing one in theatrical matters, being usually devoted by managers to the preparation of forthcoming novelties. There are a few changes in the bills at the leading places of amusement, to night, but nothing of a very striking character. The most noticeable novelty is the commencement of the Wizard of the North at the Academy of Music, where during six nights he will give a series of magical soirees. This is the first time our Fourteenth-streethouse has been let for such a purpose, and recalls irresistibly the career of the Astor place Opera-house, which, it will be remembered, passed into the hands of the conjurors in a like manner. Prof. ANDERSON is one of the best of his kind, and will undoubtedly supply the public with a pleasant evening's entertainment. We hear from the opera now in Boston that the first week was good, and the second (notwithstanding snow and storm) moderate. Miss KELLOGG made a genuine success, and is lauded in all the papers. VERDI'S new opera -- the scene of which, it will be remembered, is laid in Boston -- drew a good house on its first performance, but appears to have fallen off in interest. The Press is favorable, and makes a great deal of fun out of the story and personages -- tracing both to American history with an amount of erudition that is almost painful. The present week brings the Boston season to an end. On their way to Philadelphia the artists will give a few performances here. "Aroldo" -- another opera by VERDI -- is the work spoken of as the attraction.

abstract: It seems to have escaped public attention that, in addition to our domestic troubles, we have a foreign quarrel on hand. We have withdrawn our Minister from Peru, and have taken the preliminary steps towards enforcing our demands on that country by war. The French Minister has offered the mediation of his Government, but no steps have yet bees taken, so far as we are aware, to avail ourselves of this proffer.
lead_paragraph: It seems to have escaped public attention that, in addition to our domestic troubles, we have a foreign quarrel on hand. We have withdrawn our Minister from Peru, and have taken the preliminary steps towards enforcing our demands on that country by war. The French Minister has offered the mediation of his Government, but no steps have yet bees taken, so far as we are aware, to avail ourselves of this proffer. As the subject is one of importance, not only on account of the consequences to which it may lead, but also of the principles which it involves, it may be well to present the facts again to the public consideration.

abstract: SAM HOUSTON, having been deposed from the Texas Governorship by the Revolutionary Convention, it is now proposed in high confederate quarters to have the contumacious old war horse immediately tried for treason and executed as a traitor. Things quite as amazing as this have been done down there lately by the precipitators; and it is quite likely that the sanguinary ruffians will be satisfied with nothing less than the blood of the man who has so seriously thwarted their purposes.

abstract: As we live and grow older it seems that all the pleasant illusions fostered in youth by the minor drama and the romantic novels of the Minerva press are destined to obliteration. The last idol shattered is that scarlet representative of manly honor and chivalrous decorum, -- the British Officer. In how many theatres have we seen this honored ideal laying his white buckskin glove over his red bosom, and gallantly bowing a refusal of all thanks from the young lady just rescued, along with her gray-haired grandfather, from the clutches of a dozen villainous-looking bandits, by his single arm and sword! Through how many lachrymose pages of sentimental novels have our young eyes traced the dazzling careers of colonels, captains and lieutenants, all of them clad in scarlet, all the very souls of honor, and all eventually succeeding, after incredible difficulties, in bringing their stern parents to smile on their respective marriages with girls beautiful and virtuous, though dowerless -- poor and obscure, though of high or at least respectable parentage.
lead_paragraph: As we live and grow older it seems that all the pleasant illusions fostered in youth by the minor drama and the romantic novels of the Minerva press are destined to obliteration. The last idol shattered is that scarlet representative of manly honor and chivalrous decorum, -- the British Officer. In how many theatres have we seen this honored ideal laying his white buckskin glove over his red bosom, and gallantly bowing a refusal of all thanks from the young lady just rescued, along with her gray-haired grandfather, from the clutches of a dozen villainous-looking bandits, by his single arm and sword! Through how many lachrymose pages of sentimental novels have our young eyes traced the dazzling careers of colonels, captains and lieutenants, all of them clad in scarlet, all the very souls of honor, and all eventually succeeding, after incredible difficulties, in bringing their stern parents to smile on their respective marriages with girls beautiful and virtuous, though dowerless -- poor and obscure, though of high or at least respectable parentage.

abstract: MORTALITY. -- The Health Officer makes return of 116 deaths, as having been reported at his Department, during the week ending Saturday last, classified as follows: Men, 33; women, 23; boys, 36; girls, 22; adults, 58; children, 58; males, 71; females, 45; colored, 1. Diseases -- Asphyxia, bronchitis, burned, cholera morbus, colic, concussion of brain, convulsion, (puerperal,) cyanosis, debility, (adult,) diarrhoea, dropsy in the heart, dyspepsia, bilious fever, fracture, disease of heart, disease of valvular, (heart,) hooping cough, inflammation of stomach, disease of kidneys, disease of liver, difficult parturition, pleurisy, small-pox, suffocation, ulceration of bowels, varioloid. Ieach; cancer, croup, dyptheria, inflammation of bowels, 2 each; apoplexy, dropsy, typhoid fever, inflammation of liver, inflammation of lungs, marasmus, (infantile,) -- 3 each. Congestion of lungs, debility, (infantile,) typhus fever, old age -- 4 each. Dropsy in the head, 6; scarlet fever, 9; convulsions, (infantile,) 11; consumption, 17; stillborn, 9. 71 were born in the United States. 46 were five years of age or under. The deaths occurred in the several Wards as follows: First Ward, 4; Second Ward, 4; Third Ward, 6; Fourth Ward, 7; Fifth Ward, 11; Sixth Ward, 4; Seventh Ward, 4; Eighth Ward, 3; Ninth Ward, 9; Tenth Ward, 10; Eleventh Ward, 12; Twelfth Ward, 10; Thirteenth Ward, 7; Fourteenth Ward, 7; Fifteenth Ward, 1; Sixteenth Ward, 11; Seventeenth Ward, 1; Eighteenth Ward, 3; Nineteenth Ward, 2.

abstract: The steamship Teutonia, from Southampton on the morning of the 7th inst., arrived at this port early on Saturday morning. Although she sailed several hours later than the Arago, her advises are no later than those received on Friday by the latter steamer. The Teutonia brings $41,000 in specie.

abstract: With a harbor which is not equaled in the world for its easy approaches, its depth of water, for the accommodation for ships of the largest draft, which may approach the landings and discharge their cargoes at all times of tide, there is not a port in the world which has such miserable, broken, half-sunken, side-winded, tumble down docks for ships to lie at, and at which to land and receive their merchandise. The damage yearly accruing to goods by being landed on muddy docks is estimated at tens of thousands of dollars.

abstract: The Charleston Mercury keeps a correspondent in this City for the purpose, apparently, of keeping up the spirits of the Secessionists by cheerful reports of Northern sentiment. To do him justice he seems to perform his duty with zeal and assiduity. Whatever statements are required at Charleston he seems quite ready to supply. The old familiar story of Northern insurrections continues, in spite of its age and absurdity, to play an important part in his epistles. In one of the latest of them he gravely says that it was fear of such insurrections which led the Administration to decide upon not reinforcing Fort Sumpter. Here is a specimen of the "information" which he furnishes to the Seceders:

abstract: Maj. YELVERTON looks every inch a roue, neither ugly or handsome, but with a face, the aspect of which is, simply unpleasant, dubious, disagreeable. His head is bald on the back of the crown alone. He wears a moustache and flowing whiskers of reddish fair hue.
lead_paragraph: Maj. YELVERTON looks every inch a roue, neither ugly or handsome, but with a face, the aspect of which is, simply unpleasant, dubious, disagreeable. His head is bald on the back of the crown alone. He wears a moustache and flowing whiskers of reddish fair hue. He seemed very nervous and agitated, like a man who found himself "in for" the worst that could befall him, but resolved to go through it at all hazards. His manner of answering the questions was very remarkable. He generally paused a good while, as if weighing every possible bearing or effect of his answer, and shaping it accordingly, like a chess-player calculating before he made his move. His mode of pronounciation was that so often given in Punch as the language of "swell." The indignation in court while he was giving his evidence was really indescribable; but it was when he cooly detailed his directions to Mrs. YELVERTON about "getting rid of" the infant that it reached its height. Indeed, so much was it apprehended that, without waiting to catch him outside, the indignant auditors would set upon him in the court itself, that after declaring the adjournment the Chief Justice remained on the bench until he saw the court cleared of the crowd that had stayed behind in very menacing bearing towards YELVERTON. An immense concourse awaited him outside, openly avowing an intention of making him acquainted with the Liffey, running close by. In consequence of this, numerous ingenious devices were resorted to in order to get him away safely. It is said, and I believe with truth, that the War Office has intimated its intention, as soon as ever the present trial is over, to arraign Major YELVERSON before a Court-martial for "conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman." It is said that his own evidence, to the effect that he frequented as a visitor the house of a superior officer (Gen. STRAUBENZEE) in pursuance of the design of seducing the friend and guest of that officer, will be laid as one of the exact offences in the indictment. Mrs. YELVERTON is probably in her 25th year. She is under the middle height and of fair complexion. She was pale, very pale, evidently impressed, if not agitated, by the circumstances of the occasion, time, and place. Subsequently, when slightly flushed with the excitement, or possibly with the heat of the Court, her face assumed the semblance of what it doubtless was in days passed by, when it wore the charms that attracted the despoiler's gaze. Beautiful the was then indeed! Not that her features, when examined one by one, would be pronounced regular or beautiful. There was a matronly, a grave, thoughtful, sorrowful expression over all, that I am utterly unable to describe; and this it was that first struck and impressed the beholder. Grief -- grief that may not be measured, had left its traces there. There was a sadness in the first tones of her voice, and she threw a quick glance all around, in a half troubled, apprehensive, inquiring anxiety, as if she wanted to be sure that she was indeed amidst the friendly hearts fame had always told her were ever to be found in Ireland by the children of sorrow and misfortune. Hope spoke to the troubled soul that had so long lain in anguish, and thenceforth she seemed to acquire a strength none would have looked for in such a fragile frame. The countenance is oval, with a delicately pointed chin; the general expression of the face is most decidedly that of great firmness, calm, resolute, persevering, dignified power -- confidence in repose. It is the eye that lights up and makes beautiful the whole countenance, which, in fact, is one of those which has its beauty and attraction, more in expression, the seat of which can never be accurately fixed, than in mere symmetry and regularity of the individual features themselves. Her glance penetrates, while it charms as with a spell. She has a profusion of rich glossy auburn hair, which was worn a la Eugenie. Her hand, the smallness of which has been necessarily alluded to in the evidence, is, indeed, one which your fair readers would admire. Mme. YELVERTON was attired, on the first day, in a light-colored fashionable bonnet, and wore a black moire antique dress. On the following day the news had reached her of the death of Mr. BELLAMY, her brother-in-law, and, accordingly, she appeared subsequently in mourning. So far for her personal appearance; but how shall I describe what constitutes the greatest charm about her? The perfection of graceful motion in the simplest movement, and the voice -- such a voice! -- clear, soft, liquid, and musical. BREWSTER was a child in her hands. In the very first sentence exchanged between them their relative positions were fixed, and the ascendancy was hers. At the very start she completely took up her position, without effort or attempt, but somehow simply, because it was her rightful position; one which exacted the most respectful and deferential demeanor from even her antagonist.

abstract: The telegraph announces the death of Hon. GEORGE W. SCRANTON, the Representative in Congress of the Twelfth District of Pennsylvania. Mr. SCRANTON died on Sunday last at his residence in the city to which he had given existence and a name. His disease was pulmonary consumption. A native of Connecticut, Mr. SCRANTON settled many years ago in Warren County, N.J., where he married, and where, nineteen years ago, his attention was called to the unexplored mineral wealth of the Lackawanna Valley, in Luzerne County, Penn. To the development of this region he devoted his entire energies, and having secured the confidence and aid of prominent New-York capitalists, he succeeded in converting a region wholly wild and unpeopled into one of the busiest and most prosperous sections of the country. The site of the present city of Scranton, with its thousands of inhabitants and swarming streets, was, in 1840, a mere wilderness; and the change which has brought a thronging population thither, and made costly lines of railroad tributary to it, are confessedly due to the skill and ability of the deceased. Mr. SCRANTON was, in 1858, elected to represent the Luzerne District in the Thirty-sixth Congress, and rechosen last Fall to fill a seat in the Thirty-seventh. So great indeed was the personal popularity commanded by his frank generosity and extreme kindness of nature that no token of respect or honor he might consent to accept would have been denied to him by a devoted constituency. The same qualities, united with shrewd business abilities, had won him the attachment and regard of his colleagues in Congress It is doubtful whether any other Republican can hope to carry the Twelfth District.

abstract: We are authorized to sap that all the ships of the Home Squadron are out of provisions. Only for the energy and enterprise of Capt. ADAMS, of the Sabine, they would have had to leave Florida altogether.
lead_paragraph: We are authorized to sap that all the ships of the Home Squadron are out of provisions. Only for the energy and enterprise of Capt. ADAMS, of the Sabine, they would have had to leave Florida altogether. Since the vessels arrived at Pensacola, not a line had been received from the Navy Department. The steamers can get no wood and water. Another ship filled with stores should be sent off at once. A "smuggler from Pensacola" was selling water at four cents a gallon. The officers and crews of the entire fleet are told off, to land at a signal from Lieut. SLIMMER.

abstract: We have submitted, from time to time, various considerations which prove the inaptitude of the people of the Southern States for commercial enterprises. We have pointed to the facts, that they have neither the mechanical skill to build ships, the maritime skill to sail them, nor the mercantile knowledge and training necessary to make ships and sailors of any use.
lead_paragraph: We have submitted, from time to time, various considerations which prove the inaptitude of the people of the Southern States for commercial enterprises. We have pointed to the facts, that they have neither the mechanical skill to build ships, the maritime skill to sail them, nor the mercantile knowledge and training necessary to make ships and sailors of any use. But there is another great fact in the condition of the South which would be sufficient to paralyze any amount of commercial skill and aptitude in her people. We allude to the unnecessary, and therefore unprofitable, investment of nearly half her capital in human beings. In the Southern tier of States the proportion of capital which has taken this form is even greater than one-half of the whole, and the paralysis of all but agricultural enterprise is complete.

abstract: RELIGIOUS FESTIVALS. The Jewish Passover, a festival commemorative of the deliverance of the children of Israel from Egyptian bondage, commenced last evening, and will continue for eight days. The origin of the festival is given in the 12th Chapter of Exodus, and the Bible prediction that it should be forever observed by the Israelites throughout the world, has this far been strikingly fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: RELIGIOUS FESTIVALS. -- The Jewish Passover, a festival commemorative of the deliverance of the children of Israel from Egyptian bondage, commenced last evening, and will continue for eight days. The origin of the festival is given in the 12th Chapter of Exodus, and the Bible prediction that it should be forever observed by the Israelites throughout the world, has this far been strikingly fulfilled. The duties imposed upon the Jews during the Passover are, total abstinence from all kinds of leaven and leavened bread attendance of the males at the Tabernacle, and cessation of business on the first two and last two days of the festival. On the evenings of the first two days, the reading of the Sidar takes place in every Jewish family, the members, meanwhile, sitting round a table, on which are placed the bone of a lamb, representing the sacrifice of the "paschal lamb," and some bitter herbs, symbolical of the bitterness of the Egyptian bondage. After the reading of the Sidar, the family chant a service reciting their bondage and deliverance. Previous to the Passover, every Jewish household undergoes a thorough renovation, corresponding to the house-cleaning process customary among Christians. The Christian festival of Passion Week also commenced yesterday, and will be observed during the week in all the Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal Churches. On Friday next, which is Good Friday, the crucifixion will be commemorated, and Dr. VINTON will preach in the morning at Trinity Church. On Saturday, at 3 P.M., (Easter Eve,) the rite of confirmation will be administered at Trinity, by the Provisional Bishop of the Diocese.

abstract: The Galveston (Texas) News, of March 16, gives details of the departure of the United States troops from the State, and of the evacuation of Fort Brown. On the 2d Gen. NICHOLS arrived at Brownsville, where he found a letter from Capt. HILL. awaiting him, reiterating the positions which he had taken in his previous communications, and construing the course ...
lead_paragraph: The Galveston (Texas) News, of March 16, gives details of the departure of the United States troops from the State, and of the evacuation of Fort Brown. On the 2d Gen. NICHOLS arrived at Brownsville, where he found a letter from Capt. HILL. awaiting him, reiterating the positions which he had taken in his previous communications, and construing the course taken by the authorities of Texas as hostile to the United States. On the 3d the Daniel Webster arrived, and on the 4th the troops were greatly excited at hearing guns fired at Fort Brown, which they supposed to be in honor of Mr. LINCOLN'S inauguration. Capt. HILL had meantime been, superseded in command by either Capt. JOHNS or STONEMAN, his superior officers, and the negotiations concerning the withdrawal of the forces from Brownsville were conducted by Col. FORD on the part of the Texans. They were all embarked on the 5th, and the Webster, after a temporary detention off the bar by severe weather, got under way with her portion of the troops. The Rusk followed soon after.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Pofessor ANDERSON, the "Wizard of the North," commenced a series of his entertainments at this house last evening, and was greeted with a fine audience. Of Wizards who speak the English language we have but few, and their abilities, as a general thing, are third-rate.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Pofessor ANDERSON, the "Wizard of the North," commenced a series of his entertainments at this house last evening, and was greeted with a fine audience. Of Wizards who speak the English language we have but few, and their abilities, as a general thing, are third-rate. Professor ANDERSON, happily, cannot be accused of making more use of the English language than he can possibly help, and for this reason, perhaps, he is decidedly preferable to the ordinary run of performers. Conjurors have always been famous for having a jargon of their own. Prof. ANDERSON's is a little more pompous than usual, but it has the true ring of the showman. The Academy of Music is transformed, through his trumpet, into "a vast Psychomanteum," and his entertainment becomes "a farewell festival of magic on a scale of hypermetrical grandeur, with a cataclysm of wonders, forming the Kalon, and to prepon of all forms of amusement." How the little boys must open their eyes at such a tremendous prospect before them.

abstract: THE EDIFICE, C. The new Ward School building, No. 14, in the Twenty-first Ward, which has been in the course of erection for two years, was thrown open for public inspection yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The new Ward School building, No. 14, in the Twenty-first Ward, which has been in the course of erection for two years, was thrown open for public inspection yesterday. It combines all the latest improvements for strength, durability, safety and adaptability to the purpose for which it is intended. It is located in Twenty-seventh-street, between Second and Third avenues, and extends through to Twenty-eighth-street. The main building measures 55 feet front and 130 feet deep, on the two first floors, and 55 feet front and 100 feet deep, on the two upper floors, and has front wings measuring 25 feet by 26 feet, and rear wings 41 feet by 25 feet. The whole edifice is contracted of brick, with brown-stone facings on Twenty-seventh-street. The rafters are of iron, and the floors of arched brick-work similar to that of the TIMES building, thus rendering the structure fire-proof. There are thirty-four class-rooms in all, affording accommodations for teaching 1,000 pupils in the grammar-school and 1,500 in the primaries. Each class-room is provided with a wardrobe for the use of the scholars of that room, under the immediate eye of the teacher -- thus avoiding much of the loss of wearing apparel complained of at present. There are no less than 14,000 feet of play-ground, of which 5,000 feet is under cover, comprising arrangements for calisthenics. The exits from all the rooms are of ample proportions -- no less than five for the primary department floors, and three for the school-rooms of the older classes. All the stairways used by the children are built of stone. The ventilation and heating are upon the latest approved plans, being calculated to afford the utmost amount of heat and pure air requisite at all seasons. The ventilation system adopted combines the advantages of outlets for foul air from both the top and bottom of the room.

abstract: Our dispatches from Charleston inform us that Col. WARD H. LAMON, the confidential messenger of the Government, reached that city on Saturday last, and yesterday had an interview with Gov. PICKENS and Gen. BEAUREGARD.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Charleston inform us that Col. WARD H. LAMON, the confidential messenger of the Government, reached that city on Saturday last, and yesterday had an interview with Gov. PICKENS and Gen. BEAUREGARD. He subsequently visited Fort Sumpter, in company with Col. DURYEA, one of Gov. PICKENS' staff. Nothing was known as to the nature of his mission, but no doubt is entertained among the Charlestonians that the evacuation of the fort will take place tomorrow. Col. LAMON was expected to return to Washington immediately.

abstract: In my last, I noticed the fact that Senor ANTONIO VARAS had peremptorily refused to allow his name to be used by the Government party, as its candidate for the Presidency. But the organs of that party at Santiago and other towns, persist in keeping his name before the public, which gives great offence to the opposition, who begin to suspect that the Government Party intends to foist Senor VARAS on the country as the next President.

abstract: "There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious association in all other minds.
lead_paragraph: "There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious association in all other minds. Whatever notions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse -- the GOOD Nurse -- the BEST Nurse. Whether we shall have female physicians or not is a question which must be decided by time and principle, and not as a matter of taste. Pride, prejudice, caprice and custom may as well behave themselves, for if there is really a want there will also be a supply -- if there be a 'calling,' there will be a 'coming.' Nature and Human Society are always self-supplying, and though Art and Fashion may hinder, they cannot prevent.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, the case of Jefferds, indicted for the Mathews murder, a habeas corpus had been made returnable, and the prisoner's counsel, Mr. Hall, moved his discharge thereon, either upon his own recognizance, or upon such bail as the Court might determine. District-Attorney Waterbury opposed the motion, giving as his reason for not having previously brought the cause on for trial, that it was one of such importance and difficulty, that he had not yet been able properly to prepare it.

abstract: Many people have doubted, and their doubts will be confirmed by perusing the text of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS' inaugural oration, whether, after all, the Southern States of America have clearly conceived the object of their own secession.
lead_paragraph: Many people have doubted, and their doubts will be confirmed by perusing the text of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS' inaugural oration, whether, after all, the Southern States of America have clearly conceived the object of their own secession. Is it pure zeal for the maintenance and development of their favorite domestic institution, or is the consummation of a natural antagonism of interests, especially in matters of commerce? Is the question of Slavery subordinate to that of Free Trade, or is Free Trade the bribe offered to foreign nations in consideration of their pocketing their scruples about Slavery? We have had the Message of a President, and we have now the address of an Anti-President, yet we are little wiser than before, familiar as we have become during the past year with the manifestoes of outgoing and incoming monarchs, and the utterances of statesmen in every conceivable predicament, we have never read a public document so difficult to analyze and interpret as this. It begins with lofty tribute to the wisdom and patriotism of Southern planters, and a recognition of the provisional character of the existing Government; then comes an allegation that the Union has been "perverted from the purposes for which it was ordained," and a solemn appeal to Heaven that "He who knows the hearts of men will judge of the sincerity with which we intended to preserve the Government of our fathers in its spirit;" next, it repudiates the "abuse of language," by which the term "revolution" has been applied to the act of the South. The allusions to commercial policy which follow seem primarily addressed to European States, but before long, we do not exactly know how, we find ourselves again in the midst of American politics, and discover that Mr. DAVIS is not only preaching non-intervention, based on a "just perception of mutual interests," to his Northern rival, but is actually indulging the hope -- not that Southern fanaticism will be cooled, but that, enlightened by experience, "the States from which we have recently parted may seek to unite their fortunes with ours under the Government we have instituted." Not that Mr. DAVIS cares much whether they do or not. On the contrary, he confidently appeals to the issue of arms, and significantly alludes to "the well-known resources for retaliation upon the commerce of an enemy." He doubts whether there is so "much of homogeneity" between the interests of the two Confederations that "the welfare of every portion would be the aim of the whole." He fearlessly relies on the innate force of a "movement sanctioned by its justice and sustained by a virtuous people," and does not hesitate to assume that Divine Providence is on the side of Slavery, which, probably from motives of delicacy, he never mentions by name, but which must certainly be indicated by one or all of the sounding phrases, "honor, right, liberty and equality," since we are told that it is these principles which inspire "a purpose of high resolve" in the heroic Southerners.

abstract: An accident, which came very near obliterating your correspondent, has prevented any epistle since Sunday. abstract: Our dispatches from Washington indicate that the crisis at Fort Sumpter is approaching. Orders will probably be given to cut off the supplies of Major ANDERSON, and he is thrown back, therefore, upon his provisions in the fort. Whether it is intended to leave him unmolested, until compelled by starvation to surrender, or to attack the fort, is not certain, though the tenor of the intelligence indicates that the latter course will be pursued. It is probable that Major ANDERSON has orders for such an emergency; and while it is useless to speculate upon their character, all will agree, we presume, that a fight for the possession of Fort Sumpter under present circumstances would be a useless and a deplorable event.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Orzalis Y. Butler, indicted for forgery in passing counterfeit money, was put to the bar. One witness was examined, when it became evident that the bill could not be properly identified, and the District Attorney refusing to press the charge, the jury, under instructions from the Court, rendered a verdict of not guilty, and the prisoner was discharged. Counsel for the prisoner declaring that some of the most respectable gentlemen in the City were in Court ready to give his client a good character.

abstract: "There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee, 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious association in all other minds. Whatever notions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse -- the GOOD Nurse -- the BEST Nurse. Whether we shall have female physicians or not is a question which must be decided by time and principle, and not as a matter of taste. Pride, prejudice, caprice and custom may as well behave themselves, for if there is really a want there will also be a supply -- if there be a 'calling,' there will be a 'coming.' Nature and Human Society are always self-supplying, and though Art and Fashion may hinder, they cannot prevent.

abstract: The Special Committee of the Senate to inquire into the alleged corruption among New-York HarborMasters, resumed their investigations at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Astor House, Senator GRANT presiding. Some eight or nine witnesses were examined, and as the investigation took a wide range and was not restricted to the technical rules of Court proceedings, considereble irrelevant matter was intro
lead_paragraph: The Special Committee of the Senate to inquire into the alleged corruption among New-York Harbor-Masters, resumed their investigations at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Astor House, Senator GRANT presiding. Some eight or nine witnesses were examined, and as the investigation took a wide range and was not restricted to the technical rules of Court proceedings, considereble irrelevant matter was introduced in the testimony, some of which appeared to be given under the influence of strong personal feelings. This was particularly exhibited in the chief witness, who appeared as the accuser of Mr. Anable. We have only space for the main points brought out on the examination.

abstract: Fort McRea, now in the hands of the State troops, is built on a low sand spit of the main land, and it appears to rise out of the water. The bank is situated upon what is called Foster's Bank, and overlooks the west side of the mouth of Pensacola Bay. It is what they style a "bastioned" fort, built of brick masonry, with walls some fifteen feet in thickness. It is made for two tiers of guns, under bomb-proof casements, and has one tier en barbette. As far as I am able to ascertain the present armament consists of -- en barbette, 58 24 pounders and 3 ten-inch columbiads; lower tier, 24 42 pounders; second tier, 16 32 pounders and 13 eight inch columbiads. This fortification cost the Federal Government $450,000. In time of war a complete garrison would consist of 700 men. Its guns radiate at the different points of the horizon. The batteries so much talked of as being erected along the beach, amount to the utmost to some ten or fifteen 32-pounders, stolen from the forts they so gloriously captured. As I assured you yesterday, we can reinforce Fort Pickens at any moment the Government desires it.

abstract: It seems that Mr. MASON'S brother-in-law, Col. COOPER, who resigned the office of AdjutantGeneral of the United States, has received the appointment to the corresponding position at Montgomery. At the time of his resignation, his friends stated that he was induced to take the step from his knowledge of the war like policy which would be pursued by the Federal authorities.

abstract: Joseph K. Rigg vs. The Mayor, Aldermen,  This action is brought by the plaintiff, praying the equity powers of the Court to annul a contract and deed taken from the defendant for the purchase of certain property in the vicinity of Eightieth-street in this City. It appears from the complaint ...
lead_paragraph: Joseph K. Rigg vs. The Mayor, Aldermen, &c. -- This action is brought by the plaintiff, praying the equity powers of the Court to annul a contract and deed taken from the defendant for the purchase of certain property in the vicinity of Eightieth-street in this City. It appears from the complaint of the plaintff that the defendant advertised certain property for sale, at public auction, the proceeds of which were to be applied to the Sinking Fund of this City. On the 27th of December, 1852, the said property was sold pursuant to the advertisement, at which sale the plaintiff became the purchaser of twelve of the said lots, for which he took a warranty deed with full covenants. The price paid by the plaintiff was the sum of $9,000, of this $2,250 were paid in cash, and a mortgage given back to the defendants for the balance, on which plaintiff alleges that he has regularly paid the interest. The plaintiff then states that he then entered into possession of the premises conveyed, but that on the 5th of February, 1856, defendants entered upon the premises and evicted him therefrom, insisting, as alleged, that they entered upon the possession of the said property by virtue of an Act of the Legislature relative to public parks in this City. The plaintiff further alleges that at the time defendants sold said property to him they were endeavoring to have the said Act passed by the Legislature, and that such Act was passed at the special instance of the defendants. The plaintiff further alleges that adequate satisfaction has been denied him by the defendants, and asks, the equity powers of this Court to cancel the deed and the mortgage, and that he be fully compensated for all charges that he has been put to since he came into possession. The defendants deny all the material allegations in the complaint, aver that it became necessary, under and by virtue of said act, to appropriate said property, that adequate compensation has been awarded by Commissioners appointed pursuant to said act, and that the plaintiff has refused to accept the same.

abstract: The Washington correspondent of the Journal of Commerce says: "The Seward policy may prevail, and that is, for the call of a National Convention as soon as practicable, and submitting to it the expediency of a provision for the peaceful dissolution of the Union, by such boundary lines as may be determined upon, or for reconstructing the same. Meanwhile, Mr. SEWARD proposes that the Federal Government shall avoid even the appearance of a coercive policy."

abstract: The appointment Of BENJ. F. ISHERWOOD to be Engineer-in-Chief of the Navy gives very marked satisfaction to those in the service. He is a native of this City, and was educated for the profession of civil engineer, which he practiced before entering the Engineer corps of the Navy-having been employed as an assistant upon the Croton water-works, the Erie, and the Albany and Schenectady Railroads.
lead_paragraph: The appointment of BENJ. F. ISHERWOOD to be Engineer-in-Chief of the Navy gives very marked satisfaction to those in the service. He is a native of this City, and was educated for the profession of civil engineer, which he practiced before entering the Engineer corps of the Navy -- having been employed as an assistant upon the Croton water-works, the Erie, and the Albany and Schenectady Railroads. After the completion of the latter road, he published a work giving a complete description of its bridges. This, was very favorably received in Great Britain, where it was considered as the best publication then extant regarding the American system of wooden bridges.

abstract: All who have carefully watched the operations of the slave-traders in this City during the past three or four years, must be satisfied that a clean sweep is needed in the offices of the United States Marshal and District Attorney -- the heads of these Departments being no doubt responsible in a certain degree for whatever connivance may have taken place; but the subordinates -- clerks, deputies and runners -- being the men who must actually have been brought into close contact with the slave-trading machinery of corruption. As one rotten sheep is sufficient to infect a flock, so one of these old hands, experienced in the golden gains of guilty connivance, would be more than enough to endanger, if not inflict and utterly poison, the moral health of two dozen unsophisticated associates. Let there, therefore, be a clean sweep in both offices as soon as new men are appointed by the President, so that not a vestige of the horrible existing system may be left; and let the office-rooms be fumigated and made subject to all the most powerful disinfectants, so that, if possible, the leprosy of certain of the late dwellers in these temples of sin may not be transmitted to their successors.

The Republican City Convention, called for the purpose of nominating a candidate for Mayur, was held last evening in the General Committee Room, No. 9 Court-street. The Convention was organized by electing D. O. BRADLEY, Esq., of the Sixth Ward, Chairman, and J.N. STEARNS, of the Seventeenth Ward, and W.L. HUBBELL, of the Twelfth Ward, Secretaries. An informal ballot for a
lead_paragraph: REPUBLICAN MAYORALTY CONVENTION -- HENRY A. KENT NOMINATED. -- The Republican City Convention, called for the purpose of nominating a candidate for Mayur, was held last evening in the General Committee Room, No. 9 Court-street. The Convention was organized by electing D. O. BRADLEY, Esq., of the Sixth Ward, Chairman, and J.N. STEARNS, of the Seventeenth Ward, and W.L. HUBBELL, of the Twelfth Ward, Secretaries. An informal ballot for a candidate for Mayor was then had, with the following result: Henry A. Kent, 13; Frederick Scholes, 13; Thomas H. Rodman, 9; Wm.A. Coit, 8; George Hall, 7; Stephen Crowell, 3; Smith J. Eastman, 3; E.A. Lambert, I. On the first formal ballot the vote stood: Kent, 25; Hall, 19; Coit, 9. Twenty nine votes being necessary for a choice, the second formal ballot was taken, and resulted as follows: Kent, 29; Hall, 19; Coit, 9; whereupon the nomination of Mr. KENT was made unanimous. The officers of the meeting were appointed a Committee to notify Mr. KENT of his nomination; and the Convention, after giving three hearty cheers for the nominee, adjourned to meet again upon the call of the Chairman. Mr. KENT was once a member of the Common Council for two years, and for one year was President of that body. He resides at Bay Ridge. The Committee last night proceeded to his residence to fulfill the duties assigned them, when they ascertained from Mr. KENT that he would positively decline to accept the nomination -- purely, however, from business considerations. The Committee have accordingly called the Convention to meet again to-night at 8 o'clock, at the same place, to make another nomination.

abstract: Our telegraphic dispatch, giving the Mexican news per steamer. Tennessee at NewOrleans, contains several interesting items, one of the most important of which is, that Monsieur SALIGNY, the French Minister, had presented his credentials to the Constitutional Government, and been formally received.
lead_paragraph: Our telegraphic dispatch, giving the Mexican news per steamer. Tennessee at New-Orleans, contains several interesting items, one of the most important of which is, that Monsieur SALIGNY, the French Minister, had presented his credentials to the Constitutional Government, and been formally received. This is a most decided step in advance, and cannot fail to add materially to the strength and permanency of the Liberal Government, which is now recognized by, and in full and friendly communication with the United States, England and France.

abstract: The South Carolina State Convention reassembled at Charleston yesterday, and the very first action taken by it indicates a disposition on the part of a portion of its members to precipitate the question of Fort Sumpter to a speedy solution. A resolution was offered that all the supplies of provisions which Maj. ANDERSON has ...
lead_paragraph: The South Carolina State Convention reassembled at Charleston yesterday, and the very first action taken by it indicates a disposition on the part of a portion of its members to precipitate the question of Fort Sumpter to a speedy solution. A resolution was offered that all the supplies of provisions which Maj. ANDERSON has heretofore been permitted to obtain in Charleston be cut off, and that all mail facilities be denied to the garrison. The resolution is to be acted upon to-day. The correspondent of the Associated Press is of the opinion that it will be voted down, but a dispatch received in Washington expresses a different view. The latter also states that Gen. BEAUREGARD has notified the authorities at Montgomery that he is ready to commence operations against the fort. Meantime our Washington correspondent positively asserts that no order for the evacuation has yet gone forward, though there is little doubt that it will be sent this week. The visit of Col. LAMON, it appears, was partly on his own private account.

abstract: It would be encouraging could we believe that the delay in the appointment of the Commissioner of Patents is occasioned by a desire to consult the scientific fitness of things. There was, indeed, a flicker of hope in the telegram that one of the candidates whose names have been prominent, was set aside on account of "incompetence." And as the ...
lead_paragraph: It would be encouraging could we believe that the delay in the appointment of the Commissioner of Patents is occasioned by a desire to consult the scientific fitness of things. There was, indeed, a flicker of hope in the telegram that one of the candidates whose names have been prominent, was set aside on account of "incompetence." And as the mere mooting of the question of intellectual fitness as a condition of assuming the direction of this Bureau is a daring innovation, it may be regarded as a concession to right reason that will prove the entering-wedge to other and much-needed changes.

abstract: The action of the conspirators is almost telegraphic in its rapidity. With them everything depends upon haste. To stand still, even to waver, is to be lost. Hence, now that the mad rush of States from the Union has come to a halt, the precipitators hasten to turn their energies in the direction of our great Southwestern Territories; and already it appears that these, in turn, are to be cajoled or coerced into becoming dependencies of the new Negro Empire.

lead_paragraph: It would be extremely pleasant to believe that the Secession movement is merely on paper, -- and that it does not affect the ordinary operations of business in the slightest degree. Some of our cotemporaries have succeeded thus far in taking this very agreeable view of the case, and dismiss as idle and foolish all apprehension of practical inconveniences from this quarter. They insist that all the complaints of the new Tariff are unfounded and merely for effect, -- and that there is not the slightest need for any new legislation upon this subject.

abstract: THE BURGLARY AT THE NEW-YORK EXCHANGE BANK. The remarkable burglary at the New-York Exchange Bank, particulars of which were published in yesterday's TIMES, was the theme of general remark during the entire day. The peculiar features of the matter served to attract a throng about the premises, who gazed at the Bank and peered into the basement which the robbers had occupied in hopes of catching a glimpse of the mouth of the subterranean passage.
lead_paragraph: THE BURGLARY AT THE NEW-YORK EXCHANGE BANK. -- The remarkable burglary at the New-York Exchange Bank, particulars of which were published in yesterday's TIMES, was the theme of general remark during the entire day. The peculiar features of the matter served to attract a throng about the premises, who gazed at the Bank and peered into the basement which the robbers had occupied in hopes of catching a glimpse of the mouth of the subterranean passage. To avoid annoyance from the crowd, the officers of the Bank, early in the day, called for a force of police sufficient to keep them in check. Capt. JAMESON complied by sending a squad of men, who were inexorable in their determination of allowing none to go and look at the excavation. The police feel confident that the bold thieves engaged in this burglary will finally fall into their hands, and the detectives are sanguine of their ability to obtain evidence sufficient to bring the guilty to justice. Capt. JAMESON and Detective KEEFE have arrested an Englishman named JOHN SHEFFIELD, who has the reputation of being an expert burglar, on suspicion of being implicated in the matter. The prisoner is said to have been a confederate and companion of DICK COLLARD, DANIEL BARTLETT and JOSEPH MEYERS, against whom the record is very bad. COLLARD and the other men were arrested by Detective KEEFE a few weeks ago, having been found together under suspicious circumstances in the vicinity of the very bank where the present burglary was perpetrated. Upon COLLARD at that time an assortment of skeleton keys was found, with wax for taking impressions of locks, and Justice KELLY deemed the fact evidence of a character to warrant his detention, and he is now in confinement at the City Prison. With regard to SHEFFIELD, there is no positive evidence against him, but his manner and insinuations are such that the officers entertain a strong belief in his complicity with the rogues for whom they are in search. He is held, pending further developments. Mr. JOHN ALCOCK, the fortunate manufacturer of rag carpets, to whom the burglars paid $1 000 cash for the goodwill and fixtures of the basement, presented himself at the Third Ward Station house during the day, but as no suspicion attaches to him in the case, he was not placed under arrest, He left his address with Capt. JAMESON in case this testimony should be required.

abstract: Albert L. Peck vs. Thomas Burke, et al. -- This is an action against the burglars, whose daring attempt to rob the New-York Exchange Bank, by digging a tunnel from the house, No. 189 Greenwich-street, two doors above the Bank, to the vault in which the treasures of the bank are kept, was yesterday made known to the readers of the TIMES. The object of this action is to secure, by attachment, the property, carpets, &c., left in the store occupied by the burglars, and from which they have so suddenly decamped. Mr. Peck, it will be remembered was accustomed to leave his box of money with the bank each night for safekeeping. On this occasion the box was brought in a little later than usual, and the Bank clerk did not put the box inside the safe, which had then been locked up for the night, but placed it on the top of the safe, but inside the vault. The robbers were unable to open the safe, although by stripping the bars, boring holes, &c., they tried every possible means to do so. Mr. Peck's box, however, they took with them, which contained about a thousand dollars in money.
lead_paragraph: Albert L. abstract: The Auxiliary Steam Fruiter Young Rover, Capt. HUMPHREY, made her first passage from this port to Leghorn in thirty-four days. She is a full rigged bark, with Cunningham's rig applied to her topsails and topgallant sails, and her propeller, like that of a ship of war, when not in use, is holsted up. The first three days after leaving port, she had a spanking breeze, carrying a reefed foresail and topsails half reduced, going from ten to twelve knots, and making good weather; but afterward the wind changed to N.E. and blew a hurricane, which compelled her to lie to three days; the rest of the passage she encountered strong, variable winds until she reached within 180 miles of her destination, when the weather became calm. For the first time since leaving Boston, steam was got up, and she performed admirably, averaging five knots an hour, with only eighty revolutions a minute, against a heavy head swell, under steam alone. She entered the port of Leghorn in gallant style. Capt. HUMPHREY writes that she sails fast, works well, lies to like a duck, and performs under steam to his entire satisfation. The rig, in all its details, he concludes cannot be improved. -- Boston Traveller.
lead_paragraph: The Auxiliary Steam Fruiter Young Rover, Capt. HUMPHREY, made her first passage from this port to Leghorn in thirty-four days. She is a full rigged bark, with Cunningham's rig applied to her topsails and topgallant sails, and her propeller, like that of a ship of war, when not in use, is holsted up. The first three days after leaving port, she had a spanking breeze, carrying a reefed foresail and topsails half reduced, going from ten to twelve knots, and making good weather; but afterward the wind changed to N.E. and blew a hurricane, which compelled her to lie to three days; the rest of the passage she encountered strong, variable winds until she reached within 180 miles of her destination, when the weather became calm. For the first time since leaving Boston, steam was got up, and she performed admirably, averaging five knots an hour, with only eighty revolutions a minute, against a heavy head swell, under steam alone. She entered the port of Leghorn in gallant style. Capt. HUMPHREY writes that she sails fast, works well, lies to like a duck, and performs under steam to his entire satisfation. The rig, in all its details, he concludes cannot be improved. -- Boston Traveller.

abstract: There is little new to be said about Fort Sumpter. Col. LAMON, it will be seen, by our Washington dispatches, has returned to that city, and has communicated the result of his observations to the Government. Whether the order for the evacuation has yet been issued is not positively known in Washington. The Charlestonians are confident that the evacuation will take place immediately, and expect that Col. LAMON will return at once with the requisite instructions for Major ANDERSON. The Southern Commissioners yet remain inactive at the Capital. They expect, however, in the course of a week, to receive definite instructions from Montgomery.

abstract: The annual plague of house-moving will shortly be upon us, and present indications lead to the belief that the transfers of household gods and goods to new locations will be much greater than in any former year. In view of the cloudy aspect now worn by national affairs, men af prudence in all the walks of life are shortening? sail and preparing, if need be, to ride out a storm. Business men now inhabiting houses for which they pay from seven hundred to one thousand dollars a year, are actively on the lookout for residences to be rented at from four to six hundred dollars annually; and we have heard from many landlords that the class of men who are at present offering to become tenants of high-priced mansions, at rents ranging from one thousand to fifteen hundred dollars a year, are not of the kind able to furnish adequate security, or to hold out any hope of proving either permanent or profitable tenants. So general is this remark, that in many cases within our knowledge, house-owners have largely reduced the rent for the year opening next 1st of May to their present tenants, preferring the certainty of retaining house-hirers whom they know and in whom they have confidence, to the chances of either picking up an occupant of doubtful solvency, or allowing their property to remain altogether untenanted and unproductive for the next twelve months.

lead_paragraph: A copy of the following communication was handed in at the office of the City Inspector, where it was mislaid, without his inspection. He expressed the opinion, however, that the subject did not come under his jurisdiction. I respectfully offer my humble suggestions for the scrutiny of the public, of the Medical Faculty, and of the Bond of Health of this City. I remark that Disinfection is recommended for removing putrescence in cases where other means of cleansing cannot conveniently be applied. I understand that the Commissioners of Charity have made such improvements in the late filthy Tombs prison as to render disinfection unnecessary. The following is at your service if you consider it worthy of publication:

abstract: Gorham D. Abbott vs. The American Hard Rubber Company et als. -- In this case, which has heretofore been noticed in the TIMES, pursuant to the lease granted by the Court, the plaintiff, by a supplemental complaint, seeks to restrain the American Hard Rubber Company, a corporation recently created in this State, (which is not to be confounded with the original Hard Rubber Company of Connecticut,) from any interference or control of the property and assets of the original Corporation, and from the use of the same corporate name. It will be remembered that the property of the original Corporation was transferred to certain parties, in fraud, as the plaintiff claims, of the rights of the stockholders. It is claimed that the property of the original Company has come into the hands of the new organization, and that the new organization had notice of the rights of the plaintiff in the premises.

abstract: The City of Buffalo vs. Orasamus H. Marshall, administrator, &c. -- This case was referred to in the TIMES of yesterday. The main question of law involved in its determination is, what amounts to a dedication of a public street within the limits of a Corporation? The Holland Land Company, which formerly owned the entire site of the village of Buffalo, dedicated a street up and down the Big Buffalo Creek. That road was subsequently recognized and recorded by the proper authorities of the village. Afterwards, however, the City of Buffalo opened a new street, running to and from this creek, which covers the lot in controversy.
