abstract: O.U.A. CELEBRATION. Washington Chapter No. 2, O.U.A., celebrated their sixteenth anniversary on Tuesday evening by a ball and supper at the Appollo Rooms. The Stars and Stripes were beautifully draped about the room, while the insignia of the Order was interspersed within the folds of the flag at regular intervals, and patriotic mottoes met the eye on every side. At about 10 o'clock a company of 300 ...
lead_paragraph: O.U.A. CELEBRATION. -- Washington Chapter No. 2, O.U.A., celebrated their sixteenth anniversary on Tuesday evening by a ball and supper at the Appollo Rooms. The Stars and Stripes were beautifully draped about the room, while the insignia of the Order was interspersed within the folds of the flag at regular intervals, and patriotic mottoes met the eye on every side. At about 10 o'clock a company of 300 ladies and gentlemen took their seats at the table, and after a blessing had been invoked by Rev. Mr. FLAGG, operations were commenced upon the substantials provided. A number of toasts, appropriate to the occasion, were drunk and were responded to by J.W. MASON, H.C. LANIUS, WM. W. OSBORN, HORACE BLISS and others. From one of the speeches we learned that since the organization of Washington Chapter they had received over $22,000, and that after paying all their expenses have a balance of about $6,000 in the Savings Bank. A strong Union sentiment pervaded all the speeches, and so lively and entertaining were they that it was with the greatest reluctance the company left the table and betook themselves to dancing. Wallace's Band was in attendance during the entire evening, and the festivities were kept up until long after midnight.

lead_paragraph: -- The Richmond Examiner is in a sad state of mind. Its normal condition is one of senseless ferocity, and this is stimulated just now by a fearful foreboding which haunts it, that Virginia will not, after all, secede. To bring about this result it resorts to all kinds of influences. It appeals alternately to terror, to interest and to pride. Its Washington correspondent conducts mainly the alarming department of the paper, and reveals such astounding plots on the part of the Federal Government as must make the hair of old Virginia absolutely stand on end. Mr. SEWARD'S subtle machinations form the staple of a good deal of his denunciations. Mr. S. has been soothing the South with assurances of peace:

abstract: The State of Louisiana evidently feels the novel dignity attending its position as a member of the Chivalrous Confederacy, and is accordingly making arrangements on a liberal scale to maintain its Governor hereafter in a style suitable to the magnificent prospects which open before it after the protective duties on sugar shall have been repealed. Acting under this impulse, "the elegant establishment erected by the late United States Government upon the garrison grounds of Baton Rouge for the residence of the commanding officer of the Ordnance Department" has been duly confiscated by the State authorities, and has been duly "appropriated" as a private residence for the Governor of the State and his family! For stealing forts, arsenals or vessels of war, there may have been some pretext, however shallow, of justification. But this following up of the Mint robbery by the larceny of a private dwelling, rather surpasses in cool effrontery and disregard of the Eighth Commandment anything we have yet had from the rattlesnake and pelican region.
lead_paragraph: The State of Louisiana evidently feels the novel dignity attending its position as a member of the Chivalrous Confederacy, and is accordingly making arrangements on a liberal scale to maintain its Governor hereafter in a style suitable to the magnificent prospects which open before it after the protective duties on sugar shall have been repealed. abstract: UNSAFE-BUILD ING ACT." An amendment to the "Unsafe Building act" of last Winter passed the Assembly a few days since by a vote of 76 to 8, and the bill is now before the Senate. This matter is one affecting the safety of human life, not alone by making provision for the proper construction of buildings, but also by ...
lead_paragraph: UNSAFE-BUILDING ACT." -- An amendment to the "Unsafe Building act" of last Winter passed the Assembly a few days since by a vote of 76 to 8, and the bill is now before the Senate. This matter is one affecting the safety of human life, not alone by making provision for the proper construction of buildings, but also by insisting that suitable means of escape should be attached to tenement-houses of this City in case of fire. Some of the provisions of the bill appear to be distasteful to landlords as well as to a considerable portion of the Fire Department, and it is understood that a strong lobby influence is at work to defeat the whole matter. The landlords look upon the twenty-fifth section of the bill with especial disfavor, because it requires fire-proof stairs, balconies, iron bridges, and other means of escape on all isolated houses, containing more than six families; while the firemen find an objectionable feature in the demand that the Inspectors of Buildings must be practical mechanics. They do not think it a fair thing either that the appointment of these officials should be taken out of the hands of the Chief Engineer and his Assistants, where it at present rests, and are in favor of requiring no other qualification for the position than the fact that its incumbent must be an exempt fireman.

abstract: The publication of the aggregate returns of the census of 1860 enables us to present in the form of a compact and striking diagram the relative growth of each State in the Union from the year 1790 until the present time. It is upon precisely the same plan as the diagram by which some few years ago we illustrated the results of the census of 1850. We are indebted now, as we were then, to Prof. GILLESPIE, of Union College, for this idea. The character of the diagram is seen at a glance. In the left hand column the States are arranged in the order of their actual rank in 1790, -- Virginia being first, Massachusetts second, Tennesse sixteenth, &c., in order of population. I the right-hand column they are arranged in the order of their respective ranks in 1860, -- New-York first, Tennessee ninth, Michigan sixteenth, &c. The intervening space is divided into parts, each representing ten years. The heavily shaded lines extending across these columns trace, by their zigzag course, the ups and downs of the several States, in their relative rank at intervals of ten years each, during the seventy years that have elapsed. Thus Virginia, which stood first in 1790, held that rank for two periods until 1810, when she began to decline, and became second in 1820, third in 1830, and fourth in 1840, which position she continued to hold until 1850, when she again began to decline, and is now the fifth. New-York, beginning fifth, became third in ten years, second in ten more, first in ten more, and has held that proud position ever since. The decline of some of the States has been as rapid and marked as the advance of others. Thus, New-Hampshire, standing tenth in 1790, fell to the eleventh in 1800, to the fifteenth, in 1810, and held that position ten years, when she again fell to the eighteenth in 1830, to the twenty-second in 1840, and held that place until 1850, when she entered upon a very rapid relative decline, and in 1860 was the twenty-seventh. Ohio, on the other hand, which entered upon the course in 1800 as the seventeenth., rose to be thirteenth in 1810, to be fifth in 1820, fourth in 1830, and third in 1840 -- the position which she holds at present. Others of the States have been marked by curious alterations. Thus, Mississippi, beginning nineteenth in 1800, held that place ten years; in 1820 she had fallen to the twenty-first, and in 1830 to the twenly-sccond, when she began to rise, and, in 1840 stood seventeenth, fifteenth in 1850, and fourteenth in 1860. Arkansas is the only State which held the same relative rank in 1850 as she had at the beginning, and her position has been changed every ten years since her existence, and is now twenty-fifth, which is one degree higher than she started, and is the same which she held in 1840.
lead_paragraph: The publication of the aggregate returns of the census of 1860 enables us to present in the form of a compact and striking diagram the relative growth of each State in the Union from the year 1790 until the present time. It is upon precisely the same plan as the diagram by which some few years ago we illustrated the results of the census of 1850. We are indebted now, as we were then, to Prof. GILLESPIE, of Union College, for this idea. The character of the diagram is seen at a glance. In the left hand column the States are arranged in the order of their actual rank in 1790, -- Virginia being first, Massachusetts second, Tennesse sixteenth, &c., in order of population. I the right-hand column they are arranged in the order of their respective ranks in 1860, -- New-York first, Tennessee ninth, Michigan sixteenth, &c. The intervening space is divided into parts, each representing ten years. The heavily shaded lines extending across these columns trace, by their zigzag course, the ups and downs of the several States, in their relative rank at intervals of ten years each, during the seventy years that have elapsed. Thus Virginia, which stood first in 1790, held that rank for two periods until 1810, when she began to decline, and became second in 1820, third in 1830, and fourth in 1840, which position she continued to hold until 1850, when she again began to decline, and is now the fifth. New-York, beginning fifth, became third in ten years, second in ten more, first in ten more, and has held that proud position ever since. The decline of some of the States has been as rapid and marked as the advance of others. Thus, New-Hampshire, standing tenth in 1790, fell to the eleventh in 1800, to the fifteenth, in 1810, and held that position ten years, when she again fell to the eighteenth in 1830, to the twenty-second in 1840, and held that place until 1850, when she entered upon a very rapid relative decline, and in 1860 was the twenty-seventh. Ohio, on the other hand, which entered upon the course in 1800 as the seventeenth., rose to be thirteenth in 1810, to be fifth in 1820, fourth in 1830, and third in 1840 -- the position which she holds at present. Others of the States have been marked by curious alterations. Thus, Mississippi, beginning nineteenth in 1800, held that place ten years; in 1820 she had fallen to the twenty-first, and in 1830 to the twenly-sccond, when she began to rise, and, in 1840 stood seventeenth, fifteenth in 1850, and fourteenth in 1860. Arkansas is the only State which held the same relative rank in 1850 as she had at the beginning, and her position has been changed every ten years since her existence, and is now twenty-fifth, which is one degree higher than she started, and is the same which she held in 1840.

abstract: At the close of last week, our Banks held $39,480,734 in specie, being an increase for the week of $3,261,058, with recent arrivals, which will largely swell the statement for the next. This amount is unprecedented in the history of our Banks. So wide a departure from the ordinary rule proves some great change in the ordinary routine of business. Is it a salutary one, indicating great prosperity, or is it the result and evidence of the present commercial embarrassment?

abstract: It appears after all that our distinguished fellow-citizen and late Congressional Representative, JOHN COCHRANE, was not the recipient of any special musical honors during his late visit to Richmond, Va.; though it is sorrowfully admitted by certain worthy residents of that chivalrous capital, that Mr. COCHRANE did receive the overplus, or waste-pipe flow of a musical ovation designed in honor of a Lieutenant JAY, "who had resigned his commission in the United States Army," -- doubtless after having received assurances of being made Captain in the Cotton State Army. It was in glorification of JAY, it seems, that the serenade was given; and the call for COCHRANE to appear on the balcony and make a speech was nothing more than unpremeditated or incidental and ill-considered addition to the programme of jubilation in JAY'S honor -- Mr. COCHRANE owing his invitation exclusively to the fact that he chanced to be boarding at the same hotel with the seceded Lieutenant.

abstract: Judging from the fact that twenty-five bills are said to have passed their third readings in the House of Assembly on last Tuesday, it may well be doubted whether the non-appointment of a Grinding Committee is a blessing without bane. With such a Committee in full operation and controlling the machinery of the ...
lead_paragraph: Judging from the fact that twenty-five bills are said to have passed their third readings in the House of Assembly on last Tuesday, it may well be doubted whether the non-appointment of a Grinding Committee is a blessing without bane. With such a Committee in full operation and controlling the machinery of the House, it is very true that a few doubtful or even bad bills may at times have been forced through without sufficient consideration; but under the system now prevailing, of no special examining Committee, and but a limited number of days for the continuance of the session, we are threatened with the passage of every bill on the General Calendar, utterly without reference to questions of merit or legality, and simply for the purpose of saving time.

abstract: Our late visitor, M. DU CHAILLU, bids fair to be the lion of the next London season, in a literary and scientific point of view. His book has been engaged by Mr. MURRAY on exceedingly liberal terms, and that astute publisher looks forward to its meeting with as much success as his great prize, Mr. MOTLEY'S History of the Netherlands. It will be issued under the title of Explorations ...
lead_paragraph: Our late visitor, M. DU CHAILLU, bids fair to be the lion of the next London season, in a literary and scientific point of view. His book has been engaged by Mr. MURRAY on exceedingly liberal terms, and that astute publisher looks forward to its meeting with as much success as his great prize, Mr. MOTLEY's History of the Netherlands. It will be issued under the title of Explorations and Adventures in parts of Equatorial Africa never before visited; with accounts of the manners and customs of the people, and the chase of the gorilla, the nest-building ape, chimpanzee, crocodile, elephant, hippopotamus, &c. With map and illustrations. At a late meeting of the Geographical Society, Sir RODERIC I. MURCHIESON in the chair, at which M. DU CHAILLU gave a synopsis of his adventures, the commendations of the first living authority, Professor OWEN, were such as only discoveries of the greatest importance could justify. He stated, emphatically, that the additions to Zoology, made by M. DU CHAILLU, consisted of two thousand undescribed species of birds, and two hundred of the class mammalia, all new to science. Recalling the young Frenchman has received, would now produce a different result. His book will be brought out here by Messrs. HARPERS, who are, indeed, the original publishers, the work being prepared for them.

abstract: -The boiler which furnished the steam for driving the machinery of the Michigan Flouring Mill. in Detroit, exploded with terrific violence on March 18. The engineer, JAMES COLLINS, who was tending his engine at the time, was buried up in the ruins, but was taken out unhurt. An employe in the planing mill, at work at a lathe, escaped injury, although the lathe itself was broken to pieces. George S. and J.H. BOWEN, well-known Lake-street merchants, were passing down State-street, some thirty rods from the mill, when the explosion occurred, and were completely enveloped in the steam, dust and flying fragments of iron and timbers. A long, heavy flue fell directly behind them, crushing their buggy and missing them only by a few inches. Other persons had equally miraculous escapes. Shortly after the accident, a fire broke out in the ruins, but it was promptly extinguished. The cause of the explosion is not stated, if indeed it is known. It was certainly a miraculous escape from something far worse than the loss of $3,000, which will cover the entire damage.

abstract: Senators DOUGLAS and BRECKINRIDGE do not agree now any better than they did during the Presidential canvass. The former stands by the Union, -- the latter would take ground against it if he thought it would be safe. Mr. DOUGLAS declares that the South has no ground of complaint against the Union: -- Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, on the other hand, thinks that unless their wrongs are redressed, they will be perfectly justified in seceding. Upon all these points the two Senators are distinctly and decidedly at variance.

abstract: REPUBLICAN MAYORALTY CONVENTION -- NOMINATION OF FREDERICK SCHOLES. -- Mr. HENRY A. KENT having declined the nomination as a candidate for Mayor, tendered him by the Republican Convention on Friday evening last, that body reassembled last evening to fill the vacancy. An informal ballot was taken, which resulted as follows: FREDERICK SCHOLES, 39 votes; WILLIAM COIT, 16. On motion, Mr. SCHOLES was nominated by acclamation. A Committee then waited upon Mr. SCHOLES, who in a short time was presented to the Convention, when, in a few brief remarks, he accepted the nomination. The Convention then adjourned sine die. Mr. SCHOLES now represents the Nineteenth Ward in the Board of Aldermen.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. Journalists seem to enjoy an unusual degree of success just now. Not only do they obtain a share of political rewards which engross men's minds so much, but the more worthy honors of literature are grasped by them with a steady hand. Mr. WILKINS, the dramatic critic of the Herald, was fortunate enough last evening to win the approval of a critical audience for his latest bantling.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Journalists seem to enjoy an unusual degree of success just now. Not only do they obtain a share of political rewards which engross men's minds so much, but the more worthy honors of literature are grasped by them with a steady hand. Mr. WILKINS, the dramatic critic of the Herald, was fortunate enough last evening to win the approval of a critical audience for his latest bantling. The mere record of the fact is sufficient to prove that he deserved it, for in this City a dull dramatic jury is unknown. If a play is bad, the verdict is prompt; if good, equally unhesitating and to the point. Against the hordes of boredom, come they in musical, literary or dramatic shape, all New-York protests vehemently and with utter loathing.

abstract: On Tuesday night two boatmen named William Smith and Edward Stubbs, called for beer in the porter-house of Andrew Faeber, No. 73 James-street, and paid therefor with a counterfeit $2 bill on the Mer- ...
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night two boatmen named William Smith and Edward Stubbs, called for beer in the porter-house of Andrew Faeber, No. 73 James-street, and paid therefor with a counterfeit $2 bill on the Merchants' Bank of Lowell, Mass. Both left the place, but Faeber discovered the cheat in time to have them arrested. After the men were in the hands of the Police, Stubbs was observed to throw a bill away but other counterfeits were found upon him. Justice KELLY committed both prisoners for examination.

abstract: James S. Egbert vs. The Mayor of New-York. -- This action is brought by the plaintiff, who was appointed clerk of the Centre Market in 1851 to recover the sum of $358 95. He alleges that, by virtue of his appointment, he was entitled to rooms over the market for family purposes, but that in 1855 the defendants took the same from him and deprived him of their use. He, therefore, claims that he has been thereby put to the expense and damaged to the extent of $358 95.
lead_paragraph: James S. Egbert vs. The Mayor of New-York. -- This action is brought by the plaintiff, who was appointed clerk of the Centre Market in 1851 to recover the sum of $358 95. abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. -- Next to Mr. FORREST'S unprecedented engagement, the most auspicious event of the season is the return home of Nixon's Royal Circus, which took place last evening, and was witnessed by an audience packed to the steaming point. The troupe has lately been in Havana, and in that gay capital has enjoyed a success which was not, we hope, quite so bad a failure as ordinary successes are apt to be there. The HANLONS were greatly admired; ZOYARA created a sensation, and a Spanish Clown revenged himself on his species by making jokes, which, it may readily be believed, were no better than they should be. All this without the horses, which, after all, constitute a portion of the attractions. Mr. NIXON returned a short time since flushed with his triumph, and with his really excellent troupe will remain at his present quarters until the 1st of May, when it is expected the house will be rented for other purposes. The performances last evening were thoroughly excellent -- the CLINE BROTHERS, very capital acrobats, taking the place of the HANLONS, who are temporarily disabled by a broken neck, back-bone, or other trifle of the kind. Mlle. ZOYARA made her appearance in a brilliant act of equitation, aud was warmly received by the audience.

abstract: The "muffled" movement in Poland, unanimous and resolute as it assuredly is, and spreading with formidable celerity from the centre to the borders of the land, is significant of a most serious and self-reliant sentiment, -- one truly national in its character, and intelligently cognizant of the moral sympathy of the times, as manifested in the healthy progress of liberal ideas throughout Europe. Nor is it to the Poles alone that, in the existing complication, this sympathy is confined. They seem to impart no more than they receive, and the generous opinions for which they live and hope, are reflected upon them from autocratic minds. Prince GORTSCHAKOFF recommends that their tranquil but earnest petition to be reinstalled in their traditions and their aspirations, be granted; and the same Czar who glorifies his dynasty by the emancipation of 45,000,000 of serfs, claims additional lustre for it by bestowing upon the Kingdom of Poland a separate Council of State, with the patriot Prince ZAMOISKY at the head of it. Such, is the Czar's reply to the People's petition, as brought to Warsaw, on the 13th inst., by Gen. MAYENDORFF.
lead_paragraph: The "muffled" movement in Poland, unanimous and resolute as it assuredly is, and spreading with formidable celerity from the centre to the borders of the land, is significant of a most serious and self-reliant sentiment, -- one truly national in its character, and intelligently cognizant of the moral sympathy of the times, as manifested in the healthy progress of liberal ideas throughout Europe. Nor is it to the Poles alone that, in the existing complication, this sympathy is confined. They seem to impart no more than they receive, and the generous opinions for which they live and hope, are reflected upon them from autocratic minds. Prince GORTSCHAKOFF recommends that their tranquil but earnest petition to be reinstalled in their traditions and their aspirations, be granted; and the same Czar who glorifies his dynasty by the emancipation of 45,000,000 of serfs, claims additional lustre for it by bestowing upon the Kingdom of Poland a separate Council of State, with the patriot Prince ZAMOISKY at the head of it. Such, is the Czar's reply to the People's petition, as brought to Warsaw, on the 13th inst., by Gen. MAYENDORFF.

abstract: The Hibirnia, one of the large new paddle-wheel steamships, built for the Atlantic Royal Mail Company, and commanded by Capt. PROWSE, late chief officer of the Great Eastern, went out to Stoke's-bayon the morning of the 12th for an official trial in the presence of the Government authorities. This vessel was built by the firm of PALMER BROTHERS & Co., at Jarrow, on the Tyne, and the following are her leading dimensions; Length over all, 378 feet; length of keel, 360 feet 5 inches; beam, 40 feet 4 inches; depth of hold, 29 feet 2 inches; breadth, over paddles, 71 feet 6 inches; registered tonnage, 1,520.99. She is propelled by three oscillating engines of 800 nominal and 3,500 actual horse-power, with cylinders 80 inches in diameter; has 8 boilers, with 20,000 square feet of heating surface, and 40 furnaces, fitted up with BEARDSMORE'S and GALLOWAY'S patent superheaters. The ship is built in water-tight compartments. She makes up a total of 650 berths, 567 of which are for passengers, and the whole of the saloonand cabin accommodation is of the most superior character. The trial to-day took place under verydisadvantageous circumstances, the wind blowing heavily from the northwest, the force being calculated at from 6 to 8. Four runs were made at the measured mile, with the following results: First run, four minutes eight seconds, equal to 14.516 knots per hour; second, four minutes ten seconds, or 14.400 knots. third, 4m. 12sec., or 14,285 knots; fourth, 3 minutes 57 seconds, or 15,190 knots; average of the four runs, 14,500 knots per hour. Revolutions of engines, 22 per minute; pressure of steam, 23 pounds to the square inch; vacuum, 25 pounds; draught of water, 16 feet aft, and 16 feet 3 inches forward; weight on board, 670 tons of coal and 60 tons of ballast. There were a few official and scientific gentlemen present to witness the trial, inducing Capt. PATEY, R.N., Admiralty Superintendent or Mail Packets at this port; Er. DINNEN. Admiralty Surveyor, from Portsmouth; Messrs. MURRAY and RUBIE, Surveyors to the Board of Trade; Mr. WEIR, the Company's Manager; and Mr. GLOVER, their Superintending Engineer; Messrs. PALMERS, PORTER, &c. The Hibernia will leave for Galway in a day or two, and take the mails from that port, on the 26th inst., for St. John's, New-Brunswick, and New-York. Another of the Atlantic Company's new fleet, named the Columbia, under the command of Capt. ROBERT LEITH, arrived here yesterday, and has been decked for the purpose of undergoing the necessary official survey before taking her place on the Galway line. She will be followed in a few days by the Anglia, also to be docked and surveyed. The Columbia and Anglia have been built by Messrs. MARTIN, SAMUELSON & Co., of Hull, and are sister ships to the Hibernia, as far as relates to dimensions, tonnage, and general proportions.

abstract: NATIONAL UNION DEMOCRATIC CITY CONVENTION. -- The delegates to the above Convention held an adjourned meeting last night at Cooper Hall, in Jersey City. A motion to withdraw the name of Mr. THOS. E. TILDEN, for Recorder, was lost by a tie vote. Nearly all of the Democratic delegates then withdrew. PATRICK H. NUGENT then moved that the Convention adjourn sine die. The motion was lost, when he withdrew, leaving only Messrs. KEENAN, WORTENDYEE and COX to represent the Democracy in the Convention. The following nominations were men made: For Assessors, LOUIS M. DECAMP (Amer.) and SMITH MEAD (Dem.) Collector of Taxes, SAMUEL A. FRENCH (Dem.) Water Commissioners, JOHN CASSIDY (short term) and EPHRAIM PRAY (long term.) The nomination of Mr. AUGUSTUS A. HARDENBERGH, for Mayor, was not positively accepted. He left the matter in the hands of the Convention. It is stated that Hon. SAMUEL A. FRENCH will be nominated by his friends for Mayor.

Water Commissioners, JOHN CASSIDY (short term) and EPHRAIM PRAY (long term.) The nomination of Mr. AUGUSTUS A. HARDENBERGH, for Mayor, was not positively accepted. He left the matter in the hands of the Convention. It is stated that Hon. SAMUEL A. FRENCH will be nominated by his friends for Mayor.

abstract: No communication has yet been received from the Administration by the Southern Commissioners, indicating the policy to be pursued towards the Southern Confederacy, notwithstanding the assertions which have been made to the contrary. They expect to be satisfied on this point, however, in a few days. A story was current in Washington yesterday that they had received positive intelligence of the evacuation of Fort Sumpter, but it proved, on inquiry, to be incorrect. They have no doubt that the evacuation will soon take place, if it has not already been effected.

abstract: The finest poem of the German HEINE is that in which the palm-tree and the pine are depicted, surrounded by the opposing associations of the desert and the snow-drift, and Mr. CHURCH seems resolved that his fame shall rest upon a painted antithesis of the same character. Having achieved a world-wide reputation by his "Heart of the Andes," in which all the luxuriance of tropical life, and all the varied beauty of organic lines and colors, are displayed in most brilliant effect, he is now prepared to gratify the public with a "View in the Arctic Region," which by its excellence fully confirms the law of esthetics, so frequently set forth by the late Prof. DOD, in his lectures on "Architecture " -- that none appreciate any point of beauty in nature or art so well as those who have entered into the spirit of its opposite. In these two paintings of Mr. CHURCH we have, to a degree striking enough to become a historical and classical instance, an illustration of the fact that "diversity of sentiment does not interfere with unity of excellence" in the works of a single man.

In these two paintings of Mr. CHURCH we have, to a degree striking enough to become a historical and classical instance, an illustration of the fact that "diversity of sentiment does not interfere with unity of excellence" in the works of a single man.

abstract: NEW-YORK UNIVERSITY -- JUNIOR EXHIBITION. -- The exhibition of the Junior Class of the New-York University took place yesterday, in the large Chapel of the Institution on Washington square, and the students of the class who took part in it acquitted themselves, in the terms of their tertiary motto, with a ter-tiary termination, "Fortiter, fideliter, feliciter." An overflowing, partly feminine and entirely gratified audience listened to the exercises in public speaking which commenced at 10 1/2 A.M., and lasted several hours. The crush of crinoline and wreck of hoops, when belated damsets endeavored to gain ingress to the crowded hall, was fearful to contemplate and direful to undergo. Chancellor FERRIS presided, and on the platform, with him were the Faculties of the College. The declamations were good, bad and indifferent, as on such occasions the declamations usually are. Music by Grafulla's Seventh Regiment Band preceded the first and followed every second speech, and at the close the Webster prize was presented to the student whom a Committee appointed for the purpose, declared to be the best orator of the occasion. CORNELIUS BRETT, whose oration was entitled "God with us," carried, off the palm so far as the Committee had anything to do with it; but the palms of the audience seemed to award the highest meed to WILLIAM H. BEADLESTON, whose theme was "Man the Author of his Destiny." Both deserved praise, and both received it; and there were others whose efforts were by many esteemed better than that of either. A musical melange of National airs was so well rendered at the conclusion of the exhibition that the audience was completely carried away with it -- at least all left the building immediately.

abstract: -- Capt. Charles S. Turnbull, of the Metropolitan Police, who has been suffering for the past two months under an acute attack of rheumatism, is now convalescent, and, probably, will soon resume command of the Police in the Seventeenth Ward. Capt. Turnbull has been connected with the Department more than twelve years, and his many acquaintances, formed during his long tenure of office, will rejoice to hear of his restoration to health, particularly as at one time his physicians despaired of his recovery, and some enterprising newsmongers went so far as to publish his demise in the evening papers.
lead_paragraph: -- Capt. Charles S. abstract: Our readers will remember the very picturesque account of the pillage and subsequent burning, by the allied forces, of the famous Summer Palace near Peking, which we copied from English journals in December last. The story was an animating one, full of the splendor and the havoc of war, and calculated to excite the cupidity of the reader, if not his martial impulses, by its luxurious details of "loot" -- profuse and curiously magnificent. The Tartars had insulted a flag of truce, and made prisoners of the party bearing it, under circumstances of deliberate atrocity. Two of the officers were spirited away, and two died from the brutal treatment they received. The grossest indignities were offered to all, -- the correspondent of the London Times being of the number. In some instances their faces were repeatedly and violently rubbed in the dust, and their pinioned bodies exposed for three days, without food, to the scorching sun at noon, and the cold and penetrating dews of that season; from time to time, too, they were kicked and beaten, so severely that the most gallant of their number died delirious, as he lay on the ground, bound to a Seikh soldier.
lead_paragraph: Our readers will remember the very picturesque account of the pillage and subsequent burning, by the allied forces, of the famous Summer Palace near Peking, which we copied from English journals in December last. abstract: It is of course a matter of surprise to no one that we are obliged to read, upon each fresh arrival from Europe, such denunciations of our new tariff law, as we reproduce in other columns of this paper. There never, in fact, was an important measure that attracted less attention on its passage, or, when the public consciousness was fully aroused, was more reprobated the world over as ill-timed and mischievous to the last degree, than the enactment in question. We resisted its passage upon the very grounds that are now almost universally urged for its repeal; and showed that it would alienate the Border States, lose us the sympathy of Europe, andabove all, yield neither revenue, nor protect our industry, because it could not be enforced.The public, however, could not be awakenedfrom its lethargy, and in a community now unanimous for its repeal, we found difficultyin getting a second. But the measure is a law. What is to be done with it? Repeal it, as a matter of course. This should be the first act of the Administration. It is a commercial as well as a political necessity. The crisis is imminent and demands immediate action.

abstract: The decisive enunciation of the will of the people of the Cotton States as to union or disunion, is necessarily only a question of time. If, as asserted, it is really the desire of a majority in one or more of these States that their political fortunes should remain united with ours, -- and be sure that if such union be their interest it will be also their desire -- neither the truculence of conspirators nor the terrorism of mob-law, can permanently prevent their voice being heard or their will from being obeyed. So far, the people have really had no voice at all in the formation of the Government which now claims to rule over them.
lead_paragraph: The decisive enunciation of the will of the people of the Cotton States as to union or disunion, is necessarily only a question of time. abstract: The French and English Governments are filling out a powerful fleet of war steamers for the United States. The suggestion came from England, and France will furnish on her part three of her first-class new frigates; the English contingent will perhaps be larger. The precise object of this fleet it will be impossible to ascertain, as it will probably sail with sealed orders. We may...

abstract: Drafts drawn by the Cataract Bank at Lockport, N.Y., on the Ocean Bank, of New-York, for $7,000 have been sold to bankers. One of the party concerned in the disposal of them has been arrested, and $50,000 of the same kind of drafts were found in his trunk. Another of the implicated party has gone West with $40,000 more.

abstract: The Madrid journals of the 5th contain reports of what took place in the Congress on the preceding day with respect to the incident mentioned by telegraph -- the interpellation on the subject of a speech of Lord PALMERSTON attacking the conduct of Spain with regard to the Slave trade, and the reply which the Duke de Tetuan (O'DONNELL) gave to it. It was M. GONZALEZ BRAVO who drew attention to the language of Lord PALMERSTON, and who demanded explanations from the Government respecting it; and, in doing so, be described that language as "sovereignly offensive" to Spain. The Duke de Tetuan, in answer, said: "I rise to give ample explanations to show the injustice of the accusations which have been brought not only against the Spanish Government -- which is a very grave fact -- but against the Spanish nation -- a circumstance which augments the gravity of the language used in the English Chamber." The Minister then proceeded to say that in 1835 Spain had entered into a treaty to put down the Slave trade, and he maintained that she had faithfully executed it, in proof of which he dwelt on the fact that the value of a slave in Cuba is now three or four fold what it was then. He affirmed that the different Captains-General of Cuba, and especially Gens. DE LA CONCHA and SERRANO, had always exerted themselves actively to prevent the introduction of slaves into the island. He stated that the English Cabinet itself had on more than one occasion borne testimony to the efforts made by the Spanish Government to put down the Slave-trade; and he contended that if certain Spaniards had engaged in that illegal traffic neither the Government nor the nation was responsible. He next went on to say that probably the language used by Lord PALMERSTON had fallen from him to the heat of debate, and would not be repeated in a calmer moment; and he then made the declaration, briefly mentioned by telegraph, which is as follows: "The Government declares that it has received no official communication couched in the terms used in the House of Commons, nor in anything like them, and it hopes that none will be sent. But if such an one should be forwarded the Spanish Government will not receive it or, at least, will not give any answer whatever to it." This drew forth loud applause, and the Minister, after hinting that perhaps the language ascribed to Lord PALMERSTON might not have been correctly translated, repeated the declaration. M. GONZALES BRAVO thanked the President of the Council for what he said, and the latter declared that, though in Spain party dissensions might exist, yet that when the honor or the independence of the Spanish nation was attacked, all Spaniards would rise as one man to defend it. This, also, was warmly applauded, and the matter ended.

abstract: John P. Beckman, Administrator, &c., vs. The People and Geo. M. Chapman et al. -- This case is quite celebrated in the annals of the Courts. The action was commenced in 1831, by the plaintiff, as administrator with the will annexed, to procure a judicial construction of the last will and testament of Wm. Barthrop, processed. Barthrop died at Kimerhock on the 20th of October, 1838 leaving a real and personal estate estimated at nearly $200,000. Most of this estate was personal.

abstract: Hiram R. Smith, Administrator, &c., of Joseph Ward, Respondent vs. The New York Central Railroad Company, Appellants. -- This action was brought to recover damages for an alleged negligence of the defendants, and was tried at the Albany Circuit in March, 1856, the plaintiff recovering $5,000. Ward, it appeals, resided in Richland, Ohio, and was a dealer in hogs. On Saturday, the 24th of March, he was on his way to the Albany market with a quantity of hogs, and took the cars at Buffalo for that city, paying to the defendants 4134 for the transportation of two car-loads of hogs to that city. Mr. Ward accompanied his stock, having a "arover's pass," which provided that the holder "takes all responsibility as to the injury of himself or stock." At Rochester the car in which Ward and others had ridden from Buffalo was changed for an emigrant car, and in that they proceeded toward Albany. At Oriskany, this car went off the track. Ward jumped off and received an injury of which he died in a few minutes. It was claimed on the part of the plaintiff that the car provided at Rochester was unsafe, by reason of its having a flat wheel, and that this defect was the occasion of its going off the track. On the past of the defendants it was claimed that the running off the track was occassioned by a broken rail; that the hat wheel car was safe, and that the broken rail was a casually against which the defendants guarded by every precaution.
lead_paragraph: Hiram R. Smith, Administrator, &c., of Joseph Ward, Respondent vs. The New York Central Railroad Company, Appellants. -- This action was brought to recover damages for an alleged negligence of the defendants, and was tried at the Albany Circuit in March, 1856, the plaintiff recovering $5,000. Ward, it appeals, resided in Richland, Ohio, and was a dealer in hogs. On Saturday, the 24th of March, he was on his way to the Albany market with a quantity of hogs, and took the cars at Buffalo for that city, paying to the defendants 4134 for the transportation of two car-loads of hogs to that city. Mr. Ward accompanied his stock, having a "arover's pass," which provided that the holder "takes all responsibility as to the injury of himself or stock." At Rochester the car in which Ward and others had ridden from Buffalo was changed for an emigrant car, and in that they proceeded toward Albany. At Oriskany, this car went off the track. Ward jumped off and received an injury of which he died in a few minutes. It was claimed on the part of the plaintiff that the car provided at Rochester was unsafe, by reason of its having a flat wheel, and that this defect was the occasion of its going off the track. On the past of the defendants it was claimed that the running off the track was occassioned by a broken rail; that the hat wheel car was safe, and that the broken rail was a casually against which the defendants guarded by every precaution.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, the District-Attorney moved on the trial of John Jolly, indicted for the murder of a child, Alexander McLane, on the 22d of January last. Mr. Allen briefly opened to the jury, and Mrs. Mary McLane was called and testified that she lived at No. 158 1/2 Cherry-street; the deceased was her child; and at the time of its death, in January last, was three years old; on the day of its death she left it in her own room, with Mrs. Johnson, while she went up stairs to get a little girl to go on an errand for her; on passing the door of the prisoner, the witness heard him and his wife quarelling; they then rushed out into the entry, he asking his wife, "Did you call me that name," and she replying, "no;" to which he answered, "you'd better look out, if you do;" the wife, as she ran down the stairs, turned to her husband and said you are a -- (using a profane and obscene expression;) he then threw at her a shoe which he had in his hand; Mrs. Jolly had her child in her arms, and the witness said, "Look out for your child;" witness', oldest child was on the landing with her; Mrs. Johnson was holding the other one, Alexander, (the deceased,) in the witness' room; witness went down, stairs; and as she got to the door it was open, and Mrs. Johnson exclaimed, "Oh, Mrs. McLane your baby is killed," the child held its hands up and streamed; witness took it in her arms, and it cited badly for an hour; the shoe that was thrown into the room hit it on the head; there was a slight mark on the left side of the child's head, which was sore; the child was ailing all the rest of the day; witness had him in her arms till nine o'clock, when he was put in his cradle; he died at seven o'clock the next morning; the prisoner was a seafaring man, as was also the husband of the witness.

abstract: Mr. JOHN WEED, of Rochester, has just returned home from an eight months absence in the employ of the Overland Mail Company. He reports that at some points on the Texas division, the Union sentiment continues strong, and in other places the people are almost unanimous in favor of secession. The Texas Rangers had threatened Fort Fillmore, in Arizona. It has one company of mounted rifles. Fort Buchanan has two companies of infantry and one company of dragoons. The number of Government troops quartered at Fort Breckinridge is unknown. At Fort Davis, Texas, 280 miles from Mesilla, the troops are throwing up embankments, in anticipation of an attack. At Sherman, Texas, the Union men had organized a company of 300 Rangers, and were determined to resist the ordinance of secession, and to stand by the stars and stripes as long as they have ammunition!

abstract: The telegraph informs us that Mr. RUSSELL, Special Correspondent of the London Times, has had an interview with the Secretary of State, and was presented by him to the President.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph informs us that Mr. RUSSELL, Special Correspondent of the London Times, has had an interview with the Secretary of State, and was presented by him to the President. The London Times has never been recognized by our Goverment as an independent sovereignty; but there is no Minister at Washington whose intelligent friendship is now half so important to our Government, as that of the Envoy from that journal. He has come here on a special mission, on behalf of the people of Great Britain. His duties are precisely those which the Envoys of every great Power profess to perform, -- namely, to keep his principals advised of all transactions in which their interests are involved, and to establish such relations, and inaugurate such a policy, as their permanent welfare may seem to require. But unlike them he performs his task in the face of the world. His dispatches are not filed away in dusty pigeon holes, and kept sacred from sight or knowledge of men, until they have lost all their importance, and may be published without danger of producing any effect. It is his mission to spread, day by day, before the world, the fullest reports of whatever he may see and hear, with such inferences and comments as his judgment and experience may prompt. He represents the people, and not the placemen of England: and he transacts the business of his mission directly with them.

abstract: The Schooner Restless, Capt. JEO. D. SANDERS, being refused a Federal clearance at Mobile for Havana, was compelled to proceed without one, the ...
lead_paragraph: The Schooner Restless, Capt. JEO. D. SANDERS, being refused a Federal clearance at Mobile for Havana, was compelled to proceed without one, the Captain making the usual "protest" before the Spanish Consul. On his arrival here with a cargo from Havana, the vessel was charged $250 foreign tonnage duties, and was then seized for forfeiture as a foreign vessel sailing without a proper register. These facts having been laid before the Secretary of the Treasury, through the United States District Attorney here, Mr. CHASE has remitted the forfeiture of the vessel on the payment of all cost, charges and expenses. The cargo of the vessel will also be released, without doubt, but some delay in the papers reaching Washington probably accounts for the non-receipt of that order also by the same mail. As this case forms a precedent for action in others of the same character, it is thought that all seizures of vessels for like causes will hereafter be discontinued. A sharp look-out, however, will be kept on all vessels arriving from seceded ports for foreign goods which have not paid the duties. While the costs and expenses in these cases are somewhat onerous to the parties concerned, and must operate against their hereafter seeking these ports for freight, they would have been much greater had the "monitions" and other steps for the forfeiture of the vessels been made out.

abstract: The vast plain of the Ganges is blest bountifully with rains only in Bengal; in the provinces farther north indeed, throughout all Upper India the poor soil, sparingly refreshed by the clouds, yields its single annual crop to artificial irrigation mainly. The ...
lead_paragraph: The vast plain of the Ganges is blest bountifully with rains only in Bengal; in the provinces farther north -- indeed, throughout all Upper India -- the poor soil, sparingly refreshed by the clouds, yields its single annual crop to artificial irrigation mainly. The lands in which the "rain crops" are sown lie fallow in the cold season, and those of the Spring crops during the rains. The rain crops are planted, after one plowing, in the last weeks of June, and are reaped in October. The Spring crop is sown in October and reaped in April. The former consist of cotton and millet, a small proportion of indigo, rice, sugar-cane, and Indian corn, with some bajaree, and other coarse native grains. The latter is the wheat crop -- the great food harvest for the bazaars of the cities; for the ryots, and all of the lowly agricultural class, subsist principally upon bajaree, and those humbler grains which are flung into the softened ground with the rice, after the June showers. The wheat crop is watered less by rain, which at that season in Upper India is neither so frequent or abundant, than by irrigation, through ditches arid canals.

abstract: REPUBLICAN RATIFICATION MEETING A mass Republican meeting was held in Musical Hall last evening, under the auspices of the "Banner Club," ...
lead_paragraph: REPUBLICAN RATIFICATION MEETING. -- A mass Republican meeting was held in Musical Hall last evening, under the auspices of the "Banner Club," to ratify the nomination of FREDERICK SCHOLES as the Republican candidate for Mayor. The meeting was presided offer by H.H. LLOYD, Vice-President of the Association, and addresses were made by DAVIS DUDLEY FIELD, SIEWART L. WOODFORD, E.D. SMITH, Mr. SCHOLES, the candidate for Mayor, and Mr. BEARD, of the Tenth Ward. The room was well filled, and much enthusiasm prevailed, reminding one of the many scenes witnessed during the last campaign.

abstract: Miss Walling and Miss Van Deventer, residents of South Amboy, N.J., while returning a few afternoons since from the village of Washington, where they had been to make some purchases, were attacked by a scoundrel, who evidently intended to rob them. He knocked down one of them, and stamped on her violently, but was prevented from accomplishing the robbery by the screams of the other lady. The occurrence caused great excitement.
lead_paragraph: Miss Walling and Miss Van Deventer, residents of South Amboy, N.J., while returning a few afternoons since from the village of Washington, where they had been to make some purchases, were attacked by a scoundrel, who evidently intended to rob them. He knocked down one of them, and stamped on her violently, but was prevented from accomplishing the robbery by the screams of the other lady. The occurrence caused great excitement.

abstract: The action of Virginia is probably, more important, to the future of this country, than that of any other State. There is a strong and unscrupulous party within her borders, which is determined upon forcing her to join the Southern Confederacy. If they succeed, North Carolina and Maryland, at least, will probably do likewise, -- and the chances are, that in such a contingency, all the Slave States would pursue the same course.

abstract: On Monday Connecticut elects State officers and four Members of Congress, and on Wednesday Rhode Island elects State officers and two Members of Congress. In both States ...
lead_paragraph: On Monday Connecticut elects State officers and four Members of Congress, and on Wednesday Rhode Island elects State officers and two Members of Congress. In both States the election has marked and unusual importance. Both voted for Mr. LINCOLN and a Republican Administration; and it has been felt by the Opposition to be a matter of special interest to detach both of them from its support at the earliest possible moment. No pains or efforts have been spared, therefore, to reverse in these States the verdict of last November.

abstract: Nothing definite has been ascertained with reference to the origin of the fire on Thursday midnight, at Nos. 114 and 116 Nassau street, but it is supposed to have broken out in the fourth story. As has already been stated, both buildings were totally destroyed, the front wall alone remaining. About 11 o'clock ...
lead_paragraph: Nothing definite has been ascertained with reference to the origin of the fire on Thursday midnight, at Nos. 114 and 116 Nassau street, but it is supposed to have broken out in the fourth story. As has already been stated, both buildings were totally destroyed, the front wall alone remaining. About 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon it was discovered that considerable fire existed among the ruins, and the surrounding buildings being endangered thereby, the services of Southwark Steam engine No. 38 were brought into requisition, and, after laboring at intervals until after nightfall, the flames were finally extinguished.

abstract: In the midst of the present dearth of occupation in almost every business pursuit, those who turn "the wheels of justice" in the Criminal Courts of this City find themselves excepted from the list of "unemployed hands."
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the present dearth of occupation in almost every business pursuit, those who turn "the wheels of justice" in the Criminal Courts of this City find themselves excepted from the list of "unemployed hands." In the General Sessions alone, since the 1st of January, when the new Recorder and City Judge came upon the Bench, no fewer than three hundred and thirty-two indictments have been disposed of, either by trial or confession of the parties accused. Of these a hundred and seventeen have been cleared from the calendar during the present month. The disposal of this immense amount of business in so short a time is due, in part, to the industry of Assistant District-Attorney ANTHON, who has alone tried nearly every case, and partly to the disposition which the new Judges have shown to devote exclusive attention to their public duties, in spite of the claims of private affairs, or even of personal comfort. As a general rule they have prolonged the daily sessions of the Court an hour beyond the previous time of adjournment, and have frequently sat till into the evening; while, instead of adjourning at the end of the second or third week of the month, they have prolonged each term till within a day or two of the succeeding one. The Court adjourned the present month on Thursday, and the April term will open on Monday.
headline: {'main': 'Our Criminal Courts.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Criminal Courts.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The intelligence which reaches us from the West Indies by the Quaker City, which left Havana on the 25th inst., and arrived at this port last evening, is of the most startling character, and almost ...
lead_paragraph: The intelligence which reaches us from the West Indies by the Quaker City, which left Havana on the 25th inst., and arrived at this port last evening, is of the most startling character, and almost rivals in importance to the United States the events which are transpiring within our own borders. Spain, it seems, is disposed to take advantage of our dissensions, and our consequent indisposition or inability to enforce the Monroe doctrine, and is taking measures to restore to her domains some of the fair possessions which she has heretofore lost through adverse fortune. San Domingo is the first point to which she has directed her attention, and we now receive the astounding announcement that a virtual annexation has already taken place. During some time past, it appears, a system of colonization has been quietly going on, large bodies of emigrants being introduced upon the island, with the view of promoting disaffection towards the existing Government, and otherwise furthering the interests of Spain. On the 16th inst. the Spanish flag was hoisted, much to the astonishment of the blacks and native population, who appear to have been taken entirely by surprise; and on the 23d, immediately on the receipt of the news at Havana, the Spanish frigate Blanca sailed to the assistance of the colonists, fully armed and equipped, and with a large number of troops on board. She was to be followed as soon as possible by two screw steam-frigates, with an army of 5,000 men, when the "protectorate," as the Spaniards are pleased to term it, would be fully established. It was also reported that a large additional military and naval force was on the way from Spain to Cuba, to be ready for any emergency in which it might be required. The Island of Hayti is indicated as the next point of operations.

abstract: Cardell et al. vs. John A. Godfrey. -- Action for goods sold and delivered. The summons stated that the complaint would be filed in the office of the Clerk of the County of New-York, and did not state that a copy was annexed to the summons and served therewith upon the defendant, although such was the fact. On the twentieth day after the service of the summons, the defendant served a notice of appearance and demand of a copy of complaint. The plaintiffs' attorney disregarded the demand for a copy of the complaint, and upon motion of adjustment of costs, entered judgment. This was a motion upon the part of the defendant to set aside and vacate the judgment entered as irregular, the motion papers showing the above facts.

abstract: Foreign Quarterlies and Reviews have long usurped the field of criticism, to the almost utter exclusion of authorities of American origin. Perhaps the fault has hitherto rested chiefly with ourselves. Reviews have been started in our country ...
lead_paragraph: Foreign Quarterlies and Reviews have long usurped the field of criticism, to the almost utter exclusion of authorities of American origin. Perhaps the fault has hitherto rested chiefly with ourselves. Reviews have been started in our country often enough; which moved on at a rattling pace and bade fair to come in at least within hail of the winning post, but by some fatality they failed. In some instances we apprehend that they were too weak to walk alone -- much less to run -- in others they were crowded off the course. In the National Quarterly Review, published and edited by EDWARD J. SEARS, we have a publication which gives signs of greater vigor and longer life. It has now been on the course for about two years, and as yet manifests no signs of giving out. The March number fully warrants our praise. It contains live articles on prominent topics and discriminating criticisms of the principal publications, both American and foreign, of the day.

abstract: Mr. SEWELL is now and has been for some years upon the editorial staff of the TIMES, and these letters, which originally appeared in its columns, were written during two successive Winters which he spent in the West India Islands.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SEWELL is now and has been for some years upon the editorial staff of the TIMES, and these letters, which originally appeared in its columns, were written during two successive Winters which he spent in the West India Islands. They undoubtedly embody the most careful and satisfactory exposition of the great subject of Emancipation in those Islands, which has hitherto been made. They are entirely dispassionate, -- not written to sustain a theory or to affect current politics, -- and are marked by careful observation, a clear and precise statement of facts, and a judicial estimate of their bearing upon general principles. The author's object, as he himself expresses it, was to give, "as free from comment as possible, such statistical and other information concerning the West Indian population, their habits and customs, their industry, their commerce, and their Government, as he has been able to procure from reliable sources, or to gain from personal observation," He has performed this task with great industry, fidelity and success: -- and then he has not scrupled to draw such inferences as these facts seem to warrant.

abstract: March 23 was an interesting day at Frankfort, Ky. Gov. WICKLIFFE made a most eloquent and earnest appeal for the Union, arguing that Kentucky...
lead_paragraph: March 23 was an interesting day at Frankfort, Ky. Gov. WICKLIFFE made a most eloquent and earnest appeal for the Union, arguing that Kentucky would inevitably be the loser should she go with the C.S.A. In the course of his speech he said that, to his great grief, his only son was for the Southern Confederacy, but he was satisfied that he would outlive it, although the speaker hardly expected to do so himself. In the evening, Gov. MOREBEAD urged the necessity of taking the preliminary steps for the assembling of a Border State Convention.

abstract: The People ex rel. The Commissioners of Emigration vs. The Supervisors of Richmond County. -- It will be remembered that in April, 1860, the Legislature passed an act appointing Commissioners to take evidence, and award the amount of damages sustained, by reason of the burning of the Quarantine Hospital on Staten Island. Pursuant to their appointment the Commissioners took evidence, and reported the damages at $107,251 79. Subsequently the County paid over to the State Treasurer their bonds to the amount of the award under protest.

abstract: SLIPPERY AS AN EEL. JOHN POTTER, a singular specimen of humanity, apparently twenty years of age, and with hair of fiery color, was apprehended on ...
lead_paragraph: SLIPPERY AS AN EEL. -- JOHN POTTER, a singular specimen of humanity, apparently twenty years of age, and with hair of fiery color, was apprehended on Thursday, by the Third Ward Police, on a charge of being a fugitive from Elmira, N.Y., where he had been guilty of violating the Eighth Commandment. The young man was first arrested three weeks ago, by officer LUZ, of Elmira, who came to this City for the purpose. LEE, on that occasion, put his prisoner under lock and key in a hotel in Robinson-street, and went himself to look at the interesting things about the City. During his absence his captive escaped by jumping from the window of the room in which he was confined, and remained at large several days. Finally having been recaptured, he was handcuffed and departed in LEE'S custody for Elmira, via the New-York and Erie Railroad. Before reaching Port Jervis Mr. LEE was taken sick, and leaving his prisoner in the rear car of the train, he went forward to take a nap in the baggage car. When he awoke, to his utter astonishment he discovered that POTTER had again given him the slip, though without intending to do so, as the car in which he was riding was switched off at Port Jervis and detached from the train. Before a telegram could notify the authorities at Port Jervis to arrest the young man, he had taken his departure, carrying with him, it is alleged, a carpet bag containing his late custodian's property, with which he came back to this City. POTTER, however, denies that he committed the last mentioned theft. He is detained at Head-quarters until LEE comes here to claim him.

abstract: The predicament in which both the Government and the commerce of the country are placed, through the non-enforcement of our revenue laws, is now thoroughly understood the world over. It is as if we should enact ...
lead_paragraph: The predicament in which both the Government and the commerce of the country are placed, through the non-enforcement of our revenue laws, is now thoroughly understood the world over. It is as if we should enact that a certain number of our ports should be exempted from their operation. Importations would naturally tend toward these, although they might be greatly inferior in their accommodations or means for distribution. Twenty-five, or thirty, or fifty per cent, saved of their cost would amply compensate for a great many disadvantages. The enactment of such injustice by any Government, would afford good cause for its deposition. Is it much different to consent to its enactment by a rebelling State or port, whereby they may secure to themselves a crowning advantage at the cost of those remaining loyal? The result in both cases is the same, showing either alternative on the part of Government to be equally indefensible. Can Government for an instant rest under the imputation of counseling or permitting legislation that raises rebel provinces to power upon the ruins of those that remain faithful, and that secures to the favorable consideration of the civilized world a revolt, whose sole motive was the perpetuation of Slavery?

abstract: The annual Trade Sale of the New-York BookPublishers Association has opened most favorably, notwithstanding the rather inauspicious state of the political weather, and the dexterous auctioneers appear to experience no difficulty in raising the wind requisite to swell their sales.
lead_paragraph: The annual Trade Sale of the New-York Book-Publishers Association has opened most favorably, notwithstanding the rather inauspicious state of the political weather, and the dexterous auctioneers appear to experience no difficulty in raising the wind requisite to swell their sales. This success is attributable, perhaps, in no small degree, to the new and spacious rooms in which the sale is this year held. In that somewhat storied street, commonly known as Mercer, a stately building devoted to books rears its head, and flings a ray of respectability through the whole length of the ruinous rue. It is here that Messrs. GEO. A. LEAVITT & Co. preside, scattering the contents of the catalogue, with lavish hands, to the four corners of the country.
